ORDINANCE NO. 19 - 10
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE CITY CODE OF THE CITY OF MASON CITY, IOWA, BY REPEALING TITLE 10 “BUILDING
REGULATIONS”, CHAPTER 2: “BUILDING CODES”, ARTICLE F: “HOUSING CODE” SECTION 3: “AMENDMENTS TO CODE;
CHAPTER 1”AND SECTION 8: “AMENDMENTS TO THE CODE; CHAPTER 6:” AND ADOPTING A NEW SECTION 3 AND
SECTION 8 IN LIEU THEREOF
BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of the City of Mason City, Iowa:
Section 1: That the City Code of the City of Mason City, Iowa, should be and the same is hereby amended by repealing Title 10: “Building
Regulations”, Chapter 2: “Building Codes”, Article F: “Housing Code”, Section 3: “Amendments to Code: Chapter 1” and adopting new Section 3 in lieu
thereof as follows:
"TITLE 10
CHAPTER 2
BUILDING CODES
ARTICLE F. HOUSING CODE
10-2F-3: AMENDMENTS TO CODE; Chapter 1: Chapter 1, Scope And Administration, of the 2015 International Property Maintenance Code (or the most current
edition) is adopted, except as hereby amended, deleted, modified, revised, or added to, as specifically set forth as follows:
A. 101.1, Title: Delete and replace. These regulations shall be known as the International Property Maintenance Code of the City of Mason City, Iowa,
hereinafter referred to as "the Housing Code", or "this Code".
B. 103.1, General: Delete and replace. Enforcement and administration of this Code shall be the responsibility of the Code official, under direction of the
Director of Development Services.
C. 103.5, Fees: Delete and replace. The fees for activities and services performed by the Development Services Department in carrying out its
responsibilities under this Code shall be determined from time to time by resolution adopted by the City Council.
D. 106.3, Prosecution Of Violation: Delete and replace last sentence only. Any action taken by the authority having jurisdiction on such premises shall be
charged against the real estate upon which the structure is located and shall be a lien upon such real estate and may be collected by any other legal
means or resource.
E. 108.4 Placarding: Delete and replace. Upon failure of the owner, owner’s authorized agent or person responsible to comply with the notice provisions
within the time given, the code official shall post on the premises or on defective equipment a placard bearing a statement of the penalties provided for
occupying the premises, operating the equipment or removing the placard.
F. 108.4.1 Placard removal: delete and replace. The code official shall remove the placard whenever the defect or defects upon which the placarding
action were based have been eliminated. Any person who defaces or removes a placard without the approval of the code official shall be subject to the
penalties provided by this code.
G. 109.1, Imminent Danger: delete and replace first and second sentence only. When, in the opinion of the code official, there is imminent danger of failure
or collapse of a building or structure which endangers life, or when any structure or part of a structure has fallen and life is endangered by the
occupation of the structure, or when there is actual or potential danger to the building occupants or those in the proximity of any structure because of
explosives, explosive fumes or vapors or the presence of toxic fumes, gases or materials, or operation of defective or dangerous equipment, or when
the occupants are using the premises for illegal activities or storage of illegal substances that may pose a danger to the occupants or persons in
proximity thereof, or a condition exists from which the code official determines that immediate action is required to protect the health or safety of the
occupants or the general public, the code official is hereby authorized and empowered to order and require the occupants to vacate the premises
forthwith. The code official shall cause to be posted at the front or main entrance to such structure a placard declaring the structure to be unsafe and
prohibiting its occupancy.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 2/358
H. 111.1, Application For Appeal: Delete and replace first sentence only. Any person directly affected by a decision of the Code official or a notice or order
issued under this Code shall have the right to appeal to the Housing Advisory and Appeals Board, provided that a written application for appeal is filed
no more than twenty (20) calendar days after the action or decision being appealed.
I. 111.2, Membership Of The Board: Delete and replace. The board shall be comprised of five (5) persons who shall be appointed by the Mayor with
approval of the City Council. The Code official shall serve as a non-voting ex-officio member of the board.
J. 111.2.1, Alternate Members: Delete.
K. 111.2.2, Chairman: Delete and replace. Chair and Vice-Chair. The board shall elect a Chair and Vice-Chair from among its members. Such Chair, or in
his/her absence, the Vice-Chair, shall conduct all meetings and may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses.
L. 111.2.4, Secretary: Delete and replace. The Code official shall serve as Secretary to the board and shall distribute all decisions and findings in writing to
the landlord and the occupant. The Secretary shall cause all records and minutes of the board to be maintained by the Development Services
Department and the City Clerk.
M. 111.2.6, add subsection: Terms: Members of the board shall be appointed for terms of five (5) years, from the first day of April following their
appointment, except for appointments to fill vacancies which shall be for the unexpired term of any member. The Mayor, for cause, may remove any
member from office. Upon completion of their term of office, members shall continue to serve in their full capacity until a successor has been duly
appointed.
N. 111.2.7, add subsection: Vacancies: Vacancies on the board caused by death, resignation or other reason shall be promptly filled by appointment of the
Mayor and approval of the City Council for the unexpired term of office.
O. 111.3, Notice Of Meetings: Delete and replace. Upon receipt of a complete appeal application and filing fee, the Code official shall establish a date for
the hearing to be held within fifteen (15) business days of the date upon which the completed application was received, and shall send a notice of the
hearing to the appellant as well as the respective property owner and occupant, if different from owner.
P. 111.4.2, add subsection: Extensions Of Time: In response to an appeal of a notice and order, the board may grant an extension of time to comply with a
notice and order for not more than twelve (12) months, subject to appropriate conditions, and provided that the board makes specific findings of fact
based upon evidence relating to the following:
1. That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in carrying out the strict letter of any notice and order; and
2. That such an extension is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this Code in securing the public health, safety and general welfare;
and
3. That the violation(s) in question do not constitute an imminent danger, per section 109.1.
Q. 111.4.3, add subsection: Variances: In response to an appeal of a notice and order, the board may grant a variance from a specific provision of this
Code in a specific case, subject to appropriate conditions and provided the board makes specific findings of fact based upon evidence related to the
following:
1. That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in carrying out the strict letter of any notice and order; and
2. That the effect of the application of the provisions would be arbitrary in the specific case; and
3. That an extension would not constitute an appropriate remedy for these practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships; and
4. That the variance is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this Code in securing the public health, safety and general welfare and
does not constitute an imminent danger to the public.
(2017 Code)
R. 112.4, Failure to Comply: Delete and replace. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such
work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be subject to citation for a simple misdemeanor, as outlined in
section 1-4-1 of the city code.
Section 2: That the City Code of the City of Mason City, Iowa, should be and the same is hereby amended by repealing Title 10: “Building
Regulations”, Chapter 2: “Building Codes”, Article F: “Housing Code”, Section 8: “Amendments to Code: Chapter 6” and adopting a new Section 8 in lieu
thereof as follows:
"TITLE 10
CHAPTER 2
BUILDING CODES
ARTICLE F. HOUSING CODE
10-2F-8: AMENDMENTS TO CODE; CHAPTER 6: Chapter 6, Mechanical And Electrical Requirements, of the 2015 International Property Maintenance
Code (or the most current edition) is adopted, except as hereby amended, deleted, modified, revised, or added to, as specifically set forth as follows:
A. 602.1, Facilities Required, add to end of section: Heating systems requiring electrical energy for operation shall be provided with an independent circuit.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 3/358
B. 602.2, Residential Occupancies, delete and replace last sentence only: Cooking appliances shall not be used, nor shall unvented fuel burning space
heaters be used, as a means to provide required heating. No fuel burning furnace shall be located within any sleeping room or bathroom unless
provided with adequate ducting for air supply from the exterior, and provided the combustion chamber for such heating unit is sealed from the room in
an airtight manner. Fuel burning space heaters are prohibited in dwelling units.
C. 602.2, Residential Occupancies, delete the "Exception" paragraph.
D. 602.3, Heat supply, delete and replace [DATE] to [DATE]: September 15 to May 15.
E. 602.34, Occupiable Work Spaces, delete and replace: Indoor occupiable work spaces shall be supplied with heat, during the period from September 15
to May 15 to maintain a minimum temperature of 65°F (18°C) during the period the spaces are occupied.
F. 604.2, Service, add to end of section: Where fusible equipment is in place, Type S fuses will be required.
G. 605.2, Receptacles, delete and replace third (second to last) sentence only: Any bathroom or toilet room receptacle outlet shall have ground fault
interrupter protection. In any room other than a bathroom or toilet room, any receptacle within 36 inches (36") of a water source and all exterior outlets
shall have ground fault interrupter protection.
H. 605.3, Luminaires, delete and replace first sentence only: Every public hall, interior stairway, toilet room, kitchen, bathroom, laundry room, boiler room
and furnace room shall contain at least one electric luminaire with a switch that is easily accessible from the entrance to the room. All dwellings shall
have lighted entrances and exits controlled by interior switches that are convenient and accessible.
(2017 Code)
Section 3: That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed.
Section 4: If any section, provision, or part of this ordinance shall be adjudged to be invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication shall not affect
the validity of the Ordinance as a whole or any section thereof, or part thereof, not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional.
Section 5: This ordinance shall be in full force and effect upon its final passage, approval and publication as required by law.

ORDINANCE NO. 19 - 14
AN ORDINANCE TO UPDATE CERTAIN PORTIONS OF
THE CITY CODE RELATING TO MOBILE VENDORS
AND CERTAIN PERSONAL SERVICES
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 4/358
WHEREAS, the City Council of the City of Mason City has received a request from the Chief of Police of Mason City, Iowa to make certain changes to the City
Code of Mason City, Iowa;
AND, WHEREAS, said changes relate to the regulation of mobile vendors and certain personal services involving fortune tellers, palmists, and clairvoyants in the
City of Mason City, Iowa;
NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED, by the City Council of the City of Mason City, Iowa:
Section 1: THAT Section 3-9-2: DEFINITIONS of the City Code of the City of Mason City, Iowa, should be and the same hereby is amended to read as
follows:
3-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
PEDDLER/VENDOR: Any person carrying goods or merchandise who sells or offers for sale for immediate delivery such goods or merchandise from house to house or
upon the public street.
SOLICITOR: Any person who solicits or attempts to solicit from house to house or upon the public street any contribution or donation or any order for goods, services,
subscriptions or merchandise to be delivered at a future date.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Iowa Code section 9C.1 and any revisions thereto defines the term transient merchant and lists State requirements for applicants. This
section of the Iowa Code also lists specific exemptions that do not require a transient merchant license. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
AND THAT Section 3-9-4: GENERAL REGULATIONS of the City Code of the City of Mason City, Iowa, should be and the same hereby is amended to read as
follows:
3-9-4: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
A. Licensee shall maintain a distance of seventy five feet (75') from the entrance of any business which is selling the same type of product as the peddler/vendor. Mobile
vendors may be prohibited in areas where sidewalks are not wide enough to accommodate both pedestrians and the vendor.
B. There shall be maintained a distance of not less than twenty feet (20') between vendors.
C. The vendor's operation shall not impede the free flow of pedestrian traffic along sidewalks or plaza right-of-way, nor shall they interfere with pedestrian movement into
or out of retail establishments. (1985 Code)
D. No pushcart shall have dimensions exceeding four feet (4') in width, eight feet (8') in length, and eight feet (8') in height. All pushcarts must be aesthetically pleasing in
appearance, and shall be maintained in a neat and orderly fashion. Each pushcart shall be capable of being moved and kept under control by one (1) person traveling on
foot. The City Administrator may grant a special license to a handicapped person to operate a pushcart propelled by an electric motor; provided, that the applicant meets
all other conditions for a license. During transit of the pushcart (whether it be towed by vehicle, carried by trailer, or pushed by hand) the pushcart operator shall be
subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a motor vehicle as provided by law except as to the provisions which by their very nature can have no application.
E. The applicant shall have obtained all necessary permits required by the State of Iowa Department of Health or other applicable regulatory agency.
F. The construction of an addition to an existing store front for permanent, temporary or seasonal use of abutting public right-of-way shall require an encroachment permit
as specified in title 5, chapter 1, article C of this Code.
G. All peddlers and solicitors are only permitted to go door-to-door between sunrise and sunset.
H. No person, firm, corporation or other organization shall sell, display, or otherwise offer for sale any merchandise or other materials on any sidewalk, street, public
right-of-way, or other public property without first obtaining approval by the City Council or by a duly authorized representative. Application for such license shall be
made in writing to the City Clerk. The Clerk shall refer such application to the appropriate City departments for review and report. Said application along with the
appropriate department reports shall then be forwarded to the City Council or to a duly authorized representative for action to approve or disapprove. Persons, firms,
corporations or other organizations having valid contracts with the City authorizing activities hereinbefore described are excepted from the terms of this subsection for the
activities specifically authorized in the contract.
The City Council reserves the right to require the relocation of any licensed pushcart or transient merchant to a new location in the event public safety or congestion so
requires, based on the discretion of the Council. (1985 Code; and. 2017 Code)
AND THAT Section 8-3-9: FORTUNE TELLERS, PALMISTS, CLAIRVOYANTS of the City Code of the City of Mason City, Iowa, should be and the same is
hereby repealed as follows:
Section 2: That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the revisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed.
Section 3: If any section, revision, or part of this ordinance shall be adjudged to be invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudications shall not affect the validity
of the ordinance as a whole or any section thereof, or part thereof, not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional.
Section 4: This ordinance shall be in full force and effect upon its final passage, approval and publication as required by law.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.

PREFACE
This City Code of Mason City, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including Ordinance 19-9, passed June 18, 2019. Ordinances of the City
adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this City Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code has been amended, superseded or repealed.

Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 17-15
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE OFFICIAL CITY CODE OF THE CITY OF MASON CITY, CERRO GORDO COUNTY, IOWA TO BE KNOWN AS THE
"2017 CITY CODE, MASON CITY, IOWA"; PROVIDING FOR THE ADOPTION AND READOPTION OF ALL ORDINANCES OF A GENERAL NATURE
AND PROVIDING FOR THE RETENTION OF ALL SPECIAL ORDINANCES AND PROVIDING A SAVING CLAUSE
BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of the City of Mason City, Iowa:
Section 1: The official City Code of Mason City shall be and comprise that certain loose leaf volume published by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., containing
thirteen (13) titles and appropriate chapters, articles and sections within the titles published upon order of the City Council and containing all of the general
effect ordinances of the City.
Section 2: The ordinances of a general nature contained in this official City Code shall be deemed to be continuous provisions and not reenactments of the
same material on the same subject. Nor shall the repeal of any general ordinance affect or be deemed to cause any special ordinance to have been
repealed, but such special ordinances, including but not limited to franchise ordinances, tax levy ordinances, land description ordinances or bonding
ordinances shall continue in full force and effect as though no new City Code had been prepared and hereby adopted.
Section 3: Amendments to the official 2017 City Code, as hereby adopted, shall be made by ordinance amending or repealing a specific title, chapter,
article or section of this Code. Such amendments shall refer to the said section to be amended or repealed by section number and such changes, when
adopted by the governing body, shall be incorporated into the official Code by replacement pages, properly marked and identified and prepared by Sterling
Codifiers, Inc., for insertion in each of the official Code books in existence.
Section 4: That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed.
Section 5: If any section, provision, or part of this ordinance shall be adjudged to be invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication shall not affect the validity
of the Ordinance as a whole or any section thereof, or part thereof, not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional.
Section 6: This ordinance shall be in full force and effect upon its final passage, approval and publication as required by law.
PASSED AND APPROVED this 5th day of December, 2017.
/s/Eric Bookmeyer
Eric Bookmeyer, Mayor
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 6/358

Title 1
ADMINISTRATION
Chapter 1
CITY CODE
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Governing Body, this Code is hereby declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official City Code of the CITY OF MASON
CITY, IOWA. Any reference made to the number of any section contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same under its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to this
Code by title in any legal document. (1985 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this State
as the ordinances of the City of general and permanent effect. (1985 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
A. Any additions or amendments to this Code, when passed as ordinances amending this Code, and which indicate the intention of the Council to make
the same a part hereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code so that a reference to the Code shall be understood as including them.
B. Any ordinance amending this Code shall set forth the title, chapter and section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Code. (1985
Code)
1-1-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS AND AGENTS:
When the provisions of any section of this Code prohibit the commission of an act, not only the person actually doing the prohibited act or omitting the
directed act, but also the employer and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the said person shall be guilty of the offense described
and liable to the penalty set forth. (1985 Code)
Chapter 2
SAVING CLAUSE
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the City passed prior to the adoption of this Code are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being still in
force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving clauses contained in the following section), from which are
excluded the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances; appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and
annexations; franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing
the execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public
places; improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections; ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or
from the City; and all special ordinances. (1985 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, services or rates of public
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 7/358
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this Code or by virtue of the preceding section, excepting as this Code may contain provisions for
such matters, in which case this Code shall be considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (1985 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions upon the
same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the City herein
repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this Code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the
same provision; nor shall this chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the City under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the adoption of
this Code. (1985 Code)
Chapter 3
DEFINITIONS
1-3-1: DEFINITIONS; RULES OF WORD CONSTRUCTION:
In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the City, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless the context
clearly requires otherwise:
CITY: The City of Mason City, in the County of Cerro Gordo, in the State of Iowa.
CITY COUNCIL, COUNCIL: The City Council of the City of Mason City.
CITY SEAL: The seal of the City described as follows: a disk having around the margin thereof the words "City Seal" and within the circle on the face
thereof the words "City of Mason City, Iowa".
CODE: The Code of Mason City, Iowa, and all amendments thereto.
COMPUTING TIME: In computing time, the first day shall be excluded and the last included, unless the last falls on Sunday, in which case the time
prescribed shall be extended so as to include the whole of the following Monday.
COUNTY: The County of Cerro Gordo in the State of Iowa.
FISCAL YEAR: The Municipal fiscal year beginning on July 1 of each year and ending on June 30 of the following year.
GENDER: Whenever the masculine gender is used, females as well as males shall be deemed to be included.
IN THE CITY: All territory over which the City now has or shall hereafter acquire jurisdiction.
JOINT AUTHORITY: Words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more public officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of them, unless it shall be otherwise expressed in the ordinance or resolution giving the authority.
MONTH: A calendar month.
NUMBER: Whenever any words in any section of this Code import the plural number, the singular shall be deemed to be included and whenever the
singular number shall be used, it shall be deemed to include the plural.
OATH: The word "oath" shall be deemed to include an affirmation, and the word "sworn" shall be construed to include the word "affirmed".
OCCUPANT OR TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall mean any person who holds a written or oral lease of, or actually occupies the whole or
part of such building or land, either alone or with others.
OR, AND: The word "or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or", if the sense requires it.
OWNER: Any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or a part of any property, either alone or with
others.
PERSON: A natural person, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, and also includes a firm, partnership or corporation, its or their successors or
assigns or the agent of any of them.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Every species of property, except real property as defined by this section.
PRECEDING, FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Real and personal property.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 8/358
REAL PROPERTY: Lands, tenements and hereditaments and shall embrace all chattels real.
SHALL: The word "shall" is mandatory.
STATE: The State of Iowa.
STATUTE REFERENCES: Whenever reference is made to the Iowa Code, this shall mean and have reference to the latest edition of the Iowa Code, as
amended and supplemented.
TENSE: Words in the present tense shall include the future.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: Printing and any other mode of representing words and letters, but unless a facsimile signature is authorized when the written
signature of any person is required by law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in the proper handwriting of such person or in
case he is unable to write, by his proper mark, witnessed as required by law.
YEAR: A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed. (1953 Code § 3-1; amd. 1985 Code; Ord. 1476, 1-15-1979; 2017 Code)
1-3-2: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections,
including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (1985 Code)
Chapter 4
GENERAL PENALTY
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Any person who shall be found guilty of violating the provisions of any section of this Code now existing, or hereafter enacted, for which no other penalty is
provided, shall be punished as provided in Iowa Code sections 903.1(1)(a) and 364.3(2) in the case of simple misdemeanors or as provided in Iowa Code
section 364.3(6) in the case of Municipal infractions. (Ord. 01-22, 10-16-2001; amd. 2017 Code)
ARTICLE A. MUNICIPAL INFRACTIONS
1-4A-1: DEFINITIONS:
MUNICIPAL INFRACTION: Except those provisions specifically provided under State law as a felony, an aggravated misdemeanor, or a serious
misdemeanor or a simple misdemeanor under chapters 687 through 747 of the Code of Iowa, the doing of any act prohibited or declared to be unlawful, an
offense or a misdemeanor by the Code of ordinances, City of Mason City, or any ordinance or Code herein adopted by reference, or omission or failure to
perform any act or duty required by the Code of ordinances, City of Mason City, or any ordinance or Code herein adopted by reference, is a Municipal
infraction and is punishable by a civil penalty as provided herein.
OFFICER: Any employee or official authorized to enforce the Code of ordinances of the City of Mason City.
REPEAT OFFENSE: A recurring violation of the same section of the Code of ordinances. (Ord. 88-29, 12-5-1988)
1-4A-2: VIOLATIONS, PENALTIES AND ALTERNATIVE RELIEF:
A. A Municipal infraction is punishable by a civil penalty of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation or, if the infraction is a
repeat offense, a civil penalty not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each repeat offense. (Ord. 01-23, 10-16-2001; amd. 2017 Code)
B. Each day that violation occurs or is permitted to exist by the violator constitutes a separate offense.
C. Seeking a civil penalty as authorized in this chapter does not preclude a City from seeking alternative relief from the court in the same action. (Ord. 88-
29, 12-5-1988)
1-4A-3: CIVIL CITATIONS:
A. Any officer authorized by the City to enforce the Code of ordinances may issue a civil citation to a person who commits a Municipal infraction.
B. The citation may be served by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested.
C. A copy of the citation shall be sent to the Clerk of the District Court. (Ord. 88-29, 12-5-1988)
D. The citation shall serve as notification that a civil offense has been committed and shall contain the following information:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 9/358
1. The name and address of the defendant.
2. The name or description of the infraction attested to by the officer issuing the citation.
3. The location and time of the infraction.
4. The time and place of court appearance.
5. The penalty for failure to appear in court. (Ord. 88-29, 12-5-1988; amd. 2017 Code)

Chapter 6
CITY COUNCIL
1-6-1: THE COUNCIL:
Composition of the City Council shall consist of one (1) Council member from each of the four (4) wards established in section 1-9-5 of this title, together
with two (2) Council members elected at large, as provided in section 372.13, Iowa Code. (1953 Code § 6-1; amd. 1985 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 12/358
1-6-2: POWERS; DUTIES:
The Council shall have and exercise all legislative powers, functions and duties conferred upon the Council by the applicable statutes of the State of Iowa
and the provisions of this Code. It shall levy all taxes, apportion and appropriate all funds, and audit and allow all bills, accounts and claims. The Council
shall have and exercise general authority, either directly or through the authority of the City Administrator, over the City waterworks, the wastewater
treatment plant, the City Library and its Board of Trustees, the MacNider Art Museum and its Board of Trustees, City Airport and its Board of Trustees, the
City park system and the Park and Recreation Board, the Civil Service Commission, the Planning and Zoning Commission and the Community
Development Director, the Public Works Director, the City Attorney, the Finance Director, the City Clerk and all commissions, boards and officers provided
by law and not specifically assigned to any other department. (1953 Code § 6-2; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
1-6-3: MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: The time for holding regular meetings of the City Council is hereby fixed at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. on the first and third Tuesdays
of each month, except that if any regular meeting date is a legal holiday, an alternate date shall be designated and posted as required. (Ord. 97-10, 4-
15-1997; amd. 2017 Code)
B. Special Meetings: The City Council may hold special meetings when called by the Mayor or a majority of the members of the Council. (1953 Code § 6-
4; amd. Ord. 935, 4-20-1964; 2017 Code)
C. Quorum: A quorum for the transaction of business shall consist of a majority of the usual number of members of the Council to which the City is entitled,
except that a lesser number may adjourn any meeting to a day and hour certain. (1953 Code § 6-5)
D. Presiding Officer: The Mayor, or in the absence of the Mayor, the Mayor Pro Tem, shall preside at all Council meetings. In the absence of either of the
foregoing, the Council may appoint a Council member to chair the meeting. The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum and may have
persons creating disorder removed from the meeting. (Ord. 89-31, 12-18-1989)
1-6-4: STANDING COMMITTEES:
A. Establishment: The Council shall establish standing committees as they deem necessary, consisting of three (3) or more members as appointed by the
Mayor with Council approval; the first person named shall chair the meeting(s). All standing committees shall establish rules of procedure. The Mayor
will be an ex officio member of all committees.
B. Committee Reports: Reports of committees may be presented at a subsequent Council meeting, or at any meeting the committee deems necessary. A
statement of the issues, the opinions and recommendations of the committee shall be presented orally or in writing thereon; and any final
recommendation must be presented in the form of a proposed ordinance, resolution or motion. (Ord. 89-31, 12-18-1989)
Chapter 7
MAYOR
1-7-1: QUALIFICATIONS AND DUTIES:
The Mayor shall be elected at large and shall be the presiding officer of the City Council and shall have and exercise all powers and duties conferred upon
him by section 372.14, Code of Iowa, and the provisions of this Code. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996)
1-7-2: CONSERVATOR OF THE PEACE:
The Mayor may take command of the police and govern the City by proclamation, upon making a determination that a time of emergency or public danger
exists. Within the City limits, the Mayor has all the powers conferred upon the Sheriff to suppress disorders, as provided in section 372.14, Code of Iowa.
(1953 Code § 19-4; amd. 1985 Code)
1-7-3: REPORTS:
The Mayor shall, at the first regular meeting of the newly elected Council in January and at such other times as he may deem expedient, report to the
Council concerning the Municipal affairs of the City and recommend the adoption of such measures as to him may seem advisable. (1953 Code § 19-5)
1-7-4: DUTIES:
The Mayor shall also perform such other duties compatible with the nature of his office as herein required or as may hereinafter be required by the
provisions of this Code or resolution of the Council. The Mayor may vote to break a tie vote on motions not involving ordinances, resolutions, spending
over ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or appointments made by the Council alone, as provided in section 372.4, Code of Iowa. (Ord. 93-29, 10-5-1993)
1-7-5: MAYOR PRO TEM:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 13/358
Except for limitations otherwise provided herein, the Mayor Pro Tem shall perform the duties of the Mayor in case of absence or inability of the Mayor to
perform the duties of his office. In the exercise of the duties of his office, the Mayor Pro Tem shall not have power to employ or to discharge from
employment officers or employees that the Mayor has power to appoint or discharge. The Mayor Pro Tem shall have the right to vote as a member of the
Council. (1985 Code)
Chapter 8
MUNICIPAL OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
1-8-1: BONDS OF OFFICERS:
The Director of Finance and no others shall, prior to entering upon performance of duties, provide an official's bond, as required by law in the penal
amount as may from time to time be fixed by the City Council, but in no event less than the minimum penal amount of two hundred seventy five thousand
dollars ($275,000.00). (Ord. 95-20, 10-17-1995)
1-8-2: BLANKET BONDS:
The following officers and no others shall be covered by a blanket bond purchased by the City in the penal amount as may from time to time be fixed by
the City Council indemnifying and holding harmless the City against loss occasioned by their failure to perform faithfully their respective duties:
Attorney
Chief of Police
City Administrator/City Clerk
City Engineer
Mayor
Mayor Pro Tem
Operation and Maintenance Manager
All officers and employees, except those specified in this section and section 1-8-1 of this chapter, shall be covered by a blanket bond indemnifying and
holding harmless the City against loss occasioned by embezzlement or any other dishonest act in such penal amounts as may from time to time be fixed
by the City Council. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997; 2017 Code)
1-8-3: AUTHORITY TO PURCHASE:
The Mayor and Clerk are hereby authorized and directed to purchase individual and blanket bonds as provided in sections 1-8-1 and 1-8-2 of this chapter
from funds of the City legally usable for such purposes and to carry out, in all other respects, the policy of placing under blanket bonds all officers and
employees as near as may be. (Ord. 696, 7-1-1955)
1-8-4: SALARIES DETERMINED:
The annual salaries of officials of the City shall be determined by the Council. Said salaries shall be paid on a biweekly basis, in twenty six (26) equal
installments, and shall be in the amounts fixed by the Council from time to time. (Ord. 1079, 7-7-1969)
1-8-5: SALARIES OF COUNCIL MEMBERS:
Commencing January 1, 2014, the salary of Council members of the City is hereby fixed at the sum of four thousand nine hundred dollars ($4,900.00) per
year, payable biweekly. Commencing January 1, 2015, the salary of Council members of the City is hereby fixed at the sum of seven thousand four
hundred dollars ($7,400.00) per year, payable biweekly. (Ord. 13-17, 5-21-2013)
1-8-6: SALARY OF MAYOR:
Commencing January 1, 2014, the salary of the Mayor is hereby fixed at the sum of ten thousand seven hundred dollars ($10,700.00) per year, payable
biweekly. Commencing January 1, 2015, the salary of the Mayor is hereby fixed at the sum of thirteen thousand two hundred dollars ($13,200.00) per year,
payable biweekly. (Ord. 13-18, 5-21-2013)
1-8-7: MILEAGE:
Each officer or employee driving his own automobile on City business shall be entitled to claim reimbursement for the expenses thereof at the current rate,
as established by the U.S. General Service Administration, per mile of actual and necessary driving in the course of his employment. Verified and itemized
claims for such reimbursement shall be filed monthly upon forms provided by the Finance Director and shall set out the name of the claimant, his official
capacity, the number of miles actually and necessarily driven on City business, and any other expenses actually and necessarily incurred on behalf of the
City. Such claims shall be paid only upon approval by the Finance Director. (Ord. 1537, 3-3-1980; amd. Ord. 95-20, 10-17-1995; 2017 Code)
1-8-8: GIFTS:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 14/358
No public official, public employee, or candidate, or that person's immediate family member shall, directly or indirectly, accept or receive any gift or series
of gifts from a restricted donor, as set out in sections 68B.2 and 68B.22, Iowa Code. "Gift" means a rendering of anything of value in return for which legal
consideration of equal or greater value is not given and received. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996)
ARTICLE A. DEPUTY CITY CLERK
1-8A-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM:
The Deputy City Clerk shall be appointed by the City Administrator/City Clerk, subject to the approval of the City Council, as provided by subsection 1-8C-
3Q of this chapter and shall hold office thereafter, or until a successor is duly appointed and qualified.
The Deputy City Clerk shall perform all the duties prescribed by this Code and the laws of the State for the Deputy Clerk.
A. Exception: The Administrator/City Clerk shall authenticate all measures or documents. Only in the absence of the City Administrator/City Clerk shall the
Deputy City Clerk be authorized to authenticate all measures or documents. (Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
1-8A-2: SEAL; RECORDS; DOCUMENTS:
The Deputy City Clerk shall be the keeper of the seal of the City and shall, under the direction of the Administrator/City Clerk or other authorized officer,
affix the seal to all public instruments, or documents which by law or provisions of this Code are required to be attested by the affixing of the seal. The
Deputy City Clerk shall have the custody of and safely keep all public records, documents, ordinances, resolutions, orders of the Council, and such other
papers and documents which may be filed in the office or delivered into the custody of the Deputy City Clerk. The Deputy City Clerk shall be custodian of
all bonds running in favor of the City. (Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
1-8A-3: COUNCIL RECORDS; ORDINANCES:
The Deputy City Clerk shall attend all sessions of the Council and keep true and correct minutes of the proceedings thereof in a book or books to be kept
and provided for that purpose. The Deputy City Clerk shall also file all original drafts of ordinances and resolutions passed or adopted by the Council and
shall accurately record such ordinances and resolutions in the ordinance book and resolution book, respectively, and shall properly index the same. The
Deputy City Clerk shall cause all ordinances requiring publication to be published as directed therein and shall, upon publication, preserve the original
proof thereof in a book or file kept and maintained for that purpose, all in accordance with section 380.7, Iowa Code. (Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997; amd. 2017
Code)
1-8A-4: DEEDS; EASEMENTS; AGREEMENTS; CONTRACTS:
The Deputy City Clerk shall keep a book of deeds, easements, agreements and contracts in which the Deputy City Clerk shall cause to be recorded all
deeds, contracts, agreements and easements executed or entered into by the City, and shall keep an index of the contents thereof. (Ord. 97-29, 11-18-
1997)
1-8A-5: COPY OF RECORDS:
It shall be the duty of the Deputy City Clerk to furnish to any City officer charged with the duty of serving any notice, order or resolution, a copy of such
notice or paper. (Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
ARTICLE B. DIRECTOR OF FINANCE
1-8B-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM:
The Director of Finance shall be appointed by the City Administrator, subject to the approval of the City Council, as provided by article C of this chapter
and shall hold office thereafter, or until a successor is duly appointed and qualified. (Ord. 94-6, 3-1-1994)
1-8B-2: DUTIES:
The Director of Finance shall have and perform all of the powers and duties prescribed by law and the provisions of this Code, and shall be the general
accountant of the City. He shall receive and preserve in his office all account books, vouchers, documents, and papers relating to all accounts and
transactions of the City, its revenues, debts, and fiscal affairs; he shall be the custodian of the bond of the Clerk and of all public records and papers
relating to his office except such as are by law placed in the custody of some other officer. (Ord. 1179, 3-6-1972; amd. Ord. 91-6, 4-2-1991; Ord. 94-6, 3-1-
1994)
1-8B-3: CHIEF WARRANT OFFICER:
A. The Director of Finance shall be the Chief Warrant Officer of the City, and as such, is hereby authorized and directed to affix his signature to all warrants
on behalf of the City. In the absence of the Chief Warrant Officer, the City Administrator/City Clerk shall act as his alternate to sign warrants on behalf of
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 15/358
the City. (Ord. 91-6, 4-2-1991; amd. Ord. 94-6, 3-1-1994; 2017 Code)
B. The Director of Finance shall keep a warrant register, upon which shall be entered the number, date of issuance, to whom issued, amount, and fund
upon which each warrant is drawn. He shall also keep a distribution ledger, showing the number of each warrant, the fund upon which it is drawn, the
purpose for which it is drawn, and the amount appropriated for each fund, together with the balance remaining therein, together with such other and
further records and books as may be required to keep an accurate record of all monies received by the City, the funds to which the same are allocated,
and of all monies paid out by the City, together with the funds upon which the same are charged to.
C. The Director of Finance is authorized to pay routine claims for regular monthly recurring routine bills in advance of the approval of the City Council.
(Ord. 1179, 3-6-1972; amd. Ord. 91-6, 4-2-1991; Ord. 94-6, 3-1-1994)
1-8B-4: REPORTS:
The Director of Finance shall make a detailed monthly report to the Council, which report shall contain a list of all warrants drawn, all receipts from any
source whatsoever, the funds to which the same were credited, and the balances in the various funds. He shall also make a summarized monthly report to
the Council containing a statement of the receipts and disbursements in the various funds. On or before December 1 of each year, he shall furnish a
certified copy of all annual reports required by specified officials of the State. (Ord. 1539, 3-3-1980; amd. Ord. 91-6, 4-2-1991; Ord. 94-6, 3-1-1994; 2017
Code)
1-8B-5: PURCHASE OF SUPPLIES:
The Director of Finance shall purchase all goods, materials, and supplies needed by the City, and shall enter into consultations with department heads and
the City Council to determine needs for all departments of the City, and shall enforce quality standards for goods purchased. He shall prepare detailed
claims for all purchases made by the City before payment for said goods is made. (Ord. 1179, 3-6-1972; amd. Ord. 91-6, 4-2-1991; Ord. 94-6, 3-1-1994)
1-8B-6: ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES:
The Director of Finance shall be responsible for the management and operations of the City's Data Processing Division, IT Division, GIS Director, Grant
Administrator, and the Cashier's Division. The Director shall also perform all duties and functions as the Chief Investment Officer and Treasurer for the
City. (Ord. 13-03, 3-5-2013; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8B-7: ASSISTANT FINANCE DIRECTOR:
When authorized by the City Administrator, an Assistant Finance Director may be appointed by the Director, subject to the approval of the City
Administrator, and shall hold office thereafter, or until a successor is appointed and qualified. The Assistant Director shall, in the absence or inability of the
Director to act, perform all the duties and acts which may be required by the Director, Mayor, or Council. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996)
ARTICLE C. CITY ADMINISTRATOR/CITY CLERK
1-8C-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
The Office of City Administrator/City Clerk is hereby created as provided by section 372.4, Iowa Code. The City Administrator/City Clerk shall be appointed
by majority vote of the City Council for an indefinite term until removed or until a successor has been duly appointed and qualified. The Administrator/Clerk
shall be chosen by the Council solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to actual experience in or
knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office hereinafter set forth. At the time of appointment, the person need not be a resident of
the City or State, but during the Administrator's/Clerk's tenure of office, shall reside within a ten (10) mile radius of the City or according to terms of
employment agreement. The City Administrator/City Clerk shall receive an annual salary in such amount as may be fixed from time to time by the Council.
(Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997; 2017 Code)
1-8C-2: REMOVAL:
The City Council may remove the City Administrator/City Clerk at any time by a majority vote of the Council on the recommendation of the Mayor or on its
own initiative. Any removal shall be subject to the provisions of section 372.15, Iowa Code. Except for removal for cause, after the completion of twelve
(12) months' service, the City Administrator/City Clerk may not be removed without sixty (60) days' notice. (Ord. 93-18, 9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-
1997)
1-8C-3: ADMINISTRATION AND DUTIES:
The City Administrator/City Clerk shall be the Chief Administrative Officer of the City and shall be responsible to the Mayor and City Council for the proper
administration of all affairs of the City. All departments of the City, except as otherwise provided by ordinance, shall be responsible to the
Administrator/Clerk. The duties of the Administrator/Clerk shall be as follows: (Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
A. Implement all policy directives promulgated by the Mayor, in his executive capacity, and by the City Council, in its legislative capacity.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 16/358
B. Supervise enforcement and execution of the City laws and supervise the City's administrative policies and procedures including personnel and
purchasing.
C. Coordinate and direct all City services provided through the various departments of the City.
D. Attend all meetings of the Council unless excused by the Mayor.
E. Keep the Mayor and City Council informed on the progress of City projects, programs and policies. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993)
F. Recommend to the Council, from time to time, any measures as the Administrator/Clerk shall deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or
welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services within the City.
G. Supervise and direct the official conduct of all officials and those employees of the City whom the Administrator/Clerk has power to appoint and also
those department heads or supervisors who report to or through the Office of City Administrator/City Clerk.
H. Prepare a proposed budget annually in cooperation with appropriate supervisory personnel of the City and all City boards, commissions or other
administrative agencies, and submit it to the Council. The Administrator/Clerk shall be responsible for administering the budget as adopted by the
Council and ensuring all expenditures are provided for by the budget or such amendments to the budget as may, from time to time, be approved by the
Council.
I. Keep the Mayor and City Council fully apprised of the financial and other conditions of the City and of future needs. The Administrator/Clerk shall
prepare and submit a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the City within thirty (30) days of the end of each fiscal year and
shall provide such other reports as the City Council may request. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
J. Cooperate with any administrative agency, board or commission of the City and act as technical advisor when applying for grants to enable the Mayor,
City Council, boards and commissions to enhance their funding.
K. Supervise the construction, improvement, repair, maintenance and management of all City property, capital improvements and undertakings of the City,
including the making and preservation of all surveys, maps, plans, drawings, specifications and estimates for capital improvements except for those
activities subject to the management or control of an administrative board, commission or agency. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993)
L. Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies, and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget and may approve capital and repair
expenditures up to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for operational needs and up to twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for emergency needs.
The Administrator/Clerk shall negotiate and recommend to the City Council, for its approval, all other contracts for the necessary operation of or
maintenance of City services not subject to the bidding requirements of section 26.3, Iowa Code. On all expenditures for public improvements in
excess of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) let for public bid pursuant to chapter 26, Iowa Code, the Administrator/Clerk shall receive the
sealed bids and present them to the Council with a recommendation for awarding the contract1. (Ord. 07-26, 10-16-2007; amd. 2017 Code)
M. Conduct or supervise all business affairs of the City and cause accurate records to be kept by modern and efficient accounting methods. (Ord. 93-28,
9-7-1993)
N. Have charge and control of the Police and Fire Departments, except that the Mayor shall take command of the police and govern the City by
proclamation upon making a determination that a time of emergency or public danger exists as provided in section 372.14, Iowa Code. The Mayor may,
at any time, delegate in writing to the Administrator/Clerk, such emergency powers. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
O. Perform all other duties as may be required by the direction of the Council. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993)
P. Consolidate or combine offices, positions, departments or units under the Administrator's/Clerk's jurisdiction, with the approval of the City Council. (Ord.
93-28, 9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
Q. Appoint or employ, classify or reclassify appointed officials, subject to the approval of the City Council and all employees of the City, except for the
provisions of the Veteran's Preference Law, chapter 35C and Civil Service Law, chapter 400, and except for provisions of section 372.8, Iowa Code,
governing the Office of the City Clerk and such other officials or employees for whom another method of appointment is specifically provided by
ordinance or by State law. (Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
R. Have the power to discipline and to discharge summarily any official, appointee or employee the Administrator/Clerk is empowered to appoint or employ
subject, however, to the provisions of Civil Service Law, any personnel policy duly adopted by the Council, and subject to the right of hearing provided
by section 372.15, Iowa Code.
S. Summarily investigate, or cause to be investigated, the affairs and conduct of any department, agency, officer or employee subject to the supervision of
the Administrator/Clerk. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
T. Assist the City Council and the Planning and Zoning Commission in the carrying out of the Comprehensive Plan for City development and assist all
other forms of planning within the City government. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 17/358
1-8C-4: COUNCIL NOT TO INTERFERE WITH APPOINTMENTS OR REMOVALS:
Neither the Council nor any of its members shall direct or request the appointment of any person to, or removal from, Office by the City Administrator/City
Clerk or any of the Administrator's/Clerk's subordinates, or in any manner take part in the appointment or removal of officials and employees in the
administrative services of the City. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the City Council and its members shall deal with the administrative service solely
through the City Administrator/City Clerk and neither the Council nor any member thereof shall give orders to any subordinates of the City
Administrator/City Clerk, either publicly or privately. (Ord. 93-28, 9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
1-8C-5: BOND:
The City Administrator/City Clerk shall furnish a surety bond to be approved by the Council, said bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of all
the Administrator's/Clerk's duties and in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). The premium of the bond shall be paid by the City. (Ord. 93-28,
9-7-1993; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997)
ARTICLE D. CITY ATTORNEY
1-8D-1: APPOINTMENT:
The Council shall appoint a City Attorney and any Assistant City Attorney to serve at the discretion of the Council. Engagement of the City Attorney and
any Assistant City Attorney shall be at compensation levels and upon other terms and conditions established by the Council. Any Assistant City Attorney
shall have duties and responsibilities assigned by the City Attorney and approved by the City Administrator. Duties and responsibilities of the City Attorney
may be shared or divided with any Assistant City Attorney subject to approval by the City Administrator. (Ord. 11-20, 11-1-2011)
1-8D-2: ATTORNEY FOR CITY:
The City Attorney shall act as attorney for the City in all legal matters affecting the City's interest and appear on behalf of the City before any court,
tribunal, commission or board. The City Attorney shall prosecute or defend all actions and proceedings involving the City when requested to do so by the
Council or City Administrator. (Ord. 11-20, 11-1-2011)
1-8D-3: POWER OF ATTORNEY:
The City Attorney shall sign in behalf of the City all appeal bonds and other bonds and papers that may be necessary in connection with matters before
any court and the City shall be bound with respect thereto. (Ord. 11-20, 11-1-2011)
1-8D-4: ADDITIONAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The City Attorney shall be the Chief Legal Advisor to the Council and other City officers in respect to their duties. In connection therewith, the City Attorney
shall have the duty and responsibility to:
A. Upon request of the Council, Mayor or City Administrator, attend meetings of the Council.
B. Draw ordinances and report to the Council respecting defects in ordinances when they become known to the City Attorney.
C. Prepare documents of a legal nature regarding matters in which the City is interested at the request of any Council member, the Mayor or City
Administrator.
D. Give advice or issue opinions on questions of law arising out of any ordinance, contract, claim, dispute, demand, proceeding or matter affecting the City,
at the request of any Council member, the Mayor or City Administrator.
E. Provide such other legal services respecting matters affecting the City as required by City ordinances or State law or as requested by the Council,
Mayor or City Administrator. (Ord. 11-20, 11-1-2011)
1-8D-5: REPORT TO COUNCIL:
The City Attorney shall submit to the Council not later than January 31 of each year a report on all civil cases involving the City settled or decided during
the preceding year ended December 31 and as of then pending. (Ord. 11-20, 11-1-2011)
1-8D-6: SPECIAL COUNSEL:
When deemed necessary or appropriate, special counsel may be retained by the City upon approval by the Council. (Ord. 11-20, 11-1-2011)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 18/358
ARTICLE E. CITY ASSESSOR
1-8E-1: APPOINTMENT:
There shall be selected a City Assessor in accordance with the provisions of section 441.1, Code of Iowa, as amended. (1985 Code)
1-8E-2: MEETINGS:
The Mayor is hereby ordered and directed to call joint meetings of the Conference Board, consisting of the Board of Supervisors of Cerro Gordo County,
the School Board of Mason City Independent School District and the Council of the City, from time to time as may be required by law to comply with and to
put into effect the provisions of said section 441.6, Code of Iowa, as amended. (1953 Code § 23-5; amd. Ord. 1626, 3-15-1982)
1-8E-3: EXAMINING BOARD:
There is hereby created, as set forth in chapter 441 of the Code of Iowa, a three (3) member Examining Board consisting of a representative from each
unit of the Conference Board, who shall serve a term of six (6) years; the purpose of said Examining Board is to conduct examinations and certify eligible
candidates for the position of Assessor to the Conference Board. (1985 Code)
1-8E-4: BOARD OF REVIEW:
There is hereby created, as set forth in section 441.31, Code of Iowa, a Board of Review whose purpose is to hold annual sessions during the month of
May and for an additional period as required under section 441.37, Code of Iowa, and shall hold as many meetings as required to discharge its duties,
which is to equalize assessments on property. (1985 Code)
ARTICLE F. DEPARTMENT OF CITY ENGINEER
1-8F-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created the department of City Engineering in the City, which shall consist of the Engineering Division which includes the Traffic Control
Division, water supply and waterworks system, the sanitary sewer system and the stormwater collection system of the City. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996; amd.
2017 Code)
1-8F-2: CITY ENGINEER; APPOINTMENT:
Said City Engineer shall be appointed by the City Administrator, subject to the approval of the City Council and shall hold office thereafter, or until a
successor is duly appointed and qualified. Said City Engineer shall be a registered professional engineer, registered by the Board of Engineering
Examiners of the State of Iowa, or if a registered professional engineer in another state, be able to obtain registration in the State of Iowa within one (1)
year of appointment. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8F-3: DUTIES:
The City Engineer shall be responsible for the management, operation and maintenance of the Engineering Division and the Supervisors/Superintendents
of each division, subject to the approval of the City Administrator. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8F-4: SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS:
In all cases where private property is proposed to be assessed for public improvements, it shall be the duty of the City Engineer to advise the City
Administrator/Council with reference to the value of the respective lots, parts of lots, or parcels of land, and the property of any railway company or street
railway company whose property may be liable for such special assessment, and to determine the amounts which may be assessed against the owners
thereof. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8F-5: ASSISTANT CITY ENGINEER:
A. Appointment, Term: When authorized by the City Administrator, an Assistant City Engineer may be appointed by the City Engineer, subject to the
approval of the City Administrator, and shall hold office thereafter, or until a successor is appointed and qualified. Said Assistant shall be a registered
engineer in training at time of appointment.
B. Supervision, Duties: The Assistant City Engineer shall be under the direct supervision of the City Engineer, and shall perform all utilities and engineering
related duties and functions as assigned by the City Engineer. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996; amd. 2017 Code)
ARTICLE G. DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES

1-8G-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is established the Department of Human Resources in the City, which shall consist of the Director of Human Resources and such other employees
as may from time to time be appointed by the City Administrator. (Ord. 11-21, 11-1-2011)
1-8G-2: APPOINTMENT OF DIRECTOR:
The Director of Human Resources shall be appointed by the City Administrator and serve under the supervision and direction of the City Administrator.
(Ord. 11-21, 11-1-2011)
1-8G-3: DUTIES OF DIRECTOR:
A. Manage, operate and maintain Department of Human Resources.
B. Administer personnel system subject to personnel rules approved and adopted by the City Council and subject to applicable City ordinances and as
directed by the City Administrator.
C. Make all appointments to City service in accordance with personnel rules then in effect, unless such power is specifically assigned by law to another
appointing authority.
D. Act as liaison between Civil Service Commission and City and support person for commission.
E. Recruit applicants for civil service and noncivil service positions.
F. Prepare and periodically review and revise personnel rules and regulations for presentation to the City Council for adoption, covering titles,
classifications, working hours, leaves of absence, transfers and promotions, cause for discharge and suspension, sexual harassment and such other
subjects as may be necessary or advisable to carry out the intent and purpose of the City personnel system.
G. Negotiate and administer labor management contracts within the purview of the State Public Employment Relations Act.
H. Process all Municipal employment appointments, status changes and other personnel actions and maintain personnel records.
I. Coordinate employee training programs.
J. Ensure that all employment policies and practices of the City are administered consistently with applicable law.

ARTICLE H. DEVELOPMENT SERVICES DEPARTMENT
1-8H-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created and established a Development Services Department in the City of Mason City, which shall consist of the Director of Development
Services and such other employees as may from time to time be appointed by the City Administrator.
A. The Development Services Department shall be organized into the following divisions, which shall be under the direction of the Director of Development
Services:
1. The Planning and Zoning Division;
2. The Transit Operations and Safety Division;
3. The Building Inspections Division; and
4. The Code Enforcement Division. (Ord. 13-04, 3-5-2013; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8H-2: DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
The Director of Development Services shall be appointed by the City Administrator. (Ord. 13-04, 3-5-2013)
1-8H-3: DUTIES OF DIRECTOR:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 20/358
The Director of Development Services shall be under the direct administrative supervision of the City Administrator, and shall have the following duties and
perform the following functions:
A. Direct development of the community's Comprehensive Plan, subdivision and zoning ordinances, including the necessary research, analysis, plan
preparation, design, program development, and writing and editing of reports.
B. Direct development and implementation of the City's community development plans and redevelopment plans, and coordinate with other departments
and agencies regarding housing initiatives, and assist in Building and Zoning Code enforcement.
C. Direct analysis of the City's physical and socioeconomic characteristics; direct land use, population and economic forecasts.
D. Act as technical advisor on planning, economic growth and development matters to the Mayor, City Council, City Administrator, Planning and Zoning
Commission, Zoning Board of Adjustment and appear before the Council and commission to report or advise on major planning, economic growth and
community development projects, significant economic, housing, land use and population study findings, and new planning and development
techniques being utilized in other communities.
E. Work with all City departments in matters relating to planning, economic growth and community development programs.
F. Work with Federal, State and adjoining local governments in implementing the City's planning, economic growth and community development programs.
G. Prepare and administer the departmental budgets; assign staff, determine schedules, and review progress of departmental projects and initiatives.
H. Review public works projects referred to the department by other City departments, special districts, the County and other governmental agencies.
I. In cooperation with other departments, maintain the long range capital needs list, prepare the capital improvements program, and aid in the development
of the annual budget.
J. Prepare educational and informational materials, consult with developers, public officials, local agencies and citizens on planning, economic growth and
development matters; coordinate and review work performed by professional consulting firms retained for planning, and development studies. (Ord. 13-
04, 3-5-2013)
K. Manage the personnel process and related agreements for animal control Code enforcement and stray animal shelter responsibilities under title 8 of
this Code and related duties as assigned by the Director of Development Services.
L. Shall be responsible for the management, operation and maintenance of the Development Services Department and shall appoint staff required to
operate the department subject to the approval of the City Administrator, and as approved by the City Council, from time to time. (Ord. 13-04, 3-5-2013;
amd. 2017 Code)
1-8H-4: PLANNING AND ZONING DIVISION:
The Planning and Zoning Division shall be under the direction of the Planning and Zoning Manager. The Planning and Zoning Division shall be responsible
for administration of all planning, zoning, subdivision and related duties and functions as required or authorized by this Code and applicable State and
Federal regulations or statutes; zoning administration and enforcement; and related duties as assigned by the Director of Development Services. (Ord. 13-
04, 3-5-2013)
1-8H-5: TRANSIT OPERATIONS AND SAFETY DIVISION:
The Transit Operations and Safety Division shall be under the direction of the Transit Operations and Safety Manager.
A. Transit Operations: The Transit Operations and Safety Division shall manage the City's transit functions. In addition, Division Manager shall prepare and
manage the division budget, ensure proper use of public funds, seek improvements to the operation of the City transit system, conduct studies, and
encourage growth of the system.
B. Safety: The Transit Operations and Safety Manager shall coordinate the City's safety function, to promote employee and public safety, manage and
minimize liability risk, and provide training as necessary or as required to meet local, State and Federal guidelines and requirements. (Ord. 13-04, 3-5-
2013; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8H-6: BUILDING INSPECTIONS DIVISION:
The Building Inspections Division shall be under the direction of the Chief Building Official. The Chief Building Official shall have the following duties:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 21/358
A. Serves as the Chief Building Official of the City. Reviews and enforces building safety ordinances. Examines plans and inspects construction projects to
determine compliance with City ordinances.
B. Acts as advisor on building and Code enforcement matters to the City Administrator, Director of Development Services, Mayor, City Council and other
City departments.
C. Supervises the building maintenance and repairs of City Hall.
D. Works with other City departments in matters relating to building codes and Building Code enforcement.
E. In consultation with the Code Enforcement Division, supervises condemnation and demolition of unsafe or abandoned structures within Mason City.
F. Consults with contractors, developers, public officials, local agencies, and citizens on Building Code matters; coordinates and reviews work performed
by architects, contractors and developers.
G. Other related duties as assigned by the Director of Development Services. (Ord. 13-04, 3-5-2013; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8H-7: CODE ENFORCEMENT DIVISION:
The Code Enforcement Division shall be under the direction of the Code Enforcement Manager.
A. The Code Enforcement Division shall perform all Nuisance Code enforcement responsibilities under title 4 of this Code and the Housing Code and
rental dwelling unit inspection requirements under title 10, chapter 2, article F of this Code.
B. The Code Enforcement Officers shall observe and investigate Nuisance and Housing Code complaints and violations, issue and serve notice to abate,
and shall make reasonable accommodations to violators to gain compliance with this Code.
C. The Code Enforcement Officers shall have authority to issue citations and authority to act as an officer of the court when requested.
D. The Code Enforcement Division shall consult with the Building Inspections Division regarding condemnation and demolition of unsafe or abandoned
structures, and shall supervise the process. (2017 Code)
ARTICLE I. BAND DIRECTOR
1-8I-1: EMPLOYMENT OF BAND DIRECTOR:
The City Administrator, subject to the approval of the Council, shall enter into a contract of employment of a band director and for members of the
Municipal band. (Ord. 96-26, 12-17-1996; amd. 2017 Code)
1-8I-2: PROVISIONS OF CONTRACT:
The contract for the band shall provide for the furnishing of free concerts for a reasonable period of time during the summer months and shall also provide
for the compensation to be paid to said band director and to the members of said band. (1953 Code § 25-2)
1-8I-3: PAYMENTS FROM BAND FUND:
The compensation of the band director, members of the band, and all expenses with reference to the band shall be paid from funds of the City legally
usable for such purposes. (1953 Code § 25-3)
Chapter 9
MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
1-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms are hereby defined:
ELECTIONS: Municipal or special elections approved by the City Council, provided by chapter 376, Iowa Code.
MAJORITY: One (1) vote more than one-half (1/2) the number of votes cast for all candidates for a particular office, as provided in section 376.9, Iowa
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 22/358
Code, provided, however, that in at large elections in which more than one (1) position is to be filled, "majority" shall be one (1) vote more than the total
number of votes cast for all candidates divided by the number of positions to be filled. (Ord. 97-24, 10-7-1997)
1-9-2: CANDIDATES FOR CITY OFFICES:
All candidates for all elective City offices shall be nominated by petition as provided by sections 376.4 through 376.9, Iowa Code, and any amendments
thereto. (Ord. 97-24, 10-7-1997)
1-9-3: RUNOFF ELECTIONS ADOPTED:
The provisions of section 376.9, Iowa Code, providing for a runoff election are hereby adopted in lieu of the requirement for a primary in sections 376.6
and 376.7 thereof. (Ord. 97-24, 10-7-1997; amd. 2017 Code)
Each candidate at a Municipal election receiving a majority of all votes cast for the office sought shall be declared elected. A runoff election shall be held
only for positions unfilled because of failure of a sufficient number of candidates to receive a majority vote in the regular City election. Candidates for runoff
are those who do not receive a majority of the votes cast for the office for which they have filed as follows:
A. If no candidate for a single office receives a majority of the votes cast for that office, the two (2) candidates receiving the largest number of votes
shall be placed upon the runoff ballot.
B. In an at large election to fill more than one (1) position, any candidate receiving a "majority" of the votes as defined in section 1-9-1 of this chapter
shall be declared elected. If a sufficient number of candidates do not receive a majority of the votes to fill all of the positions, those candidates
receiving the highest number of votes less than a majority equal to twice the number of positions remaining to be filled shall be placed on the runoff
ballot.
Any such runoff election shall be held four (4) weeks after the date of the regular City election and shall be conducted in the same manner as regular City
elections.
Candidates in the runoff election who receive the highest number of votes cast for each office on the ballot are elected to the extent necessary to fill the
positions open. (Ord. 97-24, 10-7-1997)
1-9-4: ELECTION COSTS:
The cost of any Municipal election shall be borne by the City and shall be subject to the approval of the City Council. (Ord. 1477, 1-15-1979)

Chapter 10
CONTRACT LETTING PROCEDURES
1-10-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall implement the provisions of Iowa Code chapters 23A.3, 26.3, 73A, 362, 572 and 573 regulating the advertisement and award of public
improvement contracts. This chapter establishes uniform requirements for construction contractors, subcontractors, vendors and suppliers who perform
services or construction work for a governmental body of the City on public improvement projects, and is to be construed, applied and enforced in
accordance with Iowa law. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
1-10-2: PURPOSE AND POLICY:
The purpose of this chapter is to prescribe the City Administrator's, or a designee, authority to administer public improvement contracts. In order to protect
the public interest, it is the expressed purpose of this chapter to simplify, clarify and modernize the City's contract letting procedure to prevent fraud,
misrepresentation, collusion, favoritism, discrimination, improvidence, price fixing and bid peddling in the administration of public contracts. (Ord. 94-20, 8-
16-1994)
1-10-3: DEFINITIONS:
For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined unless the context otherwise requires:
