ADDENDA: Any written notice, typed statement or graphic instrument issued to prospective bidders prior to the receipt of bids.
BIDDER: Any business which submits an offer or proposal on the prescribed form setting forth the prices for the work to be performed.
BIDDING DOCUMENTS: The advertisement or invitation for bids, instructions to bidders, the bid form and the proposed contract documents, including all
addenda issued prior to receipt of bids.
BIDDING REQUIREMENTS: The advertisement or invitation for bids, general instruction to bidders, prebid instructions to bidders and the bid form.
BUSINESS: Any person, corporation, partnership, individual, sole proprietorship, joint stock, company, joint venture or any other private legal entity.
Business also means a contractor, subcontractor, vender or supplier.
CHANGE ORDER: A written order directing a contractor to make changes under that clause of the contract which allows the City to order changes without
consent of the contractor, and all such change orders shall require written approval from the Public Services Director, or a designee.
CONSTRUCTION: The process of building, altering, repairing, improving or demolishing any public structure or building, or other public improvements of
any kind to any public real property. It does not include the routine operation, standard repair or customary maintenance of existing structures, buildings or
real property.
CONTRACT: All types of City agreements, regardless of their identification and any claim, account or demand against or agreement with a government
body, expressed or implied. The term "contract" shall not include employment agreements or collective bargaining agreements.
CONTRACT MODIFICATION: Any written alteration approved by the Public Services Director or a designee, in specifications, delivery point, rate of
delivery, period of performance, price, quantity, or other provisions of any contract accomplished by mutual action of the parties to the contract.
CONTRACTOR: Any business having a fully executed contract with a government body.
DATA: Recorded information regardless of form or characteristic.
DEFECTIVE WORK: Work that is unsatisfactory, faulty, deficient or fails to conform to the contract drawings and specifications, or does not meet the
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 25/358
requirements of any inspection, reference standard, test or approval referred to in the drawings and specifications or has been damaged prior to
recommendation of final payment.
DESIGNEE: A duly authorized representative of the Public Services Director holding an appointed position.
EMERGENCY: A sudden or unexpected situation or occurrence which would vitally affect the life, safety, health or property of citizens, or cause serious
loss or injury to the City. Emergency does not mean situations or occurrences which could have been anticipated through reasonable diligence and
foresight.
EMPLOYEE: An individual drawing a salary from the City of Mason City, whether elected or not, and any noncompensated individual performing personal
services for the City.
GOVERNMENT BODY: Any City department, commission, board, committee or agency.
GRATUITY: Consideration in any form, including but not limited to a gift, commission, discount and bonus.
IRRESPONSIBLE BIDDER: A bidder or a prospective bidder who fails to furnish, upon request from the Public Services Director or a designee, proof of
qualifications, financial stability, Iowa Labor Department certification and any other data required by this chapter. The term also means a bidder or
prospective bidder who has repeatedly made slow or unsatisfactory deliveries or progress during prior construction contracts, or who has violated, or
attempted to violate the provisions of other City contracts.
LOWEST RESPONSIBLE BIDDER: The bidder whose bid is the lowest of those bidders possessing the skill, financial resources and the ability to faithfully
perform the work outlined in the project manual.
MATERIALLY VARIES: Any item in the project manual that is made mandatory and nonwaivable.
PLANS: All drawings, diagrams, illustrations, schedules and other data or information which are specifically prepared or assembled in the project manual.
PROJECT MANUAL: The bidding requirements (invitation to bid and instructions to bidders), the contract forms (agreement, bond and certificates), the
contract conditions (general conditions, modifications to general conditions) and the project specifications.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS: Any building or construction work, either within or outside the corporate limits of the City, to be paid for, in whole or in part, by
the use of funds of the City, regardless of sources, including a building or improvement constructed or operated jointly with any other public or private
agency, but excluding urban renewal and low rent housing projects, industrial aid projects under Iowa Code chapter 419, emergency work or work
performed by employees of the City or a government body.
RESPONSIBLE BIDDER: A business which has the capability in all respects to perform fully the work as outlined in the project manual, and the integrity
and reliability which will assure good faith performance.
RESPONSIVE BIDDER: A business which has submitted a bid which conforms in all material respects with the project manual, both as to the method and
timeliness of submission and to the substance of any contract provision.
SERVICES: The furnishing of labor, time or effort by a contractor not involving the delivery of a specific end product other than reports which are merely
incidental to the required performance. This term shall not include employment agreements or collective bargaining agreements.
SPECIFICATIONS: Those portions of the contract document consisting of the mandatory written technical descriptions of materials, equipment,
construction systems, standards of workmanship as applied to the work and certain administrative details applicable thereto.
SUPPLIER: A manufacturer, fabricator, supplier, distributor, material person or vendor having a direct contract with the contractor or with any subcontractor
to furnish materials or equipment to be incorporated in the work by the contractor or any subcontractor.
TARGETED SMALL BUSINESS: A business as defined in the City's Targeted Small Business Guidelines, which is fifty one percent (51%) or more owned
and daily controlled by a female or a minority and is a mandatory requirement on all City projects.
WORK: The entire completed construction or the various separately identifiable parts thereof required to be furnished under the contract drawings and
specifications. Work also includes the contractor performing or furnishing labor, materials and equipment into the construction, and performing or providing
services and submitting documentation, all as required by the contract specifications. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994; amd. Ord. 94-20, 8-16-1994; 2017 Code)
1-10-4: GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF APPLICABLE LAW:
Unless provided elsewhere in this chapter, the principles of law and equity, including the Uniform Commercial Code of Iowa, and laws relative to capacity
to contract, agency, fraud, misrepresentation, duress, coercion, mistake or bankruptcy shall supplement the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-
1994)
1-10-5: LAWS AND REGULATIONS:
Every bidder and contractor shall give all notices and comply with all laws and regulations of the City and State applicable to successfully performing a City
contract. If a bidder or contractor's action in connection with a contract is contrary to the laws and regulations of the City, the contractor or bidder shall bear
all claims, costs, losses and damages caused by, arising out of or resulting therefrom. A contractor or bidder shall be presumed to know or have
constructive knowledge of all laws and regulations of the City. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
1-10-6: REQUIREMENT OF GOOD FAITH:
All government bodies, businesses, bidders and contractors involved in the solicitation, negotiation, performance or administration of a City contract shall
act in good faith and fair dealing in trade. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 26/358
1-10-7: LOCAL PURCHASES:
The City Administrator, or designee, shall establish a City policy which requires consideration of purchasing goods, services and construction work from
Mason City owned businesses and from targeted small businesses which offer their goods, services and construction work at a cost and consideration,
relatively equal to businesses not located in the corporate limits of Mason City. (Ord. 94-20, 8-16-1994)
1-10-8: PROHIBITED INTERESTS IN PUBLIC CONTRACT:
In accordance with Iowa Code section 362.5, no City officer or employee shall have an interest, direct or indirect, in any contract or job of work or material
or the profits thereof or services to be furnished or performed for the officer's or employee's City. Except as provided for in subsections 3a through 3m of
section 362.5, a contract entered into in violation of this chapter shall be void. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
1-10-9: CONTRACT LETTING PROCEDURE:
When the estimated total cost to the City of a public improvement exceeds the sum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), or the adjusted
competitive bid threshold established in Iowa Code section 314.1B, the Public Services Director, or designee, shall advertise for sealed bids for the
proposed improvement by posting a notice to bidders as provided in Iowa Code section 362.3, except that the notice to bidders may be posted not less
than thirteen (13) days and not more than forty five (45) days before the date for filing bids. When the cost of a public improvement is less than one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), or the adjusted competitive bid threshold established in Iowa Code section 314.1B, the Public Services Director,
or designee, will not be compelled to advertise for sealed bids, but shall solicit, on an equal basis, sealed quotations from three (3) or more bidders,
including targeted small businesses. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this section shall not apply to contracts for emergency repairs to public improvements;
provided, however, that such emergency repairs shall be made with such competition as is practicable under the circumstances. A written determination of
the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be included in the contract file. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
1-10-10: DIVULGING SEALED BIDS:
No public officer, deputy or employee shall directly or indirectly or in any manner whatsoever, at any time or in any manner than as provided by law, open
any sealed bid or convey or divulge to any person, business or bidder any part of the contents of a sealed bid, on any proposed public project under this
chapter. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
1-10-11: OPENING OF BIDS:
A. Receive And Open Bids: The Public Services Director, or designee, and the City Clerk shall preside at the public meeting convened to receive, open
and announce the amount of the bids. The Public Services Director shall reject any and all bidders who have been deemed irresponsible and unreliable
under section 1-10-16 of this chapter, based on the bidder's past work performance with the City. Each bidder shall accompany the bid with a bid
security amounting to not less than ten percent (10%) of the estimated total contract cost of the public improvement, or the amount of each bid. The bid
security shall be submitted in a separate sealed envelope and shall be opened by the City Clerk before the bid is disclosed. The bidder's security shall
be in the form of a cashier's or certified check drawn on a bank in Iowa or a bank chartered under the laws of the United States, or a certified share
draft drawn on a credit union in Iowa or chartered under the law of the United States, or a corporate surety which is satisfactory to the City.
B. Bid Security: The City Clerk shall determine the legal sufficiency of the bid security before the bidder's proposal is opened. The bid security shall contain
no condition except as provided by law. All bids that are submitted with legally insufficient bid security shall be rejected and returned to the bidder by
the City Clerk. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event the bidder fails to execute the contract as provided in the plans and specifications, or by this
chapter, the full amount of the bid security shall be forfeited to the City in liquidation of damages for such failure. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
1-10-12: REJECTION OF BIDS:
General bids shall be for the complete work as outlined in the plans and specifications. Every general bid shall be on the form supplied by the City. No
general bid shall be rejected because the bidder failed to submit prices for, or information related to, any item or items for which no specific space is
provided on the form or which contains minor numerical errors. A bid containing minor immaterial defects or minor irregularities shall be accepted and read
under advisement; provided, however, that the reading of a bid, or the reading of a bid under advisement, shall not operate as a waiver of any immaterial
defects or deficiencies in the bid. Bids that materially vary from the project specifications shall be rejected for any of the following reasons:
A. If the bid is on a form other than that which is found in the project manual, as if the form is altered or any part thereof is detached.
B. If there are unauthorized additions, conditional or alternate bids, or irregularities of any kind which make the bid incomplete, indefinite or ambiguous as
to its meaning.
C. If the bidder adds any unauthorized provisions in the bid reserving the bidder a right to accept or reject an award of the contract, or adds any provision
giving the bidder a right to not enter into a contract with the City after approval of award.
D. If the bid does not contain a unit price for each pay item listed in the bid form, except in the case of authorized alternate pay items or if any unit prices
are obviously unbalanced, either in excess of or below the reasonable market analysis values.
E. If the bidder knowingly submits false, misleading or deceptive data or information with its bid proposal or commits the same for its subcontractors. (Ord.
08-15, 11-4-2008)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 27/358
1-10-13: CONTRACT AWARD:
A. Bid Tabulation: The City Engineer, or designee, shall submit a bid tabulation to the City Council at a public City Council meeting which will include a brief
description of any defects or irregularities. The City Council thereafter may waive any and all such immaterial defects or irregularities upon determining
such waiver to be in the best interest of the City. The City Council shall reserve the right to reject any and all general bids if it determined that the low
bidder, or their subcontractors, are not competent to perform the work as specified in the contract, and may reject any and all bids received, fix a new
date for receiving bids and order publication of a new notice to bidders.
B. Notice Of Award: Should the City Council award the contract, the City Clerk shall give the successful bidder an official notice of award within thirty (30)
days of the opening of the bids. Within fifteen (15) days after receipt of the notice of award of contract, the successful bidder shall execute at least three
(3) counterparts of the agreement and provide the City Clerk with a performance payment bond as required by Iowa Code chapter 573, and such other
contract documents as required by the project manual. Failure on the part of the successful bidder to fully comply with the foregoing submissions within
twenty (20) days of receiving notice shall be considered just cause for voiding the agreement and the bidder forfeiting its bid bond.
C. Disclosure Of Subcontractors: A bidder awarded a construction contract with the City shall disclose the names of all subcontractors, who will work on
the project being bid, within forty eight (48) hours after the approval of the contract. If a subcontractor named by a bidder awarded a City construction
contract is replaced, or if the cost of work to be done by a subcontractor is reduced, the bidder shall disclose the name of the new subcontractor or the
amount of the reduced cost. (Ord. 08-15, 11-4-2008)
1-10-14: TIE LOW BIDS:
In the event identical low bids are received for the project from general bidders who are deemed to be responsive and responsible, the City Council may
award the contract to a locally owned business as it deems to be in the best interests of the City. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
1-10-15: SUSPENSION OF BIDDERS:
Based on the recommendation of the City Administrator, or designee, the City Council may suspend a bidder, contractor or subcontractor, depending on
the severity of the offense, from participating in other City construction contracts, or from taking part in City work as a subcontractor, for a period of not less
than six (6) months, nor more than eighteen (18) months. Any bidder, contractor or subcontractor who violates any provision in this section shall be
suspended for a period of time after a public hearing before the City Council Public Services Committee when it finds that the bidder, contractor or
subcontractor engaged in any of the following acts: (Ord. 94-20, 8-16-1994)
A. Continually failed or refused to correct deficient work or replace substandard or unauthorized materials found by the Public Services Department, or its
agent, or fails to make prompt progress payments to subcontractors for materials or labor in accordance with Iowa Code chapter 573.
B. Continually found not to be in reasonably close conformity with the project document or failed to correct work so as to be reasonably acceptable. (Ord.
94-3, 2-15-1994)
C. Continually failed to carry on the work in an acceptable manner or refused to comply with a written order of the Public Services Director, or designee,
within a reasonable time, or has responded to the Public Services Director, designee, City official or employee in any manner which is either
threatening, disparaging or insulting.
D. Persistently failed to timely complete a contract, or sought unreasonable extensions of time on current projects, or refused to comply with directives of
the Public Services Director, designee or the City Council.
E. Failed to perform the contract with skilled workers as required in the project document, or otherwise assigned or disposed of work to an unauthorized
contractor or to subcontract any portion thereof without approval of the Public Services Director, or a designee. (Ord. 94-20, 8-16-1994)
F. Forfeited a bid bond or failed to enter into a contract upon an offer of award by the City Council in response to a prior advertisement for bids for the
same project, or any combination of projects involving the same work for which the award is currently being considered.
G. Failed to comply with the nondiscrimination requirements of the standard specifications or special provisions as outlined in the contract.
H. Persistently or repeatedly refuses or fails to comply with the City's Target Small Business Program requirements and to effectively utilize female and
minority owned businesses on City public improvement projects, or has wilfully disregarded the rules, regulations and directives of the Mason City
Human Rights Commission1.
I. Failed to comply with the requirements of the Federal Davis Bacon requirements to pay prevailing wages during the course of a federally funded project,
as required by Federal law.
J. Been disqualified, suspended or debarred by any agency of the State, any of its municipalities or any Federal agency.
K. Subcontracted, employed, or otherwise used the services of anyone who has been disqualified by the City Council from working on City projects, or
employed or otherwise used the services of a City employee as prescribed in section 1-10-8 of this chapter.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 28/358
L. Been convicted of, or pled guilty to, or declared nolo contendere to, a charge of engaging in any conspiracy, collusion, price fixing or combination
thereof, or other unlawful act in restraint of trade, or business discrimination, or of similar charges in any Federal Court or a court of this or any other
state.
M. Offered, promised or given a gratuity to any person elected, selected, appointed, employed or otherwise engaged in public service to secure or fulfill a
City contract, or has employed as its own employees during the course of the project any of the foregoing. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
1-10-16: PROCEDURE FOR SUSPENSION:
A. Suspension: Following an investigation, the City Administrator, or authorized designee, shall determine if cause exists to suspend a bidder, contractor or
subcontractor from participating in subsequent City construction or repair work. If the City Administrator, or designee, finds that cause exists to
suspend, such findings shall be set forth in writing with a recommendation for suspension to the City Council Public Services Committee. The City
Administrator, or designee, shall officially serve notice on the respondent party within five (5) working days of the finding. The notice shall set forth in
detail the reasons supporting the recommendation, and the suggested period of suspension. The notice shall be sent to the respondent by certified
mail, return receipt requested.
B. Protest: Any business which receives official notification from the City Administrator, or designee, that suspension has been recommended may protest
the finding to the Public Services Committee. The protest shall be submitted in writing to the City Clerk within fourteen (14) days after receipt of the
notice. The City Clerk shall immediately schedule a hearing at which time the business must be allowed to present evidence or argument against the
suspension. The Public Services Committee hearing shall be scheduled by the City Clerk within ten (10) days of receipt of the written protest. Following
the suspension hearing, the Public Services Committee shall issue a proposed decision to the City Council to either support the suspension for a time
specified by the committee, or overrule the City Administrator's, or designee's, determination.
C. Action On Decision: If the City Council does not act on the Public Services Committee's proposed decision within thirty (30) days thereafter, the
committee's decision shall be considered accepted and binding. If suspension is the final outcome of the procedure outlined herein, the business shall
be immediately suspended. (Ord. 94-20, 8-16-1994)
1-10-17: MOTION FOR RECONSIDERATION:
Reconsideration of an adverse decision of the Public Services Committee may be requested by the contractor, appellant, or any interested party who
submitted comments during the Public Service Committee proceeding, and any agency involving the protest. The motion for reconsideration shall contain
a detailed statement of the factual and legal grounds upon which reversal or modification is deemed warranted, specifying any errors of law made or
information not previously considered. Such motions shall be filed not later than ten (10) days after official service notice and receipt of such adverse
decision. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
1-10-18: EX PARTE COMMUNICATION:
No Public Services Committee member or City Council member shall receive, ex parte, any evidence, explanation, analysis or advice, whether written or
oral, regarding any matter at issue in an appeal, nor shall any person, contractor or employee directly or indirectly, ex parte, submit to the Public Services
Committee or City Council, any evidence, explanation, analysis or advice, whether written or oral, regarding any matter at issue in a protest or appeal.
(Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
1-10-19: JUDICIAL REVIEW:
A business adversely affected by a decision of the City may file a petition for judicial review in the Cerro Gordo County District Court. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-
1994)
1-10-20: DECEPTION RELATING TO CITY CONTRACTS:
A business commits a prima facie violation of this chapter if, in the course of business, it wilfully makes false statements, whether by affidavit, report or
other representation to any City official, employee, board or commission for the purpose of influencing the acceptance of a bid or contract. A business
which wilfully prevents or attempts to prevent any City officer or employee from performing their duty commits a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-
1994)
1-10-21: PENALTY:
Any business which is found after hearing to have violated the provisions of subsections 1-10-15I, J, K and L and section 1-10-18 of this chapter shall be
disbarred for three (3) years from conducting business with the City, or participating in any other City public improvement for a period not exceeding three
(3) years. (Ord. 94-3, 2-15-1994)
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 29/358
Chapter 1
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION
2-1-1: PURPOSE:
The Civil Service Commission of the City shall be an administrative tribunal created under the authority of chapter 400, Iowa Code. The purpose of said
commission shall be to preserve and protect the rights and privileges of civil service employees within City government, and to ensure efficient, effective
and harmonious public service for residents of Mason City. The purpose of the commission shall also be to hear and determine matters as set out in
section 2-1-8 of this chapter involving the rights and privileges of civil service employees based on the merits of each case. (Ord. 1616, 11-16-1981)
2-1-2: APPOINTMENTS; TERMS:
The Mayor, subject to the approval of the City Council, shall appoint three (3) Civil Service Commissioners who shall hold office, one (1) until the first
Monday in April of the second year, one (1) until the first Monday in April of the third year, and one (1) until the first Monday in April of the fourth year after
such appointment, and whose successor shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years except that in case of a vacancy, the appointment shall be made to
fill the unexpired term. (Ord. 97-22, 9-2-1997)
2-1-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Commissioners must be citizens of Iowa, eligible electors as defined in chapter 39, Iowa Code, and residents of the City preceding their appointment
and shall serve without compensation. A person, while on the commission, shall not hold or be a candidate for any office of public trust. (Ord. 87-20, 9-21-
1987; amd. 2017 Code)
Civil Service Commissioners shall not buy from, sell to, or in any manner become parties directly to any contract to furnish supplies, material, or labor to
the City in which they are Commissioners. (Ord. 87-20, 9-21-1987)
2-1-4: CHAIRMAN; CLERK; RECORDS:
The commission shall elect a Chairperson from among its members. (Ord. 87-20, 9-21-1987)
For purposes of this chapter, the City Clerk, or a designee of the City Clerk, shall be Clerk of the commission and custodian of all records of the
commission. If an employee is appointed Clerk of the commission who is employed in a civil service status at the time of appointment as Clerk of the
commission, the appointee shall retain the civil service rights held before the appointment. (Ord. 97-22, 9-2-1997)
The Civil Service Commission shall keep a record of all its meetings and also a complete individual service record of each civil service employee which
record shall be permanent and kept up to date.
When duly certified by the Clerk of the commission, copies of all records and entries or papers pertaining to said record shall be admissible in evidence
with the same force and effect as the originals. All civil service records shall be confidential except as otherwise provided by State law, and shall be kept
under locked file. (Ord. 87-20, 9-21-1987)
2-1-5: MEETING PLACE; SUPPLIES:
The Civil Service Commission shall hereby be authorized the use of a meeting room within City Hall and the Council shall supply the commission with all
necessary equipment and qualified staff to enable it to properly perform its duties. (Ord. 97-22, 9-2-1997)
2-1-6: DUTIES:
The Civil Service Commission shall have and exercise the powers and duties as set forth in chapter 400, Iowa Code. The Civil Service Commission shall
adopt rules and regulations governing the administration of the Civil Service Program and shall also have the power to adopt, amend and rescind any
other rules and regulations necessary for the conducting of its business and for the preparation and administration of civil service examinations. (Ord.
1616, 11-16-1981)
2-1-7: APPLICABILITY; EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all appointive officers and employees except those positions set out in section 400.6, Iowa Code, or the most
recent amendment thereto. (Ord. 97-22, 9-2-1997; amd. 2017 Code)
2-1-8: HEARINGS AND APPEALS:
The Civil Service Commission shall have jurisdiction over suspensions, demotions, and discharges if no grievance procedure is provided in a collective
bargaining agreement applicable to a civil service employee and shall hold hearings on appeals regarding the same, if requested, within the terms of the
Civil Service Rules and Regulations. (Ord. 97-22, 9-2-1997)
2-1-9: JUDICIAL REVIEW:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 30/358
Judicial review of the final actions of the commission may be sought in accordance with section 400.27, Iowa Code. (Ord. 1616, 11-16-1981)
Chapter 2
CITY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
2-2-1: APPOINTMENT OF COMMISSION:
Pursuant to chapter 414, Code of Iowa, there shall be a City Planning and Zoning Commission which shall consist of seven (7) members who shall be
citizens of the City and shall be qualified by knowledge or experience to act in matters pertaining to the development of a City plan and the amending of
City zoning ordinances, and who shall not hold any elective office in the Municipal government. The members shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to
the approval of the City Council for terms of five (5) years following their appointment, and shall serve without compensation except for actual expenses,
which shall be subject to the approval of the City Council. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
2-2-2: VACANCIES:
A member whose term has expired shall continue to serve until a successor is appointed and approved. In the event of any vacancies on the City Planning
and Zoning Commission, the appointment of a successor shall be made by the Mayor, subject to the approval of the Council, and shall be for the balance
of the unexpired term. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976; amd. 2017 Code)
2-2-3: ORGANIZATION:
This commission shall annually, at its first meeting in April, choose one (1) of its members to act as Chair of the commission, and another of its members
Vice Chair, who shall perform all the duties of the Chair during his/her absence or disability. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976; amd. 2017 Code)
The City Planning and Zoning Commission shall adopt such rules and regulations governing its organization and procedures as may be deemed
necessary. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976)
2-2-4: POWERS AND DUTIES, PLANNING:
A. Approval Of Plats: When required by title 11, chapter 3 of this Code, all plans, plats or replats of subdivisions of land embraced in Mason City or within
the City's extraterritorial jurisdiction, laid out in lots or plats with the streets, alleys or other portions of the same intended to be dedicated to the public,
shall first be submitted to the City Planning and Zoning Commission, and its recommendation obtained before action by the City Council.
B. Approval Of Street Or Park Improvement: No plan for any street, park, parkway, boulevard, trafficway, river front or other public improvement affecting
the City plan shall be finally approved, or the character or location thereof determined, unless such proposal shall first have been submitted to the City
Planning and Zoning Commission. Such requirements for recommendations shall not act as a stay upon action where the commission, after thirty (30)
days' written notice requesting such recommendations, has failed to file the same.
C. Recommendations To Improvements: No statuary, memorial or work of art in a public place, and no public building, public structure or appurtenance
shall be located or erected or a site for such structure obtained until and unless the design and proposed location of such structure be submitted to the
Planning and Zoning Commission for its recommendation. No permits for such structures shall be issued without the commission having made the
above recommendation. However, such requirements for recommendations shall not act as a stay upon action where the commission, after thirty (30)
days' written notice requesting such recommendations, has failed to file the same.
D. Comprehensive Plan: The City Planning and Zoning Commission shall have full power and authority to make or cause to be made such surveys,
studies, maps, plans or charts of the City limits which, in the opinion of the commission, bears relation to a comprehensive plan. It shall bring its studies
and recommendations to the attention of the Council, and the commission may publish said studies and recommendations.
1. For the purpose of making a Comprehensive Plan for the physical development of the City, the commission shall make careful and comprehensive
studies of present conditions and future growth of the City with due regard to its relation to neighboring territory. The plan shall be made with the
general purposes of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the City and its environs which will, in
accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience and economy in the process of development.
2. The plan shall be made with consideration of the smart planning principles in section 18B.1, Iowa Code, and may include the information specified in
section 18B.2, subsection 2, Iowa Code.
3. Before the adoption of said Comprehensive Plan, or any part of it, or any substantial amendment to it, the commission shall hold at least one (1)
public hearing. Legal notice of such hearing will be given by one (1) publication not less than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) days before the date
of the hearing. The adoption of the plan, or part, or amendment, shall require a vote of not less than two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the
commission.
4. After adoption of said plan or amendment of the same by the commission, the plan shall be forwarded for approval by the Council. If the commission
disapproves the proposed plan or amendment thereof, it may be adopted by the Council with an affirmative vote of three-fourths (3/4) of the total
membership of the Council.
5. When said plan, or any modification or amendment, shall receive the approval of the council, the said plan shall constitute the official City plan of the
City of Mason City until subsequently modified or amended. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976; amd. 2017 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 31/358
2-2-5: POWERS AND DUTIES, ZONING:
A. Recommend to the City Council the boundaries of the various original zoning districts of the City and appropriate regulations and restrictions to be
enforced therein.
B. After the adoption of such zoning district boundaries, regulations and restrictions, the City Planning and Zoning Commission may recommend to the
City Council amendments, supplements, changes or modifications. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976)
C. Before presenting any recommendation to the City Council, the commission shall, with due diligence, prepare a preliminary report and hold a public
hearing thereon before submitting its final recommendation to the City Council, in accordance with the requirements of section 12-4-2 of this Code. The
City Council shall not hold its public hearings or take action until it has received the final recommendation from the City Planning and Zoning
Commission. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976; amd. 2017 Code)
2-2-6: REPORTS:
Immediately following the expiration of the Municipal fiscal year, the City Planning and Zoning Commission shall make a report to the City Council of its
proceedings, together with a full statement of its receipts, disbursements and the progress of its work for the preceding fiscal year. (Ord. 1355, 5-3-1976)
Chapter 3
ZONING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT1
2-3-1: MEMBERSHIP:
A Zoning Board of Adjustment, to be hereinafter referred to as the "board", is hereby established pursuant to section 414.7, Code of Iowa. The board shall
consist of five (5) members, and two (2) alternates, each to be appointed by the Mayor, subject to the approval of the City Council, for a term of five (5)
years. Alternate members shall participate and vote on matters before the board only when called upon to make up a quorum or comprise a full five (5)
member panel at any meeting. In no case shall they actively participate where all five (5) regular members are present. A member whose term has expired
shall continue to serve until a successor is appointed and approved. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner for the unexpired term of the member
whose office becomes vacant. The members of the board shall serve without pay and shall be removable by the Council only for cause upon written
charges and after a public hearing. (Ord. 10-16, 7-6-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
2-3-2: ORGANIZATION:
The board shall elect a Chairman from among its own members. Such Chairman, or in his absence the Acting Chairman, may administer oaths and
compel the attendance of witnesses. There shall be a fixed place of meeting, and all meetings of the board shall be open to the public. The presence of
three (3) members shall constitute a quorum. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if
absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and it shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed
in the office of the board and shall be a public record.
Subject to the approval of the Council, the board may employ such clerical and technical assistance as may be needed to carry on its work; it shall have
the power to call upon any City official or department for assistance in the performance of its duties, and it shall be the duty of any such official or
department to render such assistance as may reasonably be expected. (Ord. 10-16, 7-6-2010)
2-3-3: DUTIES:
The Board of Adjustment shall have the powers and duties outlined in section 12-5-1 of this Code. (Ord. 10-16, 7-6-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
Chapter 4
BOARD OF HEALTH
2-4-1: DESIGNATION OF LOCAL BOARD OF HEALTH:
Pursuant to chapter 137, Code of Iowa, the Cerro Gordo County Board of Health shall be the local Board of Health for the City of Mason City. (Ord. 01-24,
11-6-2001)
2-4-2: JURISDICTION OF LOCAL BOARD OF HEALTH:
All public health matters within the City shall be under the jurisdiction of the Cerro Gordo County Board of Health, which shall have all of the powers
prescribed by sections 137.103 and 137.104 of the Iowa Code and shall also have the power to enforce appropriate ordinances of the City within its
boundaries. (Ord. 01-24, 11-6-2001; amd. 2017 Code)
2-4-3: SANITARY INSPECTOR:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 32/358
The City Administrator may from time to time appoint a Sanitary Inspector to act as the City's Health Officer.
The Sanitary Inspector shall enforce the rules and regulations of the County Health Board within the City, shall enforce the health ordinances of the City
and shall carry out such other duties as may from time to time be assigned by the City Administrator. (Ord. 01-24, 11-6-2001)
2-4-4: POLICE TO EXECUTE ORDERS:
The Chief of Police shall execute all lawful orders of the Cerro Gordo County Board of Health relating to health matters within the Municipal limits and shall
serve notices required in connection with the work of the Cerro Gordo County Board of Health in the performance of its duties and responsibilities which
require police services within the City limits. (Ord. 01-24, 11-6-2001)
2-4-5: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The Cerro Gordo County Board of Health, in addition to any rights or powers established by State law, County ordinances, or by the rules and regulations
of the local Board of Health, shall have the right to examine any cellar, room, or any other building or any place with a view to ascertain the sanitary
condition of the same, and shall have free access thereto for the purpose of examining or removing any nuisance, source of filth, or cause of sickness.
(Ord. 01-24, 11-6-2001)
2-4-6: UNSANITARY CONDITIONS:
The Cerro Gordo County Board of Health shall have full power within the Municipal limits, in addition to any and all powers provided by State law, County
ordinance or by local Board of Health rules and regulations, to require all premises within the Municipal limits which are or may hereafter become unclean
or unsanitary, or the source of nuisance, to be properly cleaned and disinfected and such nuisance removed, and to order all sources of filth, sickness,
disease or other conditions dangerous to the public or causing discomfort to the public removed, corrected, or abated at the expense of the owner of the
property. Whenever the owner of any premises disregards any such order of the Board of Health, the board may require that the order be complied with,
and the costs thereof assessed against the property in the manner provided by law. (Ord. 01-24, 11-6-2001)
2-4-7: CLOSING OF PREMISES:
Whenever the owner of any property shall fail to obey the order of the Board of Health for the removal of any unclean or unsanitary condition or any source
of filth, sickness, disease or nuisance, the board may order the occupants of said premises to move therefrom and fix some reasonable time for
compliance with such order. If the order is not complied with, the Board of Health may forcibly remove the occupants of said premises, and such premises
shall not be again occupied as a dwelling or place of business without the written permission of the local Board of Health. (1953 Code § 46-72)
2-4-8: QUARANTINE:
As set forth in chapter 139A, Code of Iowa, the local Board of Health shall see that the procedure for quarantining shall be enforced. (1985 Code; amd.
2017 Code)
2-4-9: STABLES AND MANURE:
All barns, sheds, pens or other buildings or places where animals or chickens are kept shall be kept free and clean from manure or other filth. All manure
and other filth arising from the keeping of such animals or fowls shall be kept in watertight bins or receptacles and shall be kept covered during the months
of May, June, July, August and September. All such manure and refuse shall be removed from the premises at least once each week and more often if, in
the opinion of the Health Department, such removal is necessary to preserve the health of the inhabitants of the City. (1953 Code § 46-15)
2-4-10: VIOLATIONS:
Any person who knowingly violates any provision of this chapter, or of the rules of the local board, or any lawful order, written or oral, of said board, or of its
officers or authorized agents, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1953 Code § 46-16; amd. Ord. 951, 9-24-1964)
Chapter 5
PARK AND RECREATION BOARD
2-5-1: BOARD CREATED:
A Park and Recreation Board is hereby created pursuant to section 392.1, Code of Iowa, to advise the City Council of the City of Mason City, Iowa, on the
needed facilities to provide open space such as parks, playgrounds and community facilities for other forms of recreation, pursuant to the Code of Iowa. It
shall also plan and oversee City programs and encourage other programs for the leisure time of the City's residents of all ages. (Ord. 1331, 7-21-1975;
amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
2-5-2: BOARD ORGANIZATION:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 33/358
The board shall consist of five (5) members, all citizens of the City of Mason City, Iowa, whose terms of office shall be for four (4) years. Each term of office
shall commence on January 2 following a regular Municipal election.
A. Vacancies: Any vacancy occurring on the board more than sixty (60) days prior to the next regular Municipal election shall be filled by appointment by
the Mayor, subject to the approval of the City Council. Any person so appointed shall serve until the next regular Municipal election at which a member
shall be elected to serve the remainder of the term for which the vacancy occurred.
B. Compensation: All members shall serve without compensation, but shall be entitled to the necessary expenses including travel expenses incurred in the
discharge of their duties. (Ord. 84-13, 4-2-1984; amd. 1985 Code)
2-5-3: DUTIES OF BOARD:
A. The Park and Recreation Board shall set policies, rules, regulations, and adopt procedures for the management of parks, recreation centers, recreation
programs, recreation buildings, pools, trails, golf courses, campgrounds and any other facilities dedicated to park use by the City Council.
B. The Park and Recreation Board shall make recommendations to the Council with regard to the acquisition, sale, lease or exchange of any property
dedicated or proposed to be dedicated to park and recreation use within the City.
C. The Park and Recreation Board shall develop a plan for recreation, recreation facilities, park development and maintenance. The board will update and
revise the plan as required.
D. A Park Superintendent, a Recreation Superintendent and a Golf Course Manager shall be appointed by the City Administrator subject to the approval of
the Park and Recreation Board.
E. The City Administrator shall cooperate with the Park and Recreation Board to provide for an allotment of sufficient personnel and equipment resources
to meet the park and recreation needs of the City. (Ord. 02-04, 2-5-2002)
F. The Park and Recreation Board shall annually submit a capital improvement plan to the City Administrator. (Ord. 02-04, 2-5-2002; amd. 2017 Code)
2-5-4: REPORTS:
The board shall make written reports to the Council of its activities from time to time as it deems advisable, or upon Council request. Its revenues and
expenditures shall be reported monthly by the Finance Director in the manner of other departmental expenditures, and a copy shall be provided to each
member of the board and in the Finance Director's report to the Council. (Ord. 1331, 7-21-1975)
2-5-5: RULES:
The board shall have power to make rules and regulations for the use of park or other recreational facilities, or for the conduct of recreation programs,
subject to the approval of the rules by the City Council. Such rules shall be either posted on the facility or otherwise publicized in a manner to provide
adequate notice to the using public. (Ord. 1331, 7-21-1975)
2-5-6: PENALTIES:
Violation of a board rule which has been approved by the City Council and adopted by ordinance may be cause for denial of use of a facility or
participation in a program, but such denial which extends more than one (1) day may be appealed to the board or to the City Council for a hearing. The
violation may be prosecuted as a misdemeanor if a serious offense. (Ord. 1331, 7-21-1975)
Chapter 6
ACTIVE LIVING AND TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION
2-6-1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
As the City Council has deemed it to be in the public interest of the citizens to improve livability and well being in Mason City, there is hereby created the
Active Living and Transportation Commission. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016)
2-6-2: ORGANIZATION:
A. The commission shall initially consist of five (5) members who shall be residents of the City.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 34/358
B. Members of the commission shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City Council. Members shall demonstrate a passion for
our quality of life influenced by the land use and transportation planning choices made to transform our community to a healthier, safer place to live that
provides access to economic opportunities. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016)
C. The Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, shall appoint a total of five (5) Commissioners. In addition, there shall be the following ex officio
member representatives: the Operation and Maintenance Manager, City Engineer, Director of Development Services, County Conservation Director,
County Supervisor, and North Iowa Area Council of Governments (NIACOG) Regional Planning Affiliation (RPA) Transportation Planner. Three (3)
members shall serve three (3) year terms and two (2) members shall serve two (2) year terms after initial appointments. After establishment, future
terms will be three (3) year terms. (Ord. 17-3, 1-3-2017)
D. Members may serve for more than one (1) term and each member shall serve until the appointment of a successor.
E. Vacancies occurring in the commission, other than expiration of term of office, shall be only for the unexpired portion of the term of the member
replaced.
F. Vacancies shall be filled by the City according to the original selection as aforesaid.
G. The Mayor and City Council may appoint a member of the Council as a nonvoting ex officio member to such commission.
H. The commission shall appoint a Chairperson and Vice Chair from its members.
I. Members shall serve without compensation.
J. A simple majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.
K. The City Administrator will designate a staff member to serve as the Secretary for the commission. The Secretary to the commission shall be
responsible for maintaining written records of the commission's proceedings. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016)
2-6-3: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this commission shall be to:
A. Improve livability and well being in Mason City and provide recommendations for land use, waterways, and transportation systems that best support
active living while promoting the aesthetic inspiration of our rural American culture.
B. Become the premier Midwest micropolitan community for active living transportation.
C. Develop goals and priorities to create a network of streets and public spaces to support active living and provide education and advocacy for the goals.
D. Provide recommendations for land use and transportation systems that better support the ability to move about the community.
E. Establish and promote healthy food and beverage policy at City sponsored youth sporting events.
F. Improve amenities and quality of life in the City to strengthen workforce retention and attraction of the City.
G. Educate, advocate and enforce the community on outcomes of the active living and transportation work.
H. Inform City Council of barriers to accomplishing goals, and measure and track progress.
I. Make an annual report to the City Council in December of each year. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016)
2-6-4: DEFINITIONS:
COMMISSION: The Mason City Active Living and Transportation Commission, as established by this chapter.
COMPLETE STREETS: Roads designed that are safe, comfortable and able to accommodate diverse modes, users, and activities including walking,
cycling, public transit, automobile, nearby businesses, and residents of all ages and abilities. Such street design helps create more multi-modal transport
systems and more liveable communities.
LAND USE: A. Protections that provide land use policies and zoning regulations that promote, expand and protect sites for community gardens and
farmers' markets.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 35/358
B. Establish and promote community gardens and farmers' markets and ensure protections through City Code.
LIVEABILITY: A. The quality of life a place allows and is heavily influenced by the land use and transportation planning choices made in the areas of built
environment and transportation.
B. The built environment impacts health, well being and happiness - either positively or negatively. It is a reflection of the care and thoughtfulness put
into creating the places where we live, work, and play.
C. Through our work of becoming a Blue Zones Community, we know research shows that walkable, bikeable, and livable communities are also
healthier communities, not only in terms of individual health, but also environmental and economic health.
TRANSPORTATION: Bikes, cars, public transit, all modes of transportation, and pedestrians mobility meeting ADA requirements.
WATERWAYS: Water features including rivers, canals and streams, lakes, and docks. Related features include weirs, rapids. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016; amd.
2017 Code)
2-6-5: POWERS OF COMMISSION:
A. Collect Organization Metrics: The commission will work with staff to determine appropriate metrics to support successes and develop data to determine
future goals.
B. Assess And Prioritize: The commission shall assess and prioritize short and long term vision and goals and develop and make recommendations to the
City Council for capital improvement projects during their annual report.
C. Create Partnerships: The commission will invite and seek advice from other community, county and regional organizations.
D. Grant Awards: The commission will cooperate with the Federal and State governments and any other entities in the pursuance of grants for the
purchase and improvement of properties of the commission.
E. Other Powers: In addition to those duties and powers specified above, the commission may, with City Council approval and supervision:
1. Solicit, recommend and assist in the receipt by the City of gifts and donations of real and personal property, including money for the purpose of
facilitating their goals and visions.
2. Recommend and assist in the acquisition for the City by purchase, bequest, or donation, properties for active living use.
3. Recommend and assist in the negotiation of leases, and transfer or disposition of properties in order to support active living and transportation
subject to rights of public access and other covenants and in a manner that will preserve the property.
4. Promote, educate, and provide advocacy for availability and benefits of safe and increased usage and understanding of the amenities. (Ord. 16-2, 3-
15-2016)
2-6-6: MEETINGS:
The commission shall meet at least quarterly in the months of February, April, July and November or as necessary. Time and location of the meeting shall
be determined by the commission. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016)
2-6-7: BUDGET:
The commission may apply for grants and raise funds to complete desired projects with Council approval. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016; amd. 2017 Code)
2-6-8: TERMINATION OF COMMISSION:
Such commission, known as the ALT Commission, may be discontinued by adoption of an ordinance proposing such action preceded by the publishing of
notice, as prescribed in section 362.3 of the Iowa Code, of such ordinance. (Ord. 16-2, 3-15-2016)
Chapter 7
BOARD OF LIBRARY TRUSTEES
2-7-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
As provided in section 392.5, Code of Iowa, the Board of Trustees of the Mason City Public Library, hereinafter referred to as the Board, shall consist of
seven (7) members. All Board members shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to the approval of the City Council. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975; amd. 1985
Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 36/358
2-7-2: QUALIFICATIONS OF TRUSTEES:
All of the members of the Board shall be bona fide citizens and residents of the City of Mason City, Iowa. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975)
2-7-3: ORGANIZATION OF BOARD:
A. Terms Of Office: All appointments to the Board shall be for six (6) years, except to fill vacancies. Each term shall commence on July 1. Appointments
shall be made every two (2) years of one-third (1/3) the total number as near as possible, to stagger the terms. The present incumbents are confirmed
in their appointments and terms.
B. Vacancies: The position of any Trustee shall be vacant if he moves permanently from the City, or if he is absent from six (6) consecutive regular
meetings of the Board, except in the case of sickness or temporary absence from the City. Vacancies on the Board shall be filled by appointment by the
Mayor with approval of the City Council, and the new Trustee shall fill out the unexpired term for which the appointment is made. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-
1975)
C. Compensation: Trustees shall receive no compensation for their services, but shall be reimbursed for necessary travel and other expenses incurred
while on official library business. Such reimbursement shall come from the funds appropriated to the library. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975; amd. 1985 Code)
2-7-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Board shall have and exercise the following powers and duties: (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975)
A. To meet and elect from its members a President and such other officers as it deems necessary. The City Treasurer shall serve as Board Treasurer, but
shall not be a member of the Board. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
B. To have charge, control and supervision of the public library, its appurtenances, fixtures and rooms containing the same.
C. To direct and control all the affairs of the library.
D. To employ a librarian, and authorize the librarian to employ such assistants and employees as may be necessary for the proper management of the
library, and fix their compensation; provided, however, that prior to such employment, the compensation of the librarian, assistants and employees shall
have been fixed and approved by a majority of the members of the Board voting in favor thereof. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975)
E. To remove by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Board, the librarian and provide procedures for the removal of assistants or employees for misdemeanor,
incompetency or inattention to duty, subject however to the provisions of chapter 336, Code of Iowa. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
F. To select, or authorize the librarian to select and make purchases of books, pamphlets, magazines, periodicals, papers, maps, journals or other library
materials, furniture, fixtures, stationery and supplies for the library within budgetary limits set by the Board.
G. To authorize the use of the library by nonresidents of the City of Mason City and to fix charges therefor.
H. To make and adopt, amend, modify or repeal rules and regulations not inconsistent with ordinances and the law, for the care, use, government and
management of the library and the business of the Board, fixing and enforcing penalties for violations.
I. To have exclusive control of the expenditure of all funds allocated for library purposes by the City Council, and of all monies available by gift or otherwise
for the erection of library buildings, and of all other monies belonging to the library, including fines and rentals collected under the rules of the Board.
J. To accept gifts of real property, personal property or mixed property, and devises and bequests, including trust funds; to take the title to said property in
the name of the library; to execute deeds and bills of sale for the conveyance of said property; and to expend the funds received by them from such
gifts, for the improvement of the library.
K. To keep a record of its proceedings.
L. To enforce the performance of conditions on gifts, donations, devises and bequests accepted by the City by action of the City Council.
M. To have authority to make agreements with local County historical associations, where such exist, and to set apart the necessary room and to care for
such articles as may come into the possession of the association. The Trustees are further authorized to purchase necessary receptacles and
materials for the preservation and protection of such articles as are, in their judgment, of a historical and educational nature, and pay for the same out
of funds allocated for library purposes. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975)
2-7-5: POWER TO CONTRACT WITH OTHERS FOR USE OF LIBRARY:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 37/358
A. Contracting: The Board may contract with any other Boards of Trustees of free public libraries, any other City, school corporation, private or semiprivate
organization, institution of higher learning, Township or County, or with the Trustees of any County Library District for the use of the library by their
respective residents.
B. Termination: Such a contract may be terminated at any time by mutual consent of the contracting parties. It also may be terminated by a majority vote of
the electors represented by either of the contracting parties. Such a termination proposition shall be submitted to the electors by the Governing Body of
a contracting party on a written petition of not less than five percent (5%) in number of the electors who voted for Governor in the territory of the party at
the last general election. The petition must be presented to the Governing Body not less than forty (40) days before the election. The proposition may
be submitted at any election provided by law that is held in the territory of the party who is seeking to terminate the contract. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975)
2-7-6: NONRESIDENT USE OF LIBRARY:
The Board may authorize the use of the library by nonresidents in any one (1) or more of the following ways:
A. By lending the books or other materials of the library to nonresidents on the same terms and conditions as to residents of the City, or upon payment of a
special nonresident library fee.
B. By establishing depositories of library books or other materials to be loaned to nonresidents.
C. By establishing bookmobiles or a traveling library so that books or other library materials may be loaned to nonresidents.
D. By establishing branch libraries for lending books or other library materials to nonresidents. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975)
2-7-7: LIBRARY ACCOUNT:
All monies appropriated by the City Council from the General Fund for the operation and maintenance of the library shall be set aside in an account for the
library. Expenditures shall be paid for only on orders of the Board, signed by its President. The warrant writing officer is the City Finance Director. (Ord.
1332, 7-21-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
2-7-8: ANNUAL REPORT:
The Board shall make a report to the City Council immediately after the close of the Municipal fiscal year. This report shall contain statements of the
condition of the library, the number of books added thereto, the number circulated, the amount of fines collected, and the amount of money expended in
the maintenance of the library during the year, together with such further information required by the City Council. (Ord. 1332, 7-21-1975)
Chapter 8
BOARD OF CEMETERY TRUSTEES
2-8-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is hereby created a Board of Cemetery Trustees consisting of five (5) residents of the City to be appointed by the Mayor subject to the approval of
the City Council, as provided by chapter 392, Code of Iowa. Said Trustees shall be appointed and shall serve for a period of five (5) years from April 1
following their appointment, except appointments to fill vacancies for the unexpired term of any of said Trustees. (1953 Code § 12-1; amd. 1985 Code;
2017 Code)
2-8-2: AUTHORITY:
Said Trustees shall serve without pay except they shall be paid for the actual expenses incurred by them in the performance of their duties. Said Trustees
shall select from their number a Chairman and shall have authority to employ a Superintendent, a Secretary and such other officers and employees as in
their judgment may be required for the proper management of the cemetery. (1953 Code § 12-2)
2-8-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
There is hereby conferred upon said Board of Trustees the duty of general management of said Elmwood-St. Joseph Municipal Cemetery, and it shall
have and exercise in connection therewith all of the powers and duties imposed by law in connection with the management of cemeteries, except the
power and authority to levy and impose taxes. (1953 Code § 12-3; amd. 2017 Code)
All funds shall be deposited with the City Clerk to the credit of the Cemetery Board and shall be disbursed only on order of said board by written warrants
of the City Finance Director, pursuant to mutually acceptable procedures established by the Board of Trustees and the City Council. Its revenues and
expenditures shall be reported monthly by the Finance Director, in the manner of other departmental expenditures, and a copy shall be provided to each
member of the board and in the Finance Director's report to the Council. (1953 Code § 12-3; amd. 1985 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 38/358
2-8-4: REPORTS:
The Board of Trustees shall annually, on or before December 15 of each year, file with the Finance Director a proposed estimate of expenditures for the
following fiscal year setting forth the estimated receipts, the estimated itemized disbursements and balance on hand in all funds under its management
and control, together with askings for the amount to be raised by taxation for cemetery purposes. Said Board of Trustees shall annually, on or before
August 1 of each year, file with the Finance Director a detailed report showing the amount of monies received by it during the preceding fiscal year, the
source of such receipts, and a statement of the expenditures made by it, and the purpose for which same were expended. (Ord. 1478, 1-15-1979)
ARTICLE A. CEMETERY PERPETUAL CARE FUND
2-8A-1: TRUSTEESHIP:
Pursuant to section 523I.502A, Code of Iowa, the City hereby states its willingness and intention to act as the Trustee for the perpetual maintenance of
interment spaces in Elmwood Cemetery, a cemetery located in and wholly owned by the City of Mason City, Iowa (referenced herein as "cemetery"). (2017
Code)
2-8A-2: ESTABLISHMENT OF TRUST FUND:
A perpetual trust is hereby established for said Elmwood Cemetery in accordance with Iowa Code chapter 523I, the Iowa Cemetery Act. A restricted fund
is created, to be known and designated as the "Perpetual Care Cemetery Fund", which shall be funded by the deposit of an amount equal to twenty
percent (20%) of the gross selling price, or fifty dollars ($50.00) per individual interment space included in the sale, whichever is more, for each sale of
interment space(s) within the cemetery. The fund shall be administered in accordance with the purposes and provisions of Iowa Code chapter 523I.
The Perpetual Care Cemetery Fund shall be maintained separately from all operating funds of the cemetery and the principal of the fund shall not be
reduced voluntarily except as specifically permitted by the Iowa Cemetery Act and applicable administrative regulations. (2017 Code)
2-8A-3: SALE OF INTERMENT RIGHTS:
The sale or transfer of interment rights in the cemetery shall be evidenced by a certificate of interment rights or other instrument evidencing the
conveyance of exclusive rights of interment upon payment in full of the purchase price. The agreement for interment rights shall disclose all information
required by the Iowa Cemetery Act, including the amount or percentage of money to be placed in the Perpetual Care Cemetery Fund. (2017 Code)
2-8A-4: PERPETUAL CARE REGISTRY:
The cemetery shall maintain a registry of individuals who have purchased interment rights in the cemetery subject to the care fund requirements of the
Iowa Cemetery Act, including the amounts deposited in the Perpetual Care Cemetery Fund. (2017 Code)
Chapter 9
ART MUSEUM BOARD
2-9-1: MUSEUM ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a Municipal art museum to be hereafter known as the Charles H. MacNider Art Museum. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964; amd. 1985
Code)
2-9-2: ART MUSEUM BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
As provided in chapter 392, Code of Iowa, there is hereby appointed a Board of Trustees, said Board to consist of nine (9) bona fide citizens and residents
of the City of Mason City, whose terms of office shall be for four (4) years from July 1 following their appointment to the Board, except appointments to fill
vacancies for the unexpired terms of any of said Trustees. All appointments to the Board shall be made by the Mayor subject to the approval of the City
Council. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
2-9-3: VACANCY:
Any Trustee who permanently moves outside of the City limits of Mason City, or is absent from six (6) consecutive regularly scheduled meetings of the
Board without due explanation, such as sickness or temporary absence from the area, shall render the office of said Trustee vacant. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964;
amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
2-9-4: COMPENSATION:
Members of said Board shall receive no compensation for their services, but shall be reimbursed for necessary travel and other expenses incurred while
on official museum business. Such reimbursement shall come from the funds appropriated to the art museum. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964; amd. 1985 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 39/358
2-9-5: POWERS:
Such Board of Art Museum Trustees shall have and exercise the following powers:
A. To meet and organize by the election of one (1) of their number as President of the Board, and by the election of a Secretary and such other officers
and committees as the Board may deem necessary.
B. To have charge, control and supervision of the public art museum, its works of art, appurtenances, fixtures and buildings or rooms containing the same,
directing and controlling all the affairs of such art museum. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964)
C. To employ a Director and such assistants and employees as may be necessary for the management of said art museum and to fix their compensation
in such amount as may be fixed from time to time by said Board of Trustees.
D. To remove by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of such Board the Director and to provide procedures for the removal of said assistants and employees for
misdemeanor, incompetency or inattention to the duties of such employment, subject however to the provisions of chapters 35C and 400, Code of
Iowa. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
E. To accept on behalf of the City gifts of works of art, to select and make purchases of pictures, portraits, paintings, statuary and relics and other objects
of art, in the original and in replicas or copies, books, periodicals, papers and journals on the subject of art, furniture, fixtures, stationery and supplies
for such art museum.
F. To receive, hold and dispose of all gifts, donations, devises and bequests that may be made to the City for the purpose of establishing, increasing or
improving such art museum, but when any such gift, donation, devise or bequest shall be conditioned upon any act of the City, the Council must first
determine whether such condition can or shall be complied with.
G. To make and adopt, amend, modify or repeal bylaws, rules or regulations not inconsistent with law for the care, use, government and management of
such art museum and the business of said Board, fixing and enforcing penalties for the violation thereof. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964)
H. To have exclusive control of all funds derived from taxation allocated by the City Council for its purposes, as provided by law, and of the expenditure of
all monies available by gift or otherwise for the erection of art buildings or for the promotion of such art museum and of all other money belonging to the
Art Museum Fund. All funds shall be deposited with the Finance Department to the credit of the Art Museum Board and shall be disbursed only on
orders of said Board by written warrants of the City Finance Director, pursuant to mutually acceptable procedures established by the Board of Trustees
and City Council. Its revenues and expenditures shall be reported monthly by the Finance Director, in the manner of other departmental expenditures,
and a copy shall be provided to each member of the Board and in the Finance Director's report to the City Council. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964; amd. 1985
Code; 2017 Code)
2-9-6: RECORDS:
Said Board shall keep a record of all of its proceedings. Immediately after the close of each Municipal fiscal year, said Board shall file with the Council a
written report which shall cover the last preceding fiscal year and contain a statement of the condition of the art museum, the number of pictures, portraits,
paintings, statuary or relics contained in the gallery, and all additions thereto, the amounts of fines collected, the amount of donations, devises and
bequests received during the year and the amount of money expended in the maintenance of such art museum, together with such further information as
may be required by the City Council. (Ord. 950, 9-21-1964)
Chapter 10
HUMAN RIGHTS AND HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
2-10-1: PURPOSE:
The purposes of the City of Mason City, Iowa, in enacting this chapter are:
A. To exercise the police power of the City for the protection of public health, safety and general welfare, and for the maintenance of peace and good
government, and to ensure equal opportunity for all persons in their pursuit of employment, housing, public accommodations or services and credit
transactions.
B. To prohibit discriminatory practices, whether direct or indirect, which inexcusably and/or unjustifiably deny any person rights and/or opportunities
because of a prohibited basis, and to provide for the execution of the policies embodied in the Federal Civil Rights Act (titles VI, VII and VIII), the Equal
Credit Opportunity Act, the Iowa Civil Rights Act of 1965 (as subsequently amended), the Vocational Act of 1973, the Americans with Disabilities Act
and to promote cooperation between the City and State and Federal agencies enforcing those Acts; and to establish a Commission on Human Rights
for the accomplishment of such purposes; and to these ends, the provisions of this chapter shall be liberally construed. (Ord. 14-15, 12-16-2014)
2-10-2: CODE ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted as the complete "Mason City Human Rights Code", the most current edition, of chapter 216, Code of Iowa, prepared and edited
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 40/358
by the Legislative Service Bureau. Said Civil Rights Code of the State of Iowa is, by this reference, duly adopted as fully and completely as if set out in
detail herein except as provided in this chapter. A copy of said Code is now on file in the Office of the City Clerk and at the Mason City Public Library for
public inspection. (Ord. 14-15, 12-16-2014)
2-10-3: DEFINITIONS:
In addition to, or in place of the definitions included in chapter 216, Code of Iowa, and for the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases
shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this chapter:
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION: A plan whereby a set of specific, result oriented procedures are established and to which a "person" is required to apply every
good faith effort to achieve. The objectives of those procedures are equal opportunity in public and private employment, housing, public accommodation,
credit transactions and City contracts.
AGENT OR COMMITTEE'S AGENT: A Commissioner designated by the commission.
AWARDING AUTHORITY: Any City department, agency, commission, authority, board or person, or any authorized employee, officer or Director of any of
the foregoing, including any purchasing agent of the City of Mason City who makes or enters into any contract agreement for the provision of any goods or
services of any kind or nature whatsoever for and on behalf of the City of Mason City.
COMMISSION: The Mason City Human Rights Commission created by this chapter.
COMPLAINANT: Any person filing a complaint with the commission.
CONTRACT: Any agreement which is awarded, let, procured or entered into with, or on behalf of, the City of Mason City or any awarding authority thereof.
CONTRACTOR: Any contractor, supplier, vendor, redeveloper or other person who, through a contract or other arrangement, has received, is to receive,
or is receiving funds, or in-kind contributions from the City of Mason City or any awarding authority thereof, and shall also include any subcontractor who
performs services for the City under a City contract.
PROHIBITED BASIS: Discrimination based upon race, color, familial status, religion, nationality, sex, marital status, age, sexual orientation, gender
identity, disability or ancestry, but also refers to the characteristics of individuals with whom the person or class of persons or individual deals or
associates. (Ord. 14-15, 12-16-2014)
2-10-4: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
A. In all instances, the Mason City Human Rights Code, or commission shall be substituted in place of all mention of the Iowa State Civil Rights Code,
and/or commission with the exception of section 216.19.
B. In all instances, the Mayor and City Council of the City of Mason City shall be substituted in place of all mention to the Governor and General Assembly
or Senate of the State of Iowa.
C. In all instances, the City of Mason City shall be substituted in place of all mention to the State of Iowa.
D. Section 216.3 Commission Appointed and section 216.4 Compensation and Expenses, shall be and the same are hereby repealed in their entirety and
the following is adopted in lieu thereof as provisions of the Mason City Human Rights Code: (Ord. 14-15, 2-16-2014)
Human Rights Commission: There is hereby established, under section 216.19, in the City of Mason City, Iowa, a commission to be known as the
Human Rights Commission, which shall consist of three (3) members from various racial, religious, cultural and economic groups in the City.
Members of said commission shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the consent of the commission, subject to the approval of the City Council for a
term of two (2) years, with the term of office expiring on January 1. Vacancies resulting in an unexpired term on the commission shall be filled by
appointment by the Mayor, subject to the approval of the City Council, for the unexpired term. Any Commissioner may be removed from office by the
Mayor for cause.
The commission will elect a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its membership. A quorum shall consist of two (2) Commissioners. The
commission shall adopt, amend or rescind rules as necessary for the conduct of its meetings and proceedings.
E. Section 216.6.6.a Unfair Employment Practices should be and the same is hereby amended as to read:
