Chapter 5
JUNK DEALERS AND JUNKYARDS
3-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
JUNK: Any secondhand or used parts of any automobiles, trucks, tractors or any other motor vehicles, machinery or any other equipment; and any used or
obsolete automobiles or trucks not currently licensed, except that this shall not preclude the legal storage of such unlicensed vehicle within a proper
enclosure or building by virtue of the surrender of the license plates to the County Treasurer; and scrap iron or other metals, bottles, glass, rags, rubber,
paper and all other articles usually or customarily bought or sold by junk dealers.
JUNK BUSINESS: The operating of the business of a junk dealer.
JUNK DEALER: Any person who conducts or operates a business of buying or selling any secondhand parts of automobiles, trucks, tractors or any other
motor vehicles, machinery or equipment of any kind or nature whatsoever, or the wrecking and dismantling of any used, unlicensed automobiles or trucks,
or the wrecking and dismantling of any used tractors, machinery or mechanical equipment of any kind, and/or the purchase and sale or storage of any
scrap iron, metals, bottles, rags, rubber, paper, glass or any other materials or things usually or customarily bought or sold by persons engaged in the junk
business.
JUNKYARD: A place where junk, waste, discarded, or salvaged materials are bought, sold, exchanged, stored, baled, cleaned, packed, disassembled, or
handled, including, but not limited to, auto and motor vehicle wrecking yards, house wrecking yards, used lumber yards, and yards for use of salvaged
house wrecking, structural steel materials, and equipment. (Ord. 1052, 5-6-1968; amd. 2017 Code)
3-5-2: NEW JUNK BUSINESSES:
It shall be illegal to establish a junk business or junkyard in any part of the City after July 1, 2010. Those junk businesses or junkyards legally established
prior to July 1, 2010, that have been in continuous operation up to the present may continue operation, subject to the requirements of this chapter,
including licensing, and the requirements of the zoning ordinance, title 12, chapter 6 of this Code related to nonconforming uses. (2017 Code)
3-5-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a junk business or junkyard meeting the requirements of this chapter without first procuring from the City a
license therefor and paying a license fee as hereinafter provided. Said license shall be issued upon written application of such person desiring to conduct
such business. (1953 Code § 73-2; amd. 2017 Code)
3-5-4: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee to be paid by the junk dealer shall be an annual fee in an amount established by resolution of the City Council, payable on or before March
31 of each year, application therefor to be filed with the City Clerk; and such license fee must be paid in full, prior to the issuance of any license to such
junk dealer. (1953 Code § 73-3; amd. 2017 Code)
3-5-5: FENCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to operate or conduct his business upon any premises or in any building unless said premises are completely
enclosed with a fence at least eight feet (8') in height, constructed of such material that will completely obscure said premises from the view of the public,
which conforms to the requirements of section 12-16-4 of this Code, to be approved by the building official, and to be maintained and painted in good
condition so as to avoid an unsightly appearance. (Ord. 1125, 9-8-1970; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
3-5-6: OPERATION OF BUSINESS RESTRICTED:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 56/358
A. Junk To Be Kept Within Fence: It shall be unlawful for any person to display, advertise, buy or sell any junk except within the enclosure of the lot, yard,
building or other premises used for said junk business. (1953 Code § 73-5)
B. Use Of Street And Private Property: It shall be unlawful for any secondhand or used parts of automobiles, trucks, tractors or any other motor vehicles,
machinery or equipment, obsolete, unlicensed automobiles or trucks, scrap iron or other metals, bottles, glass, rags, rubber, paper and any other junk
to remain for a period longer than one (1) hour upon any part of the public street in front of or adjacent to the place of business of any junk dealer, or
upon any private property not enclosed with a fence as defined in section 3-5-5 of this chapter, except that any such use of a public street or private
property shall not be prohibited for a currently licensed automobile, truck or other motor vehicle. For the purposes of this chapter, the word "street" shall
include the driveway, parking and sidewalk of any street, and shall include the entire width of the street from property line to property line, and shall
include avenues, alleys and all public thoroughfares and grounds. (Ord. 1125, 9-8-1970)
3-5-7: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
In case any police or other officer of the City shall find any junk dealer violating the provisions of this chapter, he shall give such junk dealer a written notice
to appear before the City Council at one (1) of its regular meetings to show cause why the Council shall not revoke the license of such junk dealer. (1953
Code § 73-7)
Chapter 6
AUCTIONEERS AND AUCTION SALES
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms as used in this chapter shall be defined and construed to mean:
AUCTION HOUSE: Any place of business where merchandise, except new merchandise unless it is new merchandise which has been assessed Personal
Property Tax or is replacement stock of merchandise inventory which was assessed a Personal Property Tax in Cerro Gordo County, is regularly and
periodically sold at auction as a permanent and principal business to be conducted at such establishment.
AUCTION SALE: The offering for sale or the selling of personal property to the highest bidder or the offering for sale or selling of personal property at a
high price and then offering the same property at successively lower prices until a buyer is secured, and conducted in the manner set forth in section
554.2328, Code of Iowa.
AUCTIONEER: Any person offering for sale or selling merchandise at an auction sale.
NEW MERCHANDISE: All merchandise or personal property not previously sold at retail. (Ord. 756, 12-17-1956; amd. 1985 Code)
3-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or cause or permit to be sold at any auction sale any merchandise unless such sale is conducted by an individual
who has applied for and obtained an auctioneer's license from the City or unless such sale is made at a regularly licensed auction house. (Ord. 756, 12-
17-1956; amd. 1985 Code)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The City Clerk is hereby authorized to grant or renew an auctioneer's license for a period not exceeding one (1) year and expiring March 31 of the
following year, to any individual applying therefor. The application for such license shall be filed with the City Clerk. The application shall contain the
following information: (Ord. 756, 12-17-1957; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
A. Proper legal name of applicant, date of birth, and phone number(s).
B. Permanent residence and business address of applicant.
C. A clear photocopy of a government issued photo identification card.
D. A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any Municipal ordinance and, if
so, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor.
E. Experience in the field of auctioneering and/or special training in the auctioneering field.
Upon such application being filed with the Clerk, the Clerk shall immediately refer the same to the Chief of Police who shall cause to be made such
investigation of the applicant's moral character and business responsibility as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. (Ord. 756, 12-17-
1957; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
3-6-4: LICENSE FEES:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 57/358
After such application for an auctioneer's license shall have been received, and before any such license shall be issued, the applicant shall pay to the City
a license fee in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00) and said license shall expire on March 31 following the issuance thereof. (Ord. 1100, 2-2-1970;
amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
3-6-5: PROHIBITED ACTS:
The following acts, omissions and practices in connection with auction sales are hereby prohibited:
A. The use of deceit, fraud and misrepresentation in the sale or offering for sale of any property.
B. The substitution of another article for that bid upon by the prospective purchaser. (Ord. 756, 12-17-1957)
C. The use of false bidders to increase bidding prices without the bidder actually intending to purchase the item. (Ord. 756, 12-17-1957; amd. 2017 Code)
D. The use of any variety of mechanical or excessive vocal sound to attract attention in violation of title 8, chapter 6 of this Code.
E. The use of any false or misleading advertising matter.
F. A sale by a person other than a licensed auctioneer named in the application.
G. Failure to exhibit an auctioneer's license to a police officer on demand at the place where the auction is being conducted.
H. Offering property for sale which has once been struck off to the highest bidder.
I. No auction shall be conducted in a manner which will cause streets or sidewalks to be blocked. (Ord. 756, 12-17-1957; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
3-6-6: AUCTION HOUSE; LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct an auction house without having first obtained a license therefor. The application for an auction
house license shall give the name or names and addresses of the owners of the business and the names and addresses of persons who are to conduct
such auctions, the place of business where the business is to be located, and such other information as the City Clerk may require. A license fee of twenty
five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid for an auction house license, and all such licenses shall expire on March 31 following the date of issuance. A person
holding an auction house license shall not be subject to the provisions of section 3-6-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 756, 12-17-1957)
3-6-7: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not extend to the sale at public auction of livestock, farm machinery or farm produce or other items commonly sold at
farm sales or to sales conducted by charitable or nonprofit organizations which have met the criteria of chapter 504A of the Code of Iowa and Federal
Internal Revenue Service requirements, or to the sales of property made by sheriffs, constables, coroners, marshals, executors, guardians or assignees of
involved debtors or bankrupts or by any other person required by law to sell personal property. This chapter shall not apply to any auction sale held and
conducted in connection with a recognized auctioneer's school, conducted in Mason City, for the training of auctioneers or prospective auctioneers,
provided no more than four (4) such school sales shall be permitted during any calendar year. (Ord. 756, 12-17-1957; amd. 2017 Code)
Chapter 7
CLOSE OUT AND GOING OUT OF BUSINESS SALES
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms as used in this chapter shall be defined and construed to mean:
ADVERTISE: Any and all methods chosen to convey notice directly or indirectly to the public that any of the sales mentioned herein are being offered, or
are intended to be offered. It includes, but is not limited to, the following methods of advertising: oral, written, printed documents or publications, live or
recorded, electronic, and over the internet.
CLOSE OUT OR GOING OUT OF BUSINESS SALE: Any sale in which the public is led to believe that the sale will include goods damaged by fire,
smoke, water, or other means regardless of whether the business intends to cease operation; that goods offered are offered to dispose of such inventory
prior to the close or cessation of business; or any of the following types of sales: adjuster, adjustment, assignee, bankrupt, benefit of creditors, benefit of
trustee, loss of lease, forced out of business, quitting business, or liquidation. It shall also include sales by a person or business which is closing one (1) of
multiple sales locations within the City.
GOODS: Any goods, wares, securities, services or merchandise, both tangibles and intangibles, or other property capable of being the object of a sale
regulated hereunder.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 58/358
LICENSE: A formal written permission issued by the City Clerk pursuant to this chapter to any person to carry on any sale as defined herein. (Ord. 1329,
8-14-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
3-7-2: APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
Each written application for a license to advertise and conduct a sale pursuant to this chapter, made to the City Clerk, shall contain the following
information: (Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975)
A. The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale.
B. The location and address of the place where such sale is to be held.
C. The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease, and the effective date of termination of such occupancy.
D. The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted. (Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
3-7-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall hold a close out or going out of business sale without first obtaining a license. (Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
3-7-4: LICENSE APPLICATION PROCEDURES:
All license applications under this chapter shall be made in writing to the City Clerk on a form obtained from said Clerk. Upon receipt of an application for a
license, and payment of the prescribed fee, the City Clerk may issue a license. (Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
3-7-5: LICENSE FEES:
At the time of filing said application, the applicant shall pay to the City a license fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for inventory in excess of fifteen
thousand dollars ($15,000.00); and a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for inventory in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) but less than fifteen
thousand dollars ($15,000.00). If the merchant holding the sale is not a resident merchant, the fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and fifty dollars
($50.00), respectively. (Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975; amd. 1985 Code)
3-7-6: PERIOD OF LICENSE:
A license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. (Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975)
3-7-7: EXTENSION OF LICENSE PERIOD:
Within the last ten (10) days of the period of any previous license, an application for extension of said license may be made to the City Clerk upon payment
of a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each day the license period is extended over the original thirty (30) days; provided, that no such single period of
extension shall exceed the period of the original license. In no event shall the license period plus the maximum extension period exceed sixty (60) days.
(Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
3-7-8: DUTIES OF LICENSEE:
A licensee hereunder shall:
A. Comply with all applicable local, State, and Federal laws.
B. Not use deceit, fraud, or misrepresentation in either such sale or advertising for such sale.
C. Have a valid City close out or going out of business license available for inspection on scene.
D. Clearly separate all goods listed as objects of the sale from any other goods present and available for sale not so listed, by properly identifying goods
for sale, by tags attached thereto or some other appropriate means reasonably calculated to apprise the public of the status of all goods. (Ord. 1329, 8-
14-1975; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
3-7-9: EXCEPTIONS:
Such sales as described in this chapter shall not be deemed to include sales by the Sheriff, by an executor or guardian, or by any party pursuant to a court
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 59/358
order.
The North Iowa Events Center property, with prior approval by the North Iowa Events Center management, or the North Iowa Fair Association doing
business as the North Iowa Events Center, are exempted from City close out or going out of business licensing requirements so long as they have prior
authorization from the proper regulating body that oversees the property and respective event(s). This does not waive civil liability responsibility from the
respective event organizer or the property owner. (Ord. 1329, 8-14-1975; amd. 2017 Code)
Chapter 8
PAWNBROKERS
3-8-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for administration of licenses and permits and for local regulation and procedures for the conduct of a
pawnbroker's business for the protection of the safety, morals and general welfare of this community. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
PAWNBROKER: Any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property or other thing of value, or who deals in the purchasing of
personal property or other things of value, on condition of selling the same back at a stipulated price, or who receives actual possession of personal
property as security for loans with or without a bill of sale is hereby defined as and declared to be a pawnbroker.
PERSON OF GOOD MORAL CHARACTER: Any person who meets all of the following requirements:
A. He has financial standing and good reputation as will satisfy the City Council that he will comply with all Iowa laws and ordinances of this City
applicable to his operation.
B. He does not possess a Federal gambling stamp.
C. He has not had a pawnbroker's license under this chapter revoked within the last two (2) years.
D. He is a citizen of the United States and a resident of Iowa, or licensed to do business in Iowa, in the case of a corporation.
E. He has not been convicted of a felony. However, if his conviction of a felony occurred more than five (5) years before the application for a license or
permit, and if his rights of citizenship have been restored by the Governor, the Council may determine that he is a person of good moral character
notwithstanding such conviction.
F. If a person is a corporation or partnership, the requirement of this subsection shall apply to each of the officers, directors or partners and to any
person who directly or indirectly owns or controls ten percent (10%) or more of any class of stock of such corporation or has an interest of ten
percent (10%) or more in the ownership or profit of such business.
G. For purposes of this provision, an individual and his spouse shall be regarded as one (1) person. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-3: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
Before engaging in business, a pawnbroker shall apply for and obtain a license from the City and shall pay therefor a yearly license fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00), said license shall expire on March 31 following the date of its issuance; provided, that if said license be issued after October 1 of any
year, the said license fee shall be the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the remainder of the year. No refund shall be allowed for any premature surrender or
revocation of any such license. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-4: ELIGIBILITY FOR PAWNBROKER'S LICENSE:
Upon meeting any requirements imposed by State law and the ordinances of this City, a person who is of good moral character, as defined by State law
and this chapter, may apply for a pawnbroker's license. In the case of a corporation or partnership, the officers of the corporation or the partners of a
partnership shall be persons of good moral character as defined by State law and this chapter. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-5: CONDITIONS FOR APPROVAL OF LICENSE; PREMISES:
An applicant for a pawnbroker's license, as a further condition for approval, must give consent in writing on the application that members of the Fire, Police
and Health Departments and the building official may enter upon the premises without warrant to inspect for violations of the provisions of State law or the
ordinances of this City.
A. No pawnbroker's license shall be approved for any premises which do not conform to all applicable laws, ordinances, resolutions and health and fire
regulations.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 60/358
B. The premises for which a pawnbroker's license is sought must be located within the district now or hereafter zoned for business purposes and conform
to the zoning requirements of the City.
C. No pawnbroker's shop shall be located within one thousand two hundred feet (1,200') of an active or operating public or private educational institution.
D. All licenses provided for in this chapter shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises of the holder of the permit and shall at all times be
subject to inspection.
E. No pawnbroker's shop shall be operated in conjunction with or share a common exterior access with any arcade, coin-operated amusement center or
other establishment housing or using coin-operated amusement devices open or available to minors.
F. No coin-operated video or amusement games of any type shall be operated on the premises of a licensed pawnshop. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
G. No alcoholic liquor, alcoholic beverage or intoxicating liquor, as defined in Iowa Code, shall be sold, consumed or kept on the premises of the holder of
a pawnbroker's license and no pawnshop shall be established or maintained upon or within any premises or building in which it shares a common
access or entrance with any establishment selling or serving alcoholic beverages or holding a liquor control license or beer permit. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-
1983; amd. 2017 Code)
3-8-6: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The application for a pawnbroker's license shall be in writing on a form provided by the City Clerk and subscribed and sworn to by one (1) of the owners,
setting forth the name of each person who is an owner of said business or, if a corporation, the names of the officers and directors of the corporation, and
the principal place of business thereof, stating the name and address of the manager, the address of the business location, and such other information as
may be required in order to investigate the good character of the applicant. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-7: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
Upon receipt of an original application for a pawnbroker's license by the City Clerk, it shall be forwarded to the Chief of Police who shall conduct an
investigation and shall submit a written report on the application and a recommendation to the Mayor as to the approval of the license. It shall be the duty
of the health inspector, the building official and the Fire Chief/Inspector to inspect the premises to determine if they conform to the requirements of the City,
and no license shall be approved until or unless an approving report has been filed with the Mayor by such officers. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-8: SIMPLIFIED APPLICATION FOR RENEWAL:
Upon receipt of an application for the renewal of a pawnbroker's license, it shall be forwarded to the Chief of Police only, who shall conduct an
investigation and shall submit a written report on the application as to the truth of the facts answered in the application and a recommendation to the
Mayor as to approval of the license or permit. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-9: BOND:
No pawnbroker's license shall be issued until a bond, for the period said license is in effect, shall first be filed, which said bond shall be in the penal sum of
two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), conditioned that said business will be conducted in accordance with the provisions of this Code and the laws of the State
of Iowa, and that such pawnbroker will account for and deliver to any person legally entitled thereto any goods, wares or merchandise or other things of
value which may have come into his hands in such business as pawnbroker, or in lieu thereof, he will pay money to the person entitled thereto for the
reasonable value thereof. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-10: NATURE OF LICENSE OR PERMIT:
A pawnbroker's license shall be a purely personal privilege and shall be revocable for cause. It shall not constitute property nor be subject to attachment
and execution nor be alienable or assignable, and in any case, it shall cease upon the death of the licensee. However, the Mayor, in his discretion, may
allow the executor or administrator of a licensee to operate the business of the decedent for a reasonable time not to exceed the expiration date of the
license. Every license shall be issued in the name of the applicant setting forth the location on which the business is located and no person holding a
license shall allow any other person to use the same or operate the business on any other location. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-11: SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION:
A pawnbroker's license may be suspended for a period up to one (1) year, or revoked by the Mayor, without refund, following notice to the licensee and
hearing by the City Council, for good cause, upon finding of any of the following causes:
A. Misrepresentation of any material fact in the application for such license.
B. Any change in the ownership or interest in the business operated under a pawnbroker's license, which change was not previously reported to and
approved by the Mayor.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 61/358
C. Any event which would have resulted in disqualification from receiving such license or permit when originally issued.
D. The failure or refusal on the part of the licensee to render any report or permit any inspection required by this chapter.
E. A finding by the City Council, after hearing, that such business is being managed, conducted or maintained in a manner that is detrimental to the public
health, morals or welfare. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-12: RECORDS KEPT:
Every pawnbroker shall keep a book in which shall be plainly written, at the time of each loan or purchase, an accurate account or description in the
English language of the goods, articles or things pawned, pledged or purchased; the amount of money loaned or paid therefor; the date received; the
name, residence and a brief description of the person pawning, pledging or selling the same; which book, plus the pawned or purchased articles, shall at
all reasonable times be open to the inspection of any law enforcement officer. Every pawnbroker purchasing or receiving on deposit for loan any article or
personal property or other thing of value shall give to the person selling or depositing the same a plainly written or printed ticket or receipt therefor,
showing the terms of said sale or loan, and a copy of the entrance in the book required herein to be kept. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-13: REPORT TO POLICE:
It shall be the duty of each pawnbroker to make out and deliver to the Chief of Police each day before the hour of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon a legible and
correct copy of each transaction transacted during the preceding day, as in the pawnbroker's book required herein to be kept. Provided, however, that no
pawnbroker shall be required to furnish such information with reference to property purchased from merchants, manufacturers or bona fide wholesale
dealers having an established place of business when such property or goods are accompanied by a bill of sale or invoice, which must be shown to any
law enforcement officer upon demand. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-14: PROHIBITED TRANSACTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to purchase or receive any property, goods or other thing of value from any minor without the written consent of the
parents or the guardian of said minor, or from any person who, at the time of making the transaction, is under the influence of intoxicating drugs or liquors,
or from any feeble minded person or person of unsound mind. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-15: TIME TO REDEEM:
No pawnbroker shall sell or dispose of any pawned or pledged article until the same shall remain in his possession for thirty (30) days after the pledge or
deposit thereof, and the same may be redeemed by the depositor or pledgor at any time within said thirty (30) days. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-16: PROPERTY TO BE HELD; REPORT TO CHIEF OF POLICE:
No personal property or other thing of value received on deposit or pledged by any pawnbroker shall be permitted to be redeemed for the period of forty
eight (48) hours after the delivery to the Chief of Police of the statement of transactions herein referred to. Whenever the Chief of Police or any member of
the Police Department shall notify any such pawnbroker not to sell any item of property so received, nor to permit the same to be redeemed, such property
shall not be sold or redeemed and must be retained in the possession of the pawnbroker for at least thirty (30) days after the receipt of such notice or until
such article has been released in writing by the police officer giving the notice. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-17: UNLAWFUL TO OPERATE WITHOUT LICENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a pawnbroker or to maintain any sign usually known as a pawnbroker's sign, such as three
(3) balls, or in any manner to advertise to loan money on pledge or deposit of personal property or other thing of value without first having applied for and
obtained a pawnbroker's license and without having complied with the regulations regarding signs contained in title 10, chapter 2, article G and title 12,
chapter 20 of this Code. (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
3-8-18: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to imprisonment in the
County Jail for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days or a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 1672, 3-7-1983)
Chapter 9
PEDDLERS, VENDORS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, SOLICITORS
3-9-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any peddler/vendor, transient merchant or solicitor to engage in business, sell or take orders for sale of merchandise, without first
securing a proper license to so engage as herein required.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 62/358
Exemption: Established merchants, organizations, businesses, vendors or peddlers participating in organized celebrations, promotions, sales or other
events approved by the City Council; authorized representatives of charitable or nonprofit organizations which have a place of business in Cerro Gordo
County, Iowa, operating under the provisions of chapter 504A of the Code of Iowa or authorized and organized under statutes or regulations of the United
States government, or approved by the Internal Revenue Service; route delivery persons who only incidentally solicit additional business or make special
sales (i.e., Schwan's, Avon); and nonprofit clubs and lodges when not ordinarily conducted as a business that do not meet the requirements of chapter
504A of the Iowa Code and are located in Cerro Gordo County, Iowa. Iowa Code section 9C.4 has additional exemptions for transient merchants only (not
vendors or solicitors). (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 19-14 - MOBILE VENDORS . Go to new ordinance.
3-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
MOBILE VENDOR: Operator of a nonmotorized vending pushcart.
PEDDLER/VENDOR: Any person carrying goods or merchandise who sells or offers for sale for immediate delivery such goods or merchandise from
house to house or upon the public street.
SOLICITOR: Any person who solicits or attempts to solicit from house to house or upon the public street any contribution or donation or any order for
goods, services, subscriptions or merchandise to be delivered at a future date.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Iowa Code section 9C.1 and any revisions thereto defines the term transient merchant and lists State requirements for
applicants. This section of the Iowa Code also lists specific exemptions that do not require a transient merchant license. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
3-9-3: LICENSE APPLICATION:
Except as provided in this chapter, before any transient merchant permit under this chapter shall be issued, each applicant for a transient merchant license
shall file with the City Clerk proof of a valid State issued transient vendor permit, and an acknowledgment from the Iowa Secretary of State that the bond
required1 of all transient merchants operating anywhere within the State of Iowa has been filed and will remain valid through the time the merchant is
operating within the City.
Applicants for a peddler/vendor, transient merchant or solicitor's license shall file with the City Clerk an application in writing, signed by the applicant, upon
a form furnished by the City Clerk. Said application shall state their legal name, date of birth, permanent and local place of residence, phone number(s), a
brief physical description of the applicant, a picture or drawing of the vehicle or cart to be used, if any, and the license plate number, the place from which
the business will be conducted, if any, the nature of the business, and a brief description of the commodities or articles proposed to be sold, or the services
to be rendered. Said application shall also contain a brief statement as to the method by which the applicant will conduct his business and a place for the
applicant to indicate whether or not the applicant has an Iowa retailer's sales tax permit and, if so, the applicant's sales tax permit number. Said application
shall also state the period of time for which a license is desired, not to exceed one (1) year for a peddler/vendor's or solicitor's license and not to exceed
sixty (60) days for a transient merchant's license. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 19-14 - MOBILE VENDORS . Go to new ordinance.
3-9-4: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
A. Licensee shall maintain a distance of seventy five feet (75') from the entrance of any business which is selling the same type of product as the
peddler/vendor. Mobile vendors may be prohibited in areas where sidewalks are not wide enough to accommodate both pedestrians and the vendor.
B. There shall be maintained a distance of not less than twenty feet (20') between vendors.
C. The vendor's operation shall not impede the free flow of pedestrian traffic along sidewalks or plaza right-of-way, nor shall they interfere with pedestrian
movement into or out of retail establishments. (1985 Code)
D. No pushcart shall have dimensions exceeding four feet (4') in width, eight feet (8') in length, and eight feet (8') in height. All pushcarts must be
aesthetically pleasing in appearance, and shall be maintained in a neat and orderly fashion. Each pushcart shall be capable of being moved and kept
under control by one (1) person traveling on foot. The City Administrator may grant a special license to a handicapped person to operate a pushcart
propelled by an electric motor; provided, that the applicant meets all other conditions for a license. During transit of the pushcart (whether it be towed
by vehicle, carried by trailer, or pushed by hand) the pushcart operator shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a motor vehicle as
provided by law except as to the provisions which by their very nature can have no application.
E. The applicant shall have obtained all necessary permits required by the State of Iowa Department of Health or other applicable regulatory agency.
Before a license under this chapter is issued to a peddler who is engaged in selling food items as a mobile food unit, an applicant shall provide to the
City Clerk evidence that the applicant possesses a State of Iowa mobile food license as required by section 137F.4 of the Code of Iowa. Each pushcart
operator and vendor shall meet USDA-FDA Food Service Sanitation Ordinance standards and Iowa Department of Agriculture Food Service Sanitation
Code for food storage, preparation and dispensing.
F. The construction of an addition to an existing store front for permanent, temporary or seasonal use of abutting public right-of-way shall require an
encroachment permit as specified in title 5, chapter 1, article C of this Code.
G. All peddlers and solicitors are only permitted to go door-to-door between sunrise and sunset.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 63/358
H. No person, firm, corporation or other organization shall sell, display, or otherwise offer for sale any merchandise or other materials on any sidewalk,
street, public right-of-way, or other public property without first obtaining approval by the City Council or by a duly authorized representative. Application
for such license shall be made in writing to the City Clerk. The Clerk shall refer such application to the appropriate City departments for review and
report. Said application along with the appropriate department reports shall then be forwarded to the City Council or to a duly authorized representative
for action to approve or disapprove. Persons, firms, corporations or other organizations having valid contracts with the City authorizing activities
hereinbefore described are excepted from the terms of this subsection for the activities specifically authorized in the contract.
The City Council reserves the right to require the relocation of any licensed pushcart or transient merchant to a new location in the event public safety
or congestion so requires, based on the discretion of the Council. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
3-9-5: INVESTIGATION AND ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The applicant shall complete the application form as required and shall submit two (2) copies to the Chief of the Police Department who shall cause such
investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good and in connection
therewith may, in his discretion, require the photographing and fingerprinting of any such applicant.
A. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the Chief of Police shall endorse on
such application his disapproval and his reasons therefor and return the said application to the City Clerk who shall notify the applicant that his
application is disapproved and that no license will be issued.
B. If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the Chief of Police shall
endorse on such application his approval and return the same to the City Clerk who shall thereafter issue the license subject to the terms and
conditions of this chapter. Such license shall contain the signature and seal of the City and show the name and address of the licensee, the class of
license issued, the kind of goods or services to be sold thereunder, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as
the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle used under such license. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
3-9-6: IDENTIFICATION CARD:
The City Clerk, at the time of issuing the license, shall issue to each licensee an identification card which shall identify the type of license issued, the
period for which the license is issued and the number of the license; in addition, the name and address of the licensee and the name of the business firm
the licensee represents. Such identification card shall, during all times the licensee is engaged in the activity for which the license is issued, be carried by
the licensee and displayed to any person requesting identification. (1985 Code)
3-9-7: LICENSE FEES:
The following license fees shall be paid by the applicant at the time the City Clerk issues the license:
Peddler/vendor $15.00 per year
Solicitor $15.00 per year
Transient merchant $25.00 for the first day, $5.00 per day for each additional day up to 60 days only
(1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
3-9-8: NUISANCE:
The practice of peddlers/vendors, solicitors, or transient merchants, whether licensed or not as required by this chapter, of going in and upon private
residences and property without having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants of said private residences and
property, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and/or disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same is
hereby declared to be a nuisance and is punishable as such nuisance as a simple misdemeanor.
No vendor vending from a motor vehicle shall conduct his/her business in such a way as would restrict or interfere with the ingress or egress of the
abutting property owner or tenant, or create or become a public nuisance, increase traffic congestion or delay, or constitute a hazard to traffic, life, or
property, or an obstruction to adequate access to fire, police, sanitation, or emergency vehicles. Furthermore, no vehicle shall remain in any one (1) place
for a period longer than necessary to make a sale after having been approached or stopped for that purpose. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
3-9-9: LICENSE NOT TRANSFERABLE:
Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter are not transferable in any situation and are to be applicable only to the person filing the application.
(2017 Code)
3-9-10: TIME RESTRICTION:
All licenses shall provide that said licenses are in force and effect only between the following hours: Monday through Saturday, nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to
seven o'clock (7:00) P.M., and Sunday, one o'clock (1:00) P.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. (2017 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 64/358
3-9-11: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
A. Reasons: The Clerk may revoke a license issued under this chapter for the following reasons:
1. Fraudulent Statements: The licensee has made fraudulent statements in the application for the license or in the conduct of the business.
2. Violation Of Law: The licensee has violated this chapter or has otherwise conducted the business in an unlawful manner.
3. Endangered Public Welfare, Health Or Safety: The licensee has conducted the business in such manner as to endanger the public welfare, safety,
order or morals.
B. Notice Of Revocation; Right To Appeal: The Clerk shall cause notice of the license revocation to be served in person by the Police Department or by
mail to the licensee's local address, which notice shall specify the reason(s) for such action. The licensee may appeal the revocation of the license to
the City Council at its next regularly scheduled meeting by filing with the Clerk a written request for an appeal to the City Council. The City Council may
affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the Clerk to revoke such license. If a license is revoked, no refund of any license fee paid shall be made. Upon
the revocation of a license, the licensee is not eligible for the issuance of a new license under this chapter for a period of one (1) year from the date the
license revocation is served in person or deposited in the U.S. mail. (2017 Code)
3-9-12: LICENSE EXEMPTIONS:
The following are exempt from the provisions of this chapter:
A. Government Officers: Officers and employees of the United States, the State of Iowa, or any subdivision or agency thereof, while in the performance of
their official duties.
B. Public Utilities: Representatives of any public utility lawfully doing business in the City, while acting in such capacity.
C. Route Salespersons: Newsboys and route salespersons who call routinely on customers on a regular basis or on an established route.
D. Charitable Organizations: Any organization which is acting under the authority of chapter 504 of the Code of Iowa and which has obtained tax exempt
status under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.
E. Resale Or Institutional Use: Persons customarily calling on businesses or institutions for the purpose of selling products for resale or institutional use.
F. Nationally Recognized Nonprofit Organizations: Members of any Boy Scout, Girl Scout, Campfire, 4-H Club, FFA and similar nationally recognized
nonprofit organizations, if the sales are to benefit the organization in its recognized operation and/or programs.
G. Community Improvement Or Benefit: Persons making door to door sales for the purpose of a community improvement or benefit, approved by the City
Council, on behalf of nonprofit, tax exempt organizations.
H. School Students: Students representing local K-12 schools conducting projects sponsored by organizations and recognized by such schools.
I. Youth Sports Organizations: Local area youth sports organizations. (2017 Code)
3-9-13: PENALTY:
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by this chapter for any particular provision or section, any person violating any provision of this chapter or
any rule or regulation adopted herein by reference shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or
imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days. (2017 Code)
Chapter 10
VEHICLES FOR HIRE, TAXICABS, LIMOUSINES
3-10-1: LICENSING REQUIRED:
A. License: No person shall operate or maintain or use any vehicle for hire without holding a minimum of a valid chauffeur's license for a passenger vehicle
less than a sixteen (16) passenger design under the laws of the State of Iowa.
B. Inspection: No person shall operate, or maintain or use any vehicle for hire without first having the vehicle pass an inspection by the Chief of Police or
his designee and obtaining a license therefor. No license shall be transferable for use on any other vehicle other than the vehicle for hire originally
licensed unless authorized by the City Clerk and only after that vehicle has passed an inspection. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 65/358
C. Exceptions:
1. An outside or non-resident vehicle for hire company and its driver/operator not permitted by the City may only drop off passengers within the City
limits. The outside/non-resident vehicle for hire company and driver/operator shall not pick up a passenger without first complying with the
requirements of this chapter.
2. Vehicles and drivers/operators legally contracted by a business or company to transport employees or other passengers as needed.
3. Vehicles and drivers/operators used to transport patients to and from medical appointments or care facilities while being compensated either in part
or in full by Medicare, Medicaid, Tricare, or any other like medical provider or insurance company. (2017 Code)
3-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
LIMOUSINE: A vehicle which carries passengers for a fare determined on the basis of time or a flat fee.
TAXICAB: A vehicle which carries passengers for a flat rate or fare determined by a taximeter as required under section 3-10-15 of this chapter.
VEHICLE FOR HIRE: Any vehicle which carries passengers for compensation including, but not limited to, limousines and taxicabs. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-
2010)
3-10-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for license shall be in writing made by the owner thereof to the City Clerk and shall contain the name and address of the owner, the make,
model, year of manufacture, engine and factory numbers and Iowa State motor vehicle license number of each motor vehicle proposed to be licensed.
(Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-4: BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION NEEDED OF DRIVERS:
The City Clerk, upon receiving an application for a license, shall have the Chief of Police or his/her designee investigate the statements contained therein
and shall investigate the reputation and character of the applicant to determine whether or not they are a proper person to engage in business as
proposed. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
No person shall operate, or maintain or use any vehicle for hire without first paying the required initial background investigation fee of twenty five dollars
($25.00) payable to the Police Department, or the ten dollar ($10.00) renewal fee payable to the City Clerk for annual drivers before being authorized by
the Chief of Police or his/her designee. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
3-10-5: INSPECTION OF VEHICLES:
Upon application for a license, each vehicle for hire shall be thoroughly inspected by the Chief of Police or his/her designee to determine whether said
vehicle is in a thoroughly safe and sanitary condition for the transportation of passengers. This inspection shall be done on an annual basis, or more often
if necessary. If an inspection reveals such vehicle to be unfit for use in public transportation, or if such vehicle does not comply with the provisions of this
chapter, no license shall be issued therefor.
The inspection also includes additional spot or surprise checks, if needed. If a spot or surprise inspection reveals such vehicle is unfit for use in public
transportation the license will be suspended until the vehicle is made fit for use in public transportation. An inspection is also required after the vehicle has
been involved in a motor vehicle collision or has sustained something other than minor or superficial damage to ensure the vehicle is still safe for public
transportation.
If, after an inspection, any vehicle for hire is determined by the Chief of Police or his/her designee to be in unsafe condition, then the vehicle shall
immediately be removed from service by the driver and the licensee. The vehicle for hire shall not be operated thereafter until the unsafe condition has
been remedied and the Chief of Police or his/her designee has reinspected such vehicle and authorized its return to service. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-6: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
No license for any vehicle for hire shall be issued until there has been filed with the City Clerk a certificate of insurance showing issuance of a liability
insurance policy covering specifically a "vehicle for hire" for the period of said license, with minimum limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00)
for a single personal injury or death, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for multiple injuries or deaths, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00)
for property damage. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-7: LICENSE FEES:
The license fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) payable to the City Clerk for each vehicle for hire license, and shall expire on March 31 following the
date of issuance. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
3-10-8: MISREPRESENTATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to give any fictitious information or to practice any fraud, misrepresentation or subterfuge in any application for a license
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 66/358
or in order to secure any license provided for by this chapter. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-9: RATES POSTED:
The owner and operator of each vehicle for hire shall keep the rates of fares charged clearly posted at all times somewhere in plain view of the passengers
of the vehicle. The posted rates shall not obstruct the view of the windshield or either window immediately to the left or right of the driver's seat. (Ord. 10-
21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-10: PREPAYMENT OF FARE:
Every driver of a vehicle for hire shall have the right to demand prepayment of a legal fare in advance and may refuse employment unless so prepaid.
(Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-11: RECEIPTS DELIVERED:
Upon request of any passenger, the operator of any vehicle for hire shall give such passenger a receipt showing the amount of fare paid, the name of the
operator, number of the vehicle and time and distance of journey; said receipt to be signed and dated by the operator. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-12: FALSE ORDER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make a false telephone call or order of any kind or nature for any vehicle for hire service whatsoever. (Ord. 10-21, 12-
7-2010)
3-10-13: DUTY OF PASSENGER TO PAY FARE OR CHARGE:
Anyone inside a vehicle for hire is presumed to be receiving a service, based on compensation, from the driver/operator, and it shall be unlawful for any
person who receives a vehicle for hire service in Mason City, Iowa, to fail or refuse to pay any lawful fare or charge due to a vehicle for hire driver. (Ord.
10-21, 12-7-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
3-10-14: VEHICLE IDENTIFICATION:
Each vehicle for hire shall display a license tag furnished by the Chief of Police or his/her designee on the lower passenger's side of the windshield.
Each vehicle for hire shall display on each side of said vehicle the name of the company it represents in plainly distinguishable letters that are at least four
inches (4") high. These letters must be permanently painted or otherwise permanently affixed. Magnetic lettering will only be allowed on a temporary basis,
not to exceed one (1) month from time of inspection, and only under the authority of the Chief of Police or his/her designee. Taxicabs may also have a
permanently mounted yellow or amber lighting display upon the roof of each vehicle with appropriate wording indicating it is a vehicle for hire and legibly
affixed thereto. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
3-10-15: TAXIMETER OPTION:
A. Inspection And Sealing:
1. It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police, or his designated representative, to inspect each taximeter at least once each year and more often as he
may deem proper and to cause the same to be sealed. All taximeters shall be so adjusted as to register within five percent (5%) the current charge
for the distance traveled.
2. The expense to have the taximeter inspected, calibrated, recalibrated and/or certified annually will be the responsibility of the vehicle for hire
owner/operator. A copy of the taximeter's maintenance records and certification shall be forwarded to the Chief of Police or his/her designee and
placed with the annual inspection report. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
B. Installation: The taximeters shall be installed in such a position within the taxicab so as to be within the plain view of the passengers and the dial
thereon shall be equipped with a flag or other device indicating whether or not said cab is in service.
C. Charges Based On Taximeters: The charges for the use of the taxicabs shall be based upon the charge shown on the taximeter, except charges for
taxicabs hired on an hourly basis.
D. Use Of Taximeters Required: It shall be unlawful for any driver of any taxicab, while carrying passengers, to display the flag attached to the taximeter in
such a position as to denote that such vehicle is not employed or to throw the flag of the taximeter in recording position while such vehicle is not
actually employed, or to fail to throw the flag of such taximeter in a nonrecording position at the termination of each and every service. (Ord. 10-21, 12-
7-2010)
3-10-16: OPERATION OF VEHICLE FOR HIRE:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 67/358
A. Passengers: A "passenger" is a person within a vehicle for hire who is not the driver/operator. Any passenger is automatically presumed to be receiving
a service based on compensation.
B. Termination Or Refusal Of Transportation: A driver of a vehicle for hire may terminate the transportation of a passenger or refuse to transport a potential
passenger if the driver reasonably believes the driver's life, safety or property is in danger.
C. Tobacco Use Prohibited: Use of tobacco within a vehicle for hire is prohibited under Iowa Code chapter 142D.
D. Use Of Cellphone, Text Messaging Device, Sound System, Or Radio By Driver: No driver, while the vehicle for hire is occupied by a passenger, shall
play a sound system or radio if the passenger or passengers request that the driver not do so. Additionally, no driver shall use a cellphone or text
messaging device while the vehicle for hire is in motion or is occupied by a passenger unless a hands free device is available.
E. Receiving And Discharging Passengers: No driver shall stop a vehicle for hire, or any portion thereof, on the traveled portion of any highway, street, or
other place open to use by the public for vehicular travel, to receive or discharge any passenger or their belongings, except where motor vehicle
parking, where stopping is specifically permitted by law or where it is otherwise safe to do so. When so permitted, the driver shall park or stop the
vehicle for hire in the manner permitted by law. No driver shall load or unload passengers or their belongings in a manner that impedes or interferes
with the orderly flow of vehicular traffic.
F. How Passengers Of Vehicle Are To Enter Or Leave Vehicle For Hire: A driver should not permit any potential passenger to enter a vehicle for hire, or
permit a passenger to exit a vehicle for hire, from the left side, except when the vehicle for hire is at the left curb of a one-way street or when the
vehicle for hire is parked or standing perpendicular to the curb at a location where such parking or standing is permitted.
G. Restriction On Number Of Passengers In Any Vehicle For Hire: A driver shall not permit more persons to enter a vehicle for hire in excess of the seating
capacity thereof, as rated by the vehicle for hire's manufacturer, including the driver.
H. Acceptance Of Additional Persons: Whenever any vehicle for hire is occupied by a passenger, the driver shall not permit any other person to occupy
such vehicle for hire, unless the passenger, having been requested by the driver, gives affirmative permission to the driver to do so.
I. Deception Of Passengers: A driver shall not deceive any passenger, or potential passenger, as to the destination, route, rate of fare, or any other
provision of this chapter.
J. Trips To Be Made By Most Direct Route: A passenger may request that a driver take a passenger specified route to the passenger's destination. If a
passenger does not specify a route, then a driver shall take the most direct route from the point of pick up to the destination. A driver may suggest, and
a passenger may approve, a less direct route.
K. Compliance With Lawful Requests Of Passengers: All drivers shall comply with all reasonable and lawful requests of passengers.
L. Lost Personal Property: All personal property found in a vehicle for hire at the end of a trip shall be immediately returned by the driver or license holder
to the passenger who left the item(s) in the vehicle for hire, if the identity of the passenger is known or can be reasonably ascertained. Otherwise, the
personal property shall be deposited by the driver with the license holder at the conclusion of the driver's tour of duty.
M. Alcohol And Controlled Substances: No driver shall ingest or be under the influence of alcoholic beverages, controlled substances or other habit
forming drugs while operating a vehicle for hire. No driver shall transport in a vehicle for hire alcoholic beverages or controlled substances other than
those carried in possession of a paying passenger.
N. Solicitation: No driver shall solicit potential passengers by word, signal or otherwise.
O. Use Of Vehicle For Hire For Unlawful Purposes: No driver or vehicle owner or license holder shall use, or permit to be used any vehicle for hire for any
unlawful purpose.
P. Drivers To Be Clean And Neat: Every driver of a vehicle for hire while on duty shall be clean and neat in dress and in person.
Q. Safety Equipment Required: All vehicles for hire shall be equipped with three (3) DOT traffic triangles, a fire extinguisher and a first aid kit.
R. Compliance With Laws And Ordinances: Every vehicle for hire shall be operated in accordance with all applicable Federal, State and local laws,
ordinances and regulations. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010; amd. 2017 Code)
3-10-17: ENFORCEMENT:
The provisions of this chapter may be enforced by the City Attorney or his/her designee, the Chief of Police or his/her designee or by any other law
enforcement officer. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-18: PENALTIES:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 68/358
A. Any vehicle owner or driver who violates any provision of this chapter, or any rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, shall be guilty of a simple
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, and not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each subsequent offense.
B. Any person, other than a vehicle owner or driver, who violates any provision of this chapter, or any rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, shall be
guilty of a simple misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, and not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each subsequent offense. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
3-10-19: EFFECT OF ENACTMENT OF THIS CHAPTER:
Every license in effect on the date of the enactment of this chapter shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. 10-21, 12-7-2010)
Chapter 11
SECURITY ALARM SYSTEMS
3-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
Iowa Administrative Rules chapter 277 (2013) and Iowa Code supplement (2013) and any subsequent revisions thereto establish definitions related to
alarm systems, alarm contractors and alarm installers. (Ord. 13-29, 9-17-2013)
3-11-2: STATE CERTIFICATION OF CONTRACTORS AND INSTALLERS REQUIRED:
Iowa Administrative Rules chapter 277 (2013) and Iowa Code supplement (2013) and any subsequent revisions thereto establish State requirements for
alarm system contractors and installers. Inquiries regarding the Alarm System Contractor and Installer Certification Program may be addressed to:
Alarm System Contractor and Installer Certification Program
Fire Marshal Division
Iowa Department of Public Safety
215 East 7th Street
Des Moines, IA 50319
Inquiries may be addressed by electronic mail to alarminfo@dps.state.ia.us, or by telephone to (515)725-6145. (Ord. 13-29, 9-17-2013)
Chapter 12
SIDEWALK CONTRACTORS
3-12-1: QUALIFICATIONS; LICENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, repair sidewalks or do any concrete work upon a portion of public property without first having obtained a
sidewalk contractor's license as provided in this chapter; provided, however, that no license shall be required of employees of the City in the exercise of
their respective duties nor to persons acting under direct contract with the City. It shall be unlawful for any person other than employees of the licensee to
operate under his license. (Ord. 1098, 2-2-1970; amd. 1985 Code)
3-12-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for said sidewalk contractor's license shall be filed with the City Clerk, which application shall describe the qualifications and experience of
the applicant in sidewalk construction. (Ord. 1098, 2-2-1970; amd. 1985 Code)
3-12-3: REQUIREMENTS FOR LICENSE:
A. Bond: The application shall be accompanied by a bond, for the period said license is in effect, in the penal sum of not less than five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), conditioned that the applicant shall indemnify the City against any damages which may occur or injury which may result because of the
want of reasonable care or lack of reasonable skill in the performance of such work, and further conditioned that all walks constructed by the applicant
shall be in accordance with the plans and specifications therefor, and the provisions of this Code. Said bond shall also be conditioned to maintain the
sidewalks for a period of three (3) years after completion.
B. Insurance: The applicant shall file with the Clerk evidence of public liability insurance acceptable to the City, to be in full force and effect for the period of
said license, with minimum limits of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for property damage, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for a single
personal injury or death, and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for multiple injuries or deaths, which insurance shall indemnify and hold harmless the
City from the same risks as hereinbefore provided for corporate surety bonds.
C. Fees: The fee for each sidewalk contractor's license shall be the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 1098, 2-2-1970; amd. 1985 Code; Ord.
92-14, 8-4-1992; 2017 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 69/358
D. Term Of License: Licenses, bonds and insurance shall be good for the period expiring March 31 following the issuance thereof.
Upon being satisfied that the application, bond and insurance comply with the provisions of this chapter, the Clerk shall issue a license to the applicant.
(Ord. 1098, 2-2-1970; amd. 1985 Code; Ord. 92-14, 8-4-1992)
3-12-4: GRADE APPLICATION REQUIRED:
No construction shall be allowed within the corporate limits of any Municipally owned property, sidewalks or alleys by any sidewalk contractor or any other
person without first obtaining a grade application for doing such work from the Engineering Department. (Ord. 92-19, 11-3-1992; amd. 2017 Code)
3-12-5: INSPECTION:
All concrete construction shall be inspected by the Engineering Department. All work shall conform to the established grade therefor provided by the City
Engineer and shall follow all requirements set forth in title 5, chapter 1, articles A, B and C of this Code. (1985 Code; amd. Ord. 91-3, 2-5-1991; 2017
Code)
3-12-6: PERMITS REQUIRED:
No construction shall be allowed within the corporate limits of any Municipally owned property, sidewalks or alleys by any City licensed sidewalk contractor
or any other person without first obtaining a permit.
A. Fees: The permit fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for new installation and twenty dollars ($20.00) for replacement and payable at time said permit is
issued; and the same shall be issued in duplicate, one (1) copy being given to the applicant and one (1) filed in the Office of the City Engineer. Permit
shall show the name of the applicant, the exact location of the concrete construction, and such other information as the City Engineer may require.
B. Owner's Permit: In cases where the owner of property or properties desires personally to do sidewalk work upon public rights-of-way immediately
adjacent to and abutting premises of which the owner has been established as the legal deed holder or contractor purchaser, said owner may appear
before the City Engineer, or his designated representative, and upon establishing that he is competent to do the specific work for which permit is
desired, and upon obtaining the permit and grade for said work to be done, said owner may then commence work. All work completed by the owner
shall be inspected as provided in section 3-12-5 of this chapter.
C. Term Of Permit: Permit is valid for thirty (30) days from the date of issuance for all sidewalk work. Sidewalk not replaced within thirty (30) days of
issuance may be replaced, without notice to the contractor or homeowner, by a City appointed sidewalk contractor. Extensions past the thirty (30) days
from the date of issuance shall only be granted by the City Engineer. The replacement of sidewalk removed in the course of underground utility work
shall be replaced by the permit holder within thirty (30) days of completion of the underground work. (Ord. 92-19, 11-3-1992; amd. 2017 Code)
Chapter 13
EXCAVATING CONTRACTORS
3-13-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, blast, excavate in, or break up any street, alley or public ground without first having obtained an excavator's
license as provided in this chapter; provided, however, that no license shall be required of officers of the City in the exercise of their respective duties nor
to persons acting under direct contract with the City. It shall be unlawful for any person other than employees of the licensee to operate under his license.
(1953 Code § 81-1)
3-13-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for an excavator's license shall be made in writing to the City Clerk. Said application shall give the name, age, residence and experience of the
applicant and such other information as may reasonably be required by the Clerk. (1953 Code § 81-2)
3-13-3: REQUIREMENTS FOR LICENSE:
A. Fee: The application for an excavator's license shall be accompanied by the license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
B. Bond: Each application for an excavator's license shall be accompanied by a bond, for the period said license is in effect, in the penal sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned that the excavator will replace any street surfaces or installations of public utilities in streets in as good
condition as they were before the excavation, that he will hold the City harmless on account of claims by any person as a result of such excavation or
blasting activities and that he will pay any and all damages for which he is legally liable as a result of such excavation and blasting activities. (Ord.
1099, 2-2-1970; amd. 2017 Code)
C. Insurance: The applicant shall file with the Clerk evidence of public liability insurance acceptable to the City to be in full force and effect for the period of
said license, with minimum limits of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for property damage, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for a single
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 70/358
personal injury or death, and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for multiple injuries or deaths, which insurance shall indemnify and hold harmless the
City from the same risks as hereinbefore provided for corporate surety bonds. Said liability insurance shall contain coverage for all blasting and
excavating operations performed by the licensee. (Ord. 1099, 2-2-1970; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
D. Term Of License: All excavators' licenses shall expire on March 31 following the date of their issuance. (Ord. 1099, 2-2-1970)
3-13-4: PERMIT REQUIRED1:
A. Excavations: No excavation within the limits of any street, alley or Municipally owned property by any excavator, contractor or any other person shall be
opened without first securing a permit for doing such work, from the Engineering Department. The permit shall be issued in duplicate, one (1) copy
being given to the applicant and one (1) filed in the Office of the City Engineer. Permit shall show the name of the applicant, the exact location of the
concrete construction, and such other information as the Engineering Department may require. (Ord. 92-19, 11-3-1992; amd. 2017 Code)
B. Connections: It shall be unlawful for any person to cut the surface of any street for the purpose of making connections with or repairs to any gas, water,
sewer or underground electrical construction located beneath such street without first securing a permit therefor from the Engineering Department.
(1953 Code § 62-1; amd. Ord. 92-19, 11-3-1992; 2017 Code)
C. Repairing Cut In Street: The person cutting or opening any street shall replace the surfacing, whether concrete pavement or otherwise, under the
supervision of and in accordance with the plans and specifications of the Engineering Department and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
The work of connecting to or repairing any gas, water, sewer or underground electrical construction shall also be done in accordance with plans and
specifications and under the supervision and control of the Engineering Department. (1953 Code § 62-3; amd. 1985 Code; Ord. 92-19, 11-3-1992;
2017 Code)
D. Fees:
1. Permit And Inspection Fees:
a. Sanitary Sewer: A permit and inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for residential, seventy five dollars ($75.00) for commercial and one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) for industrial property for each sanitary sewer service, new installation or repair, and thirty dollars ($30.00) for each sanitary
sewer disconnection.
b. Private Wastewater Disposal System: A permit and inspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
c. Storm Sewer Collection System: Permit and inspection fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for residential, seventy five dollars ($75.00) for
commercial, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for industrial property for each water service, new installation or repair, and thirty dollars ($30.00)
for each storm sewer disconnection. Permit and inspection fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each sump pump connection.
d. Water Distribution System: The permit and inspection fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each water service, new installation or repair, and thirty
dollars ($30.00) for each water service disconnection.
e. Driveway Approach: The permit and inspection fee shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) for each driveway approach and twenty dollars ($20.00) for curb
sawing, grinding or drilling.
f. Sidewalk: Permit and inspection fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each new sidewalk installation and twenty dollars ($20.00) for sidewalk
replacement.
All permits are payable at the time said permit is issued; and the same shall be issued in duplicate, one (1) copy being given to the applicant and
one (1) filed in the Engineering Department. (Ord. 92-19, 11-3-1992; amd. 2017 Code)
2. Street Cutting Permit Fee: When the surface of any street has been paved with permanent concrete pavement or other permanent type of pavement
within five (5) years of the date of application for permit to cut such street, no such permit shall be issued until the applicant shall have paid a permit
fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). This shall apply to all new services. (Ord. 97-7, 3-4-1997)
E. Test Well Drilling: Permit fees for test well drilling shall be five dollars ($5.00). (Ord. 92-19, 11-3-1992)
3-13-5: INSPECTIONS:
All sewer and water service connections shall be inspected by the Office of the City Engineer, and no such service shall be filled in or used until after
inspection and approval of the City Engineer. For inspection, the excavator shall have the main connection entirely exposed and the full line of the service
shall be exposed at intervals of ten feet (10'). (1953 Code § 81-7; amd. 1985 Code; Ord. 91-3, 2-5-1991; 2017 Code)
3-13-6: OWNER'S PERMIT:
In cases where the owner of property or properties desires personally to do sidewalk work upon a public right-of-way immediately adjacent to and abutting
premises of which the owner has been established as the legal deed holder or contract purchaser, said owner may appear before the City Engineer and
upon establishing that he is competent to do the specific work for which permit is desired, and upon obtaining the permit and grade for said work to be
done, said owner may then commence work. All work completed by the owner shall be inspected as provided in section 3-13-5 of this chapter. (1985
Code; amd. Ord. 91-3, 2-5-1991; 2017 Code)
