https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 71/358
Chapter 14
TREE TRIMMING CONTRACTORS
3-14-1: DEFINITION:
"Tree trimming contractors" shall mean any person who, for compensation, cuts or trims any tree or limbs or branches of any tree, who cuts or removes
the roots of any tree or who treats diseases of any tree. (Ord. 1592, 2-17-1981; amd. 1985 Code)
3-14-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Every tree trimmer shall, annually before engaging in work on any tree on or overhanging any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public property or on
any tree whose height is greater than the distance from the base of such tree to any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public property, obtain a license
therefor from the City Clerk. Said license shall expire on March 31 of each year. (Ord. 1592, 2-17-1981; amd. 1985 Code)
3-14-3: LICENSE FEE; INSURANCE:
A. Fee: Application for such licenses shall be made upon forms provided by the Clerk and each applicant shall pay an annual license fee of thirty five
dollars ($35.00) at the time of making such application.
B. Insurance: The applicant shall file with the Clerk evidence of public liability insurance acceptable to the City to be in full force and effect for the period of
said license, with minimum limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for
a single personal injury or death, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for multiple injuries or deaths, which insurance shall indemnify and
hold harmless the City, on account of any and all damage or injury, including death, to real or personal property, whether public or private, which arises
out of or is connected with or caused by such tree trimming contractor or his agents in the performance of his business. (Ord. 93-3, 1-19-1993; amd.
2017 Code)
Chapter 15
PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTION FOR SPECULATIVE SHELL BUILDINGS
3-15-1: INTENT:
The City Council declares it to be the intention of this chapter to provide for a property tax exemption for "speculative shell buildings" as provided by
section 427.1(27) of the Code of Iowa. (Ord. 02-03, 2-5-2002; amd. 2017 Code)
3-15-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the terms used in this chapter:
COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATION: A. An organization, which meets the membership requirements set forth below, formed within a City or
County or multicommunity group for one (1) or more of the following purposes:
1. To promote, stimulate, develop, and advance the business prosperity and economic welfare of the community, area, or region and its citizens.
2. To encourage and assist the location of new business and industry.
3. To rehabilitate and assist existing business and industry.
4. To stimulate and assist in the expansion of business activity.
B. For purposes of this definition, a "community development organization" must have at least fifteen (15) members with representation from the
following:
1. A representative from government at the level or levels corresponding to the community development organization's area of operation.
2. A representative from a private sector lending institution.
3. A representative of a community organization in the area.
4. A representative of business in the area.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 72/358
5. A representative of private citizens in the community, area, or region.
SPECULATIVE SHELL BUILDING: A building or structure owned and constructed or reconstructed by a community development organization, a not for
profit cooperative association under Iowa Code chapter 499, without a tenant or buyer for the purpose of attracting an employer or user which will
complete the building to the employer's or user's specification for manufacturing, processing, or warehousing the employer's or user's product line. (Ord.
02-03, 2-5-2002)
3-15-3: TAX ABATEMENT FOR BUILDINGS OF CERTAIN ORGANIZATIONS:
New construction of shell buildings by community development organizations, not for profit cooperative associations under chapter 499 of the Code of
Iowa for speculative purposes or the portion of the value added to buildings being reconstructed or renovated by community development organizations,
not for profit cooperative associations under Iowa Code chapter 499 in order to become speculative shell buildings may be exempt from taxation pursuant
to Iowa Code section 427.1(27). Such exemption shall be effective for the assessment year in which the building is first assessed for property taxation or
the assessment year in which the reconstruction or renovation first adds value and all subsequent years until the property is leased or sold or until the
exemption is terminated by ordinance of the City Council. Eligibility for an exemption as a speculative shell building shall be determined as of January 1 of
the assessment year. However, an exemption shall not be granted a speculative shell building of a not for profit cooperative association under Iowa Code
chapter 499 if the building is used by the cooperative association, for other than as a speculative shell building. If the shell building or any portion of the
shell building is leased or sold, the portion of the shell building which is leased or sold shall not be entitled to an exemption under this section for
subsequent years. An application shall be filed pursuant to section 427B.4 of the Code of Iowa in the manner required by section 3-15-4 of this chapter for
each project for which an exemption is claimed. (Ord. 02-03, 2-5-2002)
3-15-4: EXCEPTIONS:
A property tax exemption under this chapter shall not be granted if the property for which the exemption is claimed has received any other property tax
exemption authorized by law. (Ord. 02-03, 2-5-2002)
3-15-5: APPLICATION FOR EXEMPTION:
An application shall be filed for each speculative shell building resulting in actual value added for which an exemption is claimed in the manner provided by
section 427B.4 of the Code of Iowa. The application for exemption shall be filed by the owner of the property with the local assessor by February 1 of the
assessment year in which the value added is first assessed for taxation. Applications for exemption shall be made on forms prescribed by the Director of
Revenue and shall contain information pertaining to the nature of the improvement, its cost, and other information deemed necessary by the Director of
Revenue. (Ord. 02-03, 2-5-2002)
3-15-6: PRIOR APPROVAL:
A person may submit a proposal to the City Council for prior approval for eligibility for a tax exemption. The City Council, by ordinance, may give its prior
approval of a tax exemption for a new construction if the speculative shell building is in conformance with the zoning plans for the City, provided such
ordinance shall not be finally adopted until at least thirty (30) days after a public hearing as required by Iowa Code section 427B.1. Such prior approval
shall not entitle the owner to said exemption until the new construction has been completed and found to be qualified real estate. However, if the tax
exemption for new construction is not approved, the person may submit an amended proposal to the City Council to approve or reject. (Ord. 02-03, 2-5-
2002)
3-15-7: REPEAL OF ORDINANCE:
This chapter may be repealed by the City Council when in its opinion continuation of the exemption granted ceases to be of benefit to the City, but all
existing exemptions shall continue until their expiration. (Ord. 02-03, 2-5-2002)
Chapter 16
PARTIAL PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTIONS FOR INDUSTRIAL PROPERTY
3-16-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the terms used in this chapter:
ACTUAL VALUE ADDED: The actual value added as of the first year for which the exemption is received, except that actual value added by improvements
to machinery and equipment means the actual value as determined by the Assessor as of January 1 of each year for which the exemption is received.
NEW CONSTRUCTION: New buildings and structures and includes new buildings and structures which are constructed as additions to existing buildings
and structures. New construction does not include reconstruction of an existing building or structure which does not constitute complete replacement of an
existing building or structure or refitting of an existing building or structure, unless the reconstruction of an existing building or structure is required due to
economic obsolescence and the reconstruction is necessary to implement recognized industry standards for the manufacturing and processing of specific
products and the reconstruction is required for the owner of the building or structure to continue to competitively manufacture or process those products
which determination shall receive prior approval of the City Council upon the recommendation of the Iowa Development Commission.
NEW MACHINERY AND EQUIPMENT: New machinery and equipment assessed as real estate pursuant to section 427A.1, subsection 1, paragraph e, of
the Iowa Code, unless the machinery or equipment is part of the normal replacement or operating process to maintain or expand existing operational
status. (Ord. 03-2, 2-18-2003)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 73/358
3-16-2: INTENT:
The City Council declares it to be the intention of this chapter to provide for a partial property tax exemption for actual value added to industrial real estate
by the new construction of industrial real estate and the acquisition of or improvement to machinery and equipment assessed as real estate pursuant to
section 427A.1, subsection 1, paragraph e, of the Iowa Code, as set forth in House File 650 of the 68th General Assembly. (Ord. 03-2, 2-18-2003)
3-16-3: AMOUNT OF EXEMPTION:
The amount of actual value added which is eligible to be exempt from taxation shall be as follows:
A. For the first year: Seventy five percent (75%).
B. For the second year: Sixty percent (60%).
C. For the third year: Forty five percent (45%).
D. For the fourth year: Thirty percent (30%).
E. For the fifth year: Fifteen percent (15%).
F. After the fifth year, there shall be no exemption and the granting of the exemption hereunder for new construction constituting complete replacement of
an existing building or structure shall not result in the assessed value of the industrial real estate being reduced below the assessed value of the
industrial real estate before the start of the new construction added. (Ord. 03-2, 2-18-2003)
3-16-4: APPLICATION:
An application shall be filed for each project resulting in actual value added for which an exemption is claimed. The application for exemption shall be filed
by the owner of the property with the local Assessor by February 1 of the assessment year in which the value added is first assessed for taxation.
Applications for exemption shall be made on forms prescribed by the Director of Revenue and shall contain information pertaining to the nature of the
improvement, its cost, and other information deemed necessary by the Director of Revenue. (Ord. 03-2, 2-18-2003)
3-16-5: PRIOR APPROVAL:
A person may submit a proposal to the City Council for prior approval for eligibility for a tax exemption on new construction. The City Council, by
ordinance, may give its prior approval of a tax exemption for a new construction if the new construction is in conformance with the zoning plans for the City
and after public hearing as by law provided. Such prior approval shall not entitle the owner to said exemption until the new construction has been
completed and found to be qualified real estate. However, if the tax exemption for new construction is not approved, the person may submit an amended
proposal to the City Council to approve or reject. (Ord. 03-2, 2-18-2003)
3-16-6: REPEALER:
This chapter may be repealed by the City Council when in its opinion continuation of the exemption granted ceases to be of benefit to the City but all
existing exemptions shall continue until their expiration. (Ord. 03-2, 2-18-2003)
3-16-7: EXCEPTIONS:
A property tax exemption under this chapter shall not be granted if the property for which the exemption is claimed has received any other property tax
exemption authorized by law. (Ord. 03-2, 2-18-2003)
Title 4
HEALTH AND SANITATION
Chapter 1
NUISANCES
4-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined:
GARBAGE: Food waste; discarded or useless material.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 74/358
JUNK: Secondhand, worn or discarded articles.
NUISANCE: Whatever is injurious to health, indecent, or offensive to the senses, or an obstacle to the free use of property, so as essentially to interfere
with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property. The following, although not all inclusive, are declared to be nuisances:
A. The erecting, continuing, or using any building or other places for the exercise of any trade, employment, or manufacture, which, by occasioning
noxious fumes, offensive smells, or other annoyances, becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort, or property of individuals or the
public.
B. The causing or suffering any offal, filth, or noisome substance to accumulate or to remain in any place to the prejudice of others.
C. The obstructing or impeding without legal authority the passage of any navigable river, harbor, or collection of water.
D. The corrupting or rendering unwholesome or impure the water of any river, stream, or pond, or unlawfully diverting the same from its natural course
or state, to the injury or prejudice of others.
E. The obstructing or encumbering by fences, buildings, or otherwise the public roads, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places or
burying grounds.
F. Houses of ill fame, kept for the purpose of prostitution and lewdness, gambling houses, or houses resorted to for the use of controlled substances or
houses where drunkenness, quarreling, fighting, or breaches of the peace are carried on or permitted to the disturbance of others.
G. Billboards, signboards, and advertising signs, whether erected and constructed on public or private property, which so obstruct and impair the view
of any portion or part of a public street, avenue, highway, boulevard or alley or of a railroad or street railway track as to render dangerous the use
thereof, especially near intersecting streets.
H. Any object or structure hereafter erected within one thousand feet (1,000') of the limits of any Municipal or regularly established airport or landing
place, which may endanger or obstruct aerial navigation, including takeoff and landing, unless such object or structure constitutes a proper use or
enjoyment of the land on which the same is located.
I. The accumulation of items including, but not limited to, the following: old or scrap rope, rags, batteries, paper, trash, rubber, debris, tires, waste, used
lumber or salvaged wood; inoperable machinery, electronics, or appliances or parts of such machinery, electronics, or appliances; iron, steel, or other
old or scrap ferrous materials; old or discarded glass, tinware, plastic or old or discarded household goods or hardware, except if stored inside a
completely enclosed structure. Neatly stacked firewood located on a side yard or rear yard is not considered a nuisance.
J. The depositing or storing of "garbage" or "recyclables" (as defined in section 4-2A-1 of this title) whether it is within a totally enclosed structure or not
is prohibited except for the normal accumulation of garbage and recyclables stored for weekly City garbage collection.
K. The emission of dense smoke, noxious fumes, or fly ash.
L. Dense growth of all weeds, grasses, vines, brush, dead wood, or other vegetation in the City, so as to constitute a health, safety, or fire hazard,
pursuant to article A of this chapter.
M. Trees infected with Dutch elm disease1.
N. Planting cotton bearing cottonwood trees or any other cotton bearing poplar trees is hereby prohibited in the City of Mason City.
O. Effluent from septic tank or drainfield running or ponding on the ground in the open.
P. Any article or substance placed upon a street, alley, sidewalk, public ground, or in any ditch, waterway or gutter so as to obstruct the drainage.
Q. Junk vehicles as set out in title 8, chapter 5 of this Code.
R. All diseased animals.
S. All ponds or pools of stagnant water.
T. Carcasses of animals not disposed of within twenty four (24) hours after death, as set forth in section 167.15, Iowa Code.
U. Pollution of any public well as set out in title 6, chapter 1, article B of this Code, or cistern, stream or body of water by sewage, creamery or industrial
wastes, or other substances.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 75/358
V. Any building or portion thereof in which any of the following listed conditions exist either individually or in combination with each other to the extent of
being injurious to health, indecent, or offensive to the senses, or an obstruction to the free use of property, so as essentially to interfere with the
comfortable enjoyment of life or property, is a nuisance:
1. Infestation of insects, vermin or rodents,
2. General dilapidation or improper maintenance,
3. Lack of adequate garbage and rubbish storage and removal facilities as determined by the Code Enforcement Officer,
4. Hazardous or unsanitary premises. Those premises on which an accumulation of weeds, vegetation, junk, dead organic matter, debris, garbage,
offal, rat harborages, stagnant water, combustible materials and similar materials or conditions constitute fire, health or safety hazards,
5. Deteriorated or ineffective waterproofing of exterior walls, roof, foundations or floors, including broken windows or doors,
6. Defective or lack of weather protection for exterior wall coverings, including lack of paint, or weathering due to lack of paint or other approved
protective covering,
7. Broken, rotten, split or buckled exterior wall coverings or roof coverings.
W. The shoveling, raking, throwing, dumping or depositing of any garbage, refuse, dirt, yard wastes, solid wastes or any other materials into any
stream, river or creek or upon any stream, river or creek banks.
PROPERTY OWNER: The contract purchaser if there is one of record, otherwise the record holder of legal title.
REFUSE: Worthless or useless part of something.
RUBBISH: Useless waste or rejected matter.
TRASH: Something worth little or nothing; junk, rubbish, refuse and garbage. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008; amd. 2017 Code)
4-1-2: NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
The creation or maintenance of a nuisance is prohibited, and a nuisance, public or private, may be abated in the manner provided in this chapter or may
be prosecuted as a Municipal infraction, or both. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008)
4-1-3: OTHER CONDITIONS REGULATED:
The following actions are required and may also be abated in the manner provided in this chapter:
A. The removal of diseased trees or dead wood, but not diseased trees and dead wood outside the lot and property lines and inside the curb lines upon
the public street.
B. The numbering of buildings2.
C. The connection to public drainage systems from abutting property when necessary for public health or safety.
D. The connection to public sewer systems3 from abutting property, and the installation of sanitary toilet facilities and removal of other toilet facilities on
such property as set out in subsection 6-2-5C of this Code. (Ord. 88-30, 12-5-1988)
4-1-4: NOTICE TO ABATE NUISANCE OR CONDITION:
Whenever an authorized Municipal officer has probable cause to believe that a nuisance or other condition which is listed in section 4-1-1 of this chapter
exists, he or she may cause to be served upon the property owner as shown by the records of the County Auditor, a written notice to abate the nuisance
within a reasonable time after notice. In the alternative, an authorized Municipal officer may cause to be served upon the property owner a citation for a
Municipal infraction setting forth a specific violation of this chapter. (Ord. 88-30, 12-5-1988; amd. 2017 Code)
4-1-5: CONTENTS OF NOTICE:
A notice to abate shall contain the following:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 76/358
A. A description of the alleged nuisance or other condition.
B. The location of the alleged nuisance or condition.
C. A statement that if the property owner wishes to dispute the determination that a nuisance or other condition as prohibited by this chapter exists, such
property owner or the property owner's representative shall make a written request to the Code Enforcement Division on or before the time prescribed
in the notice which shall be not more than ten (10) days from the date of notice. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008; amd. 2017 Code)
D. A statement that if no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time that the nuisance or other prohibited condition shall conclusively be
presumed to exist.
E. A statement of the act or acts necessary to abate the nuisance or prohibited condition.
F. The required time within which the owner must complete the abatement.
G. A statement that if the nuisance or condition is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the time prescribed, the City may abate
the nuisance or other condition and assess the cost against such person and/or property. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008)
4-1-6: METHOD OF SERVICE:
The notice to abate shall be served either by: a) personal delivery; or b) posting the notice in a conspicuous place upon the premises where the nuisance
exists and sending a copy of the notice by regular United States mail. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008)
4-1-7: REQUEST FOR HEARING AND APPEAL:
Any person ordered to abate a nuisance or condition may have a hearing as to whether a nuisance or prohibited condition exists. A request for a hearing
must be made in writing and delivered to the Code Enforcement Division within the time stated in the notice, or it will be conclusively presumed that a
nuisance or prohibited condition exists and it must be abated as ordered.
At the conclusion of the hearing, the Director of Development Services shall render a written decision as to whether a nuisance or prohibited condition
exists. If the Director of Development Services finds that a nuisance or prohibited condition exists, he or she must order it abated within a time reasonable
under the circumstances. An appeal from this decision may be had by immediately filing a written notice with the City Clerk. This appeal will be heard
before the City Council at a time and place fixed by the Council. The findings of the Council shall be conclusive and, if a nuisance or prohibited condition is
found to exist, it shall be ordered abated within a time reasonable under the circumstances. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008; amd. 2017 Code)
4-1-8: ABATEMENT IN EMERGENCY:
If it is determined that an emergency exists by reason of the continuing maintenance of the nuisance or condition, the City may perform any action that
may be required under this chapter without prior notice, and assess the costs as provided herein. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008)
4-1-9: ABATEMENT BY MUNICIPALITY:
If the person notified to abate a nuisance or condition neglects or fails to abate as directed, the City may perform the required action to abate, keeping an
accurate account of the expense incurred. The expense account shall be fully itemized, verified and filed with the City Clerk who shall pay such expenses
on behalf of the Municipality. (Ord. 88-30, 12-5-1988)
4-1-10: POWERS OF CODE ENFORCEMENT DIVISION:
The Code Enforcement Officers designated by the Development Services Director may enter onto and into open unobstructed property and structures to
investigate, locate, and identify nuisances that said department has cause to believe exist on real estate in the City. The designated employees of the
division shall have full authority to declare a condition to be a public nuisance and issue appropriate notices provided for by this chapter. Thereafter, the
division shall take action as required and permitted by this chapter. Designated division employees shall have all powers and authority necessary to cause
the abatement of the nuisance under Federal, State and local laws. (Ord. 13-06, 3-5-2013; amd. 2017 Code)
4-1-11: COLLECTION OF COSTS:
The Clerk shall mail a statement of the total cost to the person failing to abide by the notice to abate and if the amount shown by the statement has not
been paid within one (1) month, the costs shall be certified to the County Auditor and it shall then be collected with, and in the same manner as, general
property taxes. (Ord. 08-04, 5-20-2008)
4-1-12: INSTALLMENT PAYMENT OF COST OF ABATEMENT:
If the amount expended to abate the nuisance or condition exceeds one hundred dollars ($100.00), the City may permit the assessment to be paid in up to
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 77/358
ten (10) annual installments, to be paid in the same manner and with the same interest rates provided for assessments against benefited property. (Ord.
08-04, 5-20-2008)
4-1-13: MUNICIPAL INFRACTION:
In addition to or in lieu of serving the owner with a notice to abate an alleged nuisance or condition, the authorized Municipal officer having probable cause
to believe that such nuisance or other prohibited condition exists may cause the creation or maintenance of the alleged nuisance or other condition to be
prosecuted as a Municipal infraction in accordance with the provisions of title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code and may seek in addition to or in lieu of
the civil penalties imposed for Municipal infractions, a court order granting the City appropriate relief to abate or to halt the violation. A wilful failure of a
defendant to pay a civil penalty or a violation of the terms or any other order of court granting appropriate relief is punishable as contempt. (Ord. 08-04, 5-
20-2008; amd. 2017 Code)
ARTICLE A. WEEDS
4-1A-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
The dense growth of weeds, vines, brush or any other similar vegetation or grass more than one foot (1') in height, on property located within the City
limits is hereby declared a hazard to public safety and health and a public nuisance. (Ord. 913, 6-3-1963; amd. 1985 Code)
Exception: Public property set aside as a natural area and private property along a controlled corridor.
The Development Services Department encourages the use of native grasses, forbs, shrubs, and trees on riparian areas adjoining streams and rivers.
However, noxious weeds as designated by Iowa Code must be controlled. (Ord. 95-13, 8-15-1995; amd. 2017 Code)
4-1A-2: DUTY TO DESTROY WEEDS:
The property owner, as shown by the records of the County Auditor, shall cut, destroy or otherwise control weeds and other growth which constitutes a
health, safety or fire hazard thereon at the expense of said property owner. (Ord. 1529, 1-21-1980)
4-1A-3: ENFORCEMENT:
The Director of Development Services is authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1529, 1-21-1980; amd. 1985 Code; Ord. 91-3, 2-5-
1991; 2017 Code)
4-1A-4: NOTICE OF ABATEMENT:
A. In the event a property owner fails to control, destroy or cut weeds or other growth which constitutes a nuisance, the Development Services Department
may serve a notice upon the property owner as determined from the records of the County Auditor by one (1) or more of the following, as necessary:
1. Posting a notice on the front door or main entry to the building;
2. Personal service, if the owner can be served within City limits;
3. United States first class mail, if the owner lives within any zip code that is within or contiguous to the boundaries of Cerro Gordo County;
4. United States certified mail with return receipt, if the owner cannot be served according to any of the above methods.
B. The notice shall direct that said nuisance be abated within five (5) business days after the completed service of notice. Said notice shall set forth those
actions which are required of the property owner. The notice shall state that, if the same owner of the same property receives more than two (2) notices
to abate in a calendar year, then any subsequent founded complaint may be abated by the City without prior notice. (Ord. 1529, 1-21-1980; amd. 1985
Code; 2017 Code)
4-1A-5: CITY ABATEMENT; FEES; ASSESSMENT OF COSTS:
A. In the event the property owner fails to perform the action required in the notice of abatement within the time prescribed therein, then the City may
perform the required action.
B. Fees for City abatement, when necessary, shall be as set forth by resolution of the City Council, including actual costs of abatement and administrative
costs. Abatement and administrative fees may be increased for multiple violations on the same property under the same ownership in any one (1)
calendar year. If more than six (6) violations occur while the property is under the same ownership in a calendar year, the owner may also be charged
with a Municipal civil infraction, as required in title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code.
C. Should the owner fail to pay fees charged for violations of this chapter within a specified and reasonable time, the City may assess the costs thereof
against the property for collection in the same manner as a property tax, pursuant to the provisions of section 364.12, Code of Iowa. (Ord. 1529, 1-21-
1980; amd. 2017 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 78/358
Chapter 2
GARBAGE, REFUSE, RECYCLABLES AND YARD WASTE
ARTICLE A. DEFINITIONS, LICENSING AND GENERAL PROVISIONS
4-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply:
GARBAGE: Waste from the storage, preparation, cooking and serving of food and a normal accumulation of combustible material associated with
household operation.
RECYCLABLES: All types of newspapers and inserts, paperboard, corrugated cardboard, clear glass food and beverage containers, tin and aluminum
cans, plastic milk, water, orange juice and windshield washer fluid jugs (#2HDPE) and other items as deemed necessary by the Public Services
Department and the Sanitation Division.
REFUSE: All refuse not classified as garbage including, but not limited to, both combustible and noncombustible material including paper, wood, wood
furniture, bedding, tin cans, metal, furniture, dirt, glass, crockery, ashes, dead animals and solid industrial and commercial waste. Refuse shall in no way
include garbage as defined herein and as also defined in section 4-2C-1 of this chapter, tires, or containers containing toxic liquids such as paint, paint
thinners, etc.
YARD WASTE: All organic debris (e.g., grass clippings, leaves, tree limbs, bark, branches, flowers, etc.) which is produced as part of yard and garden
development and maintenance. This definition does not include tree stumps. (Ord. 90-28, 12-18-1990; amd. Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993)
4-2A-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
A. License: Every mixed solid waste hauler and every recycler, doing business in the City, shall obtain an annual license to do so; however, no license
shall be required by an employee of the City or one under contract with the City for hauling garbage, refuse, recyclables or yard waste. Such license
shall be issued only after payment of the appropriate annual fee and after examination of the equipment and facilities of the licensee, by the sanitary
inspector, to determine if the licensee is properly equipped to handle solid waste and recyclables in a safe, clean and sanitary manner.
1. Solid waste hauler's license shall entitle the licensee to haul garbage, refuse, yard waste and recyclables. Said license fee is fifty dollars ($50.00).
2. Refuse or recyclable hauler's license shall entitle the licensee to haul refuse, yard waste and recyclables as herein defined and shall not include
permission to haul garbage as herein defined and as also defined in section 4-2C-1 of this chapter. The license fee is twenty five dollars ($25.00).
B. Application: The renewal application documentation shall contain the amounts (tonnages) collected during the previous year of solid waste and
recyclable materials from commercial/industrial accounts for delivery to a resource processing center. The license application must also report the
tonnage of recyclable materials collected on a monthly basis. The City Council is authorized to include any other relevant requirements in the licensing
regulations. Monthly reports listing the tonnage of recyclable materials recycled along with garbage tonnage delivered to the landfill shall be submitted
to the City no later than the tenth day of the month.
Each licensed hauler shall haul the recyclables to the designated recycling processing source and yard waste to a designated compost site or land
apply if done according to State regulations.
C. Mandatory Commercial And Industrial Collection Of Corrugated Cardboard: By virtue of its authority to enforce the Code of Iowa and the laws therein,
the City, in order to gain compliance with the Waste Reduction and Recycling Act, hereby requires solid waste, refuse, rubbish and recycling haulers,
licensed by the City, to provide mandatory collection of corrugated cardboard for their commercial/industrial accounts, and residential accounts, if not
serviced by the City, to remove the corrugated cardboard from commercial/industrial premises as defined in this article for sanitary disposal by the
method of recycling as defined herein and to provide, subject to the following conditions: (Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993)
1. Collection for corrugated cardboard shall be not less than once a week.
2. Collection may be made either from streets or alleys, where existing, at the discretion and direction of the City, with all containers provided by the
contractor to be placed within five feet (5') of the commercial/industrial premises to be served.
3. Owners of commercial and industrial premises shall cooperate in the recycling of solid waste by performing the following, which is regarded as
voluntary (other than corrugated cardboard which is regarded as mandatory):
a. All recyclable materials shall be separated from solid waste and shall be grouped together in a recycling bin.
b. Categories or classes of recyclable material shall include:
(1) Glass: Any clear glass food, beverage or similar container which includes, but is not limited to, fruit jars, jam, and jelly and other similar jars. All
such containers shall be cleaned and rinsed before being placed in containers. Lids may be discarded in a recycle bin or regular garbage.
(2) Paper Products: Glossy magazines and catalogs must be bundled securely with heavy string or placed in brown paper sacks. Newsprint must
be stacked neatly, flattened and tied securely with string or placed in brown paper sacks. Corrugated cardboard only will be accepted which
must be clean and flattened, and taped or tied securely.
(3) Plastics: Plastics such as milk jugs, water jugs or orange juice jugs, or other similar containers. All plastic shall be cleaned and rinsed (and
flattened if necessary) before being placed in a container.
(4) Metal Food And Beverage Containers: Metal food and beverage containers must be clean and have labels removed.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 79/358
c. The following are not considered recyclable materials under this article and shall be disposed of with other nonrecyclable materials.
(1) Glass: All Pyrex glass, window glass, light bulbs, mirrors, broken glass and china.
(2) Paper Products: All waxed paper and waxed cardboard.
(3) Plastics: All styrofoam, plastic food wrap such as Saran Wrap or other similar products, rigid plastic such as fast food containers and insulation.
(Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993; amd. 2017 Code)
4-2A-3: VEHICLES FOR HAULING SOLID WASTE, GARBAGE, REFUSE, RECYCLABLES OR YARD WASTE:
It shall be unlawful to haul or transport solid waste, as defined in section 4-2C-1 of this chapter, garbage, refuse, yard waste or recyclables on any public
way unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded or the load securely covered or encased in containers properly equipped so as to prevent any of its
load from dropping, leaking or otherwise escaping from the vehicle.
Yard waste and recyclables must be separated from garbage, refuse or solid waste as set out by the Cerro Gordo County Solid Waste Agency regulations.
(Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993)
4-2A-4: STORAGE:
No storage of solid waste, garbage, refuse, recyclables or yard waste shall be permitted in vehicles parked in residential districts overnight or on
weekends. (Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993)
4-2A-5: HAULING SOLID WASTE, REFUSE, YARD WASTE OR RECYCLABLES:
Nothing in this chapter is intended to prevent the owner from hauling solid waste, refuse, yard waste or recyclables accumulating on premises of the
owner; provided, such materials are disposed of at the designated Cerro Gordo County Solid Waste Agency landfill or a recyclable processing site in
accordance with this chapter. This chapter does not intend to prevent the owner from hauling yard waste to the landfill or to land apply if done according to
State regulations. (Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993)
4-2A-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision, section or paragraph of this article regarding "mandatory commercial and industrial collection - recyclable waste" or
rules, regulations or resolutions promulgated pursuant hereto, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and/or a Municipal infraction and may be prosecuted as a
misdemeanor or a Municipal infraction, or both. Upon conviction, any violator shall be punished pursuant to title 1, chapter 4, "General Penalty", and title 1,
chapter 4, article A, "Municipal Infractions", of this Code. Each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, should the licensed
hauler continue to violate the terms of this Code, the licensee shall face revocation of said license. (Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993)
ARTICLE B. SANITARY LANDFILLS
4-2B-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply:
AGENCY: The landfill of North Iowa Agency.
GARBAGE: The solid or semisolid animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods including cans,
bottles and cartons in which it was received, and wrappings in which it may be placed for disposal.
NONRESIDENTIAL PREMISES: All types of premises other than residential premises as herein defined, including, but not in limitation of, all premises
used for residential premises containing more than two-family dwelling units, and all premises used for commercial or industrial purposes, and premises
used for mobile home parks.
OWNER: In addition to the record title holder, includes any person residing in, renting, leasing or occupying any premises and as between such parties the
duties, responsibilities, liabilities and obligations hereinafter imposed shall be joint and several.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, syndicate, copartnership, corporation, trust, or other legal entity having proprietary interest in a premises or
other legal entity having responsibility for an act.
RECYCLABLES: All types of newspapers and inserts, paperboard, corrugated cardboard, clear glass food and beverage containers, tin and aluminum
cans, plastic milk, water, orange juice and windshield washer fluid jugs (#2HDPE) and other items as deemed necessary by the Public Services
Department and the Sanitation Division.
REFUSE: All refuse, junk, trash, paper, yard wastes or other substances offensive to sight or smell, or detrimental to the best interests of the community,
except dead animals not killed for food.
RESIDENTIAL PREMISES: All single-family dwellings and two-family dwellings.
SOLID WASTE: Unwanted or discarded materials resulting from commercial, industrial, domestic and agricultural operations and normal community
activities. Wastes which are solid or semisolid containing insufficient liquid to be free flowing are considered to be solid wastes, and include in part the
following: garbage, refuse, ashes and other residue of incineration, street refuse or sweepings, dead animals, solid animal waste, abandoned automobiles,
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 80/358
agricultural, commercial and industrial wastes, construction and demolition wastes and certain sewage treatment solid residue.
YARD WASTES: All organic debris (e.g., grass clippings, leaves, tree limbs, bark, branches, flowers, etc.) which is produced as part of yard and garden
development and maintenance. Does not include tree stumps. (Ord. 1134, 12-7-1970; amd. Ord. 1147, 3-1-1971; Ord. 90-28, 12-18-1990; Ord. 93-16, 8-
17-1993; Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2B-2: SANITARY LANDFILL SITES:
By virtue of contract dated on December 7, 1970, between the City and the agency, the sanitary landfill sites now and hereafter operated by the agency
are hereby designated as the public disposal sites for all garbage, refuse and solid wastes collected within the corporate limits of the City. (Ord. 1134, 12-
7-1970)
4-2B-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The rules and regulations governing the use of the sanitary landfill sites shall be as determined by the agency to be in the best interests of the general
public. The landfill sites shall normally be open to the public on such days and hours as the agency may designate; however, the agency may alter the
days and hours so scheduled to satisfy unusual conditions or emergencies. The agency shall be responsible for the operation of the landfill sites in a
manner which will assure sanitary and safe conditions at all times. Operation of the landfill sites shall comply with all regulations of all local, State, County
or Federal agencies which may have jurisdiction over such operation. (Ord. 1134, 12-7-1970)
4-2B-4: UNLAWFUL DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE:
No person shall permanently dispose of solid wastes of any kind upon any land within the corporate limits of the City unless such land has been
designated by the agency as a public landfill site; provided, however, that the prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to the deposit of inert
wastes not potentially injurious to health or the public welfare where permission to make such a deposit has been obtained from the owner or responsible
agent, nor to the filling in or grading of property with earth, mud, ashes or similar materials, provided all other applicable local and State laws have been
complied with. (Ord. 1134, 12-7-1970)
4-2B-5: POSTED INSTRUCTIONS:
No person shall deposit any solid waste at any agency landfill site except in compliance with posted instructions or instructions of an attendant in charge.
(Ord. 1134, 12-7-1970)
4-2B-6: EXCLUDED SOLID WASTE MATERIALS:
Certain materials may be excluded from those refuse materials which may be deposited at an agency landfill site. These excluded materials include
recyclable materials as defined in section 4-2B-1 of this article and may include junk automobile bodies and similar bulky objects which may require
special processing prior to disposal; trees and tree limbs, unless they have been cut into pieces not exceeding ten feet (10') in length; burning materials
containing hot or live coals; hazardous materials and other materials which the agency deems necessary to exclude. However, hazardous materials may
be deposited upon the receipt of written permission of a responsible official or attendant of the agency and subject to any special instructions issued with
said permission. Hazardous material shall include: explosive materials, materials contaminated by infection or disease, fly ash or other fine material which
may present a special hazard to landfill, personnel, equipment or to the public. (Ord. 93-26, 8-17-1993)
4-2B-7: PAYMENT FOR DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE IN CITY:
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the agency or the City on its behalf, to receive payment of any kind or request payment of any kind for the
disposal of any solid waste at any sanitary landfill site within the City.
The charging of a fee for the collection of any garbage or other solid waste from a customer by a private refuse collector shall not be construed as a
violation of this section since the disposal is considered to be incidental to the total collection and disposal service; provided, however, such collection and
disposal shall be conducted entirely by forces with equipment owned or operated by the private refuse collector. (Ord. 1134, 12-7-1970)
4-2B-8: SCHEDULE OF FEES:
Fees paid to or for the benefit of the agency for the use of the public landfill facilities shall be in accordance with the posted and published schedule of fees
of the agency or the City, as provided in the contract referred to in section 4-2B-2 of this article as follows:
Effective August 2, 1982, a charge in the amount of seventy two cents ($0.72) per month shall be charged by the City and collected from each "residential
premises" or the "owner" of such premises and from each "nonresidential premises" or the "owner" thereof, as said terms are defined in this article. With
respect to residential premises, a separate monthly charge as herein provided shall be made for each separate dwelling unit within a two-family dwelling.
With respect to nonresidential premises which are multiple-family dwellings (i.e., multiple-family dwellings have more than 2 separate family units) and
mobile home parks, a separate monthly charge as herein provided shall be made for each separate family unit within such dwelling and each separate
mobile home site within a mobile home park; provided, however, that the owner of such multiple-family dwelling or mobile home park has made request for
garbage and domestic refuse collection service for such premises by the City in the manner provided for in section 4-2C-9 of this chapter.
The charge herein provided for shall be for the use of the sanitary landfill facilities of the City and such monthly charge shall be billed to the "owner" as
herein defined. (Ord. 1648, 8-2-1982)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 81/358
4-2B-9: PAYMENT OF UNPAID CHARGES:
Bills for landfill charges shall be rendered to public utility consumers by adding to the water and garbage service a statement showing the amount of the
charge or rate for landfill service as herein provided. All landfill charges which are paid in full on or before the fifteenth day after delivery or mailing thereof
shall be eligible for a ten percent (10%) discount, and ten percent (10%) of the gross amount of said bill shall be subtracted therefrom. If any landfill
service bill shall not be paid by the twenty fifth day after the date of delivery or mailing, the property served shall be subject to immediate discontinuance of
service. (Ord. 1641, 7-19-1982; amd. 2017 Code)
4-2B-10: DEPOSITS REQUIRED:
Deposits shall be required for solid waste collection service, at the discretion of the Finance Director as provided for in subsection 6-1A-1D of this Code.
(Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2B-11: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the Police Department and all police officers of the City to enforce the provisions of this article. (Ord. 1134, 12-7-1970)
ARTICLE C. SOLID WASTES
4-2C-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply:
DOMESTIC REFUSE: The types of waste which normally originate in the residential household. It shall typically include, but not be limited to, wastepaper,
rags and clothing. It shall not include dead animals or animal excrement.
GARBAGE: Waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods, including cans, bottles and cartons in which it is received and
wrappings in which it may be placed for disposal.
OWNER: In addition to the record title holder, includes any person residing in, renting, leasing or occupying any premises and as between such parties the
duties, responsibilities, liabilities and obligations hereinafter imposed shall be joint and several.
PERSON: An individual, or group or association of individuals; a firm or any member thereof; a corporation or any executive officer, manager, person in
charge or employee thereof.
RECYCLABLES: All types of newspapers and inserts, paperboard, corrugated cardboard, clear glass food and beverage containers, tin and aluminum
cans, plastic milk, water, orange juice and windshield washer fluid jugs (#2HDPE) and other items as deemed necessary by the Public Works Department
and the Sanitation Division.
RESIDENTIAL PREMISES: All single-family dwellings and two-family dwellings.
SOLID WASTE: Unwanted or discarded materials resulting from commercial, industrial, domestic and agricultural operations and normal community
activities. Wastes which are solid or semisolid containing insufficient liquid to be free flowing are considered to be solid wastes and include in part the
following: refuse, ashes and other residue of incineration, street refuse or sweepings, dead animals, solid animal waste, agricultural, commercial and
industrial wastes, construction and demolition wastes and certain sewage treatment solid residue.
YARD WASTE: All organic debris (e.g., grass clippings, leaves, tree limbs, bark, branches, flowers, etc.) which is produced as part of yard and garden
development and maintenance; does not include tree stumps. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-2: COLLECTION BY CITY:
The City shall collect only garbage, domestic refuse, recyclables and yard waste from all residential premises as hereinabove defined in accordance with
and subject to the provisions of this article.
A. Garbage And Domestic Refuse: Garbage and domestic refuse shall be collected once weekly.
B. Yard Waste:
1. Grass clippings and leaves shall be collected once a week, at the curb, from April 1 through November 30; provided, they are in approved
biodegradable paper bags.
2. Brush and tree limbs shall be collected once a week at the curb. Tree limbs of less than four inches (4") in diameter and brush will be collected,
provided they are placed at the curb, securely tied in bundles not more than four feet (4') in length or eighteen inches (18") in diameter and weigh no
more than fifty (50) pounds. Tree limbs and brush shall not be combined with refuse or garbage for collection. All bundles must be secured with twine
or light string, not wire. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
3. Christmas trees, wreaths and roping will be collected once. All materials must be free of wire and hardware. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996; amd. 2017 Code)
Flocked trees that contain toxic substances or wire will not be picked up. Individuals will be responsible for hauling them to a designated site.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 82/358
C. Recyclables: Recyclables shall be collected once weekly and shall include:
1. Newspapers with inserts, bundled and tied with string or placed in brown paper bags.
2. Clear glass food and beverage containers, rinsed clean with caps and lids removed.
3. Tin and aluminum cans (pop cans, tin soup cans, coffee cans, etc.) rinsed clean with paper labels removed. Aerosol cans cannot be recycled. (Ord.
96-7, 3-5-1996)
4. Plastic milk jugs, water, orange juice and windshield washer fluid jugs (#2HDPE) rinsed clean. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996; amd. 2017 Code)
5. Other items as deemed by the Public Works Department and Sanitation Division.
D. Time Limit: Containers, bags, packages or other solid waste placed at the curb or alley line shall not be placed more than one (1) day in advance of the
scheduled collection day. Yard waste shall be collected once each week from April 1 through November 30 (exception: Christmas trees, wreaths or
ropings). (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-3: CONTAINER SPECIFICATIONS:
Garbage and domestic refuse containers shall not be more than thirty three (33) gallons nor less than ten (10) gallons in normal capacity except, however,
where only one (1) container is used, in which case such container may be less than ten (10) gallons in capacity. Containers shall be waterproof,
rodentproof and fitted with a tight lid. Containers shall have handles, bails or other suitable lifting devices or features. Containers shall be of a type
originally manufactured for garbage or other solid wastes, with tapered sides for easy emptying. They shall be of lightweight and sturdy construction. The
weight of any individual container along with contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. Galvanized iron and similar metal containers, rubber or fiberglass
containers and plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather may be used. Disposal bags manufactured for garbage and solid waste
disposal shall be acceptable. Oil or grease drums, paint cans and similar salvaged containers shall not be acceptable.
Yard waste containers shall be approved biodegradable paper bags and shall not exceed thirty three (33) gallons or fifty (50) pounds.
All garbage and other domestic refuse shall be placed in suitable containers. Large bulky items that cannot be reduced to fit in approved containers will not
be collected. (Ord. 13-20, 6-4-2013)
4-2C-4: TREATMENT PENDING COLLECTION:
All garbage which may attract flies or rodents shall be drained of all excess liquid, securely wrapped in paper and placed in paper bags or otherwise
packaged before it is placed in containers. All garbage shall be packaged in a manner which facilitates the safe and efficient transfer from private
containers and property to collection vehicles with minimum spillage and nuisance. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-5: LOCATION OF CONTAINERS:
The City reserves the right to designate collection from streets or alleys where the same exist. Where alley collections are designated, containers shall be
placed in plain view on the premises adjacent to the alley. Where street collections are designated, containers shall be placed at the curb line. During the
winter season, access to the containers as well as the containers themselves shall be cleared from snow by the owner within a reasonable time after a
snowfall.
Yard waste shall be placed three feet (3') to six feet (6') from garbage or other refuse. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-6: ACCUMULATIONS HAZARDOUS TO HEALTH OR PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate, on any premises, improved or vacant, or on any public place, such quantities of solid waste,
refuse, yard waste or recyclables, in containers or not, which constitute a health or sanitation hazard. It shall also be unlawful for any person to permit to
accumulate quantities of solid waste within or close to any building unless the same are stored in containers in such a manner as not to create a health or
fire hazard. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-7: PUBLIC NUISANCE:
The accumulation of solid waste, refuse, yard waste or recyclables contrary to the provisions of this chapter is hereby declared to constitute a nuisance as
set out in section 4-2C-6 of this article. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-8: PROHIBITED PRACTICE:
Combining yard waste or recyclables with garbage or refuse for removal is prohibited. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-9: PREMISES FROM WHICH REFUSE, GARBAGE, RECYCLABLES AND YARD WASTE COLLECTIONS NOT MADE BY
CITY:
No other types of premises, except "residential premises" as defined herein, shall be eligible to have their garbage or refuse collected by the City; except,
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 83/358
however: a) that owners of apartment dwellings having more than two (2) separate family units may request that the City collect the garbage, domestic
refuse, recyclables and yard waste from such premises, and b) owners of mobile home parks may request that the City collect the garbage, domestic
refuse and yard waste from such premises. In the event such apartment dwellings or mobile home parks are furnished with such collection, then each
separate family unit within such apartment dwellings or mobile home parks shall be considered to be a separate residential premises for the purpose of

The owners of all of the above referred to premises from which collections of refuse, garbage, recyclables or yard waste are not made by the City shall

of the same. Garbage must be taken from dwellings and other private places not collected by the City at least once each week. Garbage must be taken

rule, make different or additional requirements for the removal of garbage as the general welfare of the City may require, and the Public Works Director
may make such rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article which he may deem expedient or necessary for the carrying out of the provisions of
