4-2C-10: HAULING SOLID WASTE, DOMESTIC REFUSE, RECYCLABLES OR YARD WASTE:
Nothing in this article is intended to prevent the owner from hauling solid waste, garbage, domestic refuse, yard waste or recyclables accumulating on
premises of the owner, provided such materials are disposed of. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-11: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the Public Works Director to enforce the provisions of this article. (Ord. 96-7, 3-5-1996)
4-2C-12: CHARGES:
Effective with the July 1, 2019 billing, eleven dollars sixty five cents ($11.65) per month shall be charged by the City and collected from each single-family
dwelling and each separate dwelling unit within a multiple-family dwelling, or owner of a "residential premises" as defined in section 4-2C-1 of this article
serviced by garbage, domestic refuse, recyclables or yard waste collection service as provided for in this chapter. This charge shall be in payment for
collection of one bag per week and one collection of recyclables or yard waste per week as herein set out in section 4-2C-2 of this article. Such monthly
charge shall be billed to the owner as herein directed.
For each additional bag of garbage or refuse, a one dollar twenty cent ($1.20) sticker shall be attached.
The collection of garbage, refuse, recyclables and yard waste, as provided for in this chapter, and maintenance of the availability of such service, whether
or not the owner or occupant of such residential premises, is hereby declared a benefit to the said premises at least equal to the monthly charges specified
in this article. (Ord. 19-07, 6-18-2019)
4-2C-13: PAYMENTS:
Bills for collection service charges shall be rendered to public utility consumers by adding to the water service bill a statement showing the amount of the
charge or rate for garbage service as herein provided. All collection charges which are paid in full on or before the fifteenth day after delivery or mailing
thereof shall be eligible for a ten percent (10%) discount and ten percent (10%) of the gross amount of said bill shall be subtracted therefrom. If any waste
collection service bill shall not be paid by the twenty fifth day after the date of delivery or mailing, the property served shall be subject to the immediate
discontinuance of service. (Ord. 02-12, 4-16-2002)
4-2C-14: DEPOSITS:
Deposits shall be required for collection service at the discretion of the Finance Director as provided for in subsection 6-1A-1D of this Code. (Ord. 96-7, 3-
5-1996)
Chapter 3
DISCHARGE OF WATER INTO SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM
4-3-1: PURPOSE:
In adopting this chapter, the City Council finds that the discharge of water from any roof, surface, ground, sump pump, footing tile or swimming pool or
other natural precipitation into the City sanitary sewer collection system will and has on numerous occasions in the past flooded and overloaded the
sanitary sewer collection system to such an extent as to cause damage to residential property and overloaded the water reclamation facility (WRF). Such
damage is caused by the backup of sewage into the living quarters of residential homes creating a potential health hazard and exceeding the capacity of
the WRF. The City Council, therefore, finds it essential to the maintenance of health, minimization of damage to property and to maintain the life and
capacity of the WRF that the provisions of this chapter be strictly enforced to avoid and minimize these problems in the future. (Ord. 06-8, 4-4-2006)
4-3-2: DEFINITION AND METHOD:
No water from any roof, surface, ground, sump pump, footing tile, swimming pool or other natural precipitation shall be discharged into the sanitary sewer
collection system. Dwellings, including new housing construction or houses under construction, and other buildings and structures which require, because
of the infiltration of water into basements, crawl spaces and the like, a sump pump system to discharge water shall have a permanently installed discharge
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 84/358
line which shall not at any time discharge water into the sanitary sewer collection system. A permanent installation shall be one which provides for a year
round discharge connection to the City subdrain/storm sewer system. If there is no subdrain available, the surface discharge point location shall be
approved by the City Engineer. It shall consist of a rigid discharge line, without valving or quick connections for altering the path of discharge and, if
connected to the City subdrain/storm sewer line, include a check valve. (Ord. 06-8, 4-4-2006)
4-3-3: REQUIREMENTS TO DISCONNECT IMPROPER CONNECTIONS:
Any person, firm or corporation having a roof, surface, ground, sump pump, footing tile or swimming pool now connected and/or discharging into the
sanitary sewer system shall disconnect and/or remove the same. Any disconnects or openings in the sanitary sewer shall be closed or repaired in a
manner as approved by the City Engineer or his or her designee. (Ord. 06-8, 4-4-2006)
4-3-4: ACCESS AND ENTRY FOR INSPECTIONS:
Every person owning real estate or contractor/builder who are building a house within the City of Mason City that discharges into the City's sanitary sewer
system or on the ground shall allow an employee of the City or their designated representative to inspect the buildings to confirm that there is no sump
pump or other prohibited discharge into the sanitary sewer system. Any owner of property or contractor/house builder found to violate this chapter shall
make the necessary changes to comply with this chapter and furnish proof of the changes to the City within sixty (60) days from the date the violation was
identified. Inspections shall be made at a reasonable time and only after reasonable effort has been made to notify the property owner of the need for such
inspection. (Ord. 06-8, 4-4-2006)
4-3-5: FUTURE INSPECTIONS:
At any future time, if the City has reason to suspect that an illegal connection may exist in a premises, the owner, after written notice, shall allow City
representatives to inspect the building. (Ord. 06-8, 4-4-2006)
4-3-6: PENALTY:
A. Whoever shall violate any provision of this chapter for which no specific penalty is provided may be punished as set forth below.
B. Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter, shall be served by the City with written notice stating the nature of the violation and
providing at least sixty (60) days for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently
cease and correct all violations.
C. Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a Municipal infraction and shall be subject to a fine in the amount
of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Each day in which any such violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense.
D. Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the City for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the City by reason
of such violation. The City will also retain any and all civil remedies including, but not limited to, injunction or abatement actions to remedy a violation.
(Ord. 06-8, 4-4-2006)
Title 5
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
ARTICLE A. SIDEWALKS
5-1A-1: PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
It shall be the duty of the City Engineer to submit plans and specifications for permanent sidewalks to the City Council, and the same, upon approval by
the Council, shall be filed with the City Administrator/City Clerk and shall constitute the plans and specifications for all permanent sidewalks thereafter
constructed. It shall be the duty of the City Engineer to recommend changes in such plans and specifications whenever approved building practices
require the same. (1953 Code § 56-2; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997; 2017 Code)
5-1A-2: SIDEWALKS TO CONFORM TO GRADE:
All sidewalks constructed, reconstructed, relaid or repaired shall be in conformity with the plans and specifications therefor on file with the City
Administrator/City Clerk and shall conform to the established grade therefor, and all such work shall be done under the supervision and control of the City
Engineer. The City Engineer shall furnish all design specifications for such walks. (1953 Code § 56-2; amd. Ord. 97-29, 11-18-1997; 2017 Code)
5-1A-3: MAINTENANCE OBLIGATION OF ABUTTING PROPERTY OWNER:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 85/358
The abutting property owner shall maintain the sidewalk in a safe condition, in a state of good repair, and free from defects. The abutting property owner
may be liable for damages caused by failure to maintain the sidewalk. (2017 Code)
5-1A-4: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION:
All sidewalks must be constructed by licensed sidewalk contractors as set forth in title 3, chapter 12 of this Code, of the type approved by and in
accordance with the specifications of the City Engineer. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1A-5: RESOLUTION AND NOTICE FOR INSTALLATION OF SIDEWALKS:
The City Council may, by resolution, order the construction or the installation of permanent sidewalks in front of or along any piece of property abutting
upon any street or alley in the same manner as set out for any public improvement pursuant to sections 364.12 and 384.38, Code of Iowa. (1953 Code
§ 56-4; amd. 1985 Code)
5-1A-6: SIDEWALK REPAIRS; INSPECTION AND NOTICE:
It shall be the duty of the City Engineer to inspect or cause to be inspected all public sidewalks within the City and whenever the same shall become out of
repair, the City Engineer shall cause notice to be given to the owner, as shown by the records of the County Auditor, of the property abutting said public
sidewalk, such notice requiring said property owner to repair, replace or reconstruct said sidewalk, such notice to be given by certified mail in such form as
prescribed in section 364.12, Code of Iowa. (Ord. 1045, 5-6-1968; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
5-1A-7: ASSESSMENT OF COST OF SIDEWALK REPAIRS:
In the event the sidewalk repairs, as specified in the notice provided for in section 5-1A-6 of this article, are not completed within thirty (30) days of the date
of the deposit in the mail, by certified mail, of said notice to the property owner, the City Council may cause, in that event, such repair, replacement or
reconstruction to be done and assess the expense thereof against the property in front of which such repair, replacement or reconstruction is made, and
the same shall be certified to the County Auditor and collected with other taxes as set out in section 364.12, Code of Iowa. (Ord. 1045, 5-6-1968; amd.
1985 Code)
ARTICLE B. DRIVEWAYS; CUTTING CURBS
5-1B-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
A. No curb shall be cut or changed and no parking or public property shall be used for a driveway without first obtaining a permit therefor from the City
Engineer, provided the application therefor conforms to this article and to all other provisions of this Code, as set out in section 364.12, Code of Iowa.
(1953 Code § 59-1; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
B. The permit fee shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) for new installation, repair or replacement of a driveway approach and twenty dollars ($20.00) for curb
sawing or curb grinding and payable at the time said permit is issued; and the same shall be issued in duplicate, one (1) copy being given to the
applicant and one (1) filed in the Engineering Office. The permit shall show the name of the applicant, the exact location of the construction, and such
other information as the City Engineer may require. (2017 Code)
5-1B-2: FILING OF PLAN REQUIRED:
Before any such permit shall be granted, the applicant therefor shall file with the City Engineer a plat and plan of the area to be improved, which said plan
shall be accurately drawn to scale of not less than one-eighth inch to one foot (1/8" = 1') and with all principal dimensions shown. Such plan shall show the
location of all existing walks, curbs and the relative elevation of the gutters, the top of the curb and the sidewalk, all existing trees, their size and kind, fire
hydrants, water shutoff boxes, storm sewer inlets, street light poles and conduits and any other structures existing on or in the street adjacent to the
property, and shall also show the proposed location of tanks, buildings, air hose, wash racks, oil pits, pump islands and all other equipment which applicant
proposes to install on said property, together with the distance from such equipment to the street line and all proposed improvements to be installed;
provided, however, that no plat or plan shall be required for a private driveway twenty six feet (26') or less in width. (1953 Code § 59-2; amd. 1985 Code;
2017 Code)
5-1B-3: NUMBER AND SIZE OF DRIVEWAY APPROACHES:
There shall not be more than two (2) driveway approaches on any one (1) street frontage of one hundred eighty five feet (185') or less, nor more than
three (3) driveway approaches for any one (1) street frontage of over one hundred eighty five feet (185').
No driveway approach for any commercial or industrial property shall be less than twenty feet (20') nor more than forty five feet (45') in width measured at
the property line, nor more than fifty five feet (55') in width measured at the curb line.
No driveway approach for any residential property shall be more than twenty six feet (26') in width measured at the property line, nor more than thirty six
feet (36') in width measured at the curb line.
A safety zone between driveway approaches shall not be less than ten feet (10') measured at the curb line.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 86/358
A safety zone between a driveway approach and an alley approach shall not be less than ten feet (10') measured at the curb line.
No driveway approach shall be closer than twenty feet (20') to the extended curb lines of any intersecting streets.
In no event shall the curb cut for a driveway approach extend more than five feet (5') beyond the extended property line of the property being served by
this driveway. No driveway approach shall be within five feet (5') of an intersecting sidewalk or crosswalk at the property line. (Ord. 98-13, 10-20-1998;
amd. 2017 Code)
5-1B-4: PAVING OF DRIVEWAY APPROACH:
All driveway approaches shall be paved with either portland cement concrete or asphaltic cement concrete according to the Mason City standard
specifications. All driveway approaches shall be complete from the street gutter or curbing to the property line and include a portland cement concrete
sidewalk section as specified by the City Engineer. (Ord. 98-13, 10-20-1998; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1B-5: SIDEWALK AS PART OF DRIVEWAY APPROACH:
No driveway which is also a part of the public walk shall have a longitudinal slope greater than one-half inch (1/2") per foot, and no grade of walk shall be
changed so as to make the walk less than six inches (6") above the adjacent gutter. The surface of such walk shall be of a rough finish so as to prevent
slipping. (1953 Code § 59-5)
5-1B-6: CURBS:
A. When a distance from the inside curb line to the outside private property line is ten feet (10') or more, the driveway shall end at the curb line with a flare
having a radius of not less than five feet (5') and which flare shall be tangent to both the driveway and the street curb at the point of intersection. When
the distance from the inside curb line to the outside private property line is less than ten feet (10'), the driveway shall end at the curb line with a flare
having a radius equal to the distance from the inside curb line to the outside private property line minus five feet (5'). In lieu of the radius as above
described, the driveway may be flared on a straight line; provided, that the flared distance does not exceed the limits herein fixed for radii.
B. Sidewalk grades shall not be changed except as provided herein.
C. The tangent curb of any driveway shall at no time make an angle of less than forty five degrees (45°) measured from the street curb. (1953 Code § 59-
6; amd. Ord. 742-1, 3-4-1957; 2017 Code)
5-1B-7: EQUIPMENT SET BACK FROM STREET:
All pumps, oil pits, wash racks and islands, if set parallel with the street line, shall be at least twelve feet (12') from the edge of the property line, and if set
at other than right angles or parallel with the street line, same shall be fifteen feet (15') or more from the property line. All such equipment shall be so
placed that vehicles will not be stopped upon sidewalk or street while being serviced. Where visible type pumps are used, they must be installed upon an
island at least six inches (6") high and thirty inches (30") wide. (1953 Code § 59-7)
5-1B-8: DRAINAGE:
The drainage from all buildings and paved areas, wherever practicable, shall be so arranged as not to flow across a public sidewalk or onto adjoining
private or public properties. Where storm sewer connections are available, connections thereto shall be made; or whenever storm sewer connections
become available, then the same shall be made within sixty (60) days after becoming available. (1953 Code § 59-8; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1B-9: UTILITIES IN STREETS:
Wherever there may be encountered in the street or parking, Municipally owned cables, services, poles, water mains or other Municipally owned utilities,
the applicant shall obtain the written permission of the interested Municipal department for any changes necessary therein, and the reasonable expenses
and cost of all such changes shall be paid by the applicant. (1953 Code § 59-9)
5-1B-10: APPROVAL BY CITY ENGINEER:
Driveways and curbs lying on City property shall be of a type approved by and in accordance with the specifications of the City Engineer. (1953 Code § 59-
10; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1B-11: APPROACH FOR DRIVEWAYS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property in connection with a driveway thereon to use a wooden or metal approach extending from the
street to the top of the curb, regardless of whether the same clamps over the top of the curb or not, and it shall also be unlawful for any person to place
dirt, ashes or other material in the gutter next to the curb for the purpose of building up an approach for a driveway. Temporary driveway approaches within
the right-of-way shall be approved by the City Engineer. (1953 Code § 59-11; amd. 2017 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 87/358
ARTICLE C. OBSTRUCTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS
5-1C-1: DEFINITIONS:
In addition to their usual meanings, the following definitions shall apply to the terms used in this article:
AREAWAY: Any opening for stairs or any ramp or other means of ingress or egress from the street, alley or sidewalk level to any cellar or basement or any
part of a building below the level of the street, alley or sidewalk.
ENCROACHMENT: Any areaway, excavation, obstruction, opening or structure.
PUBLIC PROPERTY: Any street, highway, boulevard, avenue, alley, sidewalk, parkway, public place, plaza, mall or other real property owned or controlled
by the City, as set out in section 384.37, Code of Iowa. (1985 Code)
5-1C-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall construct, use or maintain under, in, upon or over the surface of any public property in the City any encroachment such as a chimney,
areaway, stairway, walkway, platform, step, area, railing, grate, vault, opening, room, sign, canopy, marquee, sidewalk cafe or any other encroachment
unless and until a permit, as applicable, is obtained from the City to construct, use or maintain such encroachment, except that no person shall construct,
use or maintain nor shall a permit be issued for any sign, marquee or awning which extends over the surface of any public property unless the City has
issued a permit for said encroachment in the manner specified in title 10, chapter 2, article G of this Code. No such permit shall be required, however, for
the erection and maintenance of a privately owned and maintained mailbox, where required and approved by the United States Postal Service, or for any
newspaper delivery receptacles when installed by any person who publishes a newspaper of general circulation as defined by Iowa law, for and at the
request of or by subscribers to the newspaper so long as the receptacles do not encroach in, upon or over the traveled portion of the public way. Trees,
when placed on public property in accordance with the requirements set forth in chapter 3 of this title, shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this
article. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1C-3: NUISANCES:
This article shall not be construed as authorizing the creation or maintenance of a nuisance. (1985 Code)
5-1C-4: DUTIES OF PERMIT HOLDER:
A. Damages: Any damage occurring in consequence of the creation, use or maintenance of any of the encroachments described in this article or, by
reason of any defect therein, shall be paid by the person using or maintaining such encroachment. (1985 Code)
B. Barricades: No person placing or causing any obstruction of any kind in any street, alley or public ground shall fail or neglect to secure the same by an
enclosure or barricades to cause the opening, excavation or obstruction to be protected and distinctly visible. Compliance with all Federal and State of
Iowa accessibility guidelines shall be followed. Any obstructions such as, but not limited to, barricades and signage placed in the right-of-way shall be
in compliance with the latest version of the MUTCD (Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices). (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1C-5: INSPECTIONS:
Any City employee having jurisdiction is authorized to inspect at any time the different encroachments mentioned in this article. (1985 Code; amd. 2017
Code)
5-1C-6: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
Any City employee having jurisdiction is hereby authorized to enter such areas for any purpose in connection with the legitimate use of such public
property. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1C-7: EXEMPTIONS:
Nothing in this article shall be held in any way to regulate the maintenance of manholes, pits or covers in connection with the construction and operation of
any water, telephone, gas or electric connections, pipes or conduits nor shall anything in this article be held to apply to the use of any public property of the
City by fire escapes or public service corporations wherein such right has been granted by the City. (1953 Code § 60A-3; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1C-8: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
All encroachment permit applications shall be subject to the following requirements:
A. Prerequisite To Granting:
1. No permit required under this article shall be granted for any encroachment until the required fee(s) have been paid, and until an application with
complete plans shall have been filed with the City and approved by the City Council, following review by the Planning and Zoning Administrator and
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 88/358
the City Engineer.
2. No permit shall be granted for any encroachment when it would unreasonably conflict with the rights of travel which the general public has on any
public property or would create a hazard to the movement of people or vehicles unless specifically permitted by the City Council.
3. If said applicant does not agree with the decision, the application may then be submitted to the City Council for consideration.
B. Grant; Contents: All permits required by this article shall be granted by the City Council and shall contain the name of the person securing the permit,
the date granted, the number, size and location of the encroachment and when deemed necessary, a lease, the duration and cost of which to be
determined by the City Council following review and recommendation by the City Engineer.
C. Permit Granted On Condition City Held Harmless: In granting a permit under this article, the party receiving the same shall be deemed to have agreed
to hold and shall hold the City harmless from and indemnified against all damages arising from or growing out of the construction, use or maintenance
of the encroachment. Any person who publishes a newspaper of general circulation as defined by Iowa law and who installs delivery receptacles for
such newspaper in accordance with the terms of section 5-1C-2 of this article, shall be deemed to have agreed to hold and shall hold the City harmless
from and indemnified against all damages arising from or growing out of the installation, placement, use or maintenance of such receptacles.
D. Insurance: Before granting a permit under this article, the City Council may require liability insurance in an amount satisfactory to the City and sufficient
to hold the City harmless from and indemnified against all damages arising from or growing out of the construction, use or maintenance of such
encroachment, when, in the judgment of the City Council, the public interest may require it.
E. Suspension Or Revocation Of Permits; Removal Of Encroachments: Upon determination by the building official, City Engineer or other duly authorized
agent, that an encroachment is unsafe for persons or property, is in such a state of repair as to render it useless, or when the encroachment becomes
loathsome to the senses, the City Council may, in its discretion:
1. Order suspension of the permits until such time that improvements are completed to the satisfaction of the City Council. If said improvements are not
completed within sixty (60) days, said permit shall be revocable.
2. Order revocation of the permit for said encroachment. The City Council may order removal within thirty (30) days after the issuance of written notice
of the revocation to the person maintaining the encroachment. If the encroachment is not removed within thirty (30) days, the City Council shall order
the same abated as a nuisance and shall cause the cost thereof to be assessed against the property of the permit grantee.
The City Council has the right to revoke any encroachment permit at any time. Reasons to revoke a permit may include: If the encroachment creates
conflicts with an aboveground or belowground existing or planned public utility extension, future street widening or extension or any City construction
activity.
F. Notice Of Revocation: A copy of the resolution revoking the permit required by this article shall be mailed to the person using or maintaining such
encroachment. The City Clerk shall mail a copy of the resolution revoking such permit to such person at the address shown in the permit.
G. Removal Of Encroachment; Penalty: Any encroachment, constructed or maintained without securing the permit required by section 5-1C-2 of this
article, shall constitute a public nuisance and shall be ordered abated by the City Council. The cost shall be assessed against the property of the
person constructing, using or maintaining, or causing to be constructed, used or maintained, any encroachment in connection with the real property
owned, leased or occupied by the person in violation of this article, who shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
H. Expiration Of Permits: Permits granted under the provisions of this article shall expire and become null and void if the construction or placement of the
obstruction or encroachment is not commenced within six (6) months of the date of such permit, or if said construction or placement is suspended or
abandoned for a period of six (6) months or more after work has commenced. (1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1C-9: PERMIT FEES:
A. Any person constructing, maintaining or using any area, vault, room or any other encroachment, except as listed in section 5-1C-2 of this article under,
upon or in any part of any public property, shall obtain a permit therefor from the City and shall pay to the City a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for
said permit and when required, additional lease fees. Said fee(s) shall be collected by the City at the time of issuance of the permit. (1985 Code; amd.
2017 Code)
B. Encroachments existing at the time of adoption of this section shall be exempt from permit fee payments.
C. Religious organizations shall be exempt from the payment of fees required by this article for property directly used by them for church or hospital
purposes. Charitable and benevolent organizations shall likewise be exempt from the payment of such fees for the temporary use of streets and alleys
for construction purposes, upon application and approval by the City Council. Any person who publishes a newspaper of general circulation, as defined
by Iowa law, and which installs delivery receptacles for such newspaper in accordance with the terms of section 5-1C-2 of this article pertaining thereto,
shall likewise be exempt from the payment of the fees required by this article. (1985 Code)
5-1C-10: TEMPORARY ENCROACHMENTS:
A. Dumpsters In Public Right-Of-Way:
1. Definitions:
ALLEY: A thoroughfare laid out, established and platted as such, by constituted authority.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 89/358
DUMPSTER: Any solid waste container not eligible for disposal by the City Sanitation Department.
DUMPSTER PERMIT: Any thirty (30) day permit issued by the Engineering Department for placement of a dumpster on a roadway.
OWNER: The owner of the dumpster.
ROADWAY: The entire width between property lines of a way designated as a public street when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as
a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic. (An alley is not considered a roadway.)
SUBSEQUENT DUMPSTER PERMIT: A permit issued within ninety (90) days of a previously issued permit for use at the same address.
2. Temporary Encroachment: A dumpster placed in a roadway shall be considered a temporary encroachment.
3. Liability Insurance: A dumpster shall not be placed in public right-of-way unless the owner of the dumpster has filed with the City Clerk a certificate of
insurance showing coverage of not less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence for
damages to property or injuries to persons that may be caused by the presence of the dumpster in the public right-of-way. The City shall be an
additional insured on the policy. The owner of a dumpster that has damaged public property during placement or removal, shall reimburse the City for
said damages. (Ord. 05-32, 11-15-2005)
4. Approval Of Dumpster Placed In Right-Of-Way: The owner of the dumpster shall contact the City Engineer, or designee, and request that a dumpster
be placed in the City right-of-way. The owner shall provide the proposed dumpster location, intended use, size, time frame needed and any other
information necessary. If approved, the City Engineer, or designee, will grant permission for the owner to place the dumpster in the City right-of-way.
(2017 Code)
5. Dumpster Permits: Except as hereinafter provided, a dumpster shall not be placed or remain in a roadway unless the owner has a valid dumpster
permit from the Engineering Department.
a. Permit Application: The completed application for a permit to place a dumpster on the public right-of-way shall be made by the owner of the
dumpster or the owner's designee to the Engineering Department on a form available from the department. The application must be accompanied
by a sketch showing the approximate location of the dumpster.
b. Fees: The fee for a thirty (30) day dumpster permit shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). Subsequent fees for each permit will be an additional twenty
dollars ($20.00) per thirty (30) days.
c. Issuance Of Permit: Dumpster permits shall be for a period of thirty (30) days. No more than two (2) subsequent thirty (30) day dumpster permits
shall be issued for the same address within any given calendar year. The City Engineer or designee reserves the right to waive the maximum of
two (2) subsequent permits. The City Engineer or designee may deny the permit application or revoke a permit after issuance if there is
noncompliance with any of the requirements of this section or if a health or safety concern arises.
6. Dumpster Safety Provisions: Dumpsters placed in the roadway shall not need a permit if they meet the following criteria:
a. On public rights-of-way, including both streets and alleys, both ends of any dumpster facing oncoming traffic shall have Department of
Transportation certified reflective tape. Reflective tape shall have a width of two inches (2"). The reflective tape shall run in a continuous line or in a
breaking pattern covering at least fifty percent (50%) of the perimeter of the ends and located as close to the extreme edges of the ends as
possible.
b. Dumpsters placed in the roadway shall be placed not more than twelve inches (12") from the curb, or, in the absence of a curb, from the edge of
the traveled way and shall not extend more than nine feet (9') out from the curb or, in the absence of a curb, from the edge of the traveled way.
c. Dumpsters placed in a roadway shall not be placed closer than thirty feet (30') from any intersection or alley or provide a visibility barrier for the
traveling public.
d. Dumpsters placed in a public right-of-way shall comply with all traffic restrictions applicable to motor traffic.
e. The dumpster shall not remain in the roadway longer than fourteen (14) days.
f. There shall be at least sixteen feet (16') of traveled way available along the traveled side of any dumpster placed in a roadway.
g. A dumpster placed in the public right-of-way shall not block a sidewalk.
7. Removal Of Dumpster:
a. The City Engineer or designee may, if he/she determines that the location or condition of the dumpster is a health or safety risk, require the
removal of a dumpster from any public right-of-way within twenty four (24) hours.
b. The City Engineer or designee may, if he/she determines that the owner of the dumpster has not complied with the requirements under subsection
A6 of this section, require removal or relocation of the dumpster.
8. Fines: Any owner of a dumpster in violation of the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, pay a fine of two
hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 05-32, 11-15-2005)
ARTICLE D. CONTROLLED ACCESS FACILITIES
5-1D-1: DEFINITION:
CONTROLLED ACCESS FACILITY: A highway or street specially designed for through traffic and over, from or to which owners or occupants of abutting
land, or other persons, have no right of easement or only a controlled right of easement for access, light, air or view by reason of the fact that their property
abuts upon such controlled access facility or for any other reason. Such highways or streets may be freeways open to use by all customary forms of street
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 90/358
and highway traffic or they may be parkways from which trucks, buses or other commercial vehicles shall be excluded. (Ord. 765, 1-20-1958; amd. 1985
Code)
5-1D-2: AUTHORITY FOR CONTROL OF ACCESS:
The provisions of this article relating to control of access shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the City of Mason City pursuant to chapter
306, Code of Iowa, for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety and for the promotion of the general welfare. (Ord. 765, 1-20-1958; amd.
1985 Code)
5-1D-3: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is now on file in the Office of the City Clerk a list of controlled access facilities as established by the Iowa Department of Transportation and the City
of Mason City. (Ord. 765, 1-20-1958; amd. 1985 Code)
5-1D-4: REGULATION OF ACCESS:
No person shall have any right of ingress or egress to, from or across the controlled access facilities hereby established except at existing points of
access, or at points hereinafter designated or at such points as may be hereafter jointly designated by the Iowa Department of Transportation. (Ord. 765,
1-20-1958)
5-1D-5: POINTS OF ACCESS DEFINED:
The points of access shall consist of accessways from abutting property to the adjacent traffic lane or roadway and their locations and widths shall be in
compliance with the Iowa Department of Transportation's access agency for urban areas. (Ord. 765, 1-20-1958; amd. 1985 Code)
5-1D-6: UNLAWFUL USE OF CONTROLLED ACCESS FACILITIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to:
A. Drive a vehicle over, upon or across any curb, central dividing section or other separation or dividing line on such controlled access facilities.
B. Make a left turn or a semicircular or U-turn except through an opening provided for that purpose in the dividing curb section, separation or line.
C. Drive any vehicle except in the proper lane provided for that purpose and in the proper direction and to the right of the central dividing curb, separation
section or line.
D. Drive any vehicle onto any controlled access facility from a local service road except through an opening provided for that purpose in the dividing
section or dividing line which separates such service road from the controlled access facility property. (Ord. 765, 1-20-1958)
ARTICLE E. STREETLIGHT INSTALLATION
5-1E-1: DEFINITIONS:
LONG BLOCK: Any block longer than five hundred feet (500'), measured from center of street to center of street.
LONG CUL-DE-SAC: Any cul-de-sac longer than three hundred fifty feet (350'), measured from center of street to center line of cul-de-sac radius.
STREETLIGHT: A light placed within the street right-of-way for the purpose of providing lighting for the safety of vehicular traffic. (Ord. 97-9, 3-18-1997)
5-1E-2: CRITERIA FOR INSTALLATION:
Streetlights may be installed at all street intersections or as near to the midblock as practical of a long block or at the end of a long cul-de-sac. (Ord. 97-9,
3-18-1997)
5-1E-3: TYPES OF LIGHTING:
All streetlights shall conform to City standards. The following list identifies the possible types of luminaires and the approved mounting height and pole type
that may be used in the City. All other combinations need written approval from the City Engineer. (Ord. 97-9, 3-18-1997)
Wattage Luminaire Type Mounting Height Pole Type
80 Roadway light LED 25 feet Wood
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 91/358
108 Roadway light LED 25 feet Wood
135 Roadway light LED 25 feet Wood
270 Roadway light LED 25 feet Wood
44 Pole topper LED 20 feet Fiberglass
45 Pole topper LED 20 feet Fiberglass
Note: LED means light emitting diode.
(Ord. 97-9, 3-18-1997; amd. 2017 Code)
5-1E-4: APPROVAL PROCESS:
A. If a streetlight request meets the criteria requirements in section 5-1E-2 of this article, the approval process concludes with a petition. The affected area
would be determined by the City Engineer and would include all properties with frontage abutting the affected street(s). Petitions shall be considered
according to the following criteria:
1. Each adjoining property shall be allowed one (1) vote;
2. The vote for each property shall be awarded according to the majority of owners of record on that property;
3. A simple majority shall dictate installation of a light;
4. A tie vote shall nullify the request for installation.
B. Once a legal petition is received and acted upon, a six (6) month period would need to elapse before an additional petition to reverse the action would
be accepted. (Ord. 97-9, 3-18-1997)
5-1E-5: INSTALLATION:
The streetlight shall be placed within the street right-of-way at street intersections, midblocks of long blocks, or at the end of a long cul-de-sac. Lights are
to be placed at the lot lines nearest the midblock of long blocks as practical or the end of long cul-de-sacs. All lights shall be staggered from one (1) side of
the street to the other where possible. (Ord. 97-9, 3-18-1997)
ARTICLE F. COMMERCIAL USE OF PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY
5-1F-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following definitions shall apply:
FOOD-PRIMARY ESTABLISHMENT: A business where the service of food, as opposed to liquor, is the primary focus of the business and which meets the
following criteria:
A. Serves meals prepared on the premises for consumption on the premises;
B. Has a food service menu from which customers may order;
C. Has an employee whose primary duty is the preparation of food and an employee whose primary duty is to serve food to customers;
D. Has a kitchen separate from the bar equipped with all of the following: a stove, a griddle, a grill or broiler, and a food refrigeration unit with a capacity
in excess of twenty (20) cubic feet;
E. Operates the restaurant service during at least sixty percent (60%) of the hours that the business is open to the public; and
F. Holds itself out to be a restaurant and advertises itself as a restaurant if it advertises;
G. Includes a cafe, cafeteria, coffee shop, delicatessen, ice cream shop, lunchroom or tearoom;
H. May also offer alcohol for sale on premises so long as the primary function of the business is to serve food.
LIQUOR-PRIMARY ESTABLISHMENT: An establishment where the service of alcoholic beverages directly to the public, as opposed to food, is the
primary focus of the business.
PEDESTRIAN: Any person traveling on foot or wheelchair.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 92/358
PUBLIC PLAZA: A publicly owned open area, unobstructed from the ground to the sky, that is bounded on not more than three (3) sides by the exterior
walls of one (1) or more buildings.
PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY: Any public street, alley, roadway, sidewalk, walkway, right-of-way or public way designed for vehicular, bicycle or pedestrian
travel and dedicated to public use.
SIDEWALK: The improved portion of public right-of-way dedicated to pedestrian circulation.
SIDEWALK SALES: The use of the public sidewalk or a public plaza for the display and sale of merchandise.
SIDEWALK SERVICE AREA: An outdoor area located temporarily on a public sidewalk or public plaza contiguous with and having direct access to any
building wherein a food-primary establishment or a liquor-primary establishment is located, and where food or beverages are taken for consumption by
persons sitting or standing at tables in that area. (2017 Code)
5-1F-2: USE OF PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY RESTRICTED:
Use of public right-of-way or of a public plaza for any commercial purpose shall be unlawful except as specifically authorized by this Code. (2017 Code)
5-1F-3: USE FOR SIDEWALK SERVICE AREA:
A permit for a sidewalk service area may be issued subject to the following conditions:
A. Usable Area:
1. A sidewalk service area may not extend onto the sidewalk in a manner that will not allow a minimum of five feet (5') of unobstructed sidewalk
adjacent to the street for pedestrian use, nor extend into a public plaza in a manner that will not allow an unobstructed twenty foot (20') fire lane.
2. No tables and chairs shall be placed in street corner areas defined by building lines extended to the street, and no closer than ten feet (10') from an
alley.
3. The area for a sidewalk service area shall be delineated during the hours of operation by ropes or some other suitable method which shall be clearly
visible to pedestrians. If required by the City Council, tables, chairs and other items are not required to be removed at the end of each day's
operation unless required as a condition of approval by the City Council, provided that all items are secure from unauthorized removal or impact from
wind or weather. No materials shall be stored on the public right-of-way.
4. A sidewalk service area may not utilize any public amenities such as benches, seats, tables or trash receptacles.
5. No person shall sell or display merchandise, or permit the sale or display of merchandise, under this subsection until he or she has first obtained
liability insurance or an amendment or rider to an existing liability insurance policy insuring the said person and the City and its officers and
employees, against liability which might arise out of the display or sale of merchandise by such person upon the public right-of-way or public plaza, in
an amount at least equal to the maximum statutory liability of the City, its officers and employees. The City, together with its officers and employees,
shall be named as additional insured in the said liability insurance policy, and shall meet all other requirements established by the City.
B. Days And Hours Of Operation:
1. The sidewalk service area may be operated and used any time of the year. Outdoor heating units, if used, must meet all applicable Building and Fire
Codes.
2. Sidewalk service areas shall be set up and operated each day only between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
The City Council may, as part of the initial permit approval, impose more restrictive hours.
C. Sidewalk Service Area Permit Required:
1. Establishments must apply for and obtain a sidewalk service area permit from the City prior to operation. Each applicant shall file an initial
application with the Development Services Director, on forms provided by the City and containing all pertinent information as the City may require,
and shall agree to abide by State and local laws governing use of public right-of-way. Establishments dispensing any alcoholic beverage must do so
under State and local law.
2. An initial sidewalk service area permit shall be reviewed by the City Council. The Council may impose conditions upon the use of public property to
ensure protection of the public health, safety and general welfare.
3. A sidewalk service area permit shall be issued in conjunction with yearly renewals of alcoholic beverage licenses/permits, or one (1) year from the
date of issuance for establishments not dispensing alcohol. The initial application may be less than the one (1) year period to coincide with existing
alcoholic beverage licenses/permits, and will require full payment.
4. Annual renewals shall be reviewed by the Development Services Director. If the sidewalk service area continues to operate in accordance with the
initial permit, the renewal shall be granted. The Development Services Director may impose any conditions he/she deems necessary to minimize the
impact of the sidewalk service area on neighboring properties and to ensure that the sidewalk service area does not pose a threat to public health
and safety. If the Development Services Director determines that the operation, scope or area of the sidewalk service area have changed
significantly from that approved in the initial permit, he/she may require the owner or operator to submit a new permit for review by the City Council.
5. An annual fee for a sidewalk service area permit shall be established by Council resolution.
6. An applicant for a sidewalk service area who intends to serve alcoholic beverages must file an application for and obtain an outdoor service area
permit from the State of Iowa.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 93/358
7. The City shall retain the right to terminate the sidewalk service area permit but only after written notice of violation has been given and the time to
cure the violation has expired. Grounds for termination of the sidewalk service area permit shall include, but not be limited to, violations of the State
and local liquor control laws, violations of the sidewalk service area permit, and creating a safety hazard, health hazard and/or public nuisance under
State or local law. Additionally, the City retains the right to terminate the sidewalk service area permit and direct removal of sidewalk service area
operations if, after deliberation, the City Administrator determines there is a substantial and reasonable need for use of the public right-of-way for a
valid public purpose.
8. The use of public right-of-way permitted shall in no way interfere with access to public or City utilities located and/or operated within the City's public
right-of-way. In addition, each applicant shall be required to provide a certificate of insurance satisfactory to the City, and shall agree to hold the City
harmless against any and all liability arising from interruptions, accidents or other actions arising from the sidewalk cafe operation or location in the
public right-of-way.
9. No person shall establish, operate, or be issued a permit for a sidewalk service area under this subsection until he or she has first obtained liability
insurance or an amendment or rider to an existing liability insurance policy insuring the said person and the City and its officers and employees,
against liability which might arise out of the display or sale of merchandise by such person upon the public right-of-way in an amount of at least one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) cumulative. Failure to obtain such insurance shall be a
misdemeanor violation of this Code. The City, together with its officers and employees, shall be named as additional insured in the said liability
insurance policy, and shall meet all other requirements established by the City.
D. Operation Of Sidewalk Service Area:
1. The City retains the right to limit the number of sidewalk service areas in subsection A of this section.
2. Other than signs permitted in title 12 of this Code, signs shall not be permitted in the sidewalk cafe area except on chairs, tables, umbrellas or other
amenities, as approved by the City. The amenities used in the sidewalk cafe area shall be maintained in good condition.
3. The sidewalk serving area must be arranged to allow for access to building entrances. No blockage of building entrances or exits shall be permitted
in a sidewalk cafe area.
4. Additional restroom capacity may be required to comply with local Building and Housing Codes.
5. Occupancy limits shall be determined as set forth in title 10, "Building Regulations", of this Code.
6. Sidewalk service areas shall be subject to inspection at least annually or at any other time at the direction of the City.
7. A sidewalk service area operated by a liquor-primary establishment must have an employee monitoring the area at all times during the hours liquor
is consumed.
8. "Bring your own bottle of liquor" (BYOB) is not allowed in any sidewalk service area. Any alcoholic beverage possessed or consumed in the sidewalk
service area must have been sold by the sidewalk service area permit holder.
9. The sidewalk service area permit holder shall be responsible for trash removal and must maintain the area and surrounding five feet (5') in a clean
and litter free manner during all hours of operation, and shall restore the area and surrounding five feet (5') to its normal condition as a
pedestrianway and litter free after operation each day.
10. The operation of any sidewalk service area shall be in conformity with all applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations. (2017 Code)
5-1F-4: USE FOR SIDEWALK SALES:
Any person, partnership, firm or corporation (person) that operates a retail business in Mason City may, with advance written notice to the Director of the
Development Services Department (Director), use a limited part of a sidewalk or plaza that immediately adjoins the premises of such retail business for the
display and sale of its merchandise. The Director may impose additional reasonable restrictions upon, or withdraw approval of, the use of any sidewalk or
public plaza for retail sales where necessary in his or her judgment to protect the public health, safety and general welfare or to prevent a nuisance from
developing or continuing.
A. The display and/or sale of merchandise shall not be permitted in any portion of the sidewalk or public plaza where normal pedestrian traffic flow is
obstructed.
B. No display racks, tables or other equipment of any kind shall be placed, or permitted to remain, on the sidewalk or public plaza during any period when
merchandise is not displayed and available for purchase. While such merchandise is displayed or available for purchase, all racks, tables and other
equipment shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition.
C. The use of a portion of the sidewalk or public plaza for retail display or sale shall not be an exclusive use. All public improvements including, but not
limited to, trees, light poles, traffic signals, pull boxes or manholes, or any public initiated maintenance procedures or work, shall take precedence over
the use of the public sidewalk at all times. The merchandise and display racks, tables and equipment shall be removed from the sidewalk or public
plaza immediately to permit such public initiated maintenance procedures or work.
D. No alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on the sidewalk or public plaza at any time in connection with the sidewalk sale.
E. This section applies to and permits only the sale and display of merchandise and goods, and does not permit the sale, display or provision of services
on the sidewalk or public plaza. This section does not apply to or allow the display and sale of merchandise and goods on sidewalks or public plazas by
transient vendors or other persons who do not operate retail business in a building on the property adjoining the public sidewalk or public plaza where
the display and sales take place.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 94/358
F. No person shall sell or display merchandise, or permit the sale or display of merchandise, under this section until he or she has first obtained liability
insurance or an amendment or rider to an existing liability insurance policy insuring the said person and the City and its officers and employees, against
liability which might arise out of the display or sale of merchandise by such person upon the public sidewalk in an amount of at least one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) cumulative. Failure to obtain such insurance shall be a misdemeanor violation
of this Code. The City, together with its officers and employees, shall be named as additional insured in the said liability insurance policy, and shall
meet all other requirements established by the City. (2017 Code)
5-1F-5: PENALTY:
Any violation of this article shall be considered a Municipal infraction as provided for in title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code. (2017 Code)
ARTICLE G. SIDEWALKS KEPT CLEAN, FREE FROM SNOW AND ICE
5-1G-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply:
ACCUMULATIONS: Snow and/or ice deposits.
PERSON: An individual or group or association of individuals; a firm or any member thereof; a corporation, or any executive officer, manager, person in
charge or employee thereof; and the use of a pronoun specifying one (1) gender shall include both genders.
SNOWFALL: Any snow, ice or wind event that cause accumulations on sidewalks. (Ord. 08-14, 10-7-2008)
5-1G-2: OWNER/OCCUPANT RESPONSIBILITIES:
As set out in section 364.12, Code of Iowa, the abutting property owner is responsible for the removal of the accumulations of snow and/or ice within forty
eight (48) hours of snowfall from the entire width of the sidewalk and may be liable for damages caused by the failure of the abutting property owners to
use reasonable care in the removal of accumulations. It shall be prohibited for any property owner to allow accumulations to remain on sidewalks abutting
the owner's property for more than forty eight (48) hours after snowfall.
Whenever it shall not be practicable to remove the snow and/or ice from such sidewalk by reason of the accumulation of snow and ice being frozen to the
sidewalk, then the owner or occupant shall keep and maintain such accumulations spread with fine cinders and/or sand in such a manner as to provide
traction and prevent the sidewalk from being dangerous to pedestrians. Nothing in this article shall be construed to be a substitute for the removal of
accumulations of snow and/or ice. This article shall only apply when accumulations cannot be reasonably removed, however, all accumulations shall be
removed as soon as practical. (Ord. 08-14, 10-7-2008)
5-1G-3: CITY MAY REMOVE SNOW AND ICE; NOTICE:
A. Whenever the occupant or owner of any such lot or parcel of ground abutting a sidewalk shall fail or refuse to remove the accumulation or to sprinkle
material upon frozen ice, as required by section 5-1G-2 of this article, the Development Services Department may serve a notice upon the property
owner as determined from the records of the County Auditor by one (1) or more of the following, as necessary:
1. Posting a notice on the front door or main entry to the building;
2. Personal service, if the owner can be served within the City limits;
3. United States first class mail, if the owner lives within any zip code that is within or contiguous to the boundaries of Cerro Gordo County.
4. United States certified mail with return receipt, if the owner cannot be served according to any of the above methods.
B. The notice shall direct that said nuisance shall be abated within five (5) business days after the completed service of notice. Said notice shall set forth
those actions which are required of the property owner.
C. If the owner/occupant fails to perform the action required in the notice of abatement within the time prescribed therein, the City may proceed to clear
said sidewalks of snow and ice and may assess the actual cost and expense thereof against each such lot or parcel of ground. (Ord. 08-14, 10-7-2008;
amd. 2017 Code)
5-1G-4: UNLAWFUL DEPOSIT OF SNOW AND/OR ICE:
No person shall remove, or cause to be removed, accumulations from private premises and deposit the same or cause the same to be deposited upon any
public street, avenue, alley, public square or traveled area within the City. (Ord. 08-14, 10-7-2008)
5-1G-5: ADMINISTRATION OF COSTS:
In addition to the actual cost of removing accumulations or treatment of accumulations from sidewalks abutting private property, a ten dollar ($10.00)
administrative cost shall be paid by the owner of said property.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 95/358
The property owner shall be sent a bill for said costs to permit voluntary payment thereof by the property owner. Failure to pay said bill within the stated
time period on the bill will cause the action to appear on a schedule of assessments to be forwarded to the City Clerk for consideration by the City Council
in accordance with the provisions of chapter 384 of the Code of Iowa. (Ord. 08-14, 10-7-2008)
5-1G-6: RIGHT TO ASSESS:
When the City causes to be removed accumulations and/or treats accumulations, the City may assess the actual cost plus any administrative costs for
removing such accumulations from the abutting property owners' sidewalks and/or treatment of irremovable accumulations. (Ord. 08-14, 10-7-2008)
Chapter 2
PUBLIC PARKS
5-2-1: CONTROL, SUPERVISION:
As set forth in section 364.12, Iowa Code, the City Council has established that all public parks, including dedicated pedestrian and bicycle paths owned or
maintained by the City, shall be under the direct supervision and control of the Park and Recreation Board1 which is empowered to make and prescribe
rules and regulations additional to those prescribed by this chapter for the control and custody of the parks, pedestrian and bicycle paths within the park
system of the City.
A. No person shall ride or drive any motorized vehicle in the parks, or on any pedestrian or bicycle paths included in the park system, except on
established roads, and then only at a moderate rate of speed and in no event at a rate of speed greater than fifteen (15) miles per hour.
Exception: Emergency vehicles. (Ord. 93-17, 7-20-1993)
5-2-2: PARK RULES:
The following rules are hereby prescribed and shall be observed by all persons in or upon the public parks of the City:
A. No person shall ride or drive in the parks except on established roads and ways, and then only at a moderate rate of speed, and in no event at a rate of
speed greater than fifteen (15) miles per hour.
B. Motor vehicles may be parked only in places provided therefor and must be parked in such a manner so as not to obstruct the roadway.
C. No person shall hitch a horse or other animal except where there are hitching posts provided for such purpose.
D. No person shall deface or injure any building, tree, shrub or plant, or other improvements made in or about the parks, or disturb or interfere with birds,
animals, fish, flowers or plants kept or found therein.
E. No fire shall be laid or made except in fireplaces or stoves provided therefor.
F. It shall be unlawful to use arms, explosives or weapons of any kind within a City park. (1953 Code § 17-2)
G. No person shall scatter or litter the grounds or riverbanks with any form of garbage or waste material, including fish of any kind. All litter, garbage,
papers and refuse must be deposited in the receptacles provided therefor.
Exception: Fish shall not be placed in the receptacles. (Ord. 97-21, 9-2-1997)
H. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any violent, obscene or profane language while in any park, or to conduct himself in a disorderly or obscene
manner, or to commit any nuisance in or about the park.
I. No person shall throw any foreign or waste substance into the water within or adjoining the parks; nor shall any person swim or bathe in the water
therein, except at such places as may be directed by the Park and Recreation Board and marked by signs erected in the park.
J. No person shall enter upon any portion of the ground in disregard of signs or posted notices forbidding the same.
K. It shall be unlawful for any person to transact business of any kind or give entertainment or hold public meetings or assemblies or to establish or occupy
a camp within any park except upon the written permission of the Park and Recreation Board.
L. All picnic parties, assemblies, entertainments and other uses made of the park shall occupy only the grounds designated for use for such purposes.
(1953 Code § 17-2)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 96/358
M. It shall be unlawful for any person to use, possess or consume any alcoholic beverage in the following City parks: Lester Milligan Park/Big Blue Pond,
Pierce Pond, Ray Rorick Park, West Park and Parker's Woods. Under special circumstances, a variance of this subsection can be obtained by
appearing before the Mason City Park and Recreation Board. (Ord. 03-8, 4-15-2003)
N. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or be within any of the parks between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. the
following morning, except that the pedestrians may use the sidewalks of Central Park for the purpose of crossing same. (1953 Code § 17-2)
O. It shall be unlawful for any person who walks or takes an animal upon any public park property or playground to do so without said animal being
attached to a leash or chain of sufficient strength to restrain the animal and not more than six feet (6') in length when said leash or chain is held by a
person competent to restrain and control the animal off the premises. Said person or handler shall clean up, remove and dispose of solid waste
excreted or deposited upon such public or private property. This subsection shall not apply to animals under the direct control of a handicapped person
which are specially trained for the purpose of assisting handicapped persons.
Exception: When animal(s) are included in activities such as a kennel club show, field trial or other special event. (Ord. 94-26, 11-15-1994)
P. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any use of a parkway within a public park in the City in disregard of or contrary to signs or posted notices
which may be installed by direction of the Park and Recreation Board. (Ord. 1156, 6-7-1971)
Q. It shall be unlawful for any watercraft or boat that is gasoline powered or has a gasoline mounted motor to enter Big Blue Pond in Lester Milligan Park.
Exception: Emergency personnel and vehicles.
R. It shall be unlawful to power a boat on Pierce Pond in Lester Milligan Park with a gasoline powered motor; however, a boat may have a gasoline
powered motor mounted on it but it must be out of the water.
Exception: Emergency personnel and vehicles. (Ord. 04-21, 7-20-2004)
Chapter 3
TREES AND SHRUBS
5-3-1: TITLE AND PURPOSE:
As set out in section 364.12, Code of Iowa, setting forth the authority to adopt regulations by the City Council, this chapter shall be known as and may be
cited as the STREET TREE ORDINANCE of the City of Mason City. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
BOULEVARD: Any unpaved portion of a public street located between opposing travel lanes.
CUL-DE-SAC ISLAND: The unpaved portion of a public street located between the opposing travel lanes.
INSIDE EDGE OF CURB: That side of the curb nearest the outside edge of the public sidewalk.
OUTSIDE EDGE OF PUBLIC SIDEWALK: That edge of the public sidewalk nearest the public roadway.
STREET PARKING: That portion of the public street located between the outside edge of the public sidewalk and the inside edge of the curb. (Ord. 15-07,
7-28-2015)
5-3-3: CITY FORESTER:
The Operations and Maintenance Manager/Street Supervisor, as agent, shall perform the duties of City Forester for the City and shall have charge,
custody and control of all trees and shrubs growing now or hereafter in any street parking, public parks, boulevards and public places in the City and shall
have the power to plant, care for and otherwise maintain such trees and shrubs. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-4: STREET PARKINGS IN EXCESS OF CERTAIN DISTANCES:
A. Trees may be planted in street parking where the unpaved distance between the outside edge of the sidewalk and the inside edge of the curb is more
than four and one-half feet (41/2'), and less than six feet (6') may have plantings that will not exceed thirty feet (30') in height and spread of not more
than ten feet (10') when fully grown. Such planting shall be made after first making application for and obtaining a written permit from the City Forester.
B. Trees to be planted in street parking in excess of six feet (6') shall be for a species conforming with the approved species set forth by the City Forester.
C. All planting shall be done after a permit has been obtained from the City Forester, after first having submitted an application containing information as
set forth in sections 5-3-7, 5-3-8 and 5-3-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 97/358
5-3-5: PERMIT TO PLANT OR REMOVE TREES:
No person shall plant, move, trim or remove any tree in any street parking, boulevard, park or public place in the City nor cause such action to be done by
others without first obtaining a written permit from the City Forester.
Contractors hired to trim or remove a tree on the public right-of-way or property shall be required to obtain a written permit from the City Forester and have
sufficient liability insurance, and obtain a license issued by the City Clerk's Office before performing tree service within the community.
Exception: Annual plants and flowers whose maximum mature height is less than thirty six inches (36") may be planted in any street parking and
boulevard without obtaining a permit. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-6: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMITS:
Said application shall be accompanied by a plan or drawing which shall accurately show:
A. The property of the applicant adjacent to the street parking upon which a permit to plant is sought, along with the existing public sidewalk, street,
parking area and curb located between the applicant's property line and the outside edge of the curb, all of which shall be to a definite indicated scale.
B. The species and location of each tree proposed to be planted and of those trees already existing in the street parking, also in definite scale.
C. The location of any fire hydrant, utility poles, street light pole and/or mailbox or other obstructions located upon the street parking, all of which shall be in
scaled relation to the other information required. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-7: APPLICATIONS FOR COMMERCIAL AREAS:
Trees may be planted in an area where the outside edge of the sidewalk runs continuously to the inside edge of the curb, provided the plantings be a
minimum of three feet (3') from the inside edge of the curb, and that before any tree may be planted in such areas, the owner of the property adjacent to
said street parking must first make application to and secure a permit from the City Forester as hereinafter provided.
A. Application Data:
1. Local address of the applicant's property which is adjacent to the street parking upon which a permit to plant is sought;
2. The species, number, height and trunk diameter of each tree proposed to be planted; and
3. Any additional information which the City Forester shall deem is reasonably necessary to enable the making of a fair determination of whether or not
a permit should be issued hereunder; and
4. The recommendations, along with comments, if any, by the City Planner, electrical inspector, current communications company, current power
company and the Iowa Department of Transportation when the street parking abuts the extension of a primary highway within the City.
B. Application Plan Or Drawing: Application plan or drawing shall be as set forth in section 5-3-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-8: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
The City Forester may, after review and consideration of any application as above required, issue a permit to an applicant. Any such permit issued shall be
to plant trees in strict compliance with terms and provisions of this chapter and the application and plan or drawing as finally approved by the City Forester,
a copy of which said finally approved application and plan and drawing shall be kept on file in the Office of the City Forester. All such permits shall be
issued upon the express condition that they may be revoked at any time by the City Forester and that all trees planted pursuant to said permit may be
removed by the City without liability to any person for such removal.
Further, no such permit shall be issued until the applicant shall have executed and filed with the City Forester an indemnification agreement whereby said
applicant agrees to save and hold harmless the City from any and all liability for damage or injury to person or property proximately caused by trees
planted pursuant to said permit. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-9: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
For the purpose of determining the distance under sections 5-3-6 and 5-3-7 of this chapter, where there is no existing public sidewalk or curb, then it shall
be assumed that such improvements have been installed and the location and dimensions of such improvement shall be as determined by the City
Engineer based upon projected improvements. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-10: REGULATIONS FOR PLANTING TREES AND SHRUBS:
A. All trees planted in any street parking area under this chapter shall be planted in strict accordance with the following regulations:
1. All trees planted under section 5-3-7 of this chapter in an area where the outside edge of the public sidewalk runs continuously to the inside edge of
the curb so that there is no unpaved distance between the outside edge of the public sidewalk and the inside edge of the curb shall be planted in the
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 98/358
center of an area which is at least thirty six inches (36") square and the outside line of said square area shall be the inside edge of the curb. Said
planting area may be adjusted to accommodate underground utilities; however, the size of the tree trunk at maturity shall be considered to alleviate
damage to sidewalks and curbs. Offset of tree planting shall meet all conditions.
2. All trees planted under section 5-3-6 of this chapter shall be planted at a point in the street parking at a distance of forty percent (40%) of the parking
width from the outside edge of the public sidewalk and a distance of sixty percent (60%) of the parking width from the inside edge of the curb. The
City Forester shall determine the species and the planting site whenever overhead utility wires are present.
3. All trees hereafter planted in any street parking, except section 5-3-7 of this chapter, shall be at least twenty feet (20') from any intersection street
right-of-way line; at least ten feet (10') from any fire hydrant, alley and driveway; at least one-half (1/2) the diameter of the tree canopy at maturity of
the tree, from a light standard or transmission poles. Spacing between trees shall be dependent upon species and variety of tree being planted.
Standard or large growing trees shall be at least three-fourths inch (3/4") to one inch (1") in diameter, six inches (6") above the ground and at least
five feet (5') to six feet (6') tall. Small growing trees such as flowering and ornamental trees shall be at least four feet (4') to five feet (5') tall and have
five (5) or more branches.
4. Hereafter, the total number of any tree species planted on the parking within a specified block shall equal no more than ten percent (10%) of the
combined total number of tree species that are or may be planted on the parking within that block, except the percentage may be increased by
special permission of the City Forester.
B. Shrubs may be planted in cul-de-sac islands only after a planting plan for said shrubs shall be approved by the City Forester after a statement shall be
submitted in writing assuming responsibility for maintenance of said shrubs; said responsibility assumption shall be made by adjacent property owners
or an area homeowners' association. Said responsibility shall transfer with property ownership. (Ord. 15-07, 7-28-2015)
5-3-11: PROHIBITED SPECIES OF TREES AND SHRUBS:
Hereafter, it shall be unlawful to plant any of the following described species of trees and shrubbery upon any street parking in the City along with any new
species and varieties that are known to be or which may become a public nuisance:
American elm - elm species that are certified to be disease resistant may be planted.
Ash.
