C. Special Rates: Where, in the judgment of the City Engineer, special conditions surround the use of the City water to the extent that the application of the
rental rate provided for in subsection A of this section would be inadequate or unfair to either the City or the contributor, a special rate shall be
established by the City Engineer. Each such special rate shall be contained in a written order or direction filed with the Clerk and open to public
inspection. The City Engineer is authorized to make such rates in accordance with the following rules:
1. Rate Based On Amount Of Sewage: Where a substantial portion of the City water consumed is not polluted or is not discharged into the sanitary
sewer system, the rate shall be based upon an estimate of the amount of sewage, and in the event that the property owner or contributor does not
agree to such rate, then such property owner or contributor shall, at his own expense, install a meter for the purpose of determining the amount of
sewage being discharged into the sanitary sewage system.
2. Additional Rate Based On BOD: Where the BOD (biochemical oxygen demand) of the sewage exceeds three hundred (300) parts per million by
weight, the following additional rate shall be added to the regular rate above set forth: (BOD-300) x (gallons of sewage . 1,000)(0.0017). The
contributor shall, upon the request of the Wastewater Treatment Superintendent, provide a satisfactory opening in the lateral before the sewage
reaches the sewer main where a representative sample of sewage can be taken by the Wastewater Treatment Superintendent or a designated
representative.
The Wastewater Treatment Superintendent or a designated representative shall, when he deems it necessary, take representative samples of
sewage and run the BOD test which shall be used to calculate the rate.
3. Discharging Of Waste Jeopardizing Wastewater Treatment Plant Prohibited: No sewage or industrial waste having characteristics tending, in the
opinion of the Wastewater Treatment Superintendent, to jeopardize the successful and continued operation of the wastewater treatment plant or any
of its units including sanitary sewers leading to the same, shall be discharged into the sanitary sewage system. Such waste may be pretreated by the
contributor at his own expense and discharged into said system, but said contributor shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Wastewater
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 133/358
Treatment Superintendent that such pretreatment is adequate and dependable to the extent that the sewage or waste discharged into the sanitary
system does not jeopardize the successful and continuous operation of the wastewater treatment works.
4. Optional Payment Of One- And Two-Family Residences: The owner, lessee or occupant of any one- or two-family dwelling connected with the City
sewage system shall have the option of paying his sewer rental charges for one (1) year in advance; provided, that such payment shall be made not
later than March 31. Said charge shall be based on the net water bills for the twelve (12) complete preceding months for said premises, and shall be
figured on the amount of the nine (9) lowest water bills multiplied by one and one-third (11/3) the amount thus arrived at to be multiplied by the
percentage set forth in subsection A of this section. The application of these rates is limited to residences used only for one- and two-family dwellings
and shall not apply where any commercial or industrial use is made of the premises.
5. Usage Established For Residential Structures: Effective January 1, 1991, for residential structures connected to the City sewage system without the
benefit of City water, the usage shall be established at three hundred (300) cubic feet per month per each occupant with a maximum of one thousand
five hundred (1,500) cubic feet being charged per month.
The sewer rental rates will be charged as set forth in subsection A of this section. (Ord. 09-04, 6-2-2009)
6-2A-4: PAYMENTS:
Bills for sewer rental shall be rendered to public utility consumers by adding to the water and garbage service a statement showing the amount of the
charge or rate for sewer rental as herein provided. All sewer rental charges which are paid in full on or before the fifteenth day after delivery or mailing
thereof shall be eligible for a ten percent (10%) discount and a ten percent (10%) discount of the gross amount of said bill shall be subtracted therefrom.
Any payment transmitted through the United States mail postmarked on or before the fifteenth day shall be deemed paid within fifteen (15) days. If any
sewer rental bill shall not be paid, or if transmitted through the United States mail postmarked after the twenty fifth day following the date of delivery or
mailing, the property served shall be subject to immediate discontinuance of service. (Ord. 02-12, 4-16-2002)
6-2A-5: DEPOSITS REQUIRED:
Deposits shall be required for sewer rental at the discretion of the Finance Director as provided for in subsection 6-1A-1D of this title. (Ord. 94-29, 12-20-
1994)
6-2A-6: SEWER RENTAL FUND:
All funds collected under the provisions of this article and turned over to the Finance Director shall be kept by the director in a separate and distinct fund to
be known as the Sewer Rental Fund. Said fund shall be used for the following purposes:
A. Paying the expenses of collection of said rents and the enforcement of the provisions of this article;
B. For the construction of new sanitary sewers paid for by the City, with or without special assessment against benefited and abutting property;
C. For the payment of deficiencies in assessments for the construction of new sanitary sewers;
D. For the remodeling, repair or enlargement of the sewage treatment plant or for the construction of a new sewage treatment facility;
E. For the usual operating expenses of the sewage treatment facilities, including the paying of salaries or wages of employees at said plant. (Ord. 1438, 5-
8-1978; amd. Ord. 94-29, 12-20-1994)
6-2A-7: ADJUSTMENTS TO BILL:
Only one (1) adjustment will be made during any twelve (12) month period.
If an adjustment is needed for water that did not enter the sanitary sewer system, the customer must provide verification that the water did not enter the
sanitary sewer. The bill will be adjusted by deducting the previous year's average quarterly consumption and dividing the difference between the Public
Utilities Department and the consumer.
For total credit on the sewer rental bill, the consumer may purchase a separate water meter to meter the flow not discharged to the sanitary sewer. The
credit meter shall be installed and maintained by the owner. The owner shall notify the Public Utilities Department before removing the credit meter in order
to receive credit. A service fee of two dollars ($2.00) will be charged for any part of a quarterly billing period the credit meter is used. (1985 Code)
ARTICLE B. WASTE HAULERS
6-2B-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this article, the following terms are defined as follows:
INDUSTRIAL WASTE: The liquid waste from industrial users.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 134/358
PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS (POTW): A treatment works as defined by section 212 of the Clean Water Act, owned by the City of Mason
City. This definition includes any devices and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of wastewater or industrial waste of a
liquid nature or that convey wastewater to the wastewater treatment plant, regardless of ownership.
SUPERINTENDENT: The Administrator of the Mason City Water Reclamation Division, wastewater treatment facility, POTW, or his/her designated deputy,
agent, or representative.
VEHICLE: A device equipped with a tank and used to remove or transport waste.
WASTE: Human excreta, water, scum, sludge, septage, and food waste grease solids from public and private wastewater disposal systems or holding
tanks; impervious vaults, portable, or chemical toilets; and devices used to trap grease resulting from food preparation.
WASTE HAULER: A person or firm engaged in the removal, transport, or disposal, into the City of Mason City's water reclamation facility, the contents of
any privy vault, cesspool, septic tank, chemical toilet or acceptable industrial waste, who shall be subject to the provisions of this article and shall be
referred to herein as a waste hauler.
WASTEWATER: A combination of the liquid and water carried waste from residences, commercial buildings, institutions and industrial establishments,
together with such groundwater, surface water, and stormwater as may be present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed into or permitted to
enter the POTW.
WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT: That portion of the POTW which is designed to provide treatment (including recycling and reclamation) of
wastewater and industrial waste. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
6-2B-2: LICENSE:
No waste hauler shall remove from within the City or shall dispose of waste, whether from a source inside or outside the City, into the Mason City POTW
without first obtaining a waste hauler's license from the POTW, with the following exceptions:
A. Waste haulers utilized by industrial with current wastewater discharge permit by the POTW.
B. Waste haulers granted temporary authorization by the POTW Superintendent in order to deal with an emergency. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994; amd. 2017
Code)
6-2B-3: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The waste hauler's license shall be issued by the Wastewater Treatment Plant Superintendent upon written application that shall consist of the following
minimum requirements: (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
A. Inspection: The Water Reclamation Division, upon application, shall inspect the trucks, hoses, valves, and associated equipment of the applicant for a
waste hauler's license and determine if it meets the minimum qualifications for complying with the conditions of this article. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994;
amd. 2017 Code)
B. License Fee And Bond: An application shall be required for each vehicle used by the applicant, a license fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) and a bond with
reasonable surety in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for the faithful compliance with the provisions of this article including the prompt
payment of fees, fines and damages. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
C. Renewal Of License: Renewal application must be made in the same manner as initial application. License will expire, from the date of issuance, on
March 31 every other year. Failure to pay application fees, have a current bond and permit, or completed inspection of tanker with POTW personnel will
result in relinquishing disposal privileges. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
D. Transferability Of License: Waste hauler licenses are not transferable. Waste haulers shall remove City license stickers and inform the water
reclamation facility when truck ownership is transferred. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
6-2B-4: DENIAL, SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The City may suspend, revoke or deny a waste hauler license for any of the following reasons: (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
A. The making of any false or misleading statement concerning the nature, origin or quantity of liquid waste delivered for disposal. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-
1994; amd. 2017 Code)
B. Failure to pay fees or costs as allowed by this Code.
C. Violation of the rules governing waste haulers as found in this article.
D. An inspection shows deficiencies in equipment.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 135/358
E. The waste hauler's license has been suspended by the City due to noncompliance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
6-2B-5: DENIAL, SUSPENSION, REVOCATION PROCEDURE:
In the event of an occurrence warranting the suspension or revocation of any permit issued under this article, the following procedure shall apply:
A. The Administrator or Superintendent of the POTW shall notify the permit holder, in writing, that the permit is suspended or revoked. Such notice shall be
sent to the permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the address listed on the permit holder's application. The notice shall set forth the
nature of the violation and shall set forth the period of suspension, or in the case of revocation, that the permit is revoked. The Administrator and
Superintendent shall have the authority to determine whether a violation requires suspension (and for how long) or whether the permit should be
revoked. The permit holder receiving a notice of suspension or revocation may request a hearing thereon before the Administrator and/or the
Superintendent. The hearing request must be in writing, must have a copy of the notice of suspension or revocation attached to it and must be
delivered to the POTW Superintendent no later than ten (10) days after the date of such notice at 10 1st Street N.W. If no request for a hearing is made
within the time set forth above, the suspension or revocation shall, upon the expiration of such time, become immediately effective and the permit
holder shall have no right to further hearing or appeal. If timely request of hearing is made, the permit holder shall be notified in writing of the time, date
and place of hearing which shall be not sooner than five (5), nor more than fifteen (15), working days following the receipt of the request for hearing. In
case a violation of this article is of such nature that the violation is deemed to be an immediate hazard by the Superintendent of the water reclamation
facility, the Superintendent shall be authorized to temporarily suspend the license until notice can be given and hearing held.
B. If, after such a hearing, the City Administrator or Superintendent of the POTW makes a finding based on substantial evidence that a violation of this
article did, in fact, occur as alleged, the City Administrator or Superintendent may continue suspension of, suspend or revoke the license; the
determination of whether to revoke such license shall be in the discretion of the City Administrator or Superintendent and shall be dependent upon the
circumstances surrounding the violation and its severity.
C. The decision of continued suspension or revocation made by the City Administrator or POTW Superintendent may be appealed to the City Council. In
order to appeal such decision, written notice of appeal must be filed with the City Clerk within three (3) days after receipt of the decision. Failure to file
such written notice of appeal shall constitute a waiver of right to appeal the decision of continued suspension or revocation.
D. The notice of appeal shall state the grounds for such appeal and shall be delivered personally or by certified mail to the City Clerk. The hearing of such
appeal shall be scheduled at the next regular Council meeting, if such notice is received by two o'clock (2:00) P.M. on the Thursday before the next
regular Council meeting. If notice is not received by the above designated time, the hearing will be scheduled for the next following Council meeting.
The hearing may be continued for good cause. The hearing shall be confined to the record made before the City Administrator and POTW
Superintendent, and the arguments of the parties or their representatives, but no additional evidence shall be taken. After such hearing, the City
Council may affirm or reverse the order. Such determination shall be contained in a written decision and shall be filed with the City Clerk within three (3)
days after the hearing, or any continued session thereof.
E. If the City Council affirms the action of the City Administrator and the POTW Superintendent, continuing the suspension or revocation, the City Council
shall so state and order in its written decision.
F. A licensee whose license has been revoked shall not be eligible for another waste hauler's license for a period of two (2) years. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-
1994; amd. 2017 Code)
6-2B-6: HOURS OF OPERATION:
Liquid wastes will be accepted at the disposal station between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. through four o'clock (4:00) P.M., Monday through
Friday, except by special arrangement between the waste hauler and the Superintendent to permit response to emergency conditions. Weekend and
holiday hauling will not be accepted, nor liquid waste before eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. or after four o'clock (4:00) P.M., unless prior approval from the
Superintendent, by making written or verbal request to the POTW Superintendent at least twenty four (24) hours in advance of the date the work is to be
performed. The request shall state the location of the property, the name of the owner, the date, and the hours of work. Waste haulers shall maintain the
designated location in a clean and orderly condition to avoid noxious odors and unsanitary conditions. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
6-2B-7: STANDARDS FOR VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT:
For all vehicles and equipment used by waste haulers, the licensee shall:
A. Prevent waste and wastewater from leaking, spilling, or discharging onto roads or rights-of-way.
B. Ensure proper construction and repair of the equipment to allow cleaning.
C. Maintain vehicles and equipment in an essentially rust free and sanitary condition and appearance.
D. Display the business name as it appears on the waste hauler's license in three inch (3") or larger letters on the left and right sides of the vehicle.
E. Display a City permit decal on the left side of the tanker bearing the expiration date of the license. A City permit decal shall be provided by the
Superintendent or designee as the only proof of licensing after the applicant has met all conditions and requirements of this article. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-
1994; amd. 2017 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 136/358
6-2B-8: DISPOSAL:
Waste haulers shall dispose of hauled wastes permitted in this article according to rules for land application as found in chapters 65, 69, and 121, Code of
Iowa, or at a location designated by the Wastewater Treatment Plant Superintendent. Waste disposal is only accepted during the set hours of operation.
Waste haulers may also dispose of hauled wastes at Municipal wastewater plants outside the Mason City service area where such wastes are accepted.
(Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
6-2B-9: IDENTIFICATION OF SOURCE:
Waste haulers must document the nature and origin of wastes collected and the site and method of disposal for wastes that are delivered to the
wastewater treatment plant. Such information shall be provided on a manifest form provided by the water reclamation facility. The manifest shall also
include: a) the name, address and phone number of the waste generator; b) the type of waste collected; c) the approximate volume of the load; d) any
other information consistent with identification and tracking of wastes. The Superintendent or his/her designee shall have the right to verify all information
required by this article including the right to measure, sample and analyze any waste regulated by this article. The waste hauler shall obtain approval from
the Superintendent, or his/her designee, prior to loading wastes originating from an industrial/commercial source unless previous approval is on record at
the water reclamation facility. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
6-2B-10: MIXING WASTES:
Wastes from residential and nonresidential sources shall not be mixed. Wastes from an industrial/commercial source shall not be mixed with wastes of any
type from another location. Portable toilets may be mixed with similar wastes from different locations. Grease trap waste may only be mixed with other
similar grease trap loads as long as each source is identified on the waste manifest form. Residential wastes from several sources may be mixed as long
as each source is identified.
Any tanks or equipment used for hauling waste to the POTW shall not be used for hauling hazardous or toxic wastes, as defined in the Iowa Code and in
40 CFR part 261, or other wastes detrimental to the POTW. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
6-2B-11: STANDARDS FOR DISPOSAL AT POTW:
Disposal of wastes to the POTW shall be carried out in accordance with pretreatment standards and requirements established by Federal, State, and City
governments including categorical standards developed for the waste generator's industrial category. The Superintendent may reject wastes from waste
haulers that do not comply with this section or with any other provision of this article. Waste haulers shall not deliver wastes to the Mason City POTW that:
(Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
A. Exceed the limits found in sections 6-2-9, 6-2-10, and 6-2-11 of this chapter.
B. Are hazardous waste as defined in 40 CFR part 261 or 567 IAC, and the Iowa Code.
C. Originate from sand traps, such as those located in car, truck, and trailer washes, which primarily remove sand and dirt.
D. Originate from mineral oil and grease traps, such as those located at vehicle maintenance facilities.
E. Originate from an animal confinement facility.
F. Are not completely identified or are from industrial/commercial sources that are not approved by the Superintendent as required in section 6-2B-9 of this
article.
G. Are mixed in a manner prohibited in section 6-2B-10 of this article.
H. Are wastes other than residential from outside the City limits, except through requests to the Superintendent. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994; amd. 2017
Code)
6-2B-12: REJECTION OF WASTE LOADS:
The Superintendent, or his/her designee, may reject any hauled waste load that violates or is suspected to violate the requirements of this Code or that
fails to meet any other guidelines established by the Superintendent to protect personnel, equipment, and processes at the POTW. Waste haulers must:
A. Remove rejected waste from the POTW.
B. Properly dispose of all rejected wastes in accordance with State and Federal law.
C. Provide the Superintendent with a written statement, signed by the waste hauler license holder, stating the location, date, and time the rejected load
was disposed of. The statement is due within five (5) calendar days after the waste is rejected.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 137/358
Vehicles used to haul rejected wastes shall not be allowed to enter the POTW with additional wastes until the statement required by this section is
delivered to the Superintendent. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
6-2B-13: ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES:
A. Any person, corporation or other legal entity who violates or resists the enforcement of any provisions of this article shall be guilty of a Municipal
infraction punishable by a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the initial offense and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each repeat
offense. Each violation constitutes a separate offense. Any person, corporation or other legal entity that violates a provision of this article after having
previously been found guilty of violating the same provision of this article at the same location or at a different location shall be guilty of a repeat
offense.
B. Seeking a civil penalty as authorized in this section does not preclude the City from seeking alternative relief, including any order for abatement or
injunctive relief, from the court in the same action or as a separate action. The enforcement provisions in this section are in addition to those set out in
sections 6-2-38 through 6-2-42 of this chapter. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
6-2B-14: FEE PAYMENT FOR DOMESTIC AND INDUSTRIAL WASTES:
A. A treatment fee shall be set per gallon of hauled waste which shall be equal to the cost of disposal and treatment of an equivalent mass of pollutants
otherwise delivered into the sewer system. Currently, the fee is thirty dollars ($30.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of sewage. This treatment fee
will be adjusted according to the costs associated with the administrative requirements of this article. (Ord. 07-15, 6-5-2007)
B. Loads originating outside the area served by the wastewater treatment plant shall pay a fee equal to one and one-half (11/2) times the in service fee.
C. Fees shall be computed and recorded by the Data Processing Department and shall be paid by the waste hauler on the basis of monthly billings by the
Finance Department. Limits of credit shall be reasonable limits to be determined by the Finance Department. Abuse of such credit shall be grounds for
liability on the waste hauler's bond and for refusal of disposal services to any waste hauler under this article. (Ord. 94-30, 12-20-1994)
6-2B-15: OTHER REGULATIONS:
The regulations set forth in this article are in addition to, and not in substitution of, any other applicable Federal, State, or local statutes, rules and
regulations regarding the subject matter of wastewater collection, transportation and disposal. Any person holding a permit issued under this article shall,
at all times, abide by and remain in strict compliance with all such other statutes, rules and regulations. (2017 Code)
Chapter 3
STORM SEWERS
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated, for the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated in this section:
AIR CONDITIONING AND COOLING EQUIPMENT: Any equipment or apparatus using in excess of one thousand (1,000) gallons of water in any one (1)
day for cooling or purifying purposes, the wastewater of which will not be of such a nature as will render it unfit to be wasted into storm sewers.
DOWNSPOUTS: Any duct used for carrying roof water from the roof toward the ground.
GREASE PIT: A place where vehicles or machinery are greased, the waste from which greasing is conducted to a sewer.
LOT: A continuous tract of land under one (1) ownership.
OWNER: The owner of real estate, a duly authorized agent or attorney of an owner, a tenant, purchaser, devisee, fiduciary and any person having a
vested or contingent interest in the property.
PAVED AREA: Any unroofed area surfaced in such a manner that the water falling on the same does not penetrate into the ground but runs off over the
surface.
PERSON: An individual, copartnership, corporation, fiduciary and trustee.
WASH RACK: A place other than on residential property where automobiles, trucks, busses or tractors are washed with water. (Ord. 723, 6-4-1956)
6-3-2: STORM SEWER DISTRICT:
A storm sewer district to be known as District 1 is established for the purpose of preserving the health and to meet the demands of the property owners in
said district. The boundary lines of said District 1 are now on file in the Office of the City Clerk for public inspection. (1953 § 44-1; amd. 1985 Code)
6-3-3: DRAINAGE DISTRICT:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 138/358
A drainage district to be known as Drainage District 17 has been established for the purpose of preserving the health and to meet the demands of the
property owners in said district. The boundary lines of said Drainage District 17 are now on file in the Office of the City Clerk for public inspection. (1985
Code)
6-3-4: DISCHARGE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Discharge Into Sanitary Sewers Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or cause to be discharged into any sanitary sewer any
wastewater from downspouts, drain tiles, drainage system for surface or subsurface water or air conditioning or cooling equipment.
B. Discharge Into Storm Sewers Required: The owner of property upon which is situated air conditioning and cooling equipment shall cause the
wastewater therefrom to be discharged into the storm sewer. (Ord. 1568, 7-7-1980)
6-3-5: DRAINAGE CONNECTIONS REQUIRED:
The owner of any lot or property subject to the provisions of this chapter shall cause all downspouts, drain tiles or drainage systems for surface or
subsurface water to be connected with storm sewers:
A. When the roof area exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the lot area; or
B. Where the water from the roof area is now discharged directly or indirectly into a sanitary sewer; or
C. Where downspouts now discharge onto, across or under a public sidewalk, pavement or paved area or onto an area which drains onto a public street,
avenue, alley or sidewalk; or
D. Where the area of a paved area is in excess of fifty percent (50%) of the area of the lot upon which it is situated, and where the slope and grade of such
paved area is such that the water from said paved area runs onto or across any public street, avenue, alley or sidewalk; or
E. Where the area of the paved area plus the area of the roof area when combined exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the lot area. (Ord. 723, 6-4-1956)
6-3-6: APPROVAL OF CONNECTIONS:
All connections to storm sewers shall be made under supervision of the City Engineer in an approved manner. Work shall be done only by a contractor
licensed under the provisions of title 3, chapter 13 of this Code. (Ord. 723, 6-4-1956; amd. Ord. 90-27, 12-18-1990; Ord. 92-20, 11-3-1992; 2017 Code)
6-3-7: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall be applicable only to wash racks, grease pits, air conditioning and cooling equipment, downspouts, drain tiles or other surface or
subsurface drainage systems situated on a lot adjacent to a storm sewer or if not adjacent, upon a lot which has access not exceeding one hundred feet
(100') distance to a usable storm sewer. (Ord. 723, 6-4-1956)
6-3-8: PERMITS REQUIRED:
No construction shall be allowed within the corporate limits of any Municipally owned property, sidewalks or alleys by any City licensed excavating
contractor or any other person without first obtaining a permit.
A. Fees: The permit and inspection fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for residential, seventy five dollars ($75.00) for commercial and one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00) for industrial property, and thirty dollars ($30.00) for each storm sewer disconnection, payable at time said permit is issued; and the
same shall be issued in duplicate, one (1) copy being given to the applicant and one (1) filed in the Engineering Department. Permit shall show the
name of the applicant, the exact location of the concrete construction, and such other information as the Engineering Department may require. (Ord.
92-20, 11-3-1992; amd. 2017 Code)
