Title 7
AIRPORT
Chapter 1
AIRPORT COMMISSION
7-1-1: ESTABLISHING COMMISSION:
There is hereby established the Airport Commission of the City of Mason City, Iowa, created pursuant to section 330.17, Code of Iowa, to be composed of
five (5) residents of the City of Mason City, Iowa, who shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to the approval of the City Council and who shall hold office
for six (6) years from November 1 following their appointment. (Ord. 1333, 7-21-1975; amd. 1985 Code; 2017 Code)
7-1-2: COMPENSATION; EXPENSES:
All members of the Airport Commission shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for necessary travel and other expenses incurred while
on official commission business. Such reimbursement shall come from the funds appropriated to the airport. (Ord. 1333, 7-21-1975; amd. 1985 Code)
7-1-3: JURISDICTION EXTENDED:
The police jurisdiction of the City of Mason City, and all applicable laws, regulations and orders issued pursuant thereto, are hereby extended to and made
applicable to the Mason City Municipal Airport. Any person who violates any resolution, ordinance or lawful order issued pursuant thereto on or at the
Mason City Municipal Airport shall be subject to prosecution, conviction and penalty in the same manner as if such violation occurred within the corporate
limits of the City of Mason City. (Ord. 1333, 7-21-1975)
7-1-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Airport Commission shall have the following powers, duties and authority:
A. To acquire real estate and personal property for airport purposes in the name of the City of Mason City, Iowa, by purchase, gift, condemnation, lease or
otherwise.
B. To acquire or cause to be moved, removed, abated, eliminated, mitigated or altered any structure or object protruding above the surface of the ground,
or any use of land obstructing the air space necessary for the safe and efficient flight of aircraft landing at, or taking off from, the Mason City Municipal
Airport, or otherwise constituting a hazard to such landing or taking off.
C. To make and enforce rules and regulations for the control, supervision and operation of the Mason City Municipal Airport which authority shall include
space above or in the vicinity of the Mason City Municipal Airport necessary or desirable for the safe landing and taking off of aircraft.
D. To manage, control, improve, maintain and operate the present Mason City Municipal Airport and any future Municipally owned real estate acquired for
similar purposes. (Ord. 1333, 7-21-1975)
E. To have and exercise all power, authority and duties which the City of Mason City might possess or exercise with respect to the Mason City Municipal
Airport, except the power to sell real estate comprising the Mason City Municipal Airport, which shall be sold only upon the unanimous vote of all
members of the City Council, and except as herein limited. (Ord. 1533, 1979)
7-1-5: FEDERAL AND STATE AID:
The Airport Commission is authorized to accept, receive and receipt for Federal and State monies and other monies, public or private, for the acquisition,
construction, enlargement, improvement, maintenance, equipping and operation of the Mason City Municipal Airport and other air navigation facilities and
sites therefor, and to comply with provisions of the laws of the United States and of the State of Iowa, and any rules and regulations made thereunder, for
the expenditure of Federal or State monies upon the Mason City Municipal Airport or other air navigation facilities. (Ord. 1333, 7-21-1975)
7-1-6: CHARGES AND LEASES:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 140/358
The Airport Commission may from time to time fix, establish and collect a schedule of charges for use of the Mason City Municipal Airport, or any part
thereof, which charges shall be used in connection with the maintenance and operation of said airport. The Airport Commission may lease all or any
portion of property acquired for airport purposes for a period of years not to exceed fifty (50), and shall have the authority and duty to hold such public
hearings as may be required in connection therewith, and may sell any equipment no longer required. (Ord. 1533, 1979)
7-1-7: FUNDS:
The Airport Commission shall annually certify to the City Council the amount of tax required for airport purposes in the ensuing fiscal year and shall
present to the City Council detailed budget estimates which shall be subject to approval, increase or decrease at the discretion of the City Council. (Ord.
1333, 7-21-1975)
All funds derived from taxation or otherwise for airport purposes shall be under the sole and absolute control of the Airport Commission for the purposes
prescribed herein, and shall be deposited with the City Clerk to the credit of the Airport Commission, and shall be disbursed only on orders of the Airport
Commission by written warrants of the City Finance Director, pursuant to mutually acceptable procedures established by the Airport Commission and City
Council. (Ord. 1333, 7-21-1975; amd. 1985 Code)
7-1-8: REPORTS:
The revenues and expenditures of the Airport Commission shall be reported monthly by the Finance Director, in the manner of other departmental
expenditures, and a copy shall be provided to each member of the commission and in the Finance Director's report to the City Council. (1985 Code)
Chapter 2
AIRPORT RULES AND REGULATIONS
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases as used in this chapter mean:
ARFF: Aircraft rescue and firefighting.
AIR OPERATIONS AREAS: Runways, taxiways, safety areas and approach zones on the airport.
AIRCRAFT: Machine or structure designed or used for flight in air.
AIRCRAFT FACILITIES AREAS: Hangars, ramps, aprons and other areas utilized by aircraft at the airport outside air operations areas.
AIRPORT: The Mason City, Iowa, Municipal Airport and all its improvements and appurtenances.
AIRPORT ACTIVITIES: Any one (1) of the following:
Aerial photography or survey.
Aircraft rental.
Aircraft repair station (including paint shop).
Aircraft sales.
Aircraft store.
Avionics sales and repair station.
Banner towing and aerial advertising.
Charter service.
Crop dusting, seeding, spraying and bird chasing.
Flight instruction.
Fuel service.
Power line or pipeline patrol.
Propeller sales and service.
AIRPORT EMPLOYEE: Employee of the commission.
AVIATION OPERATOR: Person under written lease with the commission providing on the airport and serving the public with one (1) airport activity and
otherwise meeting the minimum standards set forth herein for an aviation operator.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 141/358
CITY: City of Mason City, Iowa.
COMMISSION: The Airport Commission of the City.
EMERGENCY VEHICLE: Vehicle of the Police Department, Fire Department, ambulance or other vehicle transporting an airport official or airport
employee in response to an emergency.
FAA: Federal Aviation Administration, United States Department of Transportation.
FAR: Federal Aviation Regulation written, published and adopted by FAA.
FIXED BASE OPERATOR: Person under written lease with the commission providing on the airport and serving the public with at least five (5) airport
activities, three (3) of which shall be: a) aircraft repair station; b) fuel service; and c) charter service, and otherwise meeting the minimum standards set
forth herein for a fixed base operator.
FUEL TRUCK: Motor vehicle used for transporting, handling or dispensing of aviation fuel or petroleum products.
FUELING OPERATIONS: Fueling, defueling, oil service, sumping and any other activity involving the handling or dispensing of fuel or petroleum products
at the airport.
INOPERABLE AIRCRAFT: Aircraft having: a) no valid airworthiness certificate; b) no current Federal or State registration; c) broken or missing windshield
or other glass; d) deflated tire(s); or e) damaged propeller(s), control surfaces or other part rendering the aircraft incapable of safe takeoff or flight.
LOCAL OPERATOR: Person under written lease with the commission providing on the airport and serving the public with at least two (2) but not more than
four (4) airport activities and otherwise meeting the minimum standards set forth herein for a local operator.
MANAGER: The Airport Manager appointed by the commission or the airport employee designated by the Manager with commission approval.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Machine or structure designed or used for self-propelled movement on ground, except for any emergency vehicle and commission
vehicles.
NFPA: National Fire Protection Association.
NONSCHEDULED OPERATOR: Person whose operations are not required to meet regulations imposed by the FAA upon a scheduled air carrier
operating aircraft at the airport for the purpose of transporting passengers, mail, express, freight, cargo or for refueling, for hire, gift, remuneration or
reward.
PERSON: Individual, legal entity or association.
POLICE OFFICER: Person authorized by law to direct or regulate traffic and enforce airport rules and regulations.
PRIVATE AREA: Space on the airport to which public access is limited.
PUBLIC AREA: Space on the airport other than private area.
SCHEDULED AIR CARRIER: Person whose operations meet regulations imposed by the FAA upon a scheduled air carrier operating aircraft at the airport
for the purpose of transporting passengers, mail, express, freight or cargo. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008; amd. 2017 Code)
7-2-2: SCOPE AND APPLICATION:
The operation of aircraft in the air space above the airport and at the airport and other activity at the airport shall be conducted in conformity with Federal,
State and local law, including the rules, regulations, minimum standards and other provisions of this chapter. Should any provision of this chapter or local
law conflict with Federal or State law, such Federal or State law shall take precedence. Nothing herein shall be construed to waive or limit the application
of any Federal, State or local law more stringent, more restrictive or affording another remedy respecting any matter the subject of this chapter. (Ord. 08-
09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-3: CLOSING OF AIRPORT:
When the Manager believes airport facilities are unsafe for aeronautical activity, the Manager may close the airport. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-4: INTERFERING OR TAMPERING WITH AIRCRAFT:
No person, except airport employees when acting in their official capacities or other person designated by the Manager, shall put in motion or interfere or
tamper with any aircraft, aircraft part, instrument or tool, without permission of the owner. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-5: REFUSAL OF AIRPORT USE:
The Manager may restrict or prohibit any flight or other activity at the airport in the interest of public safety and welfare. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-6: CARELESS OR NEGLIGENT OPERATION:
No aircraft shall be operated: a) in a careless or negligent manner; b) while the pilot or any other person aboard the aircraft and controlling any part of its
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 142/358
operation is under the influence of an intoxicating beverage or other drug; or c) if the aircraft is in a condition or loaded so as to endanger persons or
property. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-7: AIRCRAFT EQUIPMENT:
No aircraft may land or take off unless it is equipped with brakes or other means of preventing movement on the ground and is otherwise in sound
condition. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-8: AIRCRAFT TAKEOFFS, LANDINGS AND TAXIING:
A. Aircraft takeoffs and landings shall be made only on designated runways, except by rotary wing aircraft. Turn areas shall not be used for takeoffs or
landings except in emergencies. Taxiways and ramp areas shall not be used for takeoffs or landings by fixed wing aircraft except in emergencies.
B. Rotary wing aircraft, during final landing or takeoff, shall not pass over any building, motor vehicle parking area or aircraft ramp.
C. Aircraft operating under visual flight rules shall conform to a standard left hand traffic pattern.
D. Aircraft shall taxi at a safe speed with due regard for other aircraft, persons and property and not in excess of ten (10) miles per hour while on ramps or
aprons adjacent to buildings.
E. No aircraft shall be taxied into or out of any hangar. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-9: PARKING OF AIRCRAFT:
A. Unhangared aircraft shall be parked only in areas designated by the Manager and shall be secured when left unattended. Owners of such aircraft shall
be responsible for any damage or loss resulting from noncompliance with this provision.
B. Use by aircraft or motor vehicles of ramp loading areas at the airport terminal building shall be limited to fifteen (15) minutes unless otherwise approved
by the Manager. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-10: AIRCRAFT ENGINE OPERATION:
A. No aircraft engine shall be operated by a person other than a pilot or mechanic licensed and certified in its operation.
B. Aircraft shall be operated only in locations designated by the Manager and when the operation will not endanger persons or property. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-
2008)
7-2-11: INOPERABLE AIRCRAFT:
A. Inoperable aircraft shall not be parked on the airport.
B. The owner of an inoperable aircraft shall be responsible for the parking of the inoperable aircraft on the airport in violation of this chapter.
C. Upon discovery of an inoperable aircraft parked on the airport, notification in writing shall be given the owner that:
1. Parking of the inoperable aircraft constitutes a violation of this chapter;
2. The owner must abate the violation by removing or repairing the inoperable aircraft within sixty (60) days after service of the notice;
3. Failure of the owner to remove or repair the inoperable aircraft within the sixty (60) day notice period shall be sufficient cause for removal and
disposal of the inoperable aircraft by the City and assessment of costs to the owner.
D. Each day after expiration of the sixty (60) day notice period that the inoperable aircraft remains parked on the airport, the owner may be charged with a
new violation of this chapter.
E. As an alternative to the foregoing provisions of this section, a citation for a Municipal infraction may be issued to the owner of the inoperable aircraft,
setting forth the violation of this chapter and seeking an order of removal on conviction.
F. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to inoperable aircraft under the custody and control of a person under lease with the commission and
serving the public as an aircraft repair station or as authorized by the Manager. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-12: REPAIR OF AIRCRAFT:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 143/358
No person shall repair an aircraft or aircraft part in any area other than that designated by the Manager, except minor adjustments may be made while the
aircraft is on the loading ramp preparatory to takeoff when such adjustments are necessary to prevent a delay in departure. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-13: REGISTRATION:
Owners of aircraft using the airport as a base of operation shall register with the Manager, giving such information as may be required by the Manager for
airport records. Any change in aircraft ownership will require a change in registration. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-14: THREATS:
A. A person having knowledge or suspicion of an aircraft or person possessing explosives on the airport shall notify the Manager immediately.
B. The Manager may issue directives and take action necessary to protect people and property when a threat involving explosives, weapons or sabotage
exists at the airport.
C. The Manager may establish or revise at any time procedures for dealing with threats involving explosives, weapons or sabotage. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-15: STUNT FLYING; AEROBATICS:
Events involving aerial activities not of a routine nature shall require authorization by the commission and shall be coordinated with the Manager who may
require an "air boss" experienced in directing and controlling such activities. Any such activities shall be conducted in a manner that does not endanger
persons or property. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-16: FUELING AND FLAMMABLES:
A. Fuelers: The following rules shall apply to persons engaged in fueling operations:
1. Only persons holding a permit issued by the commission may engage in fueling operations, except owners with respect to their own aircraft.
2. Application for a permit shall be made to the commission in writing.
3. Permittees shall pay flowage fees as determined and pursuant to procedures established by the commission.
B. Fueling Operations: The following rules shall apply to fueling operations: (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
1. All fueling operations shall comply with applicable FAA and NFPA Standards and Codes.
2. Fueling operations shall be conducted only at locations designated by the Manager.
3. Fuel storage areas shall be fenced, with gates and warning signs prohibiting public access.
4. No aircraft shall be fueled with one (1) or more engines running or while heat is being applied to the aircraft.
5. No aircraft shall be fueled in a hangar, other enclosed space or congested area.
6. No smoking or open flame shall be permitted within one hundred feet (100') of fueling operations.
7. In fueling operations, aircraft and fuel servicing equipment shall be bonded and operated in a manner that will prevent static ignition of volatile
liquids.
8. During fueling operations, a fueler shall have at least one (1) person on duty who has been trained in fire safety and completed an aviation fuel
training course approved by the Manager.
9. During fueling operations, at least two (2) dry chemical fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of 20B:C shall be available for immediate use.
10. During fueling operations, no person shall operate any radio, transmitter, receiver, electrical appliance, cell phone or other equipment having the
potential to cause a spark or ignition of volatile liquids.
11. Fueling operations shall cease during an electrical storm or when lightning discharges occur within the vicinity of the airport.
12. Fuelers shall take all precautions to prevent spillage of fuel; any spill in excess of one (1) gallon shall be reported to ARFF personnel for inspection
and cleanup; the fueler shall be responsible for all costs incident to each spill and cleanup.
13. Equipment used in fueling operations shall be maintained in good and safe condition; fueling shall cease in the event of an equipment malfunction
and shall not resume until the equipment has been repaired or replaced.
14. Electrical switches and fixtures in areas that could be reached by fuel or fuel vapors shall be explosion-proof.
15. Fuel trucks shall not be parked or stored inside a building except when undergoing maintenance in a building approved for the purpose. (Ord. 08-
09, 8-5-2008; amd. 2017 Code)
16. No aircraft engine shall be started when there is gasoline on the ground under the aircraft.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 144/358
17. No aircraft shall be fueled while passengers are on board, unless a passenger loading ramp is in place at an open cabin door with attendants
present or nearby.
18. No airborne radar equipment shall be operated or ground tested in an area where the directional beam is within three hundred feet (300') of another
aircraft, fueling operations, fuel truck or fuel storage facility.
19. Fuel trucks shall be conspicuously marked.
20. No flammable gas or oil exceeding ten (10) gallons in quantity shall be stored in any structure at the airport unless approved by the Manager.
21. No cylinder or flask of compressed flammable gas shall be stored in any structure at the airport.
C. Cleaning Of Aircraft: The cleaning of aircraft and parts thereof using flammables shall be conducted in open air or in a fireproof room with readily
accessible fire extinguishers.
D. Cleaning Of Floors: Flammables shall not be permitted in cleaning floors, which shall be kept clean and free from oil.
E. Disposal Of Toxic Liquids Prohibited: No flammable, corrosive or toxic liquid shall be disposed of into storm sewer, toilet, shop or hangar drains, catch
basins or ditches, or onto aprons, parking lots, roadways or elsewhere at the airport. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-17: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person on the airport to:
A. Smoke in areas designated nonsmoking by the Manager.
B. Deface, damage, destroy or remove any building, other improvement, traffic sign, signal or device, or other signage permitted by the Manager, or fence,
railing, guard, barrier, light or other device placed in the vicinity of any excavation, hole, pile of material or other hazard.
C. Enter any private area without authorization by the Manager.
D. Bring any animal, except for a service dog in the custody of its master, a dog utilized for law enforcement purposes or an animal properly leashed and
confined for air shipment.
E. Fire or discharge any weapon or possess any explosive or other dangerous article; provided, however, this prohibition shall not apply to police officers
in the discharge of their duties.
F. Interfere in any manner with airport operations.
G. Commit any act that would be in violation of law. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-18: JURISDICTION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT:
The jurisdiction of the Police Department of the City is extended to the airport and all police officers shall have authority to enforce ordinances of the City at
the airport. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-19: COMMERCIAL AIRPORT ACTIVITIES:
No commercial activity may be conducted at the airport without written agreement with the commission. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-20: CERTIFICATED AIR CARRIERS:
Schedules of rates and charges for all certificated air carriers shall be set by the commission and revised whenever deemed necessary by the
commission. Rates and charges shall include landing fees, floor rental charges and other charges that are pertinent to the operation of the airport. Such
fares and charges shall apply without discrimination to all certificated scheduled and nonscheduled air carriers using the airport. Landing fees will be
based on a weight frequency basis unless otherwise specified in a written agreement between the commission and the carrier. No person shall operate
from the airport any aircraft that is not fully certificated by and registered with the FAA and carrying a current certificate of airworthiness, with the exception
of government owned aircraft. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-21: OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
A. No motor vehicle shall be operated in an air operations area without permission from the Manager.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 145/358
B. Motor vehicle operations in aircraft facility areas may be restricted by the Manager.
C. Motor vehicles shall travel at safe speeds as conditions warrant and in no event in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour on ramps, aprons and in aircraft
facilities areas.
D. Aircraft and pedestrians shall at all times have the right-of-way over motor vehicle traffic.
E. All motor vehicles shall pass to the rear of taxiing aircraft.
F. No motor vehicle shall be operated on the airport so as to endanger persons or property.
G. Parking of motor vehicles shall be permitted only in areas and for such periods of time as designated by the Manager.
H. A motor vehicle traversing an air operations area with permission of the Manager shall be escorted by an airport employee having two-way radio
communication.
I. In the event of emergency, there shall be no motor vehicle movement on the airport unless permitted by the Manager.
J. Separate areas may be designated for parking by members of the public, airport employees, airport tenants or others as designated by the Manager.
K. Except for minor repairs necessary to remove motor vehicles from the airport, no such vehicles shall be cleaned or repaired at the airport, unless
approved by the commission.
L. All airport roadways shall have City "status".
M. The operation of motor vehicles shall otherwise be governed by applicable law. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-22: SPECIALIZED COMMERCIAL FLYING SERVICES:
A. Statement Of Concept: A specialized commercial flying services operator is a person providing for hire in the conduct of any of the following activities:
1. Crop dusting, seeding, spraying and bird chasing.
2. Banner towing and aerial advertising.
3. Aerial photography or survey.
4. Power line or pipeline patrol.
5. Any other operation specifically excluded from FAR part 135.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the commission an area of not less than four thousand five hundred (4,500) square feet of ground space including a
building thereon providing at least two thousand (2,000) square feet of floor space for aircraft and other storage and at least five hundred (500)
square feet of floor space for office and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for
customer access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a point of contact, for customer use.
2. An operator engaged in crop dusting, seeding or spraying shall make suitable arrangements and provide adequate equipment upon the leased
premises for the safe loading, unloading, storage and containment of chemicals.
3. The operator shall provide and have based upon the leased premises not less than one (1) airworthy aircraft, either owned or under written lease to
operator, meeting all requirements of the FAA and other applicable law with respect to the type of operation being performed.
4. The operator shall employ trained personnel in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards in an efficient manner, but never
less than one (1) person holding a current FAA commercial certificate, properly rated for the aircraft to be used and the type of operation being
performed.
5. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Aircraft liability: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence; passenger liability,
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; limited to two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) per passenger.
b. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence.
c. Products liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-23: AIRCRAFT RENTALS:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 146/358
A. Statement Of Concept: An aircraft rental operator is a person engaged in the rental of aircraft to the public.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the commission an area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon
providing at least four thousand (4,000) square feet of floor space for aircraft storage and at least one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space for
office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for customer
access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a point of contact, for customer use.
2. The operator shall have available upon the leased premises not less than two (2) certified and airworthy aircraft, at least one (1) of which shall be a
four-place aircraft, and at least one (1) of which shall be equipped for and capable of flight under instrument conditions.
3. The operator shall provide services upon the leased premises eight (8) hours daily, six (6) days per week. The operator shall employ trained
personnel in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards in an efficient manner, but never less than one (1) person holding a
current commercial pilot certificate with appropriate ratings, including instructor rating.
4. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Aircraft liability: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence, limited to two
hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) per passenger.
b. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence.
c. Student and renters' liability: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-24: AIRCRAFT SALES:
A. Statement Of Concept: An aircraft sales operator is a person engaged in: 1) the sale of new or used aircraft, on a retail or wholesale basis, through a
franchise, licensed dealership or distributorship of an aircraft manufacturer; and 2) arranging for such repairs, services and parts as necessary to meet
any guarantee or warranty on aircraft sold by the operator.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the commission an area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon
providing at least four thousand (4,000) square feet of floor space for display and storage of aircraft and at least one thousand (1,000) square feet of
floor space for office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for
customer access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a point of contact, for customer use.
2. The operator shall make arrangements for such repair, services and parts as necessary to meet any guarantee or warranty on new or used aircraft
sold by the operator. Such arrangements may be made by written agreement with a person engaged in activity as an operator of an approved aircraft
repair station at the airport. The operator shall provide an adequate inventory of spare parts for the type of new aircraft sold by the operator.
3. The operator shall provide services upon the leased premises eight (8) hours daily, five (5) days per week. The operator shall employ trained
personnel in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards in an efficient manner, but never less than one (1) person having a
current, effective commercial pilot certificate with single-engine rating and instructor rating.
4. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Aircraft liability: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence; passenger liability,
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; limited to two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) per passenger.
b. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence.
c. Products liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-25: AIRCRAFT REPAIR STATIONS:
A. Statement Of Concept: An aircraft repair station operator is a person providing either or both airframe and power plant repair service, which shall
include the nonexclusive right to sell aircraft parts and accessories.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the commission an area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon
providing at least four thousand (4,000) square feet of floor space for either or both airframe and power plant repair service and at least one
thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space for office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for heating, lighting and
making adequate arrangements for customer access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a point of contact, for
customer use.
2. The operator shall provide services upon the leased premises eight (8) hours daily, five (5) days per week. The operator shall employ trained
personnel in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards in an efficient manner, but never less than one (1) person currently
holding an FAA inspection authorization and otherwise certified by the FAA with ratings appropriate to the work being performed.
3. The operator shall provide equipment, supplies and parts sufficient to meet requirements for certification by the FAA as an approved aircraft repair
station.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 147/358
4. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence.
b. Hangar keepers liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each accident or replacement value of the aircraft being repaired, whichever is more.
c. Products liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-26: AVIONICS AND PROPELLER SERVICE:
A. Statement Of Concept: An avionics and propeller service operator is a person engaged in the repair of aircraft radios, propellers, instruments and
accessories for general aviation aircraft, which shall include the nonexclusive right to sell such items.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the airport an area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon
providing at least four thousand (4,000) square feet of floor space for repair service and at least one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space for
office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for customer
access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a point of contact, for customer use.
2. The operator shall provide services upon the leased premises eight (8) hours daily, five (5) days per week. The operator shall employ trained
personnel in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards in an efficient manner, but never less than one (1) person holding
appropriate certifications issued by the FAA for rating as a radio, instrument or propeller repair person.
3. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence.
b. Hangar keepers liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence.
c. Products liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-27: CHARTER SERVICES:
A. Statement Of Concept: A charter services operator is a person providing air transportation to the general public for hire, either on a charter basis
(commercial operation) or as an air taxi operator, as defined by the FAA.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the airport an area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon
providing at least four thousand (4,000) square feet of floor space for aircraft storage and at least one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space for
office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for customer
access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a point of contact, for customer use.
2. The operator shall provide, either owned or under written lease to operator, not less than one (1) single-engine, four-place aircraft and one (1) multiengine
aircraft, both of which shall meet the requirements, including for instrument operations, of the air taxi commercial operator certificate held by
the operator.
3. The operator shall provide services upon the leased premises eight (8) hours daily, six (6) days per week. During all other times, the operator shall
provide on call service. The operator shall employ trained personnel in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards in an
efficient manner, who shall include not less than at least one (1) FAA certified commercial pilot rated to permit the flight activity offered by the
operator.
4. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Aircraft liability: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence; passenger liability,
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; limited to two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) per passenger.
b. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-28: FLIGHT INSTRUCTION:
A. Statement Of Concept: A flight instruction operator is a person certified by the FAA for and engaged in the instruction of pilots in the operation of fixed or
rotary wing aircraft, with such instruction to include ground school and flight checks designed to prepare students for meeting requirements for
licensure and rating as pilots.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the commission an area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon
providing at least four thousand (4,000) square feet of floor space for aircraft storage and at least one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space for
office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for customer
access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a point of contact, for customer use.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 148/358
2. The operator shall have available for use in flight instruction, either owned or under written lease to operator, not less than two (2) properly
certificated aircraft, at least one (1) of which shall be a four-place aircraft, and at least one (1) of which shall be equipped for instrument flight
instruction.
3. The operator shall provide services upon the leased premises eight (8) hours daily, six (6) days per week. The operator shall employ trained
personnel in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards in an efficient manner, who shall include not less than at least one
(1) flight instructor certified by the FAA to provide the instruction offered.
4. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Aircraft liability: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence; passenger liability,
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; limited to two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) per passenger.
b. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence.
c. Student and renters' liability: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-29: FUELING SERVICE:
A. Statement Of Concept: A fuel service operator is a person engaged in fueling operations, which may include ramp assistance for and the parking,
storage and tiedown of aircraft within the area leased by the operator.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The operator shall lease from the commission an area of not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon
providing at least one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space for office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall be responsible for
heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for customer access to the building and furnishing it with communication facilities, including a
point of contact, for customer use.
2. The operator shall have available for use, either owned or under written lease to operator, at least two (2) 10,000-gallon fuel storage tanks at the
airport and shall provide at least two (2) grades of fuel adequate to meet the demand of general aviation users of the airport. The operator shall
provide separate meters, filter equipped dispensers and pumps, fixed or mobile, for each grade of fuel dispensed by the operator.
3. The operator may provide minor repair service that does not require a certificated mechanical rating and cabin services, but only on the ramp or
apron parking area within the leased premises and when such services may be performed efficiently at that location.
4. The operator shall make provision for the transportation of pilots and passengers of transient general aviation aircraft using the operator's facilities
and services from and to the operator's office and the airport terminal.
5. The operator shall provide and maintain equipment and supplies appropriate and necessary for the servicing of general aviation aircraft using the
airport.
6. The operator shall provide services upon the leased premises at least nine (9) hours daily, seven (7) days per week, except major holidays. During
such major holidays and all other times, the operator shall provide on call service. The operator shall employ trained personnel in such numbers as
may be required to meet the minimum standards in an efficient manner.
7. The operator shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified:
a. Comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property damage: Bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence.
b. Hangar keepers liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence.
c. Products liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence.
d. Motor vehicle liability: Bodily injury and property damage combined single limit, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-
5-2008)
7-2-30: MULTIPLE SERVICES:
A. Statement Of Concept: A multiple services operator shall be a fixed base operator (FBO) or local operator (LO).
B. Minimum Standards:
1. The FBO shall lease from the commission an area of not less than twenty five thousand (25,000) square feet of ground space including a building
thereon or to be erected thereon providing at least ten thousand (10,000) square feet of floor space for office, customer lounge and restrooms. The
LO shall lease from the commission an area of not less than sixteen thousand (16,000) square feet of ground space including a building thereon or to
be erected thereon providing at least eight thousand (8,000) square feet of floor space for office, customer lounge and restrooms. The operator shall
be responsible for heating, lighting and making adequate arrangements for customer access to the building and furnishing it with communication
facilities, including a point of contact, for customer use. The operator shall otherwise meet the minimum standards established by this chapter for
each airport activity engaged in by the operator, except where this would result in duplication, in which case the operator shall meet the highest
applicable minimum standards among those set for aviation activities engaged in by the operator.
2. The operator shall carry insurance as required to meet the minimum standards for each airport activity engaged in by the operator, except where this
would result in duplication, in which case the operator shall meet the highest applicable minimum standards among those set for airport activities
engaged in by the operator. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 149/358
7-2-31: AVIATION OPERATORS:
A. Statement Of Concept: An aviation operator is a person engaged in a single airport activity.
B. Minimum Standards:
1. Except as provided hereafter, the operator shall lease from the commission ground space including a building thereon in size not less than that
required under this chapter for the airport activity engaged in by the operator.
2. The operator shall otherwise meet the minimum standards established by this chapter for the airport activity engaged in by the operator.
C. Minimum Use Fee: In the event the airport activity of the operator, as determined by the commission, does not require the lease of space upon the
airport, the operator shall pay a fee determined by the commission and the minimum standard for rental of space otherwise applicable to the aviation
activity shall not apply. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-32: FLYING CLUBS:
A. Flying Clubs Permitted: The commission may permit flying clubs at the airport.
B. Organization And Membership: Any group seeking to function as a flying club at the airport shall make written application to the commission and
provide such documentation and other information as may be required by the commission. Only groups organized as nonprofit corporations under Iowa
law for the purpose of fostering flying for pleasure, the development of skills in aeronautics, pilotage and navigation, and increasing related awareness
and appreciation by the general public shall be considered for recognition as flying clubs at the airport.
C. Registration Of Aircraft And Commercial Restrictions: Aircraft owned, leased or used by a flying club shall be registered with the commission and may
not be leased or used for any commercial purpose. No flying club or member thereof shall provide instruction for persons other than members of the
flying club, and the flying club shall not operate or provide charter service of any nature.
D. Insurance: The flying club shall carry the following insurance with the limits specified: comprehensive public liability and comprehensive property
damage: bodily injury and property damage combined, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) single limit per occurrence. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-33: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
A. All leases entered into with the commission shall contain provisions required by the FAA for compliance with grant assurances required by the FAA in
exchange for Federal funding relative to development at the airport.
B. Evidence of all insurance required under this chapter shall be filed with the commission by the person obliged to carry the insurance. Insurance required
under this chapter shall be subject to change by the commission.
C. Evidence of every certification required under this chapter shall be filed with the commission by the person obliged to hold the certification.
D. Minimum standards relative to building requirements may be satisfied with one (1) building, attached buildings or separate buildings including at
different locations on the airport. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
7-2-34: HANGAR DEVELOPMENT:
Private development may be permitted on the airport at locations and upon terms and conditions deemed appropriate by the commission. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-
2008)
7-2-35: COMPLIANCE AND ENFORCEMENT:
A. Any police officer shall have authority to enforce ordinances of the City at the airport.
B. Any person acting in violation of a provision of this chapter may be forcibly ejected and removed from the airport by any police officer or the Manager.
C. The commission reserves the right, power and privilege to exercise all other reasonable means to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
D. Violation of this chapter is a violation of this Code, and any other applicable law and shall be punishable accordingly. (Ord. 08-09, 8-5-2008)
Chapter 3
AIRPORT ZONING
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 150/358
7-3-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the MASON CITY MUNICIPAL AIRPORT ZONING ORDINANCE or the AIRPORT ZONING
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context requires otherwise. In each case the singular shall include the
plural and the plural shall include the singular.
AERIAL NAVIGATION: The movement of an aircraft through the air.
AIRCRAFT: Any contrivance used or designed for carrying humans in flight through the air, but not including parachutes.
AIRPORT: The Mason City Municipal Airport.
AIRPORT COMMISSION: The Mason City Airport Commission or its duly appointed representative.
AIRPORT ELEVATION: One thousand two hundred thirteen feet (1,213') above mean sea level (MSL).
AIRPORT HAZARD: Any structure or tree or use of land which would exceed the Federal obstruction standards as contained in 14 CFR FAR, part 77, and
which obstructs or is otherwise hazardous to the landing or takeoff of any aircraft at the airport, or hazardous to persons or property on the ground.
AIRPORT HAZARD AREA: Any area of land or water upon which an airport hazard might be established if not prevented as provided by this chapter.
BUILDING OFFICIAL: The building official of Mason City, Iowa, or the building official of Clear Lake, Iowa, or a duly authorized designee thereof.
CITY: The City of Mason City, Iowa, and/or the City of Clear Lake, Iowa.
COUNTY: Cerro Gordo County, Iowa.
FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION (FAA): An agency of the United States government that administers the Federal regulations that relate to the use
and flight of aircraft, and related regulations. The location of the controlling FAA office may be found in section 7-3-17, "Appendix I", of this chapter.
INNER EDGE: That edge of any zone that is closest to the runway end to which the zone applies. The inner edge is perpendicular to the runway
centerline.
JURISDICTION: The City of Mason City, Iowa, and/or the City of Clear Lake, Iowa, and/or Cerro Gordo County, Iowa.
NONCOMPATIBLE USE: Any activity that would degrade the safety of people on the ground, or occupants of aircraft in flight, including, but not limited to:
putrescible waste landfills, smoke or steam producing activities, any activity that would produce electrical or radio signal interference not compatible with
safe operation of an aircraft, and those that lead to an assembly of people, including, but not limited to: residences, churches, schools, hospitals, office
buildings, shopping centers, and other uses with similar concentrations of persons.
NONCONFORMING STRUCTURE: Any structure or portion of any structure that is located within or underlying any of the zones created by this chapter
and that does not conform to the height and use provisions of this chapter.
OBSTRUCTION: Any structure or tree, the height of which exceeds that which is allowed by this chapter.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, copartnership, corporation, company, association, joint stock association, or body politic, and includes any trustee,
assignee or other similar representative thereof.
RUNWAY THRESHOLD: A designated point on any airport runway that establishes the end of the runway. The runway threshold may or may not
correspond with the end of the paved portion of the runway.
STRUCTURE: Any object, whether permanent or temporary, stationary or mobile, constructed or installed by humans, including, but not limited to:
buildings, towers, smokestacks, scaffolds, lighting fixtures, public and private roads, railways, and overhead transmission lines, including poles or other
structures supporting the same.
TREE: Any object of natural growth twenty feet (20') in height or greater, or that may be expected to grow to a height of twenty feet (20') or greater.
ZONING ADMINISTRATOR: The Zoning Administrator of Cerro Gordo County, Iowa, or a duly authorized designee thereof. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-3: AIRPORT ZONES:
In order to carry out the provisions of this chapter, there are hereby created and established certain zones which are described herein and depicted on the
Mason City Airport Zoning Map, which is hereby made a part of this chapter. Any structure or tree located in more than one (1) zone is considered to be
only in the zone with the more restrictive height and use limitation. The various zones hereby established and defined are as follows:
A. Approach Overlay Zone (AO):
1. Defined: The airspace above a sloping plane extending outward from each end of each runway, rising uniformly at a fixed ratio, and of fixed size,
through which aircraft commonly operate when arriving at, and departing from, the airport. AO Zones vary in size and slope based upon the present
or future use that can be expected for each airport runway. The AO Zones at the airport are as follows:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 151/358
a. Runway 36 (AO36): Beginning two hundred feet (200') beyond the paved portion at the end of the runway and centered on the extended
centerline of the runway, the inner edge of the zone is one thousand feet (1,000') wide, expanding uniformly to an outer edge width of sixteen
thousand feet (16,000'). The altitude of the inner edge is the same as the altitude of the runway threshold at the centerline. For each fifty feet (50')
of horizontal distance the floor of the zone rises from the inner edge one foot (1') (50:1) for a distance of ten thousand feet (10,000'), and for an
additional forty thousand feet (40,000'), for each forty feet (40') of horizontal distance, rising at a rate of one foot (1') (40:1).
b. Runway 18 (AO18): Beginning two hundred feet (200') beyond the paved portion at the end of the runway and centered on the extended
centerline of the runway, the inner edge of the zone is one thousand feet (1,000') wide, expanding uniformly to an outer edge width of sixteen
thousand feet (16,000'). The altitude of the inner edge is the same as the altitude of the runway threshold at the centerline. For each fifty feet (50')
of horizontal distance the floor of the zone rises from the inner edge one foot (1') (50:1) for a distance of ten thousand feet (10,000'), and for an
additional forty thousand feet (40,000'), for each forty feet (40') of horizontal distance, rising at a rate of one foot (1') (40:1).
c. Runway 30 (AO30): Beginning two hundred feet (200') beyond the paved portion at each end of the runway and centered on the extended
centerline of the runway, the inner edge of each zone is five hundred feet (500') wide, expanding uniformly to an outer edge width of three
thousand five hundred feet (3,500'). The altitude of the inner edge is the same as the altitude of the runway threshold at the centerline. The floor of
the zone rises from the inner edge one foot (1') for each thirty four feet (34') of horizontal distance (34:1), for a distance of ten thousand feet
(10,000').
d. Runway 12 (AO12): Beginning two hundred feet (200') beyond the paved portion at each end of the runway and centered on the extended
centerline of the runway, the inner edge of each zone is five hundred feet (500') wide, expanding uniformly to an outer edge width of three
thousand five hundred feet (3,500'). The altitude of the inner edge is the same as the altitude of the runway threshold at the centerline. The floor of
the zone rises from the inner edge one foot (1') for each thirty four feet (34') of horizontal distance (34:1), for a distance of ten thousand feet
(10,000').
2. Height Limitations:
a. Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall construct or alter any structure, nor plant or grow any tree, so as to penetrate any Approach
Overlay Zone created herein.
b. No person shall establish or maintain any private roadway in any location that would result in penetration of any AO Zone by any portion of any
vehicle that shall be permitted to operate upon such roadway.
B. Controlled Activity Zone (CA):
1. Defined: An area of fixed size, underlying the innermost portion (closest to the runway end) of the AO Zone for that runway, descending from the
floor of the AO Zone to the ground. The width and length of CA Zones may vary, and may be different on each runway end. The CA Zones for the
airport are as follows:
a. Runway 36 (CA36): Underlying the innermost two thousand five hundred feet (2,500') of the AO Zone at the south end of the runway, the width of
the CA Zone is one thousand feet (1,000') at the inner edge and expands uniformly to a width of one thousand seven hundred fifty feet (1,750').
b. Runway 18 (CA18): Underlying the innermost two thousand five hundred feet (2,500') of the AO Zone at the south end of the runway, the width of
the CA Zone is one thousand feet (1,000') at the inner edge and expands uniformly to a width of one thousand seven hundred fifty feet (1,750').
c. Runway 30/12 (CA30, CA12): Underlying the innermost one thousand seven hundred feet (1,700') of the AO Zone at each end of the runway, the
width of each CA Zone is one thousand feet (1,000') at the inner edge, expanding uniformly to a width of one thousand five hundred ten feet
(1,510').
2. Use Limitation: No person shall establish or maintain any noncompatible use in any Controlled Activity Zone.
C. Horizontal Overlay Zone (HO):
1. Defined: The airspace above a horizontal plane, the perimeter of which is established by swinging arcs of ten thousand foot (10,000') radii from the
center of the inner edge of the AO Zones of Runways 36, 18, and 30, and an arc of five thousand foot (5,000') radius from the center of the inner
edge of the AO Zone of Runway 12, and connecting the adjacent arcs by lines tangent to those arcs. The floor of the HO Zone is one hundred fifty
feet (150') above the airport elevation, or one thousand three hundred sixty three feet (1,363') above mean sea level.
2. Height Limitation: Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall construct or alter any structure, or plant or grow any tree, so as to penetrate
the Horizontal Overlay Zone created herein.
D. Transitional Overlay Zone (TO):
1. Defined: The airspace above a sloping plane rising from the sides of each runway and from the sides of each AO Zone at the rate of one foot (1') of
elevation for each seven feet (7') horizontally (7:1). The TO Zones for the airport are as follows:
a. Runway 36 (TO36): Along each side of the runway, beginning at a point five hundred feet (500') from the centerline of the runway and at right
angles to the runway centerline, and from each side of the AO Zone at the south end of the runway, at right angles to the extended runway
centerline. The TO Zone is interrupted at the point where it intersects the HO Zone, and resumes at the outer edge of the CO Zone (see
subsection E of this section) and continues outward for a distance of five thousand feet (5,000') from the edge of the AO Zone.
b. Runway 18 (TO18): Along each side of the runway, beginning at a point five hundred feet (500') from the centerline of the runway and at right
angles to the runway centerline, and from each side of the AO Zone at the north end of the runway at right angles to the extended runway
centerline. The TO Zone ends at the point where it intersects the HO Zone.
c. Runway 30/12 (TO30/12): Along each side of the runway, beginning at a point five hundred feet (500') from the centerline of the runway and at
right angles to the runway centerline, and from each side of the AO Zone at each end of the runway at right angles to the extended runway
centerline. The TO Zone ends at the point where it intersects the HO Zone.
2. Height Limitations:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 152/358
a. Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall construct or alter any structure, or plant or grow any tree, so as to penetrate any Transitional
Overlay Zone created herein.
b. No person shall establish or maintain any private roadway in any location that would result in penetration of any Transitional Overlay Zone by any
portion of any vehicle that shall be permitted to operate upon such roadway.
E. Conical Overlay Zone (CO):
1. Defined: The airspace above a sloped horizontal plane beginning at the periphery of the HO Zone and rising one foot (1') in height for each twenty
feet (20') horizontally (20:1) for a horizontal distance of four thousand feet (4,000').
2. Height Limitations: Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall construct or alter any structure, or plant or grow any tree, so as to penetrate
the Conical Overlay Zone created herein. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-4: GENERAL ZONING REGULATIONS:
A. Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall construct or alter any structure in any zone created herein without having first obtained a building
permit from the building official or a zoning permit from the Zoning Administrator. No person shall be issued a permit for any construction or alteration
without a determination or finding from the FAA. (See subsection 7-3-6B of this chapter.) Such finding or determination shall not find or determine that
the proposed construction or alteration:
1. Would create a hazard.
2. Would establish a noncompatible use.
3. Would endanger the general safety, health and welfare of persons in the vicinity of the airport, or occupants of aircraft in flight.
4. Would result in the raising of the minimum instrument flight altitude of any Federal airway, approved off airway route, or instrument approach
procedure to the airport.
B. Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall occupy any structure in any zone created herein without having first obtained an occupancy
permit from the building official or Zoning Administrator. No person shall be issued an occupancy permit for any noncompatible use.
C. No person shall establish or maintain any private roadway in any location that would result in penetration of any zone created herein by any portion of
any vehicle that shall be permitted to operate upon such roadway.
D. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no person shall, in any zone created by this chapter, or upon any land or water underlying such
zones:
1. Establish any putrescible waste landfill, or open air composting facility one (1) acre in size, or larger.
2. Create, alter, or maintain any structure or use that would create a bird strike hazard.
3. Create, alter, or maintain any structure or use in such a manner as to create electrical or radio interference with aviation navigational signals or
aircraft communications.
4. Install, align or use any lighting devices that make it difficult for pilots to distinguish between airport lights and others, create glare in the eyes of
pilots, or otherwise impair visibility.
5. Produce steam, smoke, or other visual hazard that would impair visibility.
6. Create, alter, or maintain any structure or use that would endanger or interfere with landing, takeoff or maneuvering of any aircraft.
7. Plant, or allow the growth of, any tree, which, during the normal life cycle of such tree, can be expected to grow into any zone created herein. (Ord.
09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-5: LIGHTING AND MARKING:
A. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, any person constructing or altering any structure located in any zone created by this chapter shall
install all lighting or markings upon said structure as shall be recommended by the FAA as a part of its review of the applicant's notice of proposed
construction or alteration. Such lighting or markings shall be made in a manner consistent with FAA regulations and advisories.
B. Any permit or variance granted under the provisions of this chapter may be so conditioned so as to require the owner of the land, structure, or tree in
question to permit the City or County, at its own expense, to install, operate, and maintain such lighting and/or markings as the City or County deems
necessary to indicate to operators of aircraft the presence of an airport obstruction. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-6: ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE:
A. Administration Of Regulations: The building official or Zoning Administrator shall perform the administration of these zoning regulations.
B. Notice Of Construction: Any person who proposes to construct or alter any structure in or underlying any of the zones created herein shall notify the
Administrator, Federal Aviation Administration, by filing with the appropriate Federal agency, an executed FAA Form 7460-1, notice of proposed
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 153/358
construction or alteration (see section 7-3-17, "Appendix II", of this chapter). Such notice should be given sixty (60) days prior to, and shall be given no
later than thirty (30) days prior to the earlier of the following dates:
1. The date the proposed construction or alteration is to begin.
2. The date an application for a building permit or occupancy permit is to be filed.
C. Waiver Of Notice Requirements: In the event of an emergency involving essential public services, public health, or public safety that requires immediate
construction, the building official, or Zoning Administrator, may waive the thirty (30) day notice requirement, provided that the applicant complies with
the requirements of 14 CFR FAR, part 77.17(d).
D. Issuance Of Permit: Except as otherwise provided herein, the building official or Zoning Administrator shall not issue any building permit or occupancy
permit without first:
1. Having received from the applicant a copy of the applicable FAA Form 7460-1, as submitted under subsection B of this section, and the
corresponding finding or determination from the FAA that the proposed construction or alteration complies with section 7-3-4 of this chapter.
2. Having determined that the proposed use is not noncompatible, and is consistent with the zoning provisions contained herein.
E. Exceptions: No FAA Form 7460-1 is required to be submitted to the FAA or to the building official or Zoning Administrator for a building permit for
construction or alteration of any structure which the building official or Zoning Administrator has determined that:
1. The proposed structure meets the requirements for shielding. Each and all of the following requirements are required for a determination of
shielding:
a. The property upon which the construction or alteration is proposed is located within the congested area of a City.
b. The proposed structure does not lie within any CA Zone.
c. There exists a structure or structures of a permanent and substantial nature at least as tall and at least as wide as the proposed structure, and
which lie(s) between the location of the proposed construction or alteration, and a point on the runway centerline at the threshold of the closest end
of the closest runway of the airport.
d. The shielding structure is within five hundred feet (500') of the structure that is proposed for construction or alteration.
e. It is evident beyond a reasonable doubt that the shielded structure will not adversely affect aerial navigation.
2. The proposed structure is an antenna that is no greater than twenty feet (20') in height, and does not increase the height of an existing antenna
structure.
3. The proposed structure is an airport, aerial navigation, or meteorological device, of a type approved by the FAA, the location and height of which is
fixed by function.
F. Waiver: The building official or Zoning Administrator shall set aside the provision of subsection D1 of this section when the following conditions have
been met:
1. The applicant has provided evidence that an applicable FAA Form 7460-1 has been submitted in accordance with subsection B of this section, and
that thirty (30) days or more have elapsed since said submission.
2. That the FAA has not issued a determination in response to the applicable FAA Form 7460-1.
3. The applicant agrees that should the subsequent FAA determination, when issued, find that the proposed construction or alteration constitutes a
hazard, or otherwise fails to comply with section 7-3-4 of this chapter, that the construction or alteration shall be revised and/or reconstructed so as to
alleviate the condition which the determination has found to be adverse.
a. The applicant further agrees that required revision and/or reconstruction shall be completed within one hundred twenty (120) days of the issuance
of the FAA determination.
b. The applicant further agrees that failure to revise or reconstruct as provided herein constitutes a nuisance, and is subject to abatement in
accordance with applicable law. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-7: NONCONFORMITIES:
A. The regulations prescribed herein are not retroactive and shall not be construed to require the removal of any tree, or the reconstruction or alteration, or
the discontinuation of any use of any structure made nonconforming by the adoption of this chapter.
B. Nothing contained herein shall require any change in the construction or alteration, or the intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of
which was begun prior to the effective date hereof, and which is completed within one (1) year thereafter.
C. No preexisting nonconforming structure, use, or tree shall be rebuilt, altered, allowed to grow higher, or be replanted, so as to constitute a greater
airport hazard than it was at the time that these regulations were adopted.
D. Whenever the building official or Zoning Administrator determines that a nonconforming structure has been abandoned, or more than fifty percent (50%)
torn down, physically deteriorated, damaged, or decayed, no building permit or occupancy permit shall be issued that would allow such structure to
exceed the applicable height and use provisions of this chapter. Any tree so damaged or destroyed shall be subject to the provisions of subsection 7-3-
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 154/358
4D7 of this chapter.
Notwithstanding the previous provisions of this section, the owner of any preexisting nonconforming structure or tree shall be required to permit the
installation, operation, or maintenance thereon of any markers and/or lights as shall be deemed necessary by the City or County to indicate to the
operators of aircraft, the presence of such structure or tree. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the
City or County. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-8: AIRPORT ZONING COMMISSION:
Pursuant to the provisions of section 329.9 of the Iowa Code, there shall be a Mason City Municipal Airport Zoning Commission, consisting of seven (7)
members, two (2) of whom shall be appointed by the City of Mason City, two (2) of whom shall be appointed by the City of Clear Lake, two (2) of whom
shall be appointed by the Board of Supervisors of Cerro Gordo County, and one (1) additional member whom shall be selected by a majority vote of the
City and County appointed members, and who shall serve as Chairperson of said commission. The terms of such members shall be as provided by
section 329.9 of the Iowa Code. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-9: AIRPORT ZONING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT:
Pursuant to the provisions of section 329.12 of the Iowa Code, there shall be a Mason City Airport Zoning Board of Adjustment, consisting of seven (7)
members, two (2) of whom shall be appointed by the City of Mason City, two (2) of whom shall be appointed by the City of Clear Lake, two (2) of whom
shall be appointed by the Board of Supervisors of Cerro Gordo County, and one (1) additional member who shall be selected by a majority vote of the City
and County appointed members, and who shall serve as Chairperson of said board. The terms of such members shall be as provided by section 329.12 of
the Iowa Code. The Airport Zoning Board of Adjustment shall have the duties and powers established by the Iowa Code. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-10: SPECIAL EXCEPTIONS:
A. With the concurrence of a majority vote, the Airport Zoning Board of Adjustment (the board) may, based upon a written determination from the FAA,
reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of any administrative official and may modify the provisions of this chapter in favor of an
applicant, provided:
1. Any height or use limitation contained in this chapter that is modified by the board shall not result in an obstruction to any aircraft in flight.
2. No use of land shall be permitted that would not be compatible with airport operations.
B. Any application for a special exception to the provisions of this chapter shall include as a part thereof, the written determination of the FAA pertaining to
the application, and no application shall be set for hearing by the board in the absence of such FAA determination. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-11: VARIANCES:
A. Any person desiring to construct or alter any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or otherwise use property in a manner that would constitute a
violation of this chapter, may apply to the board for a variance from these regulations. The board shall consider no application for a variance to the
requirements of this chapter unless a copy of the application has been submitted to the Airport Commission for their opinion as to the aeronautical
effects of such a variance. If the Airport Commission fails to respond to the board within sixty (60) days from its receipt of the copy of the application,
the board may make its decision in the absence of the Airport Commission opinion. Such variances may be granted by the board only where the literal
application of these regulations would result in unnecessary hardship, and are subject to the following:
1. Such variance would not be contrary to the public interest.
2. Such variance would be in the spirit of this chapter and of chapter 329 of the Iowa Code.
3. Such variance shall be granted subject to any reasonable conditions that the board may deem necessary to effectuate the purposes of this chapter
and of chapter 329 of the Iowa Code.
4. Such variance shall be subject to the requirement that the applicant shall install, operate, and maintain such markings and lighting, at the applicant's
own expense, as may be necessary to indicate to aircraft operators the existence of an airport obstruction as determined by the board.
5. Such variance shall be subject to the reservation of the right of the City and the airport, at their own expense, to go onto applicant's property to
install, operate, and maintain thereon such FAA approved markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to operators of aircraft the existence of
an airport obstruction.
B. Any person aggrieved or affected by any decision of the Airport Zoning Board of Adjustment may appeal such decision, pursuant to the provisions of the
Iowa Code. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-12: ENFORCEMENT:
Enforcement of the provisions of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the building official or Zoning Administrator, or such person(s) as the building
official or Zoning Administrator shall, from time to time, direct. However such duties of enforcement and administration shall not include any of the powers
herein delegated to the Airport Zoning Board of Adjustment. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-13: EQUITABLE REMEDIES:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 155/358
The City or the airport may, pursuant to section 329.5 of the Iowa Code, maintain an action in equity to restrain and abate as a nuisance the creation,
establishment or maintenance of an airport hazard, in violation of any provision established by this chapter, on any property, whether within or without the
territorial limits of the City. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-14: PROHIBITED ACTS:
Except as herein provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct or alter any structure, use any land, or grow any tree in violation of the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-15: PENALTIES:
Each violation of these regulations shall constitute a misdemeanor and the perpetrator thereof, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed
one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment in the County Jail for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. Each day a violation occurs or continues to
exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 09-01, 1-6-2009)
7-3-16: CONFLICTING REGULATIONS:
In the event of any conflict between regulations contained in this chapter and any other regulations applicable to the same area, whether the conflict be
with respect to height of structures or trees, use of structures or land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or requirement shall prevail. (Ord.
09-01, 1-6-2009)
