Title 8
PUBLIC SAFETY AND POLICE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
FIRE DEPARTMENT
8-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a paid Fire Department of the City which shall consist of the Chief of the Fire Department and such other officers and
firefighters as are necessary to man the equipment for the proper extinguishing of fires, pursuant to section 364.16, Code of Iowa. There shall be
established within the Fire Department the following bureaus, namely:
Division of Fire Operations
Division of Fire Prevention and Code Enforcement
Division of Emergency Medical Services
(1953 Code § 32-1; amd. 1985 Code; Ord. 92-5, 2-18-1991; 2017 Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 156/358
8-1-2: APPOINTMENTS:
A. All appointments of the Fire Department shall be made by the Chief of the Fire Department with the approval of the City Council, in accordance with
chapter 400, Code of Iowa, relating to the civil service laws and the rules and regulations of the Mason City Civil Service Commission, pursuant to title
2, chapter 1 of this Code. (1953 Code § 32-2; amd. 1985 Code)
B. All firefighting personnel appointed to or employed by the Fire Department shall, on or before completion of the probationary period, live within a ten
(10) mile radius of the City limits. (1985 Code)
8-1-3: CHIEF OF FIRE DEPARTMENT:
As set out in section 400.13, Code of Iowa, the Chief of the Fire Department shall be appointed by the City Administrator, subject to the approval of the
City Council, and shall hold office thereafter, or until a successor is duly appointed and qualified. The Chief shall have had a minimum of five (5) years'
experience in a Fire Department, or three (3) years' experience in a Fire Department and two (2) years of comparable experience or educational training.
Any person who becomes Chief of the Fire Department shall be allowed to transfer all rights the person may have acquired under chapter 410 or 411,
Code of Iowa, including employer contributions during the person's years of service in a City, employee contributions, and interest, to the retirement
system of the City that hires the person as Chief. Such person shall also transfer the number of years served as seniority toward other benefits provided
by the City which hires the person. If the Chief is relieved of that position, the person shall be entitled to remain in the department for which the person was
Chief at a position commensurate with the person's civil service status, even if this means that the City must create a position for the person to fill until a
regular position becomes vacant. The Chief of the Fire Department shall be responsible for the discipline, control and efficiency of the department and
shall have authority over all members of the department and the assignments thereof. The Chief shall have full control over all apparatus, equipment, tools
and other property belonging to the Fire Department. (Ord. 94-16, 7-19-1994; amd. 2017 Code)
8-1-4: BATTALIONS:
The Fire Department shall be divided into three (3) shifts, to be known as "battalions", designated as first, second and third battalions. One (1) battalion
shall be on duty from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. one day to eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. the next day, and shall be known as the duty battalion. Two (2)
battalions shall be off duty from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. one day to eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. the next day, and shall be known as off duty battalions. (Ord.
1128, 10-5-1970)
8-1-5: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Chief of the Fire Department, with the approval and consent of the City Administrator, shall make all the rules and regulations for the government of
the department. The Chief of the Fire Department shall also keep such records as will accurately show the activities of the department and the members
thereof. (1953 Code § 32-5; amd. 2017 Code)
8-1-6: CONTROL OF FIRES:
The Chief of the Fire Department, or in his absence at a fire, the ranking officer present thereat, shall have full control and command at all fires and of all
persons present in the vicinity of such fires; he shall have authority to summon any and all persons present to aid under his direction in the extinguishment
of any fire, in removing of personal property from burning buildings or any other building; he shall have the power to cut off gas, to cut off electric wires,
etc., in the vicinity of the fire, or to blow up or to cause to be blown up or otherwise dispose of any building or structure for the purpose of checking the
progress of any fire. He shall have authority to suppress all tumult or disorder at a fire and to require any person to leave the vicinity of the fire. (1953 Code
§ 32-6)
8-1-7: CALLING OF OFF DUTY BATTALIONS:
The Chief of the Fire Department shall have the power to call the off duty battalion and to call outside aid from other cities at any time he deems it
necessary. (1953 Code § 32-7)
8-1-8: OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT:
The Chief of the Fire Department may assign to any employee or firefighter, on his off duty time, any work similar to his duties as employee or firefighter.
For the purposes of pension and retirement rights, injuries, disabilities or death suffered while on such assigned work shall be considered as being
suffered in line of duty. (1953 Code § 32-8; amd. 1985 Code)
8-1-9: IMPERSONATION OF FIREFIGHTERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person not a member of the Fire Department to wear any cap, badge or other insignia or any part of the uniform of a member of
the Fire Department. (1953 Code § 32-10)
8-1-10: REPORTS:
The Chief of the Fire Department shall make monthly and annual reports to the City Administrator of such data and information as may be required by the
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 157/358
Mayor. In his annual report, the Chief of the Fire Department shall include a detailed statement of the condition of the apparatus and property in the
custody of the department, together with his recommendations for the improvement of the department. (1953 Code § 32-11; amd. 2017 Code)
8-1-11: FIRES OUTSIDE CITY:
A. Duties At Municipal Airport: The jurisdiction of the City, for fire prevention and fire protection and the giving of other emergency assistance, is hereby
extended to the Municipal Airport, and the Chief of the Fire Department is hereby authorized and directed to cause inspections to be made of property
thereon, and to enforce fire prevention regulations thereat, to fight fires and give other emergency assistance thereto in the same manner as within the
corporate limits of the City. (1953 Code § 33-1)
B. Aid To Other Communities: The Chief of the Fire Department, or in his absence the person acting in his place and stead, is hereby authorized, when
called upon by a community having an organized Fire Department, to send to the relief of such community such personnel and equipment from the Fire
Department of the City as in his judgment may be spared from the City at that time for such purpose. This subsection shall not require the Fire
Department to answer calls from such communities, but the answering of such calls shall be in the discretion of the Chief of the Fire Department or, in
his absence, a person acting in his place and stead. (1953 Code § 33-2; amd. 2017 Code)
C. Aid Outside Communities: The Chief of the Fire Department or, in his absence, the person acting in his place and stead is hereby authorized to answer
calls for emergency assistance within Cerro Gordo County and within the limits of counties adjacent to Cerro Gordo County, and to communities having
an organized Fire Department, and to send to the relief thereof such firefighters and equipment from the Fire Department of the City as, in his
judgment, may be spared from the City at that time for such purpose. This subsection shall not require the Fire Department to answer such calls, but
the answering of such calls shall be in the discretion of the Chief of the Fire Department or, in his absence, a person acting in his place and stead.
(1953 Code § 33-3; amd. Ord. 92-5, 2-18-1991; 2017 Code)
D. Contracts For Aid: The Chief of the Fire Department, or in his absence the person acting in his place and stead, is hereby authorized when called upon
by any person or other municipality with whom the City has heretofore contracted or with whom the City may hereafter contract to provide fire
protection or other emergency assistance, to send to the relief of such person or other municipality such firefighters and equipment from the Fire
Department of the City as, in his judgment, may be spared from the City at that time for such purpose. This subsection shall not require the Fire
Department to answer such calls from such persons or other municipalities, but the answering of such calls shall be in the discretion of the Chief of the
Fire Department or, in his absence, a person acting in his place and stead. (1953 Code § 33-4; amd. Ord. 92-5, 2-18-1991)
E. Pension, Retirement Privileges: All firefighters and equipment of the Fire Department, while engaged in answering calls provided for in this section, shall
be considered as being in the service of the City and acting in the course of their employment and in the line of duty. Firefighters, while answering such
calls, shall have the same rights, privileges and protections as though answering calls within the corporate limits of the City, including rights to pension
and retirement fund privileges. (1953 Code § 33-5; amd. Ord. 92-5, 2-18-1991)
ARTICLE A. CITY OPERATED AMBULANCE SERVICES
8-1A-1: RATES ESTABLISHED:
Rates for ambulance service shall be established from time to time as set forth by the City Council in resolution form. (Ord. 06-13, 5-16-2006)
8-1A-2: CITY ADMINISTRATOR'S AUTHORITY TO ADJUST:
The City Administrator is hereby authorized and empowered, in the City Administrator's discretion, to make adjustments in the rates and charges to be
fixed for City ambulance service in such cases where the need for such ambulance service is required to repeatedly transport a person of limited financial
means. The City Administrator shall have the authority to require proof of the financial status of a person seeking the benefits of this section for such
service. (Ord. 06-13, 5-16-2006)
8-1A-3: TRANSPORT SERVICE AGREEMENTS:
The City Administrator is hereby authorized and empowered to enter into agreements with any authorized officials or Governing Body to provide
emergency ambulance transport service. Such agreement shall be reduced in writing and signed before any such service is rendered and shall provide
that such official or Governing Body shall guarantee the payment of fees. All service authorized by County officers shall be billed directly to the County
Sheriff's Office. (Ord. 06-13, 5-16-2006)
Chapter 2
POLICE DEPARTMENT
8-2-1: ORGANIZATION:
Pursuant to section 372.14, Code of Iowa, there is hereby established the Mason City Police Department consisting of the Chief of Police, Captains,
Lieutenants, Sergeants, police officers, clerks and other employees, the number of any rank to be determined by the City Council. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011)
8-2-2: APPOINTMENTS:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 158/358
All appointments to the Police Department, except that of the Chief of Police, shall be made by the Chief of Police with the approval of the City Council in
accordance with chapter 400, Code of Iowa, relating to the civil service laws and the rules and regulations of the Mason City Civil Service Commission,
pursuant to title 2, chapter 1 of this Code. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011; amd. 2017 Code)
8-2-3: CHIEF OF POLICE:
As set out in section 400.13, Code of Iowa, the Chief of Police shall be appointed by the City Administrator, subject to the approval of the City Council, and
shall hold office thereafter, or until a successor is duly appointed and qualified. The Chief of Police shall be responsible for the discipline, control and
efficiency of the department and shall have authority over all members of the department and the assignments thereof. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011)
8-2-4: DUTIES OF CHIEF OF POLICE:
The Chief of Police shall have the general management, supervision, control and direction of all members of the Police Department, police radio system
and of all property belonging to or appertaining to the Police Department. He shall be the executive head of the Police Department. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011)
8-2-5: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to keep a record of arrests made by any member of the Police Department, whether such arrest is made under
the provisions of this Code or under the laws of the State of Iowa, which record shall show the offense for which the arrest was made, by whom made and
the disposition of the charge. He shall make such periodical reports requested. He shall supervise the collection and accounting of all parking fees, fines
for overtime parking and other parking violations collected by or through the Police Department or Parking Enforcement Bureau for and on behalf of the
City Clerk. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011; amd. 2017 Code)
8-2-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Chief of Police shall have power and it shall be his duty to promulgate orders, rules and regulations for the conduct and guidance of the members of
the Police Department, not inconsistent with law or the provisions of this Code, and shall see to the enforcement thereof. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011)
8-2-7: DISCIPLINE:
The Chief of Police may peremptorily suspend, demote or discharge any member of the department for neglect of duty, disobedience of orders,
misconduct or failure to properly perform his duties. Such actions will be in accordance with applicable laws, policies, and current collective bargaining
agreement. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011)
8-2-8: EXTRA DUTY ASSIGNMENT:
The Chief of the Police Department may assign to any employee or police officer, on his off duty time, any work similar to his duties as employee or police
officer. For the purposes of pension and retirement rights, injuries, disabilities or death suffered while on such assigned work shall be considered as being
suffered in line of duty. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011)
8-2-9: POWERS AND DUTIES OF MEMBERS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and of every member of the Police Department to preserve the peace, to enforce the laws of the State and the
provisions of this Code, to protect persons and property, to guard the public health, to prevent crimes and to arrest persons offending against the laws of
the State, the provisions of this Code or the lawful orders of the police. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011)
8-2-10: RESERVE POLICE FORCE:
A. Force Created: There is hereby created and established the Mason City reserve police force as provided by chapter 80D, Code of Iowa, and subject to
the regulations therein contained. The reserve police force shall serve until abolished by the City Council.
B. Membership: Membership in said reserve police force shall be as prescribed in said reserve's bylaws, rules and regulations and shall be subject to the
approval of the Chief of Police and City Council. The Chief of Police may, from time to time, prescribe such other bylaws, rules and regulations as they,
in their sole discretion, may deem to be desirable. All rules, regulations or bylaws of said reserve shall be approved by the Chief of Police.
Members of the reserve shall serve at the discretion of the Chief of Police and shall be removed and discharged from said reserve at any time upon
violation of any bylaw, rule or regulation prescribed as aforesaid or upon recommendation of the reserve police executive council.
Members of the reserve shall be subject to lawful orders of a member of the Mason City Police Department.
Members of the reserve shall be considered employees of the City during those periods when they are performing police duties as authorized and
directed by the Chief of Police or his designee, and they shall receive a salary of one dollar ($1.00) per year. However, said reserve members shall not
be entitled to benefits or obligations of police retirement benefits or civil service. (Ord. 11-11, 9-20-2011; amd. 2017 Code)

Chapter 3
GENERAL OFFENSES
8-3-1: BARBED WIRE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use barbed wire for the purpose of constructing any fence or of enclosing any tree, ornament, lot, park or plot of
ground except as follows:
A. Where said fences or enclosures exist at the time of passage of this section, used in agricultural situations permitted by zoning, City Council approval
shall be required to construct a new fence or replace an existing fence.
B. In industrial and commercial installations, when used atop a security type fence where said barbed wire is at least six feet (6') above ground level.
C. In other special areas as approved by the City Council.
The use of barbed wire shall not be permitted where it projects over street rights-of-way or over other private property. (Ord. 1363, 6-21-1976)
8-3-2: CEMETERIES; PROTECTION OF:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully destroy, mutilate, deface or remove any gravestone, monument or other structure in a cemetery or to mutilate,
cut, injure or destroy any fence, railing, tree, shrubbery, flowers or lawn in a cemetery, or to walk or drive in any cemetery except upon the walks and
drives therein provided, or to use any cemetery for any disrespectful or improper purposes. It shall also be unlawful for any person to enter or be within the
cemetery grounds from nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 10-17, 10-5-2010)
8-3-3: DEAD ANIMALS; HAULING OF:
Pursuant to title 4, chapter 2, article A of this Code, it shall be unlawful to haul, drag or otherwise transport any dead animal or portions of such animal
through the streets of the City without having the same in a covered, watertight container. (1985 Code)
8-3-4: DEFACING OR INJURING NOTICES OR PUBLIC SIGNS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, tear down, deface, injure or destroy, or interfere with any notice, proclamation, publication, placard, traffic
sign, signal or device, street name or number or house number or railway crossing sign or signal or sign posted or placed by authority of the City or under
license therefrom at any time before such notice, proclamation, publication, placard or sign shall have expired. (1985 Code)
8-3-5: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, except Federal, State, County and Municipal law enforcement officers in the performance of duty or training, to shoot or
discharge any firearm or air gun except when authorized and permitted by the Chief of Police after investigation for the following purposes:
A. The lawful activity of a person or firearm organization upon premises which are safe for said activity and which will not interfere with the peaceful use
and enjoyment of adjacent property.
B. To abate a nuisance caused by birds or animals upon the property owned or rented by said applicant.
All persons discharging firearms within the Municipality for the purposes set forth in subsections A and B of this section must have the written permit to
discharge said firearm(s) at the time of discharge or, when issued to a firearm organization, said permit must be displayed in a conspicuous place when
said activity is being conducted. The permits shall be nonassignable and may only be used for the purposes and at the time specified therein. (Ord.
1430, 3-20-1978)
8-3-6: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful for a person to do or permit any of the following:
A. Engage in fighting or violent behavior in any public place or near any lawful assembly of persons; provided, that participants in athletic contests may
engage in such conduct which is reasonably related to that sport. (1985 Code)
B. Make loud and raucous noise in the vicinity of any residence, public building, or hospital which causes unreasonable distress to the occupants thereof.
(1985 Code; amd. 2017 Code)
C. Direct abusive epithets or make any threatening gesture which the person knows or reasonably should know is likely to provoke a violent reaction by
another.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 160/358
D. Without lawful authority or color of authority, the person disturbs any lawful assembly or meeting of persons by conduct intended to disrupt the meeting
or assembly.
E. By words or action, initiates or circulates a report or warning of fire, epidemic or other catastrophe knowing such report to be false or such warning to be
baseless.
F. Without authority or justification, the person, group or assemblage of persons obstructs any street, sidewalk, highway or other public way with the intent
to prevent or hinder its lawful use by others. (1985 Code)
8-3-7: DISTRIBUTION OF BILLS, POSTING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to post or attach, paint, print or write any placard, notice, poster, bill, advertisement, announcement, picture or sign on
any pole, post, fence, hydrant, bridge, wall, building, window, structure, sidewalk, tree or any public property, nor shall the same be placed upon any such
privately owned property without first having secured the consent of the owner or person controlling such privately owned property. It shall also be unlawful
to scatter or throw upon any street, sidewalk or other public place any bills, pictures, notices or advertisements.
It shall also be unlawful for any person to throw, place, deposit or in any manner attach any bills, paper, cards, samples or other advertising matter in or on
any automobile or vehicle while such automobile or vehicle is standing or is parked upon any public street, alley or parking lot within the City, except that
this provision shall not apply to legal notices as provided by law. (1953 Code § 28-60)
8-3-8: CONSUMER FIREWORKS:
The purpose of this section is to regulate the sale, use, or exploding of consumer fireworks within the City. All sales, use, and exploding of consumer
fireworks shall conform to Iowa Code section 727.2, the requirements of this section, and all other applicable requirements of this Code.
A. Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
CONSUMER FIREWORKS: Shall have the same meaning as defined in Iowa Code section 727.2.
FIRE MARSHAL: An inspector appointed by the Office of the State Fire Marshal, or, if so designated by the State Fire Marshal's Office, the City Fire
Marshal.
PERMANENT BUILDING: A structure enclosed within interior walls and having a roof, built, erected and framed of a combination of materials for the
support, enclosure, shelter or protection of persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind, and which is permanently affixed to the land.
TEMPORARY STRUCTURE: A tent, canopy, stand, converted metal container, or similar enclosure that is not permanently affixed to the land, which is
not intended for permanent use, and is erected for the purpose of retail sales of consumer fireworks.
B. Sales; General Requirements:
1. Conformance With State And Local Law: All sales of consumer fireworks shall conform to the requirements of Iowa Code section 727.2, title 12,
"Zoning Regulations", of this Code, and all other applicable sections of this Code.
2. Application: Prior to establishing any sales outlet for consumer fireworks, an application on a form supplied by the Fire Department shall be
submitted, along with all required attachments, and the initial inspection fee, to the City Fire Marshal. Attachments shall include:
a. Proof Of License: Proof of licensing from the Office of the State Fire Marshal.
b. Proof Of Liability Insurance: Proof of liability insurance, separate from the building property insurance, covering all aspects of consumer fireworks
sales for a minimum amount per occurrence of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) and a minimum aggregate amount of two million dollars
($2,000,000.00).
c. Site Plan: All initial applications for establishment of a consumer fireworks sales outlet shall include a detailed site plan, drawn to a measurable
scale, showing the location of all permanent buildings on the site and the location of any temporary structures erected for sales of consumer
fireworks.
d. Emergency Contacts: The applicant shall submit a completed emergency contact information form for fireworks sales from the Mason City Fire
Department.
e. Transient Merchant License: Except for non-temporary sales and wholesale operations, all applicants shall provide proof of application for a
transient merchant license from the City Clerk.
3. Review: All initial applications for sales of consumer fireworks shall be reviewed and determined to be in compliance by the Development Review
Committee, as created in title 12, chapter 7 of this Code prior to establishment of the sales outlet or erection of any temporary structure. Upon
determination that the application is complete, the Fire Marshal shall forward the application to the Development Review Committee. The
Development Review Committee shall determine whether the request for retail sales of consumer fireworks is in compliance with the requirements of
the State Code, this section and all other applicable requirements of this Code.
a. Compliance: All sales shall comply with Iowa Code section 727.2. Location of sales, storage of consumer fireworks, and setbacks of temporary
structures shall comply with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) standards, as adopted by State Code, and with the International Fire
Code, as adopted by the City, as well as with all applicable City zoning and building ordinances.
b. Sales In A Permanent Building:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 161/358
(1) Sale of consumer fireworks within a permanent building are allowed only within a building constructed and intended for use as a commercial or
retail/service form within the Z4, Multi-Use District, or an industrial form within the Z6, Industrial District, as set forth in section 12-8-3, table 2,
subsections D and J of this Code; however, sales of consumer fireworks may not be conducted within any part of a self storage building, or a
building containing a tavern function; and further provided that all other requirements of applicable State and local codes are met.
(2) Only the initial application to establish sales of consumer fireworks shall be reviewed by the Development Review Committee to determine that
sales will be in compliance. However, any expansion of the building or expansion onto additional properties shall not commence until the
Development Review Committee has reviewed the expansion and determined it to be in compliance.
c. Sales In A Temporary Structure:
(1) Sales of consumer fireworks in a temporary structure shall be permitted only upon property within the Z6 Industrial District, as designated by
title 12 of this Code.
(2) The initial application for sales in a temporary structure shall be reviewed by the Development Review Committee to determine that sales will
be in compliance. When future inspections by the Fire Marshal identify that a change in the location of fireworks sales, display or storage,
setback of temporary structures, or other material change from the approved plan has occurred, the Fire Marshal shall order sales to cease until
a revised plan has been reviewed by the Development Review Committee and determined to be in compliance.
4. Inspections: Upon determination that all application and review requirements are complete, the City Fire Marshal shall notify the applicant and
schedule an inspection.
a. Sales of consumer fireworks within a permanent building shall be inspected annually.
b. Sales of consumer fireworks from a temporary structure shall be inspected after erection of the temporary structure for each season in which sales
will be conducted, but prior to any sales.
c. If a transient merchant license is required, the operator shall present a copy of the license to the Fire Marshal upon the initial inspection.
5. Violations: Should the Fire Marshal find any violation of this section, State Code or other applicable codes or ordinances, sales shall immediately
cease. Sales may not resume until the violation has been corrected and the Fire Marshal has determined that the operation is in full conformance.
6. Renewal:
a. Permanent Building: An emergency contact information form and transient merchant license, if applicable, for sales of consumer fireworks in a
permanent building shall be renewed annually. The Fire Marshal shall inspect the premises to determine that the sales conducted therein continue
to comply with State and local codes.
b. Temporary Structures:
(1) A consumer fireworks permit for a temporary structure shall expire on the date that the temporary structure is removed, or July 8 of each year,
whichever is sooner.
(2) Each such temporary structure must be removed by July 15 of each year.
(3) If the permit holder wishes to reestablish sales in a temporary structure at the same location the next year, the applicant shall obtain a new
updated permit or license from the State Fire Marshal's Office, as required by State Code. The application and review process for the
reestablished temporary structure sales shall be the same as required for the original application.
7. Revocation: The Fire Marshal may revoke the approval at any time due to false or fraudulent information during the application and inspection
process, or any violation of State or local requirements.
8. Inspection Fees: Inspection fees shall be set by resolution approved by the City Council.
C. Dates Of Permitted Sales:
1. All sale dates and requirements shall conform to the required City Code. Consumer fireworks may only be sold during those periods allowed under
the applicable Iowa Code.
2. Sales within a permanent structure or building shall be allowed between June 1 and July 8 and from December 10 until January 3.
3. Approved temporary structure or stand sales shall be allowed between June 13 and July 8. (Ord. 18-11, 11-20-2018)
D. Fireworks; Dates Of Exploding, Discharge And Use: No person shall explode or discharge a consumer fireworks device outside the following dates and
hours:
1. July 3 through July 4, from the hours of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. until eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
Exemption: Except as provided in subsection G, "Sanctioned Fireworks Shows And Displays", of this section.
E. Prohibited Discharge: Fireworks may not be set off on public property that includes cemeteries and parks.
F. Location Restrictions: Fireworks, when set off, must be more than two hundred (200) yards from hospitals, hospice care centers, and nursing homes.
(Ord. 18-13, 12-4-2018)
G. Sanctioned Fireworks Shows And Displays: A special fireworks permit may be obtained from the Fire Department for display of fireworks by a display
operator or operators certified by the Pyrotechnics Guild International, outside the above listed dates for a public event approved by Fire Chief or the
City Council.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 162/358
H. Other Use: Use of pistols, canes, cannons or other appliances using blank cartridges shall only be used for bona fide athletic purposes, permitted
displays, or other uses approved by Fire Chief or the City Council. (Ord. 17-10, 6-20-2017)
I. Property Control/Penalty:
1. A person who uses a consumer firework in violation of subsection D of this section; or any person who is an owner, occupant, tenant, or otherwise
having any possessory control, individually or jointly with others, of any premises who either sponsors, conducts, hosts, invites or permits the use of
consumer fireworks on said premises which is in violation of subsection D, E or F of this section, and is the intentional result of, or within the
reasonable expectations of, the person or persons having such possessory control is deemed to be in violation of this section.
2. Violation of this section shall be a Municipal infraction punishable by a penalty of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Alternatively, violation of this
section can be charged by a peace officer of the City as a simple misdemeanor. (Ord. 18-12, 12-4-2018)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 19-14 - MOBILE VENDORS . Go to new ordinance.
8-3-9: FORTUNE TELLERS, PALMISTS, CLAIRVOYANTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on the business of or act as a fortune teller, palmist, clairvoyant or phrenologist, or to tell fortunes, practice
phrenology, palmistry or clairvoyancy. (1953 Code § 28-78)
8-3-10: GAMES IN STREET:
It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in any game or sport on any street, highway or public grounds within the business section of the City, or to
use any street, avenue, sidewalk or public grounds within the City for such purpose in such a manner as to interfere with traffic or travel thereon, or to
continue such use in any event contrary to the orders of any police officer. (1953 Code § 28-58; amd. 1985 Code)
8-3-11: INHALATION OF TOXIC VAPORS PROHIBITED:
No person shall knowingly smell or inhale the fumes of toxic vapors for the purpose of causing a condition of euphoria, excitement, exhilaration,
stupefaction, or dulled senses of the nervous system, or possess, buy, or use any such substance for the purpose of violating or aiding another to violate
this section. But this section does not apply to the inhalation of anesthesia for medical or dental purposes.
As used in this section, the term "toxic vapors" means the following substances or products containing such substances: acetone, alcohols (methyl,
isopropyl, propyl, or butyl), aliphatic acetates (ethyl, methyl, propyl, or methyl cellosolve acetate), allyl isothiocyanate, benzene, butane, carbon
tetrachloride, cyclohexane, ether, freons (Freon 11 and Freon 12), hexane, methyl ethyl ketone, methyl isobutyl ketone, methylene chloride, naphtha,
nitrous oxide, perchlorethylene, propane, toluene, trichloromethane, trichloroethylene, or xylene, or other chemical substance capable of causing similar
effects upon the human body. Evidence that a container, or a similar container, if the label is missing, lists one (1) or more of these substances is prima
facie evidence that the substance in such container contains toxic vapors and emits the fumes thereof. (Ord. 11-12, 9-20-2011)
8-3-12: LITTER, DEPOSIT OF:
A. Litter Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, leave or permit to remain upon any street, alley, stream or public place, or upon any
privately owned property any litter, debris or refuse of any kind, including, but not limited to, cigarette butts, garbage, paper, cardboard, cans, bottles,
tacks, wires, nails, discarded glassware, floor covering, building material, clothing, ashes, brush; such as straw, weeds and tree trimmings, except that
the owner may deposit the same upon his premises when confined in a proper working receptacle with a tight fitting cover except that it shall be lawful
for such litter, debris and refuse to be properly transported and discarded at the Cerro Gordo County landfill.
B. Fine: Any person convicted of violating this section is guilty of a simple misdemeanor punishable by a minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
C. Exception: Property owners or tenants who create a nuisance upon property under their control would be subject to the provisions of the nuisance
ordinance. (Ord. 08-13, 9-16-2008)
8-3-13: SKATEBOARDS:
A. Purpose: The purpose of this section is to provide reasonable rules and regulations for the use and operation of skateboards, and to establish areas
where the use and operation of same are prohibited for the protection, safety and general welfare of the public in the City.
B. Definitions: For use within this section, the following terms are defined:
BUSINESS: Any property open to the public upon which activities of a commercial or retail nature are routinely conducted.
BUSINESS DISTRICT: That area bounded by and including all streets which lie between Connecticut Avenue on the east, Jefferson Avenue on the
west, Fourth Street South on the south and Fifth Street North on the north.
SKATEBOARDS: A foot, motor or wind propelled vehicle consisting of a board equipped with two (2) or more wheels tandem and guided by the user or
rider standing on same and pushing same with foot power or operating with motor or wind power.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 163/358
C. Use; Restrictions: The riding or use of skateboards within the corporate limits of the City shall be subject to the following:
1. No person shall ride or use a skateboard at any time on any street, sidewalk, plaza area or public parking lot in the business district.
2. No person shall ride or use a skateboard on a street in a residential district or area which runs parallel to a hard surface sidewalk.
3. No person shall ride or use a skateboard in a publicly owned parking lot.
4. All persons using or riding skateboards within the City shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and shall give an audible signal before overtaking
and passing a pedestrian using the same sidewalk.
5. All persons using or riding a skateboard on any street or alley shall:
a. Observe all traffic regulations, laws, and ordinances.
b. Stay as near to the side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same
direction.
6. No person shall use or ride a skateboard on privately owned parking lots unless written permission has been obtained from the owner(s).
7. No person shall use or ride a skateboard on any sidewalk abutting a business. (Ord. 90-9, 6-4-1990)
8-3-14: OBSTRUCTING USE OF STREET, SIDEWALK, ALLEY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to shovel, rake, throw, place or deposit any snow, leaves or other material or thing onto any public street or sidewalk so
as to hinder or obstruct the regular use of such street, alley or sidewalk to its full width by vehicular or pedestrian traffic. (1953 Code § 57-3; amd. Ord.
904, 11-19-1962; 1985 Code)
8-3-15: OBSTRUCTING VISIBILITY AT INTERSECTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the visibility at any street intersection by placing any vehicles, trailers, equipment or machinery, or by
shoveling, raking, throwing, blowing or depositing any snow, leaves or other materials onto a public street, sidewalk, alley or parking so as to obstruct the
view of persons regularly using such streets for vehicular traffic. (1953 Code § 57-3; amd. Ord. 904, 11-19-1962; 1985 Code)
8-3-16: PARADES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to inaugurate, cause, lead or participate in any parade, celebration or demonstration upon any street, avenue or public
grounds unless a written permit for such parade, celebration or demonstration shall first have been obtained from the Chief of Police; provided, however,
that such permit shall not protect any person from prosecution for or conviction of disorderly conduct or for the violation of any of the provisions of this
Code on account of conduct during the course of such parade or procession. (1953 Code § 28-12)
8-3-17: PERMITTING DISTURBING THE PEACE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any quarreling, fighting or unusual noise or affray, or any act or conduct prohibited in any house or upon any
premises owned, occupied, possessed or controlled by such person, in such a manner as to disturb the peace of others or the public quiet of the
neighborhood. (1953 Code § 28-2)
8-3-18: POISON FOOD:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place any poison food or substance on any street, alley or other public or private grounds in such a way that it may
endanger human life or the life of any domestic animal, except that it shall be lawful to set poison on one's own premises for the purpose of ridding the
same of vermin. (1953 Code § 28-30)
8-3-19: PUBLIC PROPERTY, PRIVATE PROPERTY; DEFACING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure or destroy, or to assist or abet in defacing, injuring or destroying, any public building, bridge, pavement,
sidewalk, drain, sewer or any other public property or improvement, or to cut, hack, injure or destroy, or to assist or to abet another in cutting, hacking,
injuring or destroying, any pole, wire, tree, fence, railing, building or other property not owned by such person. (1953 Code §§ 28-36, 28-37; amd. 1985
Code)
8-3-20: RADIO INTERFERENCE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or be responsible for the operation of any machine, apparatus or equipment generating or causing high
frequency oscillations such as to interfere with radio reception or broadcasting, without first providing for the elimination of such interference insofar as it is
possible. (1953 Code § 28-79)
8-3-21: SHOOTING, THROWING MISSILES:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 164/358
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or shoot any missile, dart, shaft, slingshot, stick, stone or ball in such a manner as to hit, injure, or endanger
any person, window or other property. (1953 Code §§ 28-65, 28-67; amd. 2017 Code)
8-3-22: STREETS, INJURY TO PAVED OR OILED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or propel any tractor, engine or other vehicle having cleats, spurs or other nonslipping devices upon its wheels
upon any paved or oiled streets, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive, drag or propel any vehicle or other heavy object on or across any of the
paved or oiled streets in such a manner as to injure or deface such street. (1953 Code § 28-42)
8-3-23: STREET MATERIALS, TAKING OF:
It shall be unlawful for any person to take or appropriate to his private use any dirt, stone or other material or thing from any street, alley or public ground,
or from any other premises, unless consent of the owner has been first obtained. (1953 Code § 28-56)
8-3-24: STREET GUARDS, REMOVAL OF:
It shall be unlawful for any person to tear down, remove or carry away any fence, railing or other guard placed about any excavation, hole or pile of dirt,
rock or other material or to remove or carry away or extinguish the light of any lantern or other light which has been set as a warning at any excavation,
hole or pile of material. (1953 Code § 28-33)
8-3-25: STREETS, REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drag, scrape or grade the surface of any public street or portion thereof, or to place any oil, gravel or any other type of
surfacing material upon any public street or portion thereof, or perform any maintenance or repair upon any public street or portion thereof without having
first obtained written permission from the City Council. (Ord. 1018, 9-5-1967)
8-3-26: SURVEY MARKS, STAKES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, disturb, destroy, move or remove any survey marks or stakes, bench or grade marks or monuments
placed upon any public or private place for the purpose of fixing grades, locating streets or marking boundary lines or for any other purpose. (1953 Code
§ 28-35)
8-3-27: URINATING AND DEFECATING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally urinate or defecate upon any public street, public sidewalk or other public property or within public view
upon private property. Nothing in this section shall be construed as to prohibit any person from urinating or defecating in any public or private restroom.
(Ord. 1674, 3-21-1983)
8-3-28: BOW AND ARROW HUNTING; PUBLIC PROPERTY, PRIVATE PROPERTY; ARCHERY RANGES:
A. Permit: It shall be unlawful for anyone to hunt with a bow and arrow inside the City limits except when a permit has been obtained from the Chief of
Police after investigation and submission of proof of possession of all applicable State licenses and game stamps and submission of written consent
from the owner(s) or person(s) in control of said private property; or, if upon public property, written consent of the proper authority. The Mayor, subject
to the approval of the City Council, shall have the authority to sign the written consent for use of bow and arrows upon City owned public property.
Exception: Properties under the jurisdiction of the Parks and Recreation Board.
Each permit shall be for a period stated on its face, but not longer than the duration of any single bow hunting season. (Ord. 89-34, 12-18-1989, eff. 1-
11-1990)
Permits issued by the Iowa Department of Natural Resources as part of a Deer Management Zone Program will be valid for the duration of the
program, as stated on the permit face. (2017 Code)
B. Archery Ranges: It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or shoot a bow and arrow within the City limits for any other purpose; unless upon an
archery range for which a permit has been obtained from the Chief of Police. (Ord. 89-34, 12-18-1989, eff. 1-11-1990; amd. 2017 Code)
C. Archery Range Permits Issued By Chief Of Police: Permits for the operation of an archery range shall be issued by the Chief of Police for a period of
not to exceed one (1) year; only upon submission of satisfactory proof or investigation by the Chief establishing that such activity can be carried on at
the particular location in reasonable safety and so as not to interfere with the peaceable use and enjoyment of adjacent property.
All persons using bow and arrows within the Municipality for the purposes set forth above must have the written permit to discharge said arrows at the
time of discharge, or when issued for an archery range, said permit must be displayed in a conspicuous place when said activity is being conducted.
The permits shall be nonassignable and may only be used for the purpose(s) and at the time(s) specified therein. (Ord. 89-34, 12-18-1989, eff. 1-11-
1990)

Chapter 4
ANIMAL CONTROL
8-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
BEEKEEPING: Apicultural activities, which includes raising bees in one (1) or more hives, boxes or colonies occupied by bees and using the honey
produced, but not including commercial honey processing or honey warehousing.
LIVESTOCK: Any animal customarily kept by humans for the purpose of providing food, fiber or work, including, but not limited to, cattle and other bovines,
horses, mules, donkeys and other equines, goats and other caprines, swine, hogs and other porcines (except oriental potbellied pigs as outlined below),
and chickens, geese, ducks, turkeys and other poultry, but excluding bees. (Ord. 14-11, 9-16-2014)
8-4-2: KEEPING OF LIVESTOCK:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, raise or harbor livestock in any zoning district other than the Z1 Agricultural District and the Z7-2 and Z7-4
Specific Use Districts, in accordance with the requirements of title 12 of this Code. (Ord. 14-11, 9-16-2014)
B. Notwithstanding the above, an oriental potbellied pig shall not be considered livestock and may be kept as a companion animal in accordance with
article A of this chapter, provided:
1. The animal's tusks must be trimmed and maintained in a manner that no tusk appears outside of the mouth of the pig when the mouth is closed;
2. All oriental potbellied pigs must be neutered or sterilized.
3. Oriental potbellied pigs kept as companion animals may not exceed a total weight of two hundred fifty (250) pounds. Pigs of any breed or type that
exceed two hundred fifty (250) pounds shall be considered livestock. (Ord. 14-11, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017 Code)
8-4-3: FEEDING OF GARBAGE TO LIVESTOCK:
It shall be unlawful for any person to feed table scraps, garbage or partially spoiled or decayed vegetable or animal matter to any livestock. (Ord. 14-11, 9-
16-2014)
8-4-4: KEEPING OF RABBITS OR POULTRY:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or raise more than a combined total of twenty five (25) rabbits, chickens or other poultry in any Z2 Sub-Urban
District or Z3 General Urban District, except where the occupant shall be in possession of at least two (2) acres of ground for the carrying on of farming
or poultry raising operations.
B. Where permitted, rabbits or poultry shall be kept within enclosures set back at least ten feet (10') from any lot line and at least thirty five feet (35') from
any residence on adjoining property or City right-of-way. (Ord. 14-11, 9-16-2014)
8-4-5: BEEKEEPING:
Beekeeping shall be allowed in the Z1, Z2 or Z3 Zoning Districts with the following restrictions:
A. The minimum lot area shall be twenty thousand (20,000) square feet;
B. Maximum number of hives allowed is two (2) hives in Z2 and Z3 Districts and ten (10) hives in Z1 District;
C. Hives shall be located in the rear yard and a minimum of fifteen feet (15') from property lines;
D. A flight path barrier shall be located in front of the hive(s), consisting of a six foot (6') fence that is one hundred percent (100%) opaque, or a similar
structure or planting not less than six feet (6') in height of sufficient density to create an opaque or nearly opaque barrier;
E. A source of water accessible to the bees must be provided on the property. (Ord. 14-11, 9-16-2014)
8-4-6: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
It shall be the duty of any person keeping or raising livestock, rabbits, poultry or bees to keep the pens, yards, hives or boxes wherein such livestock,
rabbits, poultry or bees are confined in a clean and sanitary condition. (Ord. 14-11, 9-16-2014)
ARTICLE A. COMPANION ANIMALS
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 166/358
8-4A-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this article is to establish regulations regarding the treatment and control of companion animals in the City of Mason City in order to protect
public safety while providing for recreation and enjoyment of our pets. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
ANIMAL: A nonhuman vertebrate.
ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: Any person designated by the City Administrator to enforce the regulation of animals, as outlined in this Code.
AT LARGE: Any animal off the premises of its owner. An animal shall not be deemed at large if the animal is under the direct control of its handler, and:
A. The animal is on the owner's property or on other private property with the property owner's consent, or confined within a yard. The confinement
mechanism or structure must be sufficiently constructed to contain the animal. If the animal is restrained on private property using a tie out, the tie
out line shall not be long enough to allow the animal to interfere with the lawful use of public right-of-way; or
B. The animal is confined in a cage or motor vehicle; or
C. The animal is restrained by a leash of sufficient strength to restrain the animal, not exceeding six feet (6') in length, held by a person competent to
restrain and control the animal; or
D. While in a City park, all ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to the exclusion, control or restraint of animals are obeyed, including within a
City designated dog park; or
E. The animal is a draft animal engaged in drawing vehicles or conveyances; or
F. The animal is a certified police canine, rescue dog or tracking dog acting on behalf of a public safety agency in the performance of its duties, or is
engaged in approved training or a public demonstration of its skills; service dog; certified therapy dog; or
G. The animal has been approved to participate in a parade or other event approved by the City Council; or
H. The animal and its owner are actively engaged in obedience training. Such training is prohibited on City streets, sidewalks, and in City parks (see
park rules, subsection 5-2-2O of this Code), except in a City designated dog park.
ATTACK: To approach in a hostile or aggressive manner as would cause a reasonable person to fear serious injury to self or property.
CANINES: All members of the dog family including the canids, both male and female, whether altered or not.
CITY ANIMAL SHELTER: The facility maintained by the City of Mason City for temporary domicile of companion animals that have been collected by an
enforcement officer when found stray, abandoned, or at large; or are considered dangerous or vicious; or have been relinquished.
COMPANION ANIMAL: An animal kept primarily for a person's company, service or protection, as opposed to working animals, sport animals, livestock,
and laboratory animals, which are kept primarily for performance, agricultural value, or research.
CONSTANT RESTRAINT: Fixed confinement.
DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMAL: An animal is deemed to be vicious when it meets any one (1) or more of the following:
A. Attacks, bites or claws any person while the person is on public property or lawfully on private property, including the property of the owner of the
animal.
B. Without provocation, bites, claws or otherwise injures, kills, or participates in injuring or killing any domesticated animal or fowl kept as a pet, as
livestock, or for companionship or service when the attacking animal is off the property which its owner or custodian owns, rents, or otherwise
controls.
C. Notwithstanding the above, an animal shall not be deemed to be vicious as a result of:
1. Attacking or causing injury to any person who, at the time of the attack or injury, was committing a wilful trespass or was committing or attempting
to commit other criminal conduct while upon premises occupied by the owner or keeper of that animal; or
2. Attacking or causing injury to any person who was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 167/358
3. Defending or protecting its owner, keeper or handler from an unjustified attack or assault.
4. Causing injury or death to another animal if it was defending itself from an unprovoked attack by another animal.
DESIGNATED REPRESENTATIVE: Any animal control officer, City animal shelter operators, employee of the City of Mason City, Humane Society of North
Iowa staff, and any veterinarian or veterinarian employees who are authorized to sell licenses or perform services on behalf of the City of Mason City.
DOG PARK: A suitably enclosed area, designated by the City, within which dogs are not required to be leashed or otherwise subject to physical restraint,
subject to the rules adopted by the Park Board.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: An animal control officer, City Attorney, Code Enforcement Officer or police officer, under the employ of or under contract to
the City.
EUTHANASIA: The humane destruction of an animal accomplished via a lethal injectable anesthesia that results in instantaneous and painless
unconsciousness and immediate and painless death during the loss of consciousness.
FELINES: All members of the cat family, both male and female, whether altered or not.
IMMEDIATE THREAT: Any threat to the safety of any citizen that could occur momentarily if an animal is not impounded by an enforcement officer.
LICENSE: The annual license obtainable from the City Clerk's Office, or a designated representative, which identifies the animal and its owner.
MICROCHIP: A device consisting of a small piece of semiconductor material carrying many integrated circuits, which is implanted under the skin of a
companion animal and which is used to identify the animal and other applicable information. The term microchip shall also refer to the action of implanting
the device.
OWNER: Any person, firm, association or corporation who owns, keeps, shelters or harbors an animal, or otherwise provides care, custody or has
responsibility for the animal on a permanent or temporary basis, or knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by that
person. In the event that the owner of any animal is a minor, the parent or guardian of that minor shall be responsible to ensure compliance with all
provisions of this article.
PERMIT: To either intentionally or unintentionally allow or fail to take adequate precautions to prevent.
RELINQUISH OR RELINQUISHMENT: The act by an owner to voluntarily give up ownership and control of a companion animal. A relinquished animal
shall be placed in the City animal shelter and disposed in accordance with this article. The animal cannot be considered relinquished unless a signed and
witnessed statement acknowledging the same, on a form created for this purpose, is provided to the enforcement officer. Upon relinquishment, the owner
releases all rights to the animal. A dangerous and vicious animal, even if given up voluntarily, is not considered to be relinquished under this definition.
WITHOUT PROVOCATION: Aggressive conduct initiated by any animal or aggressive conduct by an animal that is not in self-defense or in response to
aggressive conduct by any other animal or person. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017 Code)
8-4A-3: ANIMAL CONTROL:
A. The City Administrator shall designate an animal control officer and may designate any City department with the authority to enforce the provisions of
this article and chapter 351, Code of Iowa. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
B. When the animal control officer is off duty, the duties and responsibilities of the animal control officer may be assumed by an enforcement officer as
defined herein. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017 Code)
8-4A-4: RABIES VACCINATION:
All animals kept within the City, brought into the City for shows, exhibitions, or performance, or in transit, shall be vaccinated against rabies, as follows:
(Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
A. Every owner of a canine, feline or other companion animal susceptible to rabies shall obtain a rabies vaccination for the animal. It shall be unlawful for
any person to own or have an animal in his/her possession, six (6) months of age or over, which has not been vaccinated against rabies. The rabies
vaccination required by this article shall be an injection of antirabies vaccine approved by the Iowa State Department of Agriculture. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-
2014; amd. 2017 Code)
B. This requirement does not apply to animals in transit that are continuously held in secure cages and animals assigned to research, production of
biologics, and licensed animal care shelters or similar facilities. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-5: LICENSE REQUIRED:
A. License: Owners of all canines and felines over six (6) months of age, except those exempted in this section, shall obtain a license from the City Clerk
or from a designated representative agreeing to sell license tags on behalf of the City. Companion animals other than canines and felines residing in
the City of Mason City may be licensed, at the discretion of the owner.
B. Vaccination Required: Before a license is issued for any animal, the owner shall present a certificate of vaccination signed by a licensed veterinarian
that the animal has been vaccinated against rabies.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 168/358
C. Expiration And Renewal: The license shall expire one (1), two (2) or three (3) years from date of purchase, depending on the expiration of the rabies
vaccination. If the license is purchased from a veterinarian, the license shall be due and payable on the same day as the vaccination is acquired. If the
license is purchased from the City Clerk, or a designated representative, it shall be due and payable within thirty (30) days of the vaccination date. City
licenses shall be renewed for one (1), two (2) or three (3) years, depending on the expiration of the rabies vaccination, so long as the animal is living
and kept within the City.
D. Fee: The license fee shall be established by resolution approved by the City Council. A lower license fee shall be established for animals that have
been neutered or spayed. Every owner claiming a neutered or spayed animal shall furnish the veterinarian's certificate showing that the animal for
which the license is sought has had the appropriate operation.
E. Issuance Of License: Upon payment of the license fee, the City Clerk, or designated representative, shall issue to the owner a license containing a
description of the animal, the name of its owner and his/her place of residence. A record of each license issued shall be kept on file in the City Clerk's
Office as a public record. A numbered tag displaying the year in which it expires shall be delivered to the owner. The license tag shall be securely
fastened to a collar or harness which shall be worn by the animal.
F. Transfer Of Ownership: When the permanent ownership of an animal is transferred, the license may be transferred by the City Clerk by notation on the
license record, giving name and address of the new owner.
G. Transfer Of Animals Licensed Elsewhere: When an animal licensed in another Municipal jurisdiction is permanently transferred to Mason City, the
owner shall provide proof of the previous license and proof of current rabies vaccination to the City Clerk. Any tag issued by the prior licensing
jurisdiction shall be discarded. The Clerk shall issue a new license tag that shall expire upon expiration of the current rabies vaccination. If the rabies
vaccination is not current, the owner shall obtain the required vaccination prior to transfer of the license. The Clerk shall note on the license record that
the newly issued license tag effects a transfer of a license from another jurisdiction. The Clerk shall collect a transfer fee according to the fee schedule
adopted by the City Council.
H. Transfer Or Removal Of License Tag Prohibited: A license tag issued for one (1) animal shall not be transferable to another animal. The removal of a
license tag from an animal prior to the expiration of the license, by any person who is not the owner thereof or the agent of such owner, shall be
punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code.
I. Exemptions To License Requirements: The following animals are exempt from licensing requirements:
1. A certified police canine, rescue dog or tracking dog acting on behalf of a public safety agency in the performance of its duties.
2. Kennel animals that are kept or raised solely for the bona fide purpose of sale in State or Federally licensed kennels and which are kept under
constant restraint. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-6: RABIES AND LICENSE TAGS:
A. All canines and felines over the age of six (6) months shall wear a collar or harness to which a current and valid rabies vaccination tag and current City
license tag is attached. This requirement shall not apply to animals being exhibited or trained at a kennel club show, cat show or similar event or while
being transported to and from the event, if the animal is properly controlled and the owner or trainer possesses documentation of valid vaccination and
licensing.
B. Any animal found without a collar or harness upon which the rabies and license tags are attached, or found without the rabies and/or license tag
attached to its collar or harness, shall be deemed unlicensed until proof of license and/or vaccination is shown by its owner and the required collar or
harness with valid tags attached is properly worn by the animal. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-7: RIGHT TO CAPTURE OR KILL AN ANIMAL:
A. It shall be lawful for any person to capture for impoundment any at large animal for which a license is required. Upon capture, the person shall promptly
notify the Police Department or an enforcement officer of the capture.
B. It shall be lawful for any person to kill an animal, whether licensed and wearing a collar with license tag attached or unlicensed, when such animal is
caught in the act of worrying, chasing, maiming or killing any domestic animal or fowl, or when such animal is attacking or attempting to bite a person.
(Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-8: IMPOUNDING AND RECLAMATION OF ANIMALS:
A. Impoundment: An animal may be impounded in the City animal shelter when any one (1) or more of the following apply:
1. An animal is found at large, whether tame or feral.
2. An animal is not wearing a valid rabies vaccination tag, and current City license tag.
3. An animal is not receiving the proper standards of care as outlined in this article, or is tortured or otherwise mistreated in such a manner that the
enforcement officer may reasonably determine that the health or life of the animal is endangered.
4. An animal is deemed to be dangerous or vicious, according to section 8-4A-10 of this article.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 169/358
5. An animal has been determined by a veterinary professional to be feral or wild. Such animals shall be euthanized.
6. An animal that has been relinquished (as defined herein) by the owner to an enforcement officer, provided that the owner has signed a form
designed for this purpose and witnessed by the enforcement officer, acknowledging that the owner has relinquished ownership and all rights to the
animal and has no further claim on the disposition of the animal.
B. Surrender: Any person holding an animal within the City limits that is subject to impoundment under this section shall surrender the animal to the
enforcement officer.
C. Notice And Reclamation Period:
1. Notice Period: Within two (2) business days of impoundment, notice shall be given that the animal is in the custody of the City to the owner, where
known, by verbal contact, personal service, e-mail with return receipt required, or United States certified mail with return receipt required.
a. The date and time that the owner received notification shall be recorded by the designated representative serving the notice.
b. If the animal has been relinquished, no notice is required.
2. Reclamation Period: The reclamation period shall be no more than seven (7) days and shall begin upon the date and time that the owner received
notification of impoundment; provided, however, that if the owner's name or the owner's reliable contact information cannot reasonably be
determined after two (2) business days of impoundment, the animal will be held in the City animal shelter for no more than five (5) additional
calendar days. In no case, however, shall the last day of the reclamation period fall on a day that the shelter is closed to the public; in such a case,
the last day shall be the next day that the shelter is open.
3. Contact To Be Made: If the owner cannot be contacted within two (2) business days as stated in subsection C1 of this section, the enforcement
officer or designated representative shall attempt to determine ownership and contact information, to the extent reasonable, during the remaining five
(5) day reclamation period. If an owner is not or cannot be contacted within the five (5) day period, the animal may be disposed according to
subsection I of this section.
D. Reclamation Not Permitted: The following animals may not be reclaimed:
1. A dangerous or vicious animal, as determined by this article.
2. An animal that is not reclaimed within the reclamation period stated in this section, or within a City granted extension, as permitted in subsection F of
this section.
3. An animal that has been released for adoption according to the requirements of this article.
4. An animal that was relinquished. The relinquishment form, signed by the owner and witnessed by the enforcement officer, shall be kept on file.
5. An animal that is not currently licensed, vaccinated, or microchipped, unless such services are performed by a designated representative in the City
animal shelter, with all costs thereof paid for by the owner.
6. An animal for whom all costs of apprehension, impoundment and reclamation have not been paid by the owner.
E. Reclamation Permitted: An owner may reclaim an impounded animal if:
1. The animal is reclaimed within the reclamation period after receiving notice that the animal is in the custody of the City, or before expiration of any
extension granted by the City beyond the reclamation period; provided, however, that the last day does not fall on a day that the shelter is closed to
the public, in which case the last day shall be the next day that the shelter is open.
2. All costs of apprehension, impoundment, veterinary care (if provided) and any other costs outlined in this section have been paid.
3. Proof of rabies vaccination as required by this article and proof of current City license are provided; all impounded animals without proof of rabies
vaccination or current City license must have these services completed by a designated representative at the City animal shelter at the owner's
expense, before the animal will be released to the owner.
4. Proof is provided that the animal is microchipped; if the animal was not microchipped prior to impoundment, a microchip shall be implanted by a
designated representative and the costs thereof shall be paid by the owner prior to reclamation.
F. Time Extension: The animal control officer, for good and verifiable cause, may extend the reclamation period for up to three (3) additional days.
1. If the final day of the extension falls on a day when the shelter is not open to the public, the final day shall be the next day that the shelter is open.
2. The owner, if known, and the staff of the City animal shelter shall be notified of any extension.
3. If the animal control officer believes that there is cause to continue to hold the animal beyond the allowed three (3) day extension, he/she may
request the City Administrator to allow an additional extension of no more than ten (10) calendar days, provided that the last day does not fall on a
day that the shelter is not open to the public, in which case the last day may be extended to the following day that the shelter is open.
4. If the animal is reclaimed at any time, the cost of boarding and any other care shall be charged during any extension and shall be paid before the
animal is released.
G. Cruelty Or Neglect: In cases of animal cruelty or neglect, the City may seek remedies available to ensure the animal is not returned to an owner
incapable of or unwilling to provide proper care of the animal.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 170/358
H. Fees: Reclamation fees shall be determined by resolution adopted by the City Council. The reclamation fee shall increase for each reclamation after the
initial reclamation. Reclamation fees shall be lower if the animal has been previously microchipped.
I. Disposition Of Unclaimed Animals: If an animal is not reclaimed within the reclamation period as outlined above, including any approved extension, or if
an animal is not permitted to be reclaimed as required by this section, it may be placed for adoption or be euthanized.
1. An animal that is relinquished may be disposed before the reclamation period has passed, at such time determined by the animal control officer.
However, before the relinquished animal may be euthanized, the City Administrator shall review the case and make a determination, after
investigation, as follows:
a. Consultation with the animal control officer;
b. Consultation with a veterinary professional or other designated representative (other than the animal control officer) with knowledge of the animal
in question;
c. Review of any circumstances that may lead to a claim against the City; and
d. Determination that proper procedure has been followed.
2. If, in the opinion of a designated licensed veterinarian, the animal is too sick or injured to keep humanely for the designated reclamation period, the
animal may be euthanized before the reclamation period has passed.
3. Any animal placed for adoption shall thereafter be under the control of the adoption agency, and the City shall accept no further liability or
responsibility for the animal.
J. Sick Or Injured Animals: When an enforcement officer reasonably believes an animal taken into custody for impoundment is sick or injured, it shall be
taken to a licensed veterinarian for examination, treatment and care as soon as possible. The costs thereof shall be included in the cost of
impoundment at the owner's expense.
K. Ownership:
1. Disputes: After impoundment and during the reclamation period or any City granted extension, if the shelter is contacted by more than one (1)
individual or party making a reasonable claim of ownership of an impounded animal, the claimants shall be notified of the requirements of this
subsection.
a. All claimants must provide a written claim addressed to the City, stating the basis of the claim of ownership, any documents proving ownership,
and including reliable contact information.
b. Disputes or competing claims of ownership by any two (2) or more individuals or parties of an animal that has been impounded shall be resolved
by the disputing parties within the reclamation period or before expiration of any extension granted by the City. If such disputes are not resolved
within said time frame, the City may dispose of the animal as stated in subsection I of this section.
c. Questions of ownership shall be considered a civil matter and will not be decided or adjudicated by the City, except as stated in subsection K2 of
this section. Competing claimants may circumvent City disposition under this article only if an injunction is granted by a court of competent
jurisdiction, in which case ownership of the animal shall be determined by the court. The prevailing owner shall be responsible for all costs related
to extended boarding, services performed, and any other fees and penalties, prior to release of the animal.
2. Proof Of Ownership: For the purposes of this section, if ownership is disputed or claimed by multiple parties, a person may be identified as the owner
via any one (1) or more of the following, at the discretion of the City Administrator after investigation, shall be determined to be the owner, and the
animal will be released to that individual or party:
a. Due to scanning of an implanted microchip;
b. Listed on the City license for the animal;
c. Via records of multiple visits to a veterinarian;
d. A receipt of purchase;
e. Proof of adoption;
f. Registration with a certified kennel club or breed;
g. Upon the order of a court of competent jurisdiction;
h. Other reliable means of determining ownership. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017 Code)
8-4A-9: ANIMALS AT LARGE:
A. At Large Animals: No owner, handler or keeper of any animal shall permit their animal to be "at large" as defined in section 8-4A-2 of this article at any
time, whether the animal is licensed or not.
B. Exemptions: The following listed dogs are exempt: a certified police canine, rescue dog or tracking dog acting on behalf of a public safety agency in the
performance of its duties, or is engaged in approved training or a public demonstration of its skills; service dog; certified therapy dog.
C. Special Exemption For Dog Parks: A dog shall be permitted to run without restraint within the enclosed area of a designated dog park; provided, that
the dog's owner or other person responsible for the dog remains within the enclosed area of the dog park and exercises appropriate supervision and
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 171/358
control over the dog at all times. Dogs and their owners/handlers shall obey the rules for the dog park adopted by the Park Board. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-
2014)
8-4A-10: DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMALS:
A. Dangerous Or Vicious Animal Ownership: It shall be unlawful to own, keep, shelter, or harbor any "dangerous or vicious animal" as defined in section 8-
4A-2 of this article. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
B. Investigation And Notice: When the animal control officer or designated enforcement officer determines, after investigation, that an animal is dangerous
or vicious, the animal control officer or designated enforcement officer shall notify the owner or possessor by certified mail with signature, or by hand
delivery, of the status of the animal within five (5) business days of the completion of the investigation.
1. The notice shall instruct the owner or possessor of the animal that it is unlawful to own, keep, shelter or harbor a dangerous or vicious animal and
that doing so is punishable under the provisions of this article. The notice shall further inform the owner or possessor of the appeal rights set forth in
this article.
2. For reasons of public health and safety, failure to provide notice as outlined above if the enforcement officer is unable to determine the name and
location of the owner after reasonable investigation shall not prevent the City from taking a dangerous or vicious animal into custody.
C. Impoundment Of Dangerous And Vicious Animals:
1. Custody:
a. If the animal is at large, the enforcement officer may take the animal into custody immediately and notify the owner or possessor in the fashion
described above.
b. If the animal is not at large, the enforcement officer, or designee, may take the animal into custody at the time of delivery of the notice or at any
time thereafter. The owner shall surrender the animal to the enforcement officer.
c. If it is not reasonably possible to capture or restrain the animal, it may be destroyed in a reasonable manner as provided by applicable law.
d. The disposition of a dangerous and vicious animal shall be subject to the requirements of this section, even if the owner voluntarily surrenders the
animal.
2. Impoundment: The animal shall be impounded at the City animal shelter for at least ten (10) calendar days to allow the owner or possessor of the
animal to exercise appeal rights, as set out below.
3. If Owner Cannot Be Contacted: If, after reasonable investigation, the name and contact information of the owner cannot be determined within ten
(10) calendar days after the animal has been impounded, the animal shall be euthanized.
4. Appeal: The owner of an animal determined to be dangerous or vicious may appeal such determination in writing, delivered or mailed to the City
Administrator within ten (10) calendar days from the date that the animal is taken into custody.
a. If an appeal is initiated, no action may be taken against the animal until the City Administrator has ruled on the appeal.
b. The City Administrator may consult with a veterinary professional or other designated representative with knowledge of the animal in question.
c. The City Administrator shall determine if the actions of the enforcement officer are founded, in which case the appeal is denied and the animal
shall be declared dangerous or vicious.
5. Appeal Granted: If the City Administrator determines that the action of the enforcement officer is unfounded, the animal may be reclaimed as
outlined in subsection 8-4A-8E of this article, including licensing, rabies vaccination and microchipping as needed. The owner or possessor of the
