animal shall be responsible for all costs of impoundment.
6. No Appeal Filed, Or Appeal Denied: If no appeal is pursued, or if the appeal is denied, the animal shall be euthanized, unless such action is
restrained by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017 Code)
8-4A-11: REPORT OF ANIMAL BITE; SUSPECTED OR CONFIRMED RABIES; CONFINEMENT:
A. It shall be the duty of the owner of any animal which has bitten or attacked a person, or any person having knowledge of such bite or attack, to
immediately report this bite or attack to an enforcement officer. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
B. Any animal that has bitten any person shall be confined in a place designated by the animal control officer for a period of ten (10) calendar days, at the
owner's expense. The enforcement officer may monitor the animal as necessary during the confinement period. Unless the animal is suspected of, or
has been confirmed to be, suffering from rabies, after that time period, the animal may be released to the owner; provided, that the animal has been
duly licensed, vaccinated and microchipped under the provisions of this article.
C. If the enforcement officer is provided with a copy of a current valid rabies vaccination certificate for the animal, the animal control officer may, at his/her
discretion, permit the animal to be confined by the owner, on the owner's property or other site, if the owner can assure the animal will be confined
within a secure site for the entire ten (10) calendar days. The animal control officer shall be permitted to inspect the site to determine it is secure, at the
animal control officer's request. The animal may not leave the premises for any reason during the ten (10) day period.
1. The animal shall be on a leash and attended at all times whenever outside of an enclosed building.
2. Failure of an animal's owner or keeper to comply with these confinement requirements shall cause the animal to be impounded immediately, as
outlined in section 8-4A-8 of this article and the owner shall be subject to penalties as provided in this article. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 172/358
Code)
D. If a physician (in the course of treating a human victim of a bite), enforcement officer or veterinarian suspects that an animal is suffering from rabies,
this information shall be reported immediately to the animal control officer. The animal shall be taken into custody by the enforcement officer and
examined by a licensed veterinarian before being confined as outlined above. The animal shall be reexamined prior to coming out of quarantine. All
associated costs shall be paid by the owner.
E. Any animal exhibiting symptoms consistent with rabies shall be humanely euthanized and tested for rabies by an authorized diagnostic laboratory at the
owner's expense. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-12: GENERAL ANIMAL REQUIREMENTS:
A. Disturbing The Peace: A person or owner shall not harbor an animal that howls, barks, whines, bays or makes sound of any kind or nature that disturbs
the peace and quiet of the vicinity for a duration of more than fifteen (15) minutes (whether consecutive or not) in any twenty four (24) hour period.
B. Harassment: The owner of any animal shall not permit the animal to attack, harass, bite, scratch or otherwise injure or place in fear of injury any person
or animal on public or private property who has a legitimate reason to be thereon.
C. Molesting Of Animals: A person may not wilfully molest, provoke or mistreat an animal while it is confined on its owner's premises. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-
2014)
D. North Iowa Band Festival: During the North Iowa Band Festival, it is unlawful for a companion animal to be along the parade route.
E. Companion Animals In Public Parks: The City Council may, by resolution, prohibit companion animals from being present on any City right-of-way, City
owned property, or in any designated public park during any sanctioned special event. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017 Code)
F. Exempted Dogs: The following listed dogs are exempt from the above requirements: a certified police canine, rescue dog or tracking dog acting on
behalf of a public safety agency in the performance of its duties, or engaged in approved training or a public demonstration of its skills; service dog;
certified therapy dog.
G. Microchip Removal: No person, other than a licensed veterinarian, may attempt to remove a microchip that has been implanted in an animal. A
microchip may be removed by a veterinarian only when necessary for the health of the animal or for repair, replacement or upgrading of the microchip.
(Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-13: STANDARDS OF CARE:
Any owner or keeper of any animal shall not abandon the animal or cease to provide companion animal care requirements as listed in this section. An
owner shall arrange a competent, reliable person to provide the following requirements in the owner's absence. The following requirements shall be
sufficient to meet specific health requirements of the animal. Failure to comply with any standard shall be a violation of this article. Any person keeping an
animal shall:
A. Provide sufficient wholesome food at intervals and quantities appropriate for the species, suitable for the physical health and age of the animal. Food
shall be served in a clean receptacle or container.
B. Provide adequate shelter for an animal, appropriate to the species:
1. When kept outdoors, a tangle free, structurally sound, weatherproof and properly ventilated shelter providing access to shade and shelter from
exposure to weather conditions;
2. When kept indoors, a shelter that is properly ventilated and illuminated and sufficiently regulated by heating or cooling to protect the animal from
extremes of temperature, and to provide for its health and comfort.
C. Provide reasonable access to a supply of clean, fresh, potable water in a sanitary manner. If potable water is not accessible to the animal at all times, it
shall be provided daily, for such duration and of sufficient quantity as appropriate for the species.
D. Provide adequate sanitation via periodic cleaning or sanitizing indoor and outdoor facilities, and any area where the animal is confined or restrained to
remove excreta and other waste materials and dirt.
E. Provide adequate space, appropriate for the species, whereby primary enclosures and housing facilities are securely constructed and properly
maintained to provide sufficient space and confinement while allowing freedom of movement.
F. Provide adequate veterinary care during the life of the animal. All animals shall be provided with proper immunizations and preventive healthcare,
including parasite control.
G. Keep the animal cleaned and provide proper grooming as appropriate for the species. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 173/358
8-4A-14: TRAPPING AND POISONING:
A. Humane live box traps are the only approved means of trapping nuisance animals and/or birds with the exception of instant kill snap traps designed for
small rodents. Use of the following traps are prohibited: cannibear traps, snare traps, steel jaw traps, leghold traps, spring traps, or any similar device
designed to catch and hold the animal by the leg or other part of the body, or which is likely for any reason to cause injury, pain and suffering before
death.
B. It shall be unlawful to poison or attempt to poison any animal, except the use of retail rodent poison intended to poison small rodents inside buildings.
C. Certified or licensed exterminators as set out in chapter 206, Code of Iowa are exempted from these requirements. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-15: ANIMAL WASTE DISPOSAL:
A. Any person who walks or takes an animal upon public property, public right-of-way, parks, school grounds, playgrounds or the private property of
another person, shall immediately clean up, remove and properly dispose of solid waste excreted or deposited upon such public or private property.
This section shall not apply to animals participating in any parade or similar event approved by the City Council.
B. It is unlawful for the owner of any animal to keep an animal or animals in such a manner that allows the accumulation of solid waste to become a
detriment to or menace to the health of the animal, or an annoyance or health hazard to humans. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014)
8-4A-16: PENALTIES:
Any person or other entity violating any regulation in or any provision of this article, or of any amendment or supplement thereto, shall be:
A. Guilty of a simple misdemeanor, as outlined in section 903.1 of the Iowa Code, which is punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) or by imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days; or
B. Guilty of a Municipal infraction punishable by a civil penalty of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first and single offense, seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for any second offense and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each subsequent and additional offense.
C. The charge of either a simple misdemeanor or a Municipal infraction, or both, shall be determined by the enforcement officer filing the citation.
D. Each separate violation of this article, and each day such violation continues, constitutes a separate offense. (Ord. 14-12, 9-16-2014; amd. 2017 Code)
Chapter 5
INOPERABLE VEHICLES
8-5-1: PURPOSE:
It is hereby declared that the parking, dismantling, or storage of inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts upon public or private property within the corporate
limits of the City is a threat to the public health, welfare and safety and constitutes a nuisance. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall govern the interpretation of this chapter:
CITY: The City of Mason City.
DISMANTLE: To take apart; disassemble; tear down.
INOPERABLE VEHICLE: Any vehicle that has any one (1) of the following characteristics:
A. Any vehicle that does not display current State registration.
B. Any vehicle with a broken, or missing windshield, missing window, headlight, or any other missing glass.
C. Any vehicle with a broken, loose, or missing fender, door, bumper, hood, roof, steering wheel, trunk lid, muffler or tailpipe.
D. Any vehicle that is the habitat of rats, mice, snakes or any other vermin or insects.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 174/358
E. Any vehicle that lacks an engine, one (1) or more wheels, or other parts that render the vehicle inoperable, such as a truck without an engine or a
trailer missing a wheel.
F. Any vehicle that does not have all tires inflated.
G. Any vehicle that is not capable of moving in both forward and reverse gears.
PARKING: The placement on public or private property of any vehicle or vehicle part for any period of time not exceeding forty eight (48) hours.
PERMIT: To allow or fail to prevent.
PERSON: Any firm, person, partnership or corporation.
STORAGE: The placement on public or private property of any vehicle or vehicle part for any consecutive period of time exceeding forty eight (48) hours.
VEHICLE: Any implement of conveyance designed or used for the transportation of people or materials on land, water, or air, including, but not limited to,
automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, snowmobiles, boats, airplanes, helicopters, tractors, trailers, campers, motor homes, wagons, etc.
VEHICLE PART: An individual component or subassembly of a vehicle. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-3: VIOLATION DECLARED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park, dismantle, or store any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part or to permit the parking, dismantling, or storage of any
inoperable vehicle or vehicle part other than as herein provided by section 8-5-11 of this chapter. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-4: OWNER OF MOTOR VEHICLE OR VEHICLE PARTS PRIMA FACIE RESPONSIBLE:
The owner of any inoperable vehicle or vehicle part is prima facie responsible for the parking, dismantling, or storing of such vehicle or vehicle part upon
public or private property in violation of this chapter. Any owner, occupant or person in possession of real property within the City upon which one (1) or
more inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts are found is prima facie responsible for permitting such parking, dismantling, or storage of any inoperable vehicle
or vehicle part upon such property in violation of this chapter. No person shall be charged with more than one (1) violation of this chapter for any one (1)
vehicle. The owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part and the owner of real estate upon which such inoperable vehicle or vehicle part are found may
both be charged.
Each day the owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part and the owner, occupant or person in possession of real property within the City is found in
violation of this chapter and permits the violation to continue after the notice period provided in section 8-5-6 of this chapter shall be a new violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-5: NOTICE:
Upon discovery of any inoperable motor vehicle or vehicle part stored upon private property within the corporate limits of this City, any police officer, or
other City officer, official or employee having authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, may notify in writing the owner of
said motor vehicle or vehicle part, and the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored that:
A. The motor vehicle or vehicle part constitutes a violation under the provisions of this chapter.
B. The owner must abate the violation by removing or repairing same in accordance with the terms of section 8-5-6 of this chapter.
C. Failure to remove or repair same shall be sufficient cause for removal and disposal by the City and assessment of costs.
In the alternative, the City may cause to be issued to the owner of the vehicle or vehicle part, or to the owner of the property on which the vehicle or
vehicle part is found, a citation for a Municipal infraction setting forth the violation of this chapter and seeking an order of removal on conviction.
The notice provided by this section relates only to the abatement of a violation of this chapter and is not an element of a violation; provided, however, that
a second and/or any subsequent citation shall not be issued until after the notice provided herein. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-6: DUTY OF OWNER TO REMOVE OR REPAIR:
The owner of the inoperable vehicle or vehicle part which violates the provisions of this chapter, or the owner of the property upon which it is parked,
dismantled, or stored, shall, within ten (10) days after service of a written notice from any police officer, or other City officer, official or employee having
authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, remove or repair same. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-7: ABATEMENT:
If the owner of an inoperable vehicle or vehicle part or the owner of the property upon which it is parked, dismantled, or stored, shall fail to remove or
repair same in accordance with the requirements of section 8-5-6 of this chapter, any police officer, or other City officer, official or employee having
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 175/358
authority or responsibility for enforcement of any provisions of this Code, may abate such violation by causing same to be towed to a place of safekeeping
and the cost of the towing and storage shall be charged to the owner of the vehicle or vehicle part, or to the owner of the property upon which it was
parked, dismantled, or stored. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-8: AUCTION SALE:
Inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts impounded by the City may be sold at auction as provided in section 321.89, Code of Iowa, for motor vehicles
otherwise impounded. All revenues derived from the sale of inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts, however, shall accrue to the City. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-
2003)
8-5-9: INTERPRETATION:
Where any other ordinance of the City is more stringent or more restrictive than the requirements set forth herein, or any ordinance of the City affords any
other remedy, nothing herein shall be construed to waive or limit the use of and/or compliance with the provisions of such other ordinance. (Ord. 03-21, 10-
21-2003)
8-5-10: VIOLATION:
A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter may be charged as a Municipal infraction or a misdemeanor. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
8-5-11: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to inoperable vehicles or vehicle parts parked, stored, or dismantled:
A. Within a garage or other fully enclosed building;
B. Within a fully enclosed vehicle;
C. On the premises of a business operating in a properly zoned area, when necessary to the operation of said business, as authorized under the zoning
ordinance of the City. (Ord. 03-21, 10-21-2003)
Chapter 6
NOISE CONTROL
8-6-1: PURPOSE, SCOPE AND DECIBEL MEASUREMENT:
A. It is the purpose of this chapter to prevent excessive sound which is a serious hazard to the public health and welfare and to the quality of life in the City
of Mason City.
B. This chapter shall apply to the control of all noise originating within the limits of the City of Mason City.
C. The measurement of sound or noise shall be made with a sound level meter meeting the standards prescribed by the American National Standards
Institute. The instruments shall be maintained in calibration and good working order. A calibration check shall be made of the system at the time of any
noise measurement. Measurements recorded shall be taken so as to provide a proper representation of the noise source. The microphone during
measurement shall be positioned so as not to create any unnatural enhancement or diminution of the measured noise. A windscreen for the
microphone shall be used when required. The measurement shall be an A-weighted, slow response sound level. (Ord. 87-21, 10-5-1987; amd. 2017
Code)
8-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
All terminology used in this chapter and not defined in this section shall be in conformance with applicable publications of the American National Standards
Institute (ANSI) or its successor body.
A-WEIGHTED SOUND LEVEL: The sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level is
designated dB(a) or dBA.
CALIBRATION CHECK: Operators of a sound level meter may certify the accuracy of meter by either witnessing the integrity seal on the meter is intact
and that the device has a current certificate of calibration from an outside sound meter testing lab; or, using a sound calibrator with the meter before
enforcement sampling to verify the device is functioning properly. The sound calibrator emits a test sound at specific dB level(s) to compare sound level
meter readings.
DECIBEL (dB): A logarithmic and dimensionless unit of measure often used in describing the amplitude of sound.
EMERGENCY WORK: Work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, work to restore public utilities or
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 176/358
infrastructure, or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent danger.
NOISE: A sound, especially one that is loud or unpleasant or that causes disturbance.
NOISE CONTROL OFFICE: The same as the Mason City Police Department and shall have the responsibility of enforcing this chapter.
NOISE DISTURBANCE: Any sound which endangers the welfare, safety or health of a human being, or disturbs a reasonable person of normal
sensitivities, or devalues or injures personal or real property by exceeding authorized limits.
PERSON: Any individual, association, partnership, corporation or officer thereof.
REASONABLE OPERATION: Use of construction, power tools, lawn and garden equipment with a legitimate, timely purpose that minimizes disruption to
nearby persons; not used to cause annoyance or excessive disruption.
SOUND: A temporal and spatial oscillation in pressure, or other physical quantity, in a medium with internal forces that causes compression and
rarefaction of that medium, and which propagates at finite speed to distant points.
SOUND LEVEL METER: An instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time averager, output or display meter, and
weighting networks used to measure sound pressure levels in decibels when properly calibrated or currently certified to be working correctly and the
instrument is of type 2 or better, which complies with American National Standards Institute Standard 1.4-1971 or its successor.
SOUND PRESSURE: The instantaneous difference between the actual pressure and the average or barometric pressure at a given point in space, as
produced by sound energy.
SOUND PRESSURE LEVEL: Twenty (20) times the logarithm to the base ten (10) of the ratio of the RMS sound pressure to the reference pressure of
twenty (20) micronewtons per square meter (120 x 10-6N/m2). The sound pressure level is denoted Lp or SPL and is expressed in decibels. (Ord. 87-21,
10-5-1987; amd. 2017 Code)
8-6-3: EXCEPTIONS TO CHAPTER:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to:
A. The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency. This includes testing and authorized use of outdoor
warning sirens, and authorized use of emergency vehicle warning devices. Private audible alarms may be tested once per day for a maximum duration
of thirty (30) seconds between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and four o'clock (4:00) P.M. False or overly sensitive audible alarms that cause a
noise disturbance are not exempt under provisions of this chapter.
B. The emission of sound in the performance of emergency work.
C. Activities of temporary duration, permitted by law, and for which a valid noise permit has been issued by the Noise Control Office.
D. Reasonable operation of construction equipment, domestic power tools, lawn and garden equipment between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M.
E. Nonprofessional athletic contests on school property, school band practice, and school band performances between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M.
F. Funeral or memorial events of limited duration to include, but not limited to: the playing of trumpets or bagpipes, discharge of blanks during a gun volley
salute, etc.
G. Rail and air transportation and public mass transportation vehicles.
H. The emission of sound in connection with authorized band festival related activities, or authorized activities conducted on the County Fairgrounds
during the annual North Iowa Fair and Exposition.
I. The emission of sound in the performance of authorized law enforcement or military operations.
J. The emission of sound in the discharge of weapons or in fireworks displays approved by the City Council or County Board of Supervisors; or when
lawfully allowed by City ordinance.
K. The emission of sound in the reasonable operation of snow removal equipment and street cleaning equipment regardless of time of day.
L. Organized racing events on the County Fairgrounds property in such a manner that the sound level resulting from such operation exceeds ninety (90)
dBA for any period of time during such operation. Sound levels which exceed the limits herein described at the real property boundary of the receiving
land use shall be deemed a noise disturbance. Said organized racing events must end by ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. and not start before ten o'clock
(10:00) A.M. (Ord. 87-21, 10-5-1987; amd. 2017 Code)
8-6-4: NOISE DISTURBANCE PROHIBITED:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 177/358
No person shall make, continue, or cause to be made or continued, except as permitted, any noise disturbance as defined in this chapter, or any noise in
excess of the limits for such noise established in this chapter. (Ord. 87-21, 10-5-1987)
8-6-5: MAXIMUM PERMISSIBLE SOUND LEVELS BY ZONED LAND USE:
A. No person shall engage or participate in the making and creating of an excessive or unusually loud sound within the City heard and measured in the
manner prescribed in subsection 8-6-1C of this chapter, and below, except when done under and in compliance with a permit issued pursuant to this
chapter.
B. It shall be the duty of persons in a position of ownership, possession or control of premises to prevent such premises from being the site of activities
producing sound levels in excess of what is permitted under this chapter. Failure or refusal to perform such duty shall constitute a violation of this
section.
C. It shall be the duty of persons in positions of leadership or responsibility with respect to unincorporated associations, groups, gatherings and
assemblages of people to prevent such from causing or making sound levels in excess of what is permitted under this chapter. Failure or refusal to
perform such duty shall constitute a violation of this section.
D. For the purpose of determining and classifying any sound as excessive or unusually loud, the following test measurement and requirements are to be
applied:
1. The sound shall be measured at the edge of the City street or alley right-of-way reasonably appearing to be nearest to the source of the sound, or if
in a park zoned area, approximately fifty feet (50') from the source of the sound. When a complaint is received, a measurement may also be taken at
a location on the property where the complaining party was disturbed.
2. The sound shall be measured on a sound level meter of standard design and quality operated in the "A" slow response weighing scale.
3. A sound measured or registered in excess of the maximum permitted levels according to the following table, is declared to be excessive and
unusually loud and is unlawful:
Neighborhood Zoned
Characteristics Maximum Permitted
Residential:
Between 7:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M. 60
Between 10:00 P.M. to 7:00 A.M. 50
Commercial or agricultural 65
Industrial 80
Park 65
(Ord. 87-21, 10-5-1987; amd. 2017 Code)
8-6-6: NOISE PERMITS:
A. Application: Applications for a permit for relief from the provisions of this chapter may be made to the Noise Control Office, or a duly authorized
representative, pursuant to the following procedure:
1. All permits must be applied for in writing during normal business hours stating what devices are to be employed, where they are to be employed, on
what date(s) and at what times of day they are to be used, the nature of the sounds to be produced or amplified and the number of people in
attendance, and the persons responsible for the activity. Sufficient lead time must be given to the Noise Control Office to research permit application
and consult with neighboring property owners who may be impacted if a noise permit is issued.
2. Permits granted shall state with reasonable specificity the date(s), location(s), time(s), nature of the sound, devices permitted, number of people in
attendance, and the persons responsible for the activity. Permits are not transferable. The permit shall be conspicuously displayed on or near main
sound producing object or main entrance.
3. Permits shall not be arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld nor shall the free expression of ideas or lawful speech be restrained, but sound and noise
producing conduct having no communicative value and serving only to unreasonably disturb and disrupt the enjoyment of residences and normal
pursuits shall be restrained.
4. The Noise Control Office may prescribe any conditions or requirements deemed necessary to minimize adverse effects upon the community or the
surrounding neighborhood.
5. Approved noise permits may be revoked at any time by Noise Control Office if permittee or guests fail to comply with permit requirements. Permit
fees are nonrefundable in this case.
6. Denied permits may be appealed to the City Administrator or designee within fourteen (14) calendar days of a permit denial.
B. Permit Application Fees:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 178/358
1. Permit application fee for twenty four (24) hours or less is twenty five dollars ($25.00) each.
2. Permit application fee for one (1) day through seven (7) days is forty dollars ($40.00) each.
3. The Noise Control Office has discretion to waive or reduce a permit fee for a registered charitable or nonprofit organization.
C. Maximum Sound Levels: When a permit has been issued pursuant to this chapter, the sound levels listed in the following table shall be the maximum
levels permitted:
Sound Level Limit In dBA Duration
80 24 hours
83 12 hours
86 6 hours
89 3 hours
90 1.5 hours
The above stated duration for each sound level shall not be exceeded. The sound level shall be measured in the same manner as set out in section 8-6-5
of this chapter. (Ord. 87-21, 10-5-1987; amd. 2017 Code)
8-6-7: MOTORIZED VEHICLES:
A. No person shall operate the engine providing motive power, or an auxiliary engine, of a motor vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating
of ten thousand (10,000) pounds or more for a consecutive period longer than twenty (20) minutes while such vehicle is standing and located within
one hundred fifty feet (150') of property zoned and used for residential purposes except where such vehicle is standing within a completely enclosed
structure. This section shall not apply to delivery or pickup vehicles that require the operation of the engine to unload or load their vending loads. (Ord.
87-21, 10-5-1987)
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or for the owner to cause or permit to be operated within the public right-of-way in this City, any motor
vehicle which emits a noise in excess of the dBA level established in this section.
1. The maximum allowable noise levels for motor vehicles shall be seventy five (75) dBA measured at a distance of twenty five feet (25').
2. This section applies to the total noise from a motor vehicle and shall not be construed as limiting or precluding the enforcement of any other
provisions of this chapter.
3. No person shall modify the exhaust system of a motor vehicle or any other noise abatement device of a motor vehicle or operate any such vehicle or
device in this City in a manner that the noise emitted by the motor vehicle is above that emitted by the vehicles as originally manufactured. Muffler
cutouts, bypasses, or other devices which increase sound emitted shall be unlawful.
4. The sound shall be measured on a sound level meter of standard design and quality operated on the "A" slow response weighting scale. (Ord. 87-
21, 10-5-1987; amd. 2017 Code)
8-6-8: POWERS AND DUTIES OF NOISE CONTROL OFFICE; ENFORCEMENT:
The Noise Control Program established by this chapter shall be implemented, administered, and enforced by the Noise Control Office. (Ord. 87-21, 10-5-
1987; amd. 2017 Code)
8-6-9: UNLAWFUL USE OF ENGINE AND COMPRESSION BRAKES:
The use of any engine brake, compression brake, dynamic braking device, or mechanical exhaust device to brake or slow any motor vehicle that results in
excessive, loud, unusual or explosive noise from such vehicle, except for the aversion of imminent danger, is prohibited. Emergency vehicles are exempt
from the application of this section. (Ord. 06-025, 9-19-2006)
Chapter 7
HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES
8-7-1: PURPOSE:
In order to reduce the danger to public health, safety and welfare from the spills of hazardous substances, these regulations are promulgated to establish
responsibility for the removal and cleanup of spills within the City limits. (Ord. 89-25, 10-2-1989)
8-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 179/358
For the purpose of this chapter, these words have the following meanings:
CLEANUP: Actions necessary to contain, collect, control, identify, analyze, clean up, treat, disperse, remove or dispose of a hazardous substance.
HAZARDOUS CONDITION: Any situation involving the actual, imminent, or probable spillage, leakage, or release of a hazardous substance onto the land,
into water, or into the atmosphere, which creates an immediate or potential danger to the public health or safety or to the environment. For purposes of this
chapter, a site which is a hazardous waste or hazardous substance disposal site is a hazardous condition.
HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCE: Any substance or mixture of substances that presents a danger to the public health or safety and includes, but is not limited
to, a substance that is toxic, corrosive, or flammable, or that is an irritant or that generates pressure through decomposition, heat or other means.
Hazardous substance may include any hazardous waste identified or listed by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency
(EPA) under the Solid Waste Disposal Act as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, or any toxic pollutant listed under
section 307 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act as amended to January 1, 1977, or any hazardous material designated by the Secretary of
Transportation under the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act.
RESPONSIBLE PERSON: The party, whether the owner, agent, lessor, tenant, in charge of the hazardous substance or hazardous wastes being stored,
processed, or handled, or the owner or bailee transporting hazardous wastes or substances whether on public ways or grounds or on private property
where the spill would cause danger to the public or to any person or to the environment.
TREATMENT: A method, technique, or process, including neutralization, designed to change the physical, chemical or biological character or composition
of a hazardous substance so as to neutralize it or to render the substance nonhazardous, safer for transport, amenable for recovery, amenable for storage,
or to reduce it in volume. Treatment includes any activity or processing designed to change the physical form or chemical composition of hazardous
substance to render it nonhazardous. (Ord. 89-25, 10-2-1989; amd. Ord. 96-3, 1-15-1996)
8-7-3: CLEANUP REQUIRED:
Whenever a hazardous condition is created by the deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking or placing of a hazardous substance or waste or a
constituent of the hazardous waste or substance may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including
groundwaters, the responsible person shall cause the condition to be remedied by a cleanup, as defined in the preceding section, as rapidly as feasible to
an acceptable, safe condition. The costs of cleanup shall be borne by the responsible person. If the responsible person does not cause the cleanup to
begin in a reasonable time in relation to the hazard and circumstances of the incident, the City may, by an authorized officer, give reasonable notice, based
on the character of the hazardous condition, said notice setting a deadline for accomplishing the cleanup or that the City will proceed to procure cleanup
services and setting forth a reasonable estimate of the costs of cleanup and bill the responsible person for all costs associated with the cleanup, including,
but not limited to, equipment rendered unserviceable; personnel costs, including overtime; disposal costs; and any other costs associated therewith. If the
bill for those services is not paid within thirty (30) days, the City may proceed after service of notice, either by certified mail or one (1) publication in the
local newspaper and hearing before the City Council, to obtain payment by all legal means. If the cost of the cleanup is beyond the capacity of the City to
finance it, the authorized officer shall report to the Council and immediately seek any State or Federal funds available for said cleanup. (Ord. 89-25, 10-2-
1989)
8-7-4: NOTIFICATION:
The Fire Department shall be notified immediately when an unauthorized discharge becomes reportable under State or Federal regulations. The Fire
Department shall notify law enforcement officials and the Emergency Management Coordinator, and shall file the required reports at the State and Federal
level. (Ord. 96-3, 1-15-1996)
8-7-5: POLICE AUTHORITY:
If the circumstances reasonably so require, the Chief of Police of the Police Department or his representative, may:
A. Evacuate persons, even from their homes, to areas away from the site of a hazardous condition; and
B. Establish perimeters or other boundaries at or near the site of a hazardous condition beyond which no person shall cross. (Ord. 89-25, 10-2-1989)
8-7-6: CITY LIABILITY:
The City shall not be liable for any losses occurring due to any hazardous condition created which may be claimed by any person, firm, or corporation.
(Ord. 89-25, 10-2-1989)
8-7-7: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision, section, or subsection of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and/or a Municipal infraction
and may be prosecuted as a misdemeanor or a Municipal infraction, or both. Each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 89-25,
10-2-1989)
Chapter 8
NUISANCE PROPERTY
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 180/358
8-8-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide City officials with legal tools and procedures to discourage, abate, prevent and punish the use of private
residential or commercial property such that a nuisance related to the use of said property is encouraged, allowed or created. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-2: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, clause, provision or portion of this chapter is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall
not affect the remainder of this chapter. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-3: INTERPRETATION:
For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms and words are hereby defined. Words used in the present tense shall include the future, the singular number
shall include the plural and the plural number shall include the singular; the word "shall" is mandatory, the word "may" is permissive; the word "person"
includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company or corporation as well as an individual. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-4: EXCLUSIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to active and operating industrial, manufacturing, and agricultural and food processing facilities. This exclusion does not
prevent the applicability of other zoning, nuisance, or other ordinances and statutes to such facilities and activities. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-5: DEFINITIONS:
ABATE: To permanently eliminate.
AUTHORIZED VERIFICATION OFFICER: A Mason City police officer, a Mason City fire inspector, a Mason City building or housing inspector, a Mason
City Code Enforcement Officer, or a Cerro Gordo County health inspector.
BUILDING MATERIALS: Any material, including, but not limited to, lumber, brick, concrete, plaster, plaster board, gutters, floor coverings, or other similar
substances accumulated as a result of repairs, remodeling, or additions to existing buildings, or construction of new buildings, or demolition of existing
structures.
CITY ADMINISTRATOR: The City Administrator and designees including, but not limited to, attorneys appointed to represent the City.
ENVIRONMENTAL OR SOLID WASTE VIOLATION: Violation of any portion of State Statutes or County or City ordinances regarding environmental or
solid waste regulations.
FOUNDED: That a call for service resulted in the written verification to the City Administrator by an authorized verification officer on a form approved by
the City Administrator that nuisance activity has occurred or that a nuisance condition exists.
INTERESTED PARTY: A property owner, tenant or contract purchaser, or a spouse, family member, or housemate thereof.
NUISANCE: Anything defined as a nuisance by State law or County ordinance of Cerro Gordo County, by any part of this chapter, by any other ordinance
of the City of Mason City, or whatever else poses an unreasonable threat to health or safety, interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property in
an unreasonable manner, or causes annoyance or distress to a reasonable person of normal sensitivities. In addition, but without limitation, the following
are declared to be nuisances:
A. The erecting, continuing, or using of any building or property for the exercise of any activity which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive
smells, or other annoyances, becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort, or property of individuals or the public.
B. The storage, placing, keeping, or leaving of building materials, appliances, furniture, machinery, equipment, trailers or other similar personal property
or fixtures outside of a dwelling or accessory building on residential lots so as to impair the residential character and/or property value of the
surrounding lots or neighborhood. This definition shall not apply to boats, camping trailers, or similar recreational vehicles which are not otherwise
junk vehicles under this Code.
PERMITTEE: A person whose presence on the property in issue where the interested party suffers, allows, or consents to, or whose presence the
interested party acquiesces to by failing to remove or prevent the presence of.
PROPERTY: Any privately owned property and that which is affixed, incidental or appurtenant, or a particular rental unit on such property.
PROPERTY OWNER: The record titleholder of legal title as shown by the records of the County Auditor or County Recorder, unless there exists a contract
purchaser of record, in which case it means the contract purchaser.
RESIDENTIAL LOT: A lot of record within the City that has been zoned to include, or which is allowed by law to include, single-or multi-family residential
structures.
SECURE STRUCTURE: Any structure, whether or not occupied, with effective walls, roofs, windows, doors and locks so as to prevent unauthorized entry
or infestation by animals or infiltration of weather conditions. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-6: PROPERTY NUISANCES:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 181/358
A property nuisance exists:
A. When one (1) or more of the following acts are committed upon a property, or within one thousand five hundred feet (1,500') of the nearest point on the
property, by an interested party or their permittee(s):
1. Manufacture or delivery of a controlled substance in violation of Iowa Code chapter 124;
2. Kidnapping as defined in Iowa Code chapter 710;
3. Arson as defined in Iowa Code chapter 712;
4. Burglary as defined in Iowa Code chapter 713;
5. Robbery as defined in Iowa Code chapter 711;
6. Sex abuse as defined in Iowa Code chapter 709;
7. Terrorism as defined in Iowa Code section 708.6;
8. Wilful injury as defined in Iowa Code section 708.4;
9. Sexual exploitation of a minor in violation of Iowa Code section 728.12;
10. Felony gambling in violation of Iowa Code chapter 725;
11. Felony criminal mischief as defined in Iowa Code chapter 716;
12. Animal fighting in violation of Iowa Code chapter 717D.
B. When two (2) or more of the following acts are committed within a period of twelve (12) consecutive months upon, or within one thousand five hundred
feet (1,500'), of a property, by an interested party or their permittee(s):
1. Possession of a controlled substance in violation of Iowa Code chapter 124;
2. Any weapons violation as defined in Iowa Code chapter 724 or Iowa Code section 483A.36 or section 8-3-5 of this title;
3. Riot as defined in Iowa Code section 723.1;
4. Serious or aggravated misdemeanor criminal mischief as defined in Iowa Code chapter 716;
5. Prostitution as defined in Iowa Code section 725.1;
6. Serious or aggravated misdemeanor assault as defined in Iowa Code chapter 708;
7. Serious or aggravated misdemeanor theft as defined in Iowa Code chapter 714;
8. Misdemeanor gambling as defined in Iowa Code chapter 725;
9. False imprisonment as defined in Iowa Code section 710.7;
10. Failing to keep a secure structure;
11. An unpermitted or illegal use under the Mason City zoning ordinance;
12. Discharge of or hunting with a bow and arrow in violation of section 8-3-28 of this title;
13. Violation of Cerro Gordo County ordinance 51 regarding social hosts and underage consumption;
14. A social gathering constituting a disorderly premises or nuisance gathering in violation of the Mason City nuisance gathering ordinance.
C. When three (3) or more of the following acts are committed within a period of twelve (12) consecutive months upon a property, or within one thousand
five hundred feet (1,500') of the property, by an interested party or their permittee(s):
1. City, County or State Health Code violations;
2. City, County or State environmental or solid waste violations, including, but not limited to, violations of title 4 of this Code;
3. Simple misdemeanor criminal mischief in violation of section 716.6 of the Iowa Code;
4. Simple misdemeanor assault in violation of chapter 708 of the Iowa Code;
5. Disorderly conduct in violation of section 8-3-6 of this title or permitting disturbing the peace in violation of section 8-3-17 of this title;
6. Criminal trespass in violation of chapter 716 of the Iowa Code;
7. Criminal sale or use of fireworks in violation of Iowa Code section 727.2 or section 8-3-8 of this title;
8. Any violation of chapter 4 of this title regarding animal control;
9. Inhalation of toxic vapors in violation of section 8-3-11 of this title;
10. Urinating or defecating in public in violation of section 8-3-27 of this title;
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 182/358
11. Any violation of chapter 5 of this title regarding inoperable vehicles;
12. Any violation of Iowa Code section 124.414 regarding the manufacture, delivery, sale or possession of drug paraphernalia.
D. Any other condition on, or activity carried on within one thousand five hundred feet (1,500') of any part of the property, and participated in, or permitted
or contributed to by, the owner, permittee, or interested party, that otherwise constitutes a "nuisance" as defined in section 8-8-5 of this chapter.
The above references to provisions of the Iowa Code, Cerro Gordo County ordinances, or this Code should not be interpreted to mean that a
prosecution or conviction of the specific charge is a necessary prerequisite to an action under this chapter nor shall it be interpreted to mean that proof
of the action, or any element thereof, beyond a reasonable doubt is required. (Ord. 13-23, 7-16-2013)
8-8-7: PROHIBITION AND ENFORCEMENT:
The creation or maintenance of a "nuisance" as defined in this chapter is prohibited and the City of Mason City may take actions to abate any "nuisance"
as defined in this chapter by the procedures set out below. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-8: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The City Administrator or designee will make every reasonable effort to contact the private property owner in order to gain permission to enter a property
to investigate reports of nuisance activities or conditions. If unsuccessful in contacting the owner, the City Administrator or designee is authorized to enter
and remain upon private property to the extent reasonably necessary for the purpose of investigating reports of nuisance activities or conditions based
upon a founded report from an authorized verification officer. The investigation may include locating, identifying and documenting evidence related to the
reported nuisance activity or condition. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-9: NOTICE TO ABATE:
When the City Administrator has received founded reports of nuisance conditions or activities such that a specific property can be identified as a nuisance
property under the provisions of this chapter, the City Administrator may cause to be served a written notice to abate the nuisance, directed to the property
owner and other interested person responsible for the nuisance condition, as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-10: NOTICE TO ABATE; CONTENTS:
A. A notice to abate shall contain:
1. A description of the nuisance;
2. The location of the nuisance;
3. The dates that the nuisance(s) were documented;
4. Identification and address of each person causing, creating or allowing the nuisance;
5. An order for abatement requiring the property owner or interested person or permittee to consent to one (1) of the following alternatives, with the
approval of the City Administrator:
a. Agree to take all necessary steps and actions to completely and permanently abate the nuisance within the required time frame; or
b. Submit to the City Administrator a plan for abatement containing specific and substantive steps designed to eliminate the current nuisance and to
prevent future recurrence of the nuisance. The plan must be submitted to the City Administrator within twenty (20) days of the date the order for
abatement is mailed or personal service is completed. The plan may be modified or rejected by the City Administrator and resubmitted as directed
by the City Administrator. Any plan finally approved by the City Administrator shall become a part of the order for abatement; or
c. Consent by the property owner to an occupant violation with a placard on the property, or the affected unit thereof, prohibiting occupation of the
property or individual unit until reinspection of the property or unit, with reinspection to occur within three (3) business days after the request from
property owner for reinspection; or
d. Consent by the property owner to an owner/interested person violation with the surrender of the rental dwelling permit for the property, or the
affected unit thereof, with no reinstatement until reinspection and reapplication. Said reapplication may be denied if the property owner has not
taken sufficient steps to prevent the reoccurrence of the nuisance condition. After approval of the reapplication, the reinspection will occur within
three (3) business days after the request from property owner for reinspection;
6. The period of time in which the actions are to be completed;
7. A statement of the terms regarding appeal hearing;
8. A statement that:
a. If the nuisance is not completely and permanently abated within the required time period; and
b. If a plan for abatement has not been approved and completely implemented by the owner/interested person within the time period in the approved
plan; and
c. If an occupant violation, with surrender of the rental dwelling permit, has not been consented to by the owner and the nuisance abated within the
required time period; and
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 183/358
d. If an owner/interested person violation, with surrender of the rental dwelling permit, has not been consented to by the owner and the nuisance
abated within the required time period,
then the City may abate the nuisance with costs assessed against the owner and/or the interested person and/or against the property as a
property tax, and/or the City may suspend or revoke any and all permits affecting the applicable property issued by the City or City staff, and/or the
City may seek a court order finding a Municipal or criminal violation and ordering abatement.
B. The notice to abate may also contain:
1. A statement that the property owner shall be assessed the cost of police response for all founded nuisance incidents that occur following the date of
the notice to abate. Upon demonstration by the property owner that all reasonable and warranted steps to prevent or resolve the issue(s) giving rise
to the nuisance have been taken in good faith, the assessment for the cost of police response may be withdrawn. The assessment for the cost of
police response shall terminate at the end of one (1) year if the founded nuisance incidents during that year do not meet or exceed the criteria for a
problem area "nuisance" as defined in section 8-8-5 of this chapter. If applicable, when the criteria for a problem area nuisance is met or exceeded
for two (2) consecutive years following an abatement notice, the rental dwelling permit may be revoked for the affected property or unit with
reinstatement only after reinspection and reapplication.
2. For nuisances pertaining to debris or environmental violations, a statement that the City will no longer issue further written warnings and all violations
must be corrected within twenty four (24) hours otherwise the City will clean up any solid waste at the property owner's cost.
3. A statement that any failure to abate the nuisance described in the notice, and within the stated time frame, may result in the suspension of any
wine, beer or liquor permit or license held by the owner or interested party. (Ord. 13-23, 7-16-2013)
8-8-11: NOTICE TO ABATE; SERVICE:
The notice shall be sent by certified mail to the property owner and any other interested persons. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-12: FINAL ORDER TO ABATE AND IMPOSITION OF PENALTY:
No sooner than twenty (20) days following the issuance of the notice to abate, the City Administrator or designee shall issue a final order to abate
containing a description of the nuisance, the location of the nuisance, the dates that the nuisance(s) were documented, the identification of the person(s)
causing, creating or allowing the nuisance, and the actions that are required to abate the nuisance and the time frame in which the actions are to be
completed. The final order may also contain any penalty or directions for other enforcement or abatement actions that are authorized under this chapter.
(Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-13: APPEAL AND HEARING:
A. Any person ordered to abate a nuisance may have a hearing before the City Council or before such person or hearing body as the City Council may
designate, as to whether a nuisance exists. A request for a hearing must be made in writing and delivered to the City Administrator ordering the
abatement by first class mail postmarked within twenty (20) days from the date of the abatement notice, or it will be conclusively presumed that a
nuisance exists and it must be abated as ordered.
B. Any penalty imposed for failure to abate a nuisance, other than a Municipal infraction and simple misdemeanor citation, shall provide for an opportunity
to request a hearing before the City Council, or such person or hearing body as it may designate, as to whether the penalty is warranted. A request for
a hearing must be made in writing and delivered to the City Administrator ordering the abatement by first class mail postmarked within twenty (20) days
from the date of the final abatement order, or it will be conclusively presumed that the abatement required and the penalty imposed are warranted.
(Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-14: EMERGENCY:
If it is determined by the City Administrator that an emergency exists by reason of the continuing presence of a nuisance that constitutes a threat to one (1)
or more individuals or to the public, the City may perform any action reasonable designed to abate such nuisance without prior notice or hearing. The City
shall assess the costs as provided in sections 8-8-15 and 8-8-16 of this chapter and subject to the provision of section 8-8-15 of this chapter, after notice to
the property owner under the applicable provisions of sections 8-8-9 through 8-8-11 of this chapter, and opportunity for hearing as provided in section 8-8-
17 of this chapter. (Ord. 13-23, 7-16-2013)
8-8-15: ABATEMENT BY CITY:
If the person notified to abate a nuisance neglects or fails to abate as ordered, the City may perform the required action to abate, keeping an accurate
account of the costs incurred in the abatement of the nuisance. The itemized account of the costs shall be filed with the Finance Director or his designee
who may pay any outside expenses on behalf of the City. The salvage value, if any, of any item or items constituting a nuisance which is so abated by the
City, shall be retained by the City to be applied against costs. In the event the salvage proceeds exceed the costs, any such excess shall be paid to the
former owner of the property, upon proof of such ownership. If ownership is not proved within sixty (60) days of the disposal of the property, then the
excess portion of the payment shall be applied to the City's General Fund. In addition, the City, by order of the City Administrator, may suspend or revoke
any and all permits affecting the applicable property issued or granted by the City or City staff, and/or the City may seek a court order finding a Municipal
or criminal violation and ordering abatement. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
8-8-16: EXPENSES; COLLECTION:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 184/358
The Clerk shall mail a statement of the total expense incurred, minus any salvage value, to the person or persons who have failed to abide by the notice to
abate, demanding payment of the expense. Subject to the provisions of section 8-8-15 of this chapter, if the amount shown by the statement has not been
paid by the person within thirty (30) days, it shall then be collected with, and in the same manner as, special taxes, as provided in Iowa Code section
384.59(2). (Ord. 13-23, 7-16-2013)
8-8-17: EXPENSES; HEARING:
Any person notified pursuant to section 8-8-16 of this chapter who objects to the amount of expense demanded from him may have a hearing before the
Finance Committee of the City Council, or such other person or hearing body as it may designate. The hearing shall be limited to the question of the
reasonability of the amount of expense demanded. A request for hearing must be in writing and filed with the City Administrator within ten (10) days after
the date of the Finance Director or designee's demand for payment. Any collection actions will be stayed upon the filing of a request for hearing until a final
determination by the committee. The determination of the committee shall be conclusive, and shall be communicated in writing to the objector. The City
Clerk shall then proceed in the manner set forth in Iowa Code section 384.59(2), taking into account any modifications by the committee in the amount of
expense due. (Ord. 13-23, 7-16-2013)
8-8-18: UNLAWFUL ACTS:
It is unlawful for any person to:
A. Create or maintain or allow a "nuisance" as defined in this chapter.
B. Fail to abate within the time period originally prescribed by the notice to abate described in section 8-8-10 of this chapter, or such additional time period
as may be designated pursuant to the appeal process outlined in section 8-8-13 of this chapter, any "nuisance" as herein defined after having been
ordered to do so by written notice and/or order to abate under the provisions of sections 8-8-9 through 8-8-12 of this chapter.
C. Resume or allow the resumption of a nuisance after having been ordered to abate the nuisance by a written notice or final order to abate under the
provisions of sections 8-8-9 through 8-8-12 of this chapter.
D. Otherwise hinder, delay, or interfere with the City Administrator in the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter.
E. Terminate a lease agreement with or otherwise retaliate against a tenant because that tenant complained or otherwise notified the police or City official
about nuisance activities at the owner's premises. (Ord. 13-23, 7-16-2013)
8-8-19: PENALTIES:
The following are penalties that may be imposed for violating this chapter. These possible penalties may be imposed in addition to, and not in lieu of, any
sanctions specified in an abatement plan or order otherwise entered pursuant to this chapter.
A. A violation of this chapter may be punished as a simple misdemeanor in accordance with the penalties set forth in the Iowa Code.
B. A violation of this chapter may be punished as a Municipal infraction with a scheduled fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a first offense, five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second offense, and seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a third or subsequent offense.
C. A violation of this chapter may be punished by revocation or suspension of any license or permit, affecting the subject property, issued by the City of
Mason City or by City staff, in the discretion of the City Administrator and with the approval of the City Council.
D. Each day a violation persists shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 13-15, 5-7-2013)
Chapter 9
NUISANCE GATHERINGS AND DISORDERLY PREMISES
8-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms have the meanings ascribed:
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE: As defined in Iowa Code chapter 123.
DISORDERLY PREMISES: Any premises that constitutes a threat to public peace, health, safety or general welfare of the public by constituting the source
of:
A. Persons engaging in fighting or threatening violent or tumultuous behavior;
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 185/358
B. Unreasonable noise as defined as a "noise disturbance" in chapter 6 of this title or noise which is otherwise prohibited in said chapter;
C. Hazardous or offensive conditions such as, but not limited to, solid waste violations, public urination, public defecation, and indecent exposure.
EVENT OR GATHERING: Any group of two (2) or more persons who have assembled or gathered together for a social function or other activity on public
or private property whether indoors or outdoors.
HOST: To aid, conduct, allow, entertain, control or overtly permit a gathering or event. Mere knowledge that an event or gathering is occurring is insufficient
to constitute host status; but presence at the gathering or event combined with right of possession or control of the premises upon which the event or
gathering is occurring is presumed to satisfy host status.
NUISANCE GATHERING: An event or gathering that constitutes, or results in the occurrence of two (2) or more illegal activities at or as a result of the
event or gathering at the premises, including, but not limited to, the following:
A. Noise in violation of chapter 6 of this title;
B. Public disturbances, assaults, brawls, fights, indecent exposure, public urination or public defecation;
C. Unlawful sale, furnishing, or consumption of an alcoholic beverage or public intoxication;
D. Unlawful deposit of solid waste in violation of title 4 of this Code or section 8-3-12 of this title;
E. Criminal mischief in violation of chapter 716 of the Code of Iowa;
F. Criminal trespass in violation of chapter 716 of the Code of Iowa;
G. Unlawful sale, manufacture, or possession of any controlled substance;
H. Any violation of Iowa Code section 124.414 regarding the manufacture, delivery, sale or possession of drug paraphernalia;
I. Violation of Cerro Gordo County ordinance 51 regarding social host and underage consumption;
J. Violation of section 8-3-6 of this title regarding disorderly conduct;
K. Criminal sale or use of fireworks in violation of Iowa Code section 727.2 or section 8-3-8 of this title;
L. Driving any motorized vehicle or other self-propelled machine resulting in a crash, property damage, personal injury, reckless driving, or otherwise in
a careless, dangerous or reckless fashion within one thousand five hundred feet (1,500') of the closest point on the property at issue.
PREMISES: Any house, residence, yard, land, apartment, condominium, hotel or motel room, park, business, or other place of assembly, private or public,
whether owned, leased, or used with or without permission or compensation.
UNDERAGE PERSON: Any individual under the age of twenty one (21) years of age. (Ord. 13-16, 5-7-2013)
8-9-2: HOSTING OF DISORDERLY PREMISES OR NUISANCE GATHERING PROHIBITED:
No person shall host a disorderly premises or nuisance gathering. A person or persons who own the property where the disorderly premises or nuisance
gathering occurs or the person or persons in possession or control of the premises where the disorderly premises or nuisance gathering takes place, or
the person or persons in possession or control of the location of the nuisance gathering, may each, jointly and severally, be charged with violating this
section whenever any premises owner, occupant, tenant or other person having a possessory interest or control hosts, sponsors, conducts, suffers or
permits an event or gathering that at any time of the event or gathering becomes a disorderly premises or nuisance gathering. However, any owner,
occupant, tenant or other person having a possessory interest or control who requests assistance from the police to prevent a gathering from becoming a
disorderly premises or nuisance gathering prior to the police receiving complaints related to the event or gathering being a disorderly premises or nuisance
gathering shall not be considered to be in violation of this section. This exemption is only valid for one (1) occurrence per property in any calendar year.
(Ord. 13-16, 5-7-2013)
8-9-3: PENALTIES:
A. Any person who violates this chapter may be charged with a simple misdemeanor or a Municipal infraction punishable by a fine of not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than the maximum fine allowed for a single misdemeanor or a Municipal infraction under Iowa law.
B. The penalty provided herein may be imposed in addition to any penalty that may be imposed for any other criminal offense or Municipal violation arising
from the same incident. (Ord. 13-16, 5-7-2013)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 186/358
8-9-4: POLICE SERVICE FEE:
A police service fee may be imposed whenever a police officer or other Police Department representative has given notice to a person who hosts a
disorderly premises or nuisance gathering that a second response based upon a disorderly premises or nuisance gathering complaint within the next
twenty four (24) hours may result in the assessment of a police service fee. The imposition of a police service fee is in addition to the authority of the police
to otherwise take enforcement action to control the disorderly premises or nuisance gathering by ordering dispersal, making arrests or issuing citations.
The person or persons responsible for any disorderly premises or nuisance gathering for which there was a second or subsequent police response after
the provision of notice of the applicability of public service fees shall be liable to the City for the police service fees to defray the reasonable cost incurred
in any subsequent police response, jointly or severally. The Chief of Police or designee shall cause appropriate billings to be made through the Finance
Department. If the City's attempt to collect the police service fee is unsuccessful, the City may bring an action to recover the police service fee, including
reasonable attorney fees, against any person responsible for paying the debt or the debt may be turned over to a collection agency and any fees charged
by the agency shall be added to the debt. (Ord. 13-16, 5-7-2013)
Title 9
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
Chapter 1
TRAFFIC DEFINITIONS
9-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this title, the definitions detailed in section 321.1, Code of Iowa, are adopted in full by the City and incorporated as part of this title, in
addition to the following:
AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE: Vehicles of the Fire Department, police vehicles, ambulances, and emergency vehicles owned by the United
States, this State, any subdivision of this State, or any Municipality of this State, and privately owned vehicles as are designated or authorized by the
Director of Transportation under Iowa Code section 321.451.
BICYCLE: A device having two (2) wheels and having at least one (1) saddle for the use of a rider which is propelled by human power.
BUSINESS DISTRICT: The territory contiguous to and including a highway when fifty percent (50%) or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of three
hundred feet (300') or more is occupied by buildings in use for business.
CROSSWALK: That portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or connection of the lateral lines of sidewalks at intersections. Any
portion of a roadway distinctly indicated for pedestrians crossing by lines or other markings on the surface.
DRIVER OR OPERATOR: Every person who is in actual physical control of a vehicle upon a highway.
INTERSECTION: The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the
roadways of two (2) highways which join one another at or approximately at right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different
highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self-propelled and not operated upon rails. The term "car" or "automobile" shall be synonymous with the term
"motor vehicle".
OFFICIAL TIME STANDARD: Whenever certain hours are named herein, they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time, whichever shall be in
current use in this City at the time.
OFFICIAL TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES: All signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code, placed or erected by
authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic.
OFFICIAL TRAFFIC SIGNALS: Any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to
proceed.
PARK OR PARKING: The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a parking lot, public street, avenue or alley except when the operator is
temporarily stopping for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers, or loading or unloading merchandise, or an
involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of the operator of the vehicle or in compliance with a duly authorized order from
a peace officer.
PARKING LOT: Real estate purchased, leased or otherwise acquired for the use as a parking lot or other off street parking area for the parking of vehicles.
PARKWAY: A continuous area of public land comprising a way of approach or access for pedestrian or park vehicular passage, and which shall be
improved with paths, drives, plantings or other recreational features in a parklike atmosphere.
PEDESTRIAN: Any person afoot.
PERSON: Every natural person, firm, partnership, association or corporation. Where the term "person" is used in connection with the registration of a
motor vehicle, it shall include any corporation, association, partnership, company, firm, or other aggregation of individuals which owns or controls such
motor vehicle as actual owner, or for the purposes of sale or for renting, whether as agent, salesperson, or otherwise.
POLICE DEPARTMENT: Municipal agency responsible for enforcing State and local laws, detecting and preventing crime, and maintaining the peace
within the City limits of Mason City.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 187/358
POLICE OFFICER: Officers authorized to enforce laws or to make arrests.
PRIVATE ROAD OR DRIVEWAY: Every way or place in private ownership and use for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied
permission from the owner, but not by other persons.
RAILROAD: A carrier of persons or property upon cars, operated upon stationary rails.
RAILROAD TRAIN: An engine or locomotive with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails.
RESIDENCE DISTRICT: The territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business, suburban, or school district where forty percent
(40%) or more of the property upon such highway for a distance of three hundred feet (300') is occupied by dwellings or by dwellings and buildings in use
for business.
RIGHT-OF-WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway.
ROADWAY: That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel.
SAFETY OR DEADMAN THROTTLE: A device which, when pressure is removed from the engine accelerator or throttle, causes the motor to be
disengaged from the driving tract.
SCHOOL DISTRICT: The territory contiguous to and including the highway for a distance of two hundred feet (200') in either direction from a school
ground.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb lines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of
pedestrians.
SNOWMOBILE: Any self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow, ice or natural terrain steered by wheels, skis or runners.
STANDING: Any stopping of a vehicle whether occupied or not.
STOP: Complete cessation of movement. When prohibited, means any stopping of a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in
compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to public use as
a matter or right for purposes of vehicular traffic.
SUBURBAN DISTRICT: All other parts of the City not included in the business, school or residence districts.
THROUGH STREET: Every highway or portion thereof at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to stop
before entering or crossing the same and when stop signs are erected as provided in this title or such entrances are controlled by a peace officer or traffic
control signal.
TRAFFIC: Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances either singly or together while using any street for purposes of travel.
VEHICLE: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway. (Ord. 11-14, 9-20-2011)
Chapter 2
TRAFFIC ADMINISTRATION
9-2-1: POLICE ADMINISTRATION TRAFFIC CONTROL AUTHORITY:
There is hereby established in the Police Department a Traffic Division, to be under the control of an officer of police appointed by and directly responsible
to the Chief of Police. It shall be the duty of the Traffic Division, with such aid as may be rendered by other members of the Police Department, to enforce
the street traffic regulations, to make arrests for traffic violations, and to investigate accidents and to carry out the duties specially imposed upon said
division by this chapter and the traffic regulations of this Code. The Engineering Department has the authority to designate roadway, marking, and
regulatory features related to traffic control upon the City's streets. (Ord. 11-15, 9-20-2011)
9-2-2: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICERS:
Administrative Officers of the City shall conduct analyses of accidents, devise remedial measures and cooperate with other City officials in the
development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions. (Ord. 11-15, 9-20-2011)
9-2-3: STREET, ALLEY OR SIDEWALK CLOSURE:
A. Individuals are not allowed to close or partially block a City street, alley or sidewalk without prior approval from the Engineering Department. Public
safety and/or City operations and maintenance personnel may temporarily block streets, alleys or sidewalks for official purposes only.
B. A traffic control plan shall be submitted and approved by the Engineering Department at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the closure of any street,
alley or sidewalk. The traffic control plan must show the proposed area of the closure including the type and locations of all traffic control devices. The
requested dates of closure and the contact information for a person responsible for the signage shall be provided. (Ord. 11-15, 9-20-2011; amd. 2017
Code)
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 188/358
9-2-4: TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
It shall be the duty of the Engineering Department to install or supervise the installation of all traffic control devices. The Engineering Department shall
operate and maintain traffic control devices when and as required under the traffic regulations of this City and may require the placing and maintenance of
such additional traffic control devices as may be deemed necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic regulations of this City or under State law, or to
guide or warn traffic. All traffic control devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the Iowa Department of Transportation. All
traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of State law or this title shall be official traffic control devices. (Ord. 11-15, 9-20-
2011)
9-2-5: CROSSWALKS, SAFETY ZONES, TRAFFIC LANES:
The Engineering Department is hereby authorized to:
A. Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where there is particular
danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as may be deemed necessary.
B. Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be deemed necessary for the protection of pedestrians.
C. Mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as may be deemed advisable, consistent with the traffic regulations. (Ord. 11-15, 9-20-2011)
9-2-6: NO TURN MARKERS:
The Engineering Department is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left or U-turn and
shall place proper signs at such intersections. The Engineering Department is hereby authorized to place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to
intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections and such course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to
or be other than as prescribed by law or provisions of this Code. (Ord. 11-15, 9-20-2011)
9-2-7: LOADING ZONES:
The Engineering Department is hereby authorized to determine the location of loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the
same and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable. (Ord. 11-15, 9-20-2011)
9-2-8: QUIET ZONES:
The Engineering Department shall have authority to temporarily establish a zone of quiet upon any street where a person is seriously ill if requested so to
do by the written statement of at least one (1) registered physician certifying to its necessity. Said temporary zone of quiet shall embrace all territory within
a radius of two hundred feet (200') of the building occupied by the person named in the request of said physician. Said temporary zone of quiet and any
