https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 226/358
N. 111.4.2, add subsection: Extensions Of Time: In response to an appeal of a notice and order, the board may grant an extension of time to comply with a
notice and order for not more than twelve (12) months, subject to appropriate conditions, and provided that the board makes specific findings of fact
based upon evidence relating to the following:
1. That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in carrying out the strict letter of any notice and order; and
2. That such an extension is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this Code in securing the public health, safety and general welfare; and
3. That the violation(s) in question do not constitute an imminent danger, per section 109.1.
O. 111.4.3, add subsection: Variances: In response to an appeal of a notice and order, the board may grant a variance from a specific provision of this
Code in a specific case, subject to appropriate conditions and provided the board makes specific findings of fact based upon evidence related to the
following:
1. That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in carrying out the strict letter of any notice and order; and
2. That the effect of the application of the provisions would be arbitrary in the specific case; and
3. That an extension would not constitute an appropriate remedy for these practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships; and
4. That the variance is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this Code in securing the public health, safety and general welfare and does
not constitute an imminent danger to the public.
(2017 Code)
10-2F-4: AMENDMENTS TO CODE; CHAPTER 2:
Chapter 2, Definitions, of the 2015 International Property Maintenance Code (or the most current edition) is adopted, except as hereby amended, deleted,
modified, revised, or added to, as specifically set forth as follows:
A. 201.6, add new subsection: Board: The Housing Advisory and Appeals Board of the City of Mason City. All references in this Code to "board" or "Board
of Appeals" shall be considered to reference the City of Mason City Housing Advisory and Appeals Board.
B. 202, General Definitions, add definition: Accessory Building Or Structure: A structure that is not attached to the dwelling by a common wall and is not
used for living or sleeping or for human occupancy. Examples of accessory buildings or structures include garages and sheds.
C. 202, General Definitions, delete and replace: Approved: The dwelling or referenced feature of the dwelling substantially complies with this Code or other
referenced codes as determined by the Code official.
D. 202, General Definitions, add definition: Landlord: Any person who rents to another or who has custody or control of a building, or parts thereof, in
which dwelling units or rooming units are let for occupancy or offered for rent.
E. 202, General Definitions, delete and replace: Let For Occupancy Or Let: To permit, provide, or offer possession or occupancy of a dwelling, dwelling
unit, rooming unit, building, premises or structure, to be occupied by any person who is not the legal owner of record thereof, pursuant to a written or
unwritten lease, agreement or license.
F. 202, General Definitions, Owner, revise second clause only as follows: "or recorded in the official records of Cerro Gordo County as holder of a contract
to purchase, or as holding title, to the property;". The remainder of the definition before and after this clause is unchanged.
G. 202, General Definitions, add definition: Placard: A written announcement posted on a dwelling unit or rooming unit that has been determined to be unfit
for human occupancy; also referred to as "white tag".
H. 202, General Definitions, add definition: Reasonable Cause: Any condition that poses an imminent threat to the health, safety and/or welfare of the
occupant(s) or others.
I. 202, General Definitions, add definition: Rental Dwelling Permit: A written certificate of compliance, issued periodically, which grants the landlord the
option of letting for occupancy a specific unit for rental purposes and showing that the unit for which it is issued was in compliance with this Housing
Code at the time of issuance.
J. 202, General Definitions, add definition: Rental Dwelling Unit: Any dwelling unit or rooming unit that is let for occupancy as defined in this Code, where
the owner of record is not an occupant of the unit; regardless of whether or not rent is charged or paid.
(2017 Code)
10-2F-5: AMENDMENTS TO CODE; CHAPTER 3:
Chapter 3, General Requirements, of the 2015 International Property Maintenance Code (or the most current edition) is adopted, except as hereby
amended, deleted, modified, revised, or added to, as specifically set forth as follows:
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 227/358
A. 302.4, Weeds, delete and replace first sentence only: Premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of
twelve inches (12").
B. 304.14, Insect Screens, delete and replace: During the period from May 1 to November 1, every door, window and other outside opening required for
ventilation of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service areas or any areas where products to be included or utilized in food for human
consumption are processed, manufactured, packaged or stored shall be supplied with approved tightly fitting screens of minimum 16 mesh per inch (16
mesh per 25 mm), and every screen door used for insect control shall have a self-closing device in good working condition.
C. 307.1, General, delete and replace last sentence only: Guards shall not be less than 36 inches (914.4 mm) in height above the floor of the landing,
balcony, porch, deck, ramp, or other walking surface.
D. 309, Pest elimination, add new subsection 309.6, as follows:
309.6, Bedbugs.
309.6.1. Landlord's Responsibilities. In regard to bedbug infestations, the owner or landlord shall be responsible for the following:
1. The owner or landlord shall be responsible for all costs related to the inspection and treatment of a bedbug infestation in any part of a building
that contains two (2) or more rental dwelling units. This includes common areas such as shared kitchens, lounges, hallways, etc.
2. The owner or landlord shall have the infested unit(s) and all adjacent units inspected by a qualified inspector within five (5) business days of
receiving notice from a tenant that his or her unit may be infested.
3. The owner or landlord shall take reasonable measures to treat the infestation no more than five (5) business days after the inspection, including
treating adjacent units and hiring a pest control agent.
4. The owner or landlord shall not apply pesticides, unless he/she is a certified applicator.
5. The owner or landlord shall provide reasonable written or oral notice to a tenant before entering a unit for bedbug inspection or control
purposes.
6. The owner or landlord shall offer assistance to tenants who cannot comply with treatment procedures, for which they may charge a reasonable
amount.
7. The owner or landlord shall not offer or show a unit for rent if he/she knows or suspects it is infested.
8. The owner or landlord shall, upon request from a current or prospective tenant, disclose the last date when the rental unit was inspected for
bedbugs and found free of infestation.
309.6.2. Tenant's Responsibilities. In regard to bedbug infestations, the tenant of a rental dwelling unit shall be responsible for the following:
1. The tenant of a single family rental dwelling unit shall ensure that bedbugs are eradicated in accordance with this Code and shall be responsible
for the costs of inspection and eradication. The tenant shall notify the owner or landlord prior to treatment and again after eradication.
2. The tenant of a unit located within a building containing two (2) or more rental dwelling units shall:
a. Promptly notify the owner or landlord, orally or in writing, when he/she knows or suspects the unit is infested with bedbugs;
b. Grant the owner/landlord, qualified inspector, or pest control agent access to the unit;
c. Comply with reasonable measures to eliminate and control the infestation, or pay for additional costs arising from noncompliance; and
d. Refrain from moving infested material from the unit until treatment is complete or the landlord gives permission to do so.
(2017 Code)

10-2F-9: AMENDMENTS TO CODE; CHAPTER 7:

C. 702.4, Emergency Escape Openings, add the following subsections:
1. 702.4.1 Windows And Similar Means Of Egress. The bottom edge of any window in a habitable space that serves as an emergency escape opening
shall be no more than forty-four inches (44") above the floor.
2. 702.4.2 Habitable Spaces In Basements. Each bedroom in a dwelling unit located within a basement, where fifty percent (50%) or more of the
vertical height of the room is below the exterior grade, shall have at least one operable emergency escape (egress) window or exterior door, with a
minimum openable area of 5.7 square feet, leading directly to a public way.
3. 702.4.3 Window Wells. Window wells are required whenever any portion of the vertical dimension of a basement egress window is below the outside
grade. The minimum horizontal area of a window well shall be nine (9) square feet, with a minimum horizontal projection and width of thirty-six inches
(36"). The area of the window well shall allow the egress window to be fully opened. Window wells with a vertical depth greater than forty-four inches
(44") shall be equipped with a permanently affixed ladder or steps usable with the window in the fully open position. Ladders, rungs, or steps shall
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 229/358
have an inside minimum width of twelve inches (12"), shall project at least three inches (3") from the wall, and shall be spaced not more than
eighteen inches (18") on center vertically for the full height of the window well.
4. 702.4.4 Fire Escapes. No existing fire escape shall be deemed a sufficient means of egress unless it is inspected and approved by the Code official
and the Mason City Fire Marshal.

10-2F-10: RENTAL DWELLING PERMIT:
A. Permit Required For Specific Structure: No person shall rent for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, duplex, apartment, rooming unit (except a
rooming unit or units within owner occupied single-family dwellings, condominiums and containing no more than 2 roomers) or rooming house unless
the landlord has obtained a rental dwelling permit for the respective dwelling unit(s) from the Code official applicable to those portions of the specific
structure used for residential rental purposes.
B. Permit Requirements:
1. Issuance Upon Compliance: A rental dwelling permit shall be issued by the Code official indicating compliance with this Code at the time of
issuance.
a. Valid Period: A rental dwelling permit shall be valid for no more than five (5) years from the date of issuance. If a rental dwelling unit is not
occupied for any length of time during the five (5) year period, the permit shall remain valid, provided the permit is not revoked, the unit does not
become a nonrental (owner occupied) unit, and the unit continues to comply with this Code.
b. Transfer Of Permit: A rental dwelling permit shall be transferable from one landlord or owner to another at any time prior to its expiration,
termination or revocation if a notice, including name and contact information of the new landlord, is given to the Code official no more than thirty
(30) calendar days after the transfer. A rental dwelling transfer late penalty shall be charged to the subsequent landlord if more than thirty (30)
calendar days passes between the change in ownership and notification of the Code official.
2. Penalty For No Rental Dwelling Permit: All dwelling units and rooming units being let for rent and occupancy without a valid rental dwelling permit, or
an application for a permit is on file with the Code official, may be ordered vacated or it may be ordered that no further rent shall be recoverable by
the landlord of such units until compliance with this Housing Code is met. In addition, the Code official may impose a penalty if the respective
landlord does not submit an application for the necessary permit(s) more than thirty (30) calendar days after notification by the Code official that the
proper permit has not been obtained. All fees and penalties shall be in an amount established by resolution adopted by the City Council.
3. Issuance After Inspection: After inspections have been completed according to section 10-2F-11 of this article, and the Code official has determined
that all provisions of the Housing Code have been met, the Code official shall issue a rental dwelling permit no more than ten (10) business days
after the final inspection or reinspection. A rental dwelling permit shall not be issued unless the furnace check has been provided according to
subsection 10-2F-11G1 of this article and all applicable fees and penalties have been paid.
C. Extension Of Permit: Rental dwelling permits shall be valid through the expiration date contained thereon. However, extensions, which shall not exceed
sixty (60) calendar days, may be granted to cover any time period between the stated expiration date and the period of time permitted by the Code
official to remedy any violations cited subsequent to an inspection or reinspection, provided that an application to renew the rental dwelling permit is on
file.
D. Permit Renewal: A rental dwelling permit may be renewed for an additional five (5) years upon or before expiration of the current permit. To renew the
rental dwelling permit, the dwelling must be inspected as described in section 10-2F-11 of this article and found to comply with the terms of this Code.
E. Revocation Of Permit:
1. Causes: The Code official may revoke a rental dwelling permit at any time if:
a. Fraud, collusion or an illegality has been documented in the inspection or permitting process.
b. A dwelling unit fails to meet the requirements of the Housing Code, and the owner or landlord does not address the deficiencies within thirty (30)
calendar days after the initial inspection, or within fifteen (15) calendar days after the most recent reinspection. The Code official or the Board of
Housing Appeals may extend this period for due cause.
c. Fees or penalties are outstanding for more than ninety (90) days.
2. Appeal: The owner or landlord shall be notified in writing that the rental dwelling permit is being revoked and shall have ten (10) business days to file
an appeal with the Housing Advisory and Appeals Board. (Ord. 04-3, 1-6-2004; amd. 2017 Code)
10-2F-11: INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT:
A. Inspection Notices: A written notice for each inspection or reinspection shall be sent or delivered to the owner, or the owner's designated agent, prior to
conducting inspections except when a potential threat to health or safety exists which would create the need for a more immediate inspection. The
City's failure to demonstrate proof of having sent the notice shall not relieve the owner or landlord of the corrective actions ordered by the Code official
to bring the dwelling unit into compliance, nor from the associated reasonable time to complete them.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 230/358
B. Search Warrant: When entry is lawfully refused, the Code official may apply to the court of jurisdiction for a search warrant. No owner, landlord, or
occupant shall fail, neglect, or attempt to permit full access to the Code official after a search warrant, issued by the court, is presented.
C. No Show Or Failure To Notify City To Reschedule: If an owner, landlord or occupant fails to provide for access to a unit for a scheduled inspection,
including refusing entry, a "no show" penalty may be charged, unless the owner, landlord, or occupant, at least twelve (12) hours prior to the scheduled
inspection or reinspection, notifies the Code official that he/she cannot attend at the scheduled time and the inspection or reinspection is therefore
rescheduled.
D. Inspection Of Owner Occupied Dwellings: Inspection of owner occupied single-family dwellings, owner occupied condominiums, owner occupied
cooperatives, or any of the above containing an occupant group meeting the occupancy requirements of the adopted Building and Fire Codes, shall be
performed only upon request or complaint to the Code official, or upon reasonable cause as determined by the Code official.
1. The Code official shall inspect the property and create a list of deficiencies or violations, which shall be provided to the owner no less than ten (10)
business days after the inspection was performed.
2. Any deficiencies or violations identified by the Code official shall be resolved no less than thirty (30) calendar days of receiving the list from the Code
official. If reinspection is necessary, the owner shall be notified no less than five (5) calendar days before the scheduled reinspection.
E. Inspection Of Rental Dwelling Units: Rental dwelling units shall be fully inspected to ensure compliance with all requirements of this Code. Inspections
shall take place for any one (1) or more of the following purposes:
1. Upon establishment of a dwelling unit as a rental dwelling unit and submittal of a rental dwelling permit application;
2. At least once every five (5) years, for renewal of a rental dwelling permit, along with submittal of a rental dwelling permit application, to determine if
the unit continues to meet the requirements of this Code;
3. Upon request by the owner or landlord;
4. Upon receipt of a founded complaint; or
5. Upon reasonable cause as determined by the Code official.
F. Landlord Notification: If a rental dwelling unit or premises is occupied, the Code official shall first make a reasonable effort to notify the owner or landlord
and request entry; however, occupants may grant access to the Code official for rental housing inspections without permission from the owner or
landlord.
G. Rental Dwelling Permit And Renewal Inspection Process: Upon receipt of a complete rental dwelling permit application and payment of the rental
dwelling permit fee, the Code official shall schedule an initial inspection and notify the owner or landlord of the date and time thereof, no more than
thirty (30) calendar days after determination that the application is complete. An inspection shall be scheduled only if the permit fee has been paid.
1. Furnace Check: The owner or landlord shall provide, before the first inspection or within thirty (30) days of acceptance of the application, proof that
an inspection of the primary heating equipment for each dwelling unit has been conducted.
a. The owner or landlord shall engage the services of a mechanical/heating contractor to conduct a furnace inspection as part of, or no more than
two (2) years prior to, the initial inspection for new rental dwelling units, or the initial inspection for rental dwelling permit renewal, for each rental
dwelling under his/her control.
b. The owner or landlord shall be responsible for providing documentation to the Code official that a furnace inspection has been completed and that
the equipment is in good, operable and safe condition.
2. Initial Inspection: The Code official shall inspect the premises and develop a list of deficiencies or violations. The list shall be supplied to the owner or
landlord no more than ten (10) business days after the initial inspection. If the Code official finds that there are no deficiencies or violations during the
initial inspection, a rental dwelling permit shall be issued no more than ten (10) business days after the initial inspection. There is no fee for the initial
inspection. Any other fees or penalties due (such as "no show", transfer, or "no rental dwelling permit" penalties) shall be paid prior to the date and
time of the scheduled initial inspection. The inspection shall not be conducted if fees and penalties are unpaid.
3. First Reinspection: The owner or landlord shall correct any deficiencies or violations identified by the Code official during the initial inspection. The
first reinspection shall be scheduled no more than thirty (30) calendar days after the owner or landlord receives the list of deficiencies or violations. If
the Code official finds that the identified deficiencies or violations have been corrected, a rental dwelling permit shall be issued no more than ten (10)
business days after the first reinspection. If there are still deficiencies or violations, the Code official shall provide a list thereof to the owner or
landlord no more than ten (10) business days after the first reinspection. There is no fee for the first reinspection; however, any other fees or
penalties due shall be paid prior to the date and time of the scheduled first reinspection. The reinspection shall not be conducted if fees and penalties
are unpaid or the furnace check, as required in subsection G1 of this section, has not been completed, submitted and approved by the Code official.
4. Second And Subsequent Reinspections:
a. If necessary, the second or any subsequent reinspection shall be scheduled no more than fifteen (15) calendar days after the owner or landlord
receives the list of deficiencies or violations. The owner or landlord shall correct any deficiencies or violations identified by the Code official during
the prior reinspection.
b. A fee shall be charged for the second and any subsequent reinspection. This fee, in addition to any other fees or penalties due, shall be paid
before the second or subsequent reinspection is conducted. The reinspection shall not be conducted if there are any unpaid fees or penalties.
c. If the Code official finds that the identified deficiencies or violations have been corrected, a rental dwelling permit shall be issued no more than ten
(10) business days after the reinspection.
d. If there are still deficiencies or violations, the Code official shall provide a list to the owner or landlord no more than ten (10) business days after
the second or subsequent reinspection. The next reinspection shall be scheduled no more than fifteen (15) calendar days after the owner or
landlord receives the list of deficiencies or violations.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 231/358
5. Repeated Deficiencies Or Violations: Unless the owner or landlord can show good and verifiable cause, any deficiencies or violations that were
identified during an inspection or reinspection must be resolved by the next reinspection or by the next subsequent reinspection. If said deficiencies
or violations are still unresolved after any combination of two (2) successive inspections or reinspections, the Code official may deny the rental
dwelling permit.
H. Time Extensions: The Code official, for good and verifiable cause, may extend the time between inspections and reinspections and shall notify the
owner or landlord of the extension and the date and time of the inspection or reinspection upon expiration of the extension.
I. Tenant Complaints: Unless there are significant issues that constitute a hazard or danger to the occupants or to the health, safety or general welfare, a
tenant must first file a formal complaint to the owner, landlord, or designated agent. Forms for this purpose will be provided by the Development
Services Department. A copy of the form shall be provided to the Code Enforcement Officer.
1. The owner or landlord shall have no more than seven (7) days after receipt of the written complaint to address the complaint.
2. If the complaint is not remedied to the tenant's satisfaction within seven (7) business days, the complainant will notify the Code Enforcement
Division. If the Code official determines that the complaint is founded, the Code official shall schedule an inspection. If the owner or landlord refuses
entry, the Code official may seek a warrant as stated in subsection B of this section.
3. If violations are found, the owner or landlord shall have fifteen (15) calendar days to remedy the violations. A fee equal to the cost of a second or
subsequent reinspection shall be charged to the owner or landlord and paid no more than thirty (30) days after the inspection; however, if further
reinspections are needed to ensure compliance, the requisite fee shall be paid prior to any reinspections.
4. The owner or landlord shall not pursue an action for eviction, nor shall the owner or landlord cause any service, facility, equipment or utility required
by this Code to be removed, shut off, or discontinued because of, or in retaliation for, filing a complaint under this subsection.
J. Notice Of Violations: Whenever the Code official determines that a violation of the Housing Code exists, the Code official shall inform the owner or
landlord of the violation(s).
1. Right To Appeal: The Code official shall notify the owner or landlord of their right to appeal, and shall provide an appeal application form upon
request.
2. Staying Of Order Under Appeal: Except for emergency orders to vacate made according to the requirements of this Code, enforcement of any notice
and order of the Code official shall be placed on hold until a determination is made by the Housing Advisory and Appeals Board.
K. Placarding Procedures For Unfit Properties Or Rental Dwellings Without Rental Dwelling Permit: Any dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit which is
found to be so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe or vermin infested that it creates a serious hazard to the health or safety of the
occupants or of the public, or is a rental dwelling unit that has not been issued a rental dwelling permit shall be determined to be unfit for human
habitation and shall be so designated and placarded by the Code official.
1. Placarded Dwellings To Be Vacated: Any dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit or any portion thereof, placarded in accordance with this article by the
Code official, shall be vacated immediately or as ordered by the Code official.
2. Reoccupy Placarded Dwelling: No dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit or portion thereof, which has been placarded in accordance with this article,
shall again be used for human habitation until written approval is secured from, and such placard is removed by, the Code official. The Code official
shall remove such placard whenever the violations upon which the placarding action was based have been eliminated.
3. Removal Of Placard Prohibited: Except for the Code official as provided above, it shall be unlawful for any person to deface or remove a placard
from any dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit which has been deemed unfit for human habitation and placarded in accordance with this section.
4. Condemnation Referral: After a reasonable period of time after a property has been placarded and no remedial action begun, but in no case greater
than six (6) months, the Code official shall inform the proper authorities to initiate the process for condemnation and demolition of the building.
L. Distribution Of Information: The Code official shall make all rules and regulations available to the general public. Standard forms and blank notices shall
also be available upon request. (Ord. 04-3, 1-6-2004; amd. 2017 Code)
10-2F-12: OWNER RESPONSIBILITIES FOR MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY OF RENTAL DWELLING UNITS:
Rental dwelling unit owners or landlords shall be responsible for causing the dwelling and/or premises to meet the following requirements:
A. Maintenance: The rental dwelling unit owner or landlord shall maintain and repair all dwellings and outbuildings on the premises in accordance with all
requirements of this Code.
B. Access By Landlord For Maintenance: Every occupant of a dwelling unit or rooming unit shall give access to the landlord or his/her representative or
employee, to any part of such dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit or premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of maintenance or other actions
required by the Housing Code and for making corrective actions ordered by the Code official. The landlord shall provide notice to the occupant not less
than twenty four (24) hours before entry, except in cases of emergency or where notice or notification is not feasible.
C. Grading, Drainage And Landscaping Of Premises: Grading, drainage and landscaping shall be continuously maintained. This Housing Code shall not
affect the existence or maintenance of stormwater drainage systems.
D. Floors In Kitchens And Bathrooms: Every toilet room floor surface, bathroom floor surface and kitchen floor surface shall be constructed and maintained
so as to permit such floor to be easily kept in a clean, dry and sanitary condition.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 232/358
E. Landlord To Let Clean Units: No landlord shall permit occupancy of any vacant dwelling unit or rooming unit unless it is substantially clean, sanitary and
fit for human occupancy.
F. Common Areas Maintenance: Every landlord of a dwelling containing two (2) or more dwelling units or more than one (1) rooming unit shall be
responsible for maintaining, in a safe and sanitary condition, the shared public areas of the dwelling and premises thereof, unless there is a written
agreement between the landlord and occupant to the contrary.
G. Occupancy Control: No owner or operator shall allow the occupancy of a dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit to exceed the number of persons
allowed under this and other applicable codes, including the Building and Fire Codes.
H. Contact Information: The owner or landlord shall be responsible for notifying the City of any change of address or other applicable contact information. If
no new contact information is provided, the City will address correspondence to the last known address on file. (Ord. 04-3, 1-6-2004; amd. 2017 Code)
10-2F-13: OCCUPANT RESPONSIBILITIES FOR MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY OF RENTAL DWELLING UNITS:
A. Occupant Responsible For Sanitary Condition: Every occupant of a rental dwelling unit shall maintain the dwelling unit or rooming unit in a clean, safe
and sanitary condition.
1. Every floor and floor covering shall be kept substantially clean and sanitary.
2. Every wall and ceiling shall be kept substantially clean and free of dirt or greasy film.
3. No dwelling or the premises thereof shall be used substantially for the storage or handling of garbage.
4. No dwelling or the premises thereof shall be used for the storage or handling of dangerous or hazardous materials beyond typical household use.
5. No occupant of a rental dwelling unit shall deliberately or negligently destroy, deface, damage, impair or remove any part or portion of the premises
or knowingly permit any other occupant or person to do so without consent of the landlord.
B. Supplied Facilities; Smoke Detection: The landlord shall have installed batteries for all required smoke detectors at the time a new occupant moves into
a dwelling unit. Subsequent replacement of batteries required to operate smoke detection equipment shall be the responsibility of occupants unless
otherwise arranged or agreed upon by the respective occupant and landlord. Occupants of a rental dwelling unit shall notify the landlord if they become
aware that the smoke detection equipment is not operating properly. Occupants shall not cause a smoke detector to be removed.
C. Cooking In Rooming Units Prohibited: Other than meals cooked in a microwave oven, no occupant of a rooming unit shall cook meals in a rooming unit
unless an approved kitchen and/or dining room is contained within the rooming unit.
D. Occupancy Control: No occupant of a rental dwelling unit shall allow the occupancy of any dwelling unit or rooming unit within which he/she resides to
exceed the number of persons allowed under this and other applicable codes, including the Building and Fire Codes. (Ord. 04-3, 1-6-2004; amd. 2017
Code)
10-2F-14: HOUSING ADVISORY AND APPEALS BOARD:
A. Created: There is hereby created a Housing Advisory and Appeals Board.
B. Purpose And Duties: The Housing Advisory and Appeals Board shall have the authority to act upon appeal of a decision of the Code official, variances
to the requirements of this Code, extensions of time for the compliance of any order or notice, and to sustain or modify an order of the notice of
violations authorized in the International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted and amended. The Housing Advisory and Appeals Board may also
make recommendations to the City Council for changes to the Housing Code and adopt reasonable policies.
C. Board Membership And Terms Of Office: See section 111 of the International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted and amended.
D. Meeting Schedule: The Housing Advisory and Appeals Board shall meet at such intervals necessary in order to fulfill its described purposes. The
Housing Advisory and Appeals Board shall address appeals no more than fifteen (15) business days after the date upon which the Code official
received the completed appeal application, including the appeal fee.
E. Rules And Regulations: The Housing Advisory and Appeals Board may adopt rules and regulations to govern its organizational procedures as it may
deem necessary and which are not in conflict with the Housing Code or other laws.
F. Appeal Application:
1. Application: Any person aggrieved by a notice of violations or a denied rental dwelling permit or of any applicable rule or regulation issued pursuant
to the Housing Code, may apply to the Housing Advisory and Appeals Board for reconsideration of such notice and order, provided that such appeal
application is made no more than ten (10) business days after the date the notice was received. Only those matters or issues specifically raised in
the appeal application shall be considered in the hearing of the appeal.
2. Appeal Filing Fee: At the time of filing such an application for an appeal, the appellant shall pay a filing fee in an amount established by section 10-
2F-15 of this article.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 233/358
3. Application Deadline: The right to an administrative hearing and further adjudication shall be waived for the notice, order, and any portion thereof if
an appeal has not been properly filed within ten (10) business days after receipt of either the notice of violation or the written notice of a denied rental
permit.
G. Notice Of Hearing: Upon receipt of a complete appeal application and filing fee, the Code official shall establish a date for the hearing to be held within
fifteen (15) business days of the date upon which the completed application was received and shall send a notice of the hearing to the appellant, as
well as the respective landlord and occupant. (Ord. 04-3, 1-6-2004; amd. 2017 Code)
10-2F-15: FEES AND PENALTIES:
A. Schedule Established: A consolidated fee and penalty schedule shall be adopted by the City Council by resolution.
B. Fee And Penalty Deadlines:
1. Rental dwelling permit fees are due at the time of application. No inspections shall be scheduled if this fee is not paid.
2. The fee for renewal of a rental dwelling permit shall be paid for prior to or upon the expiration of the current permit. No inspections shall be
scheduled if this fee is not paid.
3. Rental dwelling transfer late penalties shall be due thirty (30) calendar days after the Code official sends a notice to the landlord requesting that
transfer information be submitted.
4. Reinspection fees shall be paid prior to the next scheduled inspection or reinspection; if such fees cannot be paid prior to the scheduled inspection
because the Code official finds that an immediate inspection or reinspection is warranted, such fees shall be due no more than thirty (30) calendar
days after the respective reinspection or complaint inspection.
5. "No show" penalties shall be paid prior to the next scheduled inspection or reinspection; if no further inspection or reinspection is required, such
penalties shall be due thirty (30) calendar days after the scheduled appointment when the "no show" took place.
6. "No rental dwelling permit" penalties shall be due thirty (30) calendar days after written notification is mailed or personally delivered by the Code
official, unless the owner or landlord has applied for a rental dwelling permit prior to the expiration of the thirty (30) day period.
7. Appeal fees shall be due at the time the respective appeal application is filed.
8. The Code official may deny or revoke a rental dwelling permit if all applicable fees and penalties are not paid.
9. The City may certify any unpaid balance, interest, and late payment fees and penalties to the County Auditor as a lien upon the rental property for
collection in the same manner as a property tax. (Ord. 04-3, 1-6-2004; amd. 2017 Code)
ARTICLE G. SIGN CODE
10-2G-1: CODE ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted as the Sign Code of the City, the 2009 International Building Code or most current edition, as adopted and amended by the State
of Iowa, as it applies to the construction, erection and maintenance of signs. An official copy of the 2009 International Building Code, including a certificate
by the City Clerk as to its adoption and effective date thereof, is now on file in the Office of the City Clerk and at the City Public Library for public
inspection. (Ord. 14-3, 2-4-2014)
10-2G-2: ZONING CODE:
In addition to the permit requirements for signs in the 2009 International Building Code, referenced in section 10-2G-1 of this article, all signs shall be
located, constructed, erected, operated and maintained in accordance with title 12, chapter 20, "Sign Regulations", of this Code. (Ord. 14-3, 2-4-2014)
10-2G-3: SIGN ERECTOR'S LICENSE; FEE; INSURANCE:
A. Sign Erector's License Required; Fee: No person shall engage or continue in the business of erecting, maintaining or replacing any sign or advertising
structure or perform any such acts for compensation without first having obtained a license for such work from the City Clerk. Such sign erector's
license shall be issued upon submission of written application and an annual license fee therefor. Said annual license fee shall be in the amount of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per year, payable to the City Clerk and shall expire on June 30 each year.
B. Insurance: The applicant shall file with the Clerk evidence of public liability insurance acceptable to the City, to be in full force and effect for the period of
said license, with minimum limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for
a single personal injury or death, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for multiple injuries or deaths, which insurance shall indemnify and
hold harmless the City, from the same risks as hereinbefore provided for corporate surety bonds.
C. Suspension; Revocation: Any sign erector's license may be suspended or revoked as follows:
1. A sign erector's license may be suspended by the "Chief Building Official" if:
a. The license was issued in error; or
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 234/358
b. The license was incorrect; or
c. The contractor has failed to comply with the ordinances and regulations of the City relating to the work for which the license was issued.
2. No license may be suspended until after a hearing is held by the "Chief Building Official". The contractor shall be mailed notice of the date, time and
place of the hearing at least ten (10) days in advance. The notice shall also state the exact ordinances or regulations the contractor is alleged to
have violated or in what way the information stated in the application was incorrect.
3. After the hearing, the "Chief Building Official" may suspend the license for any period of time up to six (6) months.
4. Such suspension shall be subject to review by appeal to the Building Advisory and Appeals Board, as set forth in article A of this chapter.
5. The Chief Building Official may revoke the license of any sign erector who has had two (2) or more suspensions within a two (2) year period. If any of
the suspensions were appealed according to subsection C4 of this section, only those suspensions that were upheld by the Building Advisory and
Appeals Board may be counted.
6. "Routine maintenance" shall be defined as the repair of an existing electrical apparatus or equipment of the same size and type for which no
changes in wiring are made. This does not include any new electrical installation or the expansion or extension of any circuit.
7. A person licensed under this section and who has obtained the State of Iowa sign installation endorsement through the Iowa Electrical Examination
Board may perform routine maintenance on a street or light pole. (Ord. 14-3, 2-4-2014)

The provisions of section 2304 shall not prohibit the dispensing of Class I and Class II liquids in the open from a fuel dispensing system supplied by
an above ground tank, not to exceed one thousand (1,000) gallons, located at commercial, industrial, government or manufacturing establishments,
and intended for fueling vehicles used in connection with their business. Such dispensing may be permitted, provided:
1. An inspection of the premises and operations has been made and approval granted by the authority having jurisdiction.
2. The tank is safeguarded against collision, spillage, and overfill, to the satisfaction of the authority having jurisdiction.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 235/358
3. The tank is listed or approved for such above ground use.
4. The tank complies with requirements for emergency relief venting, and the tank and dispensing system meet the electrical classifications of the
Code.

Appendix J and L: Delete in the International Fire Code (2015). (Ord. 17-4, 6-6-2017)
10-2I-3: OPEN BURNING:
A. Prohibited; Exceptions: Open burning for the purpose of disposal of material is prohibited except as follows:
1. Notification Of Fire Department:
a. Application; Fees: Application for a variance must be made in writing to the Fire Department. If a variance is granted, a permit fee of ten dollars
($10.00) shall cover the costs of assuring compliance. If an on site visit is required for the process of granting a variance, a fifteen dollar ($15.00)
first time fee shall be added to the cost of the permit.
b. Lot Size: Unless authorized by the Fire Chief, only single-family lots of twenty four thousand (24,000) square feet in size or larger shall be granted
a variance of this section.
c. Distance: No variance shall be granted unless the site of burning is two hundred feet (200') or more from any sensitive neighboring structure.
2. Material Restrictions: Only leaves, grass clippings, small twigs and branches produced on the site listed on the permit shall be eligible to be burned.
Burning of rubbish and paper products shall be prohibited. Rubber tires shall not be used to ignite landscape waste.
3. Time And Atmospheric Restrictions:
a. The Fire Chief shall establish periods for burning of yard waste for spring and fall. No burning shall be permitted outside of these periods except
with authorization by the Fire Chief.
b. Unless otherwise authorized by the Fire Chief, open burning shall be only on specific days, between twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to sundown.
Open burning shall be prohibited when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous.
4. Location On Property: Burning shall not take place within fifty feet (50') of a structure; within twenty five feet (25') permissible if the pile size is three
feet (3') or less in diameter and two feet (2') or less in height.
5. Containers: No burning shall be done in containers. "Burn barrels", incinerators, etc., are prohibited.
6. Fire Extinguishing Equipment: A garden hose connected to a water supply, or other approved fire extinguishing equipment must be readily available
at the burning site.
7. Attendance: All burning material shall be constantly attended by a person who shall take responsibility of the burning.
8. Discontinuance Of Burning: The Fire Chief, or a designated representative, shall be authorized to order the burning ceased if smoke emissions are a
problem.
B. Exemptions: The following shall be permitted unless prohibited:
1. Disaster Rubbish: The open burning of rubbish, including landscape waste, for the duration of the community disaster period in cases where an
officially declared emergency condition exists.
2. Trees And Trimmings:
a. The open burning of trees and trimmings not originated on the premises; provided, that the burning site is operated by the City, said burning site
being fenced and access controlled, burning is conducted on a regularly scheduled basis and is supervised at all times. Burning is conducted only
when weather conditions are favorable with respect to surrounding property, as announced by the Fire Chief and the burning site is limited to areas
at least one-fourth (1/4) mile from any inhabited building. However, when the open burning of trees and tree trimmings causes air pollution as
defined in Iowa Code section 455B.131(3), the City Fire Department or the Iowa Department of Natural Resources (IDNR) may take appropriate
action to secure relocation of the burning operation. Rubber tires shall not be used to ignite trees and tree trimmings.
b. This exemption shall not apply within the area classified as the PM 10 (inhalable) Particulate Group II area of the City. This Group II area is
described as follows:
The area in Cerro Gordo County, Iowa, in Lincoln Township including Sections 13, 24, and 25; in Lime Creek Township including Sections 18, 19,
20, 21, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, and 35; in Mason Township the West one-half (W 1/2) of Section 1, Sections 2, 3, 4, 5, 8, 9, the North onehalf
(N 1/2) of Section 11, the Northwest one-quarter (NW 1/4) of Section 12, the North one-half (N 1/2) of Section 16, the North one-half (N 1/2) of
Section 17 and the portions of Sections 10 and 15 north and west of the line from U.S. Highway 122 south on Kentucky Avenue to 9th Street S.E.
to the section line between Sections 15 and 16.
3. Flare Stacks: The open burning or flaring of waste gases.
4. Recreational Fires: Open fires for cooking, heating, camping, and recreation using liquefied petroleum gas, natural gas, charcoal or clean untreated
wood in excess of one and five-eighths inches (15/8") minimum dimension (no building materials) as fuel are permitted, provided that they comply
with the adopted Fire Code.
12/7/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=382 236/358
No recreational fires other than those for the purpose of cooking shall be permitted after twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight or before twelve o'clock
(12:00) noon.
If smoke emissions from a recreational fire cause a problem, the fire shall be extinguished by order of the Fire Chief or his designee.
5. Ceremonial Fires: Fires for the purpose of celebration by schools, churches and other organizations may be permitted by the Fire Chief or his
designee.
6. Training Fires: Fires set for the purpose of bona fide training by Fire Department personnel in firefighting methods, provided that the Executive
Director of the IDNR receives notice in writing at least one (1) week before such action commences. All asphalt roofing and asbestos containing
materials shall be removed prior to the training fire.
7. Agricultural Burns: Prescribed burning of weeds and natural prairie may be permitted by the Fire Chief or his designee.
8. Agricultural Land Use: Existing farmsteads that have been annexed into Mason City and are still zoned agricultural shall be exempt from City
ordinances on open burning except that if in the event smoke emissions were to cause a problem, the fire shall be extinguished by order of the Fire
Chief or his designee.
C. Penalties: Penalties for violations of this section shall be as permitted in this Code; repeat violators shall be subject to revocation of their burning
permits. (Ord. 17-4, 6-6-2017)
10-2I-4: SPECIAL INSPECTIONS:
A. A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) will be charged to cover costs of inspections that are conducted outside of the regular fire inspector's route and that
require reports to other agencies as set out herein; but not limited to the following: State Fire Marshal, State Department of Health, Department of
Human Services, City Council, etc.
B. A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) will be charged for fire extinguisher classes conducted by the Fire Department.
C. Regular fire inspections shall be provided free of charge. Upon the first visit, the occupant will be given a courtesy letter explaining the benefits of said
inspection and will state that a reinspection will also be provided after a reasonable date at no cost. The third and any additional inspections required
will be twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 17-4, 6-6-2017)
